明日律师

Tomorrow’s Lawyers

明日律师

TOMORROW’S LAWYERS

未来介绍

An Introduction to Your Future

第三版

THIRD EDITION

理查德·萨斯坎德

Richard Susskind

大克拉伦登街，牛津，OX2 6DP，

Great Clarendon Street, Oxford, OX2 6DP,

英国

United Kingdom

谨以此书献给

I dedicate this book to

丹尼尔、杰米和阿里，

Daniel, Jamie, and Ali,

我亲爱的孩子们，

my loving children,

带给我无尽的快乐

who bring me endless happiness

第三版序言

PREFACE TO THE THIRD EDITION

令人不安的是，疫情期间我收到了一些祝贺邮件。这些邮件指出，由于新冠疫情，律师们已经成为科技的重度使用者，因此他们坚称：“理查德，你的未来已经到来。” 言下之意，他们似乎也在暗示我或许是时候退休了。

Rather disconcertingly, I received some congratulatory emails during the pandemic. These messages noted that lawyers had become big users of technology because of COVID, and they insisted in consequence that, ‘Richard, your future has arrived’. By implication, they also seemed to be suggesting that it might be time for me to hang up my hat.

我不同意这两个主张。

I disagree with both propositions.

我并不认为仅仅因为现在许多律师经常在家办公，就意味着他们已经到达了最终的归宿。掌握视频通话和远程办公只是迈向我在书中设想的法律格局变革的初步步骤。我也不认为——我欣慰地告诉大家——我的工作已经完成了。事实上，我衷心感谢世界各地鼓励我编写第三版的众多律师和法学教师。

I do not think that lawyers have arrived at their final destination simply because many now regularly work from home. Mastering video calls and working remotely are but early steps towards the transformed legal landscape that I envisage in my books. Nor do I think—I am relieved to report—that my work is done. Indeed, I extend my heartfelt thanks to the many lawyers and law teachers around the world who have encouraged me to prepare this third edition.

然而，是否会有一天，明天的律师就和今天的律师一样，不再需要修订版本？提出这个问题是对我们现在生活和工作的时代的误解。除了疫情和战争带来的恐怖带来的变化之外，科技发展的速度如此之快，以至于在可预见的未来，我们必须预料到法律工作将处于一个无休止的变革时期。随着我们的系统日益强大，一些现有的法律工作将会消失，新的工作无疑会出现，尽管许多其中一些工作，在适当的时候，也将被机器取代。从现在开始，律师需要不断灵活变通，适应市场需求，保持竞争力。

Will there ever be a day, though, when tomorrow’s lawyers will be today’s lawyers, and so no further editions will be required? To ask that question is to misunderstand the era in which we now live and labour. Over and above changes that are brought by the horrors of pandemic and war, technology is advancing at such a ferocious rate that, for the foreseeable future, we must expect to be operating in law in a period of endless flux. As our systems become increasingly capable, some current legal jobs will fade, new jobs will doubtless emerge, although many of these, in due course, will also be taken on by machines. From here on in, lawyers will need continually to flex and adapt to keep in demand and remain relevant.

至于变化的速度，预测起来要困难得多。十年前我完成了本书的第一版。这意味着，我们现在已经走过了20年时间的一半。我最初预测，在这20年里，法律机构和律师的变化将超过过去两个世纪的总和。我从未想过这个说法会如此极端，因为事实上，法律世界在过去200年里并没有发生太大变化，至少在英国，自19世纪70年代改革以来并没有发生太大变化。无论如何，我认为没有必要修改我的预测。正如本书所讨论的，纵观整个法律生态系统，我们已经看到了显著的变化，而且变化的速度——这一点至关重要——还在继续加快。一个小小的证据可以支持这一说法：这次我不得不付出更大的努力来修订这本书。十年过去了，需要注意和做出的改变比五年前要多得多。

As to the speed of change, that is much trickier to predict. I completed the first edition of this book a decade ago. This means that we are now half-way through the 20-year period, during which, I originally predicted, legal institutions and lawyers would change more than they had in the past two centuries. I never thought that this was such an extreme claim because, in truth, the world of law has not changed much in the last 200 years, or at least, in England, since the reforms of the 1870s. In any event, I see no need to revise my forecast. As discussed throughout the book, looking across the entire legal ecosystem, we have already seen significant changes, and the pace of change—and this is vital—continues to accelerate. One modest bit of evidence to support this claim: I had to work much harder to revise the book this time round. A decade on, there were many more changes to note and make than after five years.

话虽如此，全球杰出的律师事务所仍在稳步发展。我知道许多律师事务所的领导者表示，他们在过去几年里已经大幅改变了业务模式。但我认为，我们最近在这些（非常成功的）律师事务所中看到的，只是一些边缘运营的转变，以及一些有效的营销策略，而非全面的转型。然而，变革的早期苗头已经初现，我预计2020年代将见证这些大型律师事务所所依赖的商业模式发生重大转变。

That said, the world’s outstanding law firms are still evolving at a sedate pace. I know that many of their leaders say that they have changed their businesses substantially over the last few years. But I believe what we have seen recently in these (massively successful) firms have been some operational shifts at the edges, and some good marketing too, rather than full-scale transformation. However, the early shoots of change are now visible and I anticipate that the 2020s will witness great shifts in the business models underpinning these major firms.

我预计法律变革的轨迹将呈指数级增长。过去十年，我们看到了浅显的、稳步变化，现在正看到更具爆发力的迹象。我们正处于曲线的拐点。

I expect the trajectory of change in law to follow an exponential curve. Over the past decade, we have seen a shallow, steady change and are now seeing signs of more explosive movement. We are at the knee of the curve.

从长远来看，什么才算律所的根本性变革和转型？为了回答这个问题，让我提出一个测试：当律所不到一半的收入来自收取传统人类律师工作时间的费用时，该律所就实现了根本性变革。当我们从一对一的咨询服务转向一对多的在线或嵌入式服务时，法律（以及其他职业）的根本性革命将会发生。收入将不再来自出售人们的时间，而是来自内容授权。目前，世界上没有一家律所能够接近我提出的测试。很可能永远不会有律所发生如此程度的改变。但即使他们不这样做，我相信其他替代性法律服务提供商也会抓住机会——更好地服务于他们的社区，并且正如我在正文中所说，在他们睡觉的时候赚钱。

Looking longer term, what would count for me as radical change and transformation in law firms? In answer to that question, let me propose a test, according to which a law firm has radically changed when less than half of its revenue is derived from charging for the time of traditional work of human lawyers. The fundamental revolution in law (and other professions) will come about when we move from one-to-one consultative advisory service to one-to-many online or embedded service. Income will come not from selling people’s time but from licensing content. No law firm in the world currently comes close to passing my proposed test. It may well be that no firms will ever change to this extent. But if they do not, I am confident that other alternative legal providers will instead grasp the opportunity—to serve their communities better and, as I say in the body of the text, to make money while they sleep.

最后，我要说的是，自2017年本书第二版首次出版以来，我的思考也取得了进展。此后，我又写了一部新书，题为《在线法院与司法的未来》（2019年和2021年），并与丹尼尔·萨斯坎德（Daniel Susskind）合作出版了《职业的未来》（2022年）的更新版。这些书中的一些想法和发现也融入了本书的版本中。

Finally, I should say that my own thinking has advanced since 2017, when the second edition of this book first appeared. I have since written a new work, entitled Online Courts and the Future of Justice (2019 and 2021), and, with Daniel Susskind, have published an updated edition of The Future of the Professions (2022). Some of the ideas and findings of these books have found their way into this edition.

尽管我努力让这本书简短有力，但我发现每一版都离这个目标越来越远。无论篇幅如何，我都强调这本书是一本入门书——旨在以轻快的节奏带你走进未来律师的世界。现在，其他人正在出色地将……更具体、更具体。我的目的一如既往，是鼓励对话，然后采取行动。

Although I try to keep the book short and punchy, I find myself straying further from this aspiration with each edition. No matter its length, though, I stress that this book is introductory—conceived as a brisk canter through the world of tomorrow’s lawyers. Others are now doing a great job of putting more flesh on the bones. My purpose, as always, is to encourage conversation and then action.

理查德·萨斯坎德

Richard Susskind

2022年8月

August 2022

拉德利特，英格兰

Radlett, England

第二版序言

PREFACE TO THE SECOND EDITION

本书 2013 年出版的第一版的核心主张之一是，未来 20 年法律世界的变化将比过去两个世纪的变化更大。三年过去了，我相信我们正走在正确的道路上。在此期间，法律世界发生了许多变化。举个例子——许多大型律师事务所已经设立了低成本的服务中心来承担日常法律工作；四大会计师事务所迅速提升了它们的全球法律能力；法律科技初创企业数量激增，目前全球已超过 1,000 家；法律领域的人工智能 (AI) 理念激发了整个行业的创新者的想象力，从市场领先的公司到法学院学生开发人员；在英格兰和威尔士，在我们自由化的法律制度下，无数的“替代商业结构”已经启动（现在有超过 500 个）；加拿大律师协会等专业机构已经对法律服务的未来进行了研究；高级法官一直在强烈倡导更广泛地使用技术；英国政府已承诺投资超过 10 亿英镑，用于英格兰和威尔士法院系统的现代化和数字化；无数企业内部的法律部门，尤其是在美国，已经任命了首席运营官来重新思考和管理他们的运营；而且，请读者原谅我，更多的中国购买这本书的律师数量比英国律师还要多。简而言之，短短三年间发生了翻天覆地的变化。与此同时，大多数评论员也一致认为，变革的步伐正在加快。如今，法律界的许多领导者都公开承认，法律世界正在进入一个转型期。

One of the central claims in the first edition of this book, published in 2013, was that the legal world would change more in the next 20 years than it has in the past two centuries. Three years on, I believe we are on course. In the intervening period, much has happened in the legal world. To give a flavour—many major law firms have since set up low-cost service centres to undertake routine legal work; the Big 4 accounting firms have rapidly grown their global legal capabilities; there has been a great upsurge of legaltech start-ups, now well over 1,000 worldwide; the idea of artificial intelligence (AI) in law has captured the imagination of innovators across the profession, from market leading firms to law student developers; in England and Wales, in our liberalized legal regime, innumerable ‘alternative business structures’ have been launched (there are now over 500); professional bodies, such as the Canadian Bar Association, have produced studies on the future of legal services; senior judges have been strongly advocating the wider use of technology; the British government has committed to investing over £1 billion in modernizing and digitizing the court system in England and Wales; innumerable in-house legal departments, especially in the US, have been appointing chief operating officers to rethink and manage their operations; and, if readers will forgive me, more Chinese lawyers have bought this book than English lawyers. In short, much has changed in these three short years. At the same time, most commentators agree that the pace of change is accelerating. And great numbers of leaders across the legal profession are now openly acknowledging that the world of law is entering a period of transformation.

事实上，我们才刚刚热身。

In truth, we are just warming up.

我自己的思维也在不断变化。在某种程度上，一如既往地，我从律师事务所的客户那里学到了很多东西，他们每个人都在不断进取，拥抱替代性的劳动模式和新技术。过去几年，我也一直专注于在线争议解决。我担任了民事司法委员会顾问小组的主席，该小组提出了在线法庭的想法，而在线法庭的引入现在已成为英格兰和威尔士的司法和政府政策。最重要的是，我有幸与我的儿子丹尼尔·萨斯坎德（Daniel Susskind）合著了《职业的未来》（The Future of the Professions ）一书。丹尼尔·萨斯坎德是牛津大学贝利奥尔学院的经济学研究员。这本书于2015年出版。将目光投向法律以外的其他职业，并与一位经济学家合作，让我重新审视了我过去的一些分析。

My own thinking has also moved on. In part, I have learned, as always, from my law firm clients, each of whom has been powering ahead, embracing alternative labour models as well as new technologies. I have also been preoccupied over the last couple of years with online dispute resolution. I chaired an advisory group of the Civil Justice Council that devised the idea of online courts, and their introduction is now judicial and government policy for England and Wales. Above all, I had the great privilege of writing a book, The Future of the Professions, with my son, Daniel Susskind, a Fellow in Economics at Balliol College, Oxford. This was published in 2015. Looking beyond law to other professions, and working with an economist, has led me to revisit some of my past analysis.

所有这些都表明本书的第一版如今已过时。因此，我撰写第二版的目的是，结合法律市场的最新进展以及我个人的思考和经验发展。我再次强调，本书内容简短，因为我关注的是宏观视角——广泛的趋势和可能的结果。我的主要目的是鼓励开放的辩论和反思，以期改进我们的法律体系。虽然本书最初是为年轻律师准备的，但事实证明，老律师也喜欢篇幅短小、价格低廉的书籍，因此他们也读过。我很高兴看到这一点——所有律师，除非他们今天退休，否则都是明天的律师。

All of which is to say that the first edition of this book is now out of date. Accordingly, my aim in writing this second edition is to take account of recent advances in the legal marketplace alongside developments in my own thinking and experience. Once again, I have kept it brief, because my concern here is with the big picture—the broad trends and the likely outcomes. My main purpose is to encourage open-minded debate and reflection, with a view to improving our legal systems. While the book was originally intended for young lawyers, it transpires that older lawyers also like short and inexpensive books and so they read it too. I am happy with this—all lawyers, unless they are retiring today, are tomorrow’s lawyers.

理查德·萨斯坎德

Richard Susskind

2016年10月

October 2016

拉德利特，英格兰

Radlett, England

第一版序言

PREFACE TO THE FIRST EDITION

我写这本书的目的是，为未来的律师和法律教育者提供一份通俗易懂的论述，探讨法律职业和司法系统当前面临的紧迫问题。我毫不怀疑，我们正处于法律世界根本性变革的边缘，我的主要目标是鼓励人们更广泛地讨论这些正在发挥作用的力量及其可能产生的影响。

I have written this book to provide tomorrow’s lawyers and legal educators with an accessible account of the pressing issues that currently face the legal profession and the justice system. We are, I have no doubt, on the brink of fundamental change in the world of law, and my main aim is to encourage wider discussion of the forces at play and their likely impact.

虽然本书最初旨在为下一代律师提供未来指南，但我期望更有经验的执业律师也能阅读。对于那些没有时间阅读长篇大论的忙碌专业人士来说，我希望它能比我之前的作品更有力地阐述我的观点。当然，它代表了我对法律市场趋势的全新看法。

Although originally conceived as a guide to the future for the next generation of lawyers, I expect that the book will also be read by more experienced practitioners. For busy professionals who do not have the time to read lengthy texts, I hope that it serves as a punchier version of my ideas than my previous work. Certainly, it represents a substantially updated version of my views on trends in the legal market.

我并不期望读者会完全同意我的观点。但如果这本书能够引发人们对法律和律师未来的更严肃的反思和辩论，那么我的工作就完成了。然而，由于我们生活在如此快速变化的时代，这项工作必然是未完成的。每天，我都能听到法律领域不断涌现的创新故事——这里出现了新的法律业务，那里出现了在线服务，以及源源不断的、旨在以不同方式满足客户需求的富有想象力的想法。然而，在引用这些创新时，我必须划清界限，因此我只能提及2012年5月底之前出现的发展。到本书出版时，我并不感到惊讶。如果在此期间推出了一些重要的新法律服务，则会发布。

I do not anticipate that readers will agree with all of what I say. But if the book gives rise to more serious reflection and debate about the future of the law and lawyers, then I have done my job. And yet, because we live in such rapidly shifting times, it is a job that is necessarily incomplete. Each day, I hear fresh tales of innovation in law—a new legal business here, an online facility there, and a regular flow of imaginative ideas for meeting clients’ needs in different ways. In citing these innovations, I had to draw the line somewhere, however, and so I have only been able to refer to developments that surfaced before the end of May 2012. I would not be surprised, by the time this book is published, if some important new legal services have been launched in the interim.

我要感谢一些人。首先是牛津大学出版社的团队。这是牛津大学出版社第五次同意出版我的著作，与以往一样，能够与​​这样一家享有盛誉的出版社合作是我的荣幸。我特别感谢英国的露丝·安德森（Ruth Anderson）和索菲·巴勒姆（Sophie Barham），以及美国的尼内尔·西尔伯伯格（Ninell Silberberg），感谢他们的友好支持和建议。我还必须感谢几位匿名审阅我的图书提案并提出各种建议的审稿人，我相信这些建议促成了许多重大改进。

I have some people to thank. First of all, there is the team at Oxford University Press. This is the fifth time that OUP has agreed to take on one of my books and, as ever, it has been a privilege to work with such a well-regarded publishing house. I am especially grateful to Ruth Anderson and Sophie Barham in the UK and to Ninell Silberberg in the US for their friendly support and advice. I must also record my thanks to the various referees who anonymously assessed my book proposal and made a wide range of suggestions that led, I believe, to many significant improvements.

接下来是帕特里夏·卡托 (Patricia Cato)，她帮助我完成了无数初稿，并且在理解我快速的格拉斯哥语方面仍然比任何语音识别系统表现得更好。

Next is Patricia Cato, who helped me with innumerable initial drafts and still comfortably outperforms any speech recognition system in making sense of my rapid Glaswegian.

我也受益匪浅，受益匪浅的是几位朋友和同事的指导、鼓励和批评。他们慷慨地花费了大量时间阅读本书的初稿，这些朋友和同事包括内维尔·艾森伯格、哈泽尔·格恩、丹尼尔·哈里斯、劳伦斯·米尔斯、大卫·莫利、艾伦·帕特森和托尼·威廉姆斯。我向他们每一位致以深深的谢意。

I have also benefited greatly from the guidance, encouragement, and criticisms of a small group of friends and colleagues who generously spent many hours of their time reading an early draft of the book—Neville Eisenberg, Hazel Genn, Daniel Harris, Laurence Mills, David Morley, Alan Paterson, and Tony Williams. To each, I extend my profound thanks.

两位评论者值得特别提及——我的儿子丹尼尔和杰米。如果没有他们的爱和鼓励，这本书就不可能完成。当我萌生为有抱负的律师写一本书的想法时，他们热情洋溢；当我因其他事务而难以保持写作动力时，他们激励着我；他们对之前的草稿提出了广泛的评论。他们思维的广度和清晰度令我惊叹。

Two reviewers deserve separate mention—my sons, Daniel and Jamie. This book would not have been written without their love and encouragement. They enthused when I came up with the idea of a book for aspiring lawyers, they motivated me when other commitments made it difficult to maintain momentum, and they commented extensively on earlier drafts. Their range and clarity of thought amaze me.

最后要感谢的人是阿里，我的女儿和朋友。这本书谨献给她和她的兄弟们。我珍惜我们在一起度过的每一刻美好时光。我拥有一个如此美好的女儿。

The last person but one to thank is Ali, my daughter and friend, to whom, along with her brothers, this book is dedicated. I cherish every one of the many companionable moments we spend together. I could not have a more wonderful daughter.

最后，一如既往，我非常感谢我亲爱的妻子米歇尔。30多年来，她一直包容我时而痴迷于写作。这绝非易事。她对我作品的无限支持，以及对我想法的信心，对我来说意义非凡。

And finally, as always, I am very grateful to my loving wife, Michelle. For over 30 years now, she has indulgently endured my bouts of obsessive writing. It cannot be easy. Her boundless support for my work and her confidence in my ideas mean so very much to me.

理查德·萨斯坎德

Richard Susskind

2012年6月

June 2012

拉德利特，英格兰

Radlett, England

当一扇门关闭时，另一扇门就会打开；但我们常常对那扇关闭的门凝视太久，太遗憾，以至于看不到为我们打开的门。

When one door closes, another door opens; but we often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door that we do not see the ones which open for us.

亚历山大·格雷厄姆·贝尔

ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL

机构将尽力保留他们能够解决的问题。

Institutions will try to preserve the problem to which they are the solution.

克莱·舍基

CLAY SHIRKY

如果你不知道要去哪里，你可能就到不了那里。

If you don’t know where you’re going, you might not get there.

尤吉·贝拉

YOGI BERRA

指数

Index

介绍

Introduction

本书旨在为年轻有抱负的律师们简要介绍未来。正如本书所预测和描述的那样，未来的法律世界将与过去大相径庭。我坚持我在2013年本书初版中所提出的论断，即法律机构和律师在不到二十年的时间里将经历比过去两个世纪更为剧烈的变化。

This book is a short introduction to the future for young and aspiring lawyers. Tomorrow’s legal world, as predicted and described here, will bear little resemblance to that of the past. I stand by my claim of 2013, in the first edition of this work, that legal institutions and lawyers would change more radically in less than two decades than they had in the past two centuries.

如果你是一位年轻律师，我所讨论的这场变革就在你的注视下发生。“年轻”一词应作广义理解，涵盖正在考虑法律工作的学生，以及正在思考职业发展方向的新晋升律所合伙人。我的文章也面向那些对年轻法律企业感兴趣的读者，例如法律科技初创企业和正在寻求重新定义法律市场的另类法律服务提供商。

If you are a young lawyer, the revolution I discuss is happening on your watch. ‘Young’ should be construed broadly, applying to students who are contemplating a job in law through to newly promoted partners in firms who are wondering how their careers might unfold. I also write for those who are interested in young legal businesses, such as the lawtech start-ups and the alternative legal providers that are now seeking to redefine the legal marketplace.

对于那些传统企业的元老们，他们可能读了几段之后就觉得可以不再往下读了，我在此发出一个警告。虽然未来，尤其是科技这个话题，看起来主要还是下一代人感兴趣的，但我在这里讨论的一些变革即使现在还没有，也在未来几年内就会到来。除非退休迫在眉睫，否则我在这里所说的也将直接影响到年长的律师。更重要的是，当今法律界的领导者不仅应该关注如何坚持到退休金到账，还应该关注他们的长期遗产。

To elder statesmen in traditional firms, who may feel after a couple of paragraphs that they are excused from reading on, I issue a warning. Although it may appear that the future, and particularly the topic of technology, is of interest primarily to the next generation, some of the transformations that I discuss here are coming in the next few years if not with us already. Unless retirement is imminent, what I say here will directly affect older lawyers too. More than this, leaders in the legal profession today should be concerned not just about hanging on until their pensions click in, but about their long-term legacy as well.

“我的号召面向的是心态年轻的人，无论年龄大小。”约翰·F·肯尼迪曾经说过，现在我再次重申。我主要为那些精神年轻、精力充沛、乐观向上的人写作——为那些和我一样认识到我们能够而且应该使我们的法律和司法体系现代化（我现在喜欢说“升级”）的人写作。

‘My call is to the young in heart, regardless of age’, John F. Kennedy once said, and I say this again now. I write primarily for the youthful of spirit, for the energetic, for the optimistic—for those who join me in recognizing that we can and should modernize (I now like to say ‘upgrade’) our legal and justice systems.

法律职业的中断

Discontinuity in the Legal Profession

本书问世之际，法律界正就一系列重大问题展开激烈辩论。例如，人们深切担忧公共法律经费的削减可能会减少“获得司法公正”的机会。人们担心法学院提供的昂贵学位似乎比实际就业机会还多。此外，人们还对在法庭上提起诉讼的费用过高感到不安。

This book comes at a time of great debate in the legal world over an array of vital issues. There is deep concern, for example, about cuts in public legal funding that may reduce ‘access to justice’. There are worries about law schools that seem to be offering costly places to students in greater numbers than there are job opportunities. And there is unease about the disproportionate expense of pursuing claims in the courts.

我针对这些以及其他诸多弊病提出了一些补救措施，但我提供的答案与大多数职业顾问、家长、教授和法律从业者提供的答案不同。例如，虽然大多数律师主张减少法律援助的削减，但我认为我们应该探索和实施提供法律指导的替代方式，尤其是通过在线法律服务；虽然评论员们对法学院招生过度感到不满，但我发现了一系列令人兴奋的为未来的律师提供新的职业，尽管我担心我们没有为学生和年轻的从业者做好从事这些工作的准备；虽然法官和诉讼律师正在努力控制诉讼成本，但我认为我们应该更多地使用虚拟听证会、在线法庭和在线争议解决。

I offer remedies for these and many other ills, but I do not provide the same sorts of answers as those offered by most careers advisers, parents, professors, and legal practitioners. For example, while most lawyers are arguing for smaller cuts in legal aid, I argue we should be exploring and implementing alternative ways of providing legal guidance, not least through online legal services; while commentators agitate about over-recruitment into law schools, I identify a whole set of exciting new occupations for tomorrow’s lawyers, although I am troubled that we are not preparing students and young practitioners for these jobs; and while judges and litigators are seeking to control the costs of litigation, I believe we should be increasing our use of virtual hearings, online courts, and online dispute resolution.

当今法律界的大多数人倾向于借鉴过去的经验，并假设法律行业具有连续性，以此来寻求解决方案。相反，我预见到随着时间的推移，法律行业将不再延续，并会出现一个与现有法律体系截然不同的法律行业。法律服务的未来既不是格里森式的，也不是朗波尔式的。它也不是假发、木质法庭、皮革封面的巨著或晦涩难懂的法律术语。它甚至不会成为主流的律师服务模式——即由顾问提供一对一、量身定制的专业咨询服务。为了满足客户的需求，我们需要摒弃目前大量的家庭手工业，重塑法律服务的提供方式。正如其他行业正在经历巨大的变革一样，法律行业现在也必须经历同样的变革。事实上，它已经在发生了。为客户量身定制解决方案的专家将面临新的工作方法的挑战，其特点是劳动力成本更低、大规模定制、可回收的法律知识、先进技术的广泛使用等等。

Most inhabitants of today’s legal world tend to look for solutions by extrapolating from the past and on the assumption of continuity in the legal profession. In contrast, I foresee discontinuity over time and the emergence of a legal industry that will be quite alien to the current legal establishment. The future of legal service is neither Grisham nor Rumpole. Nor is it wigs, wood-panelled courtrooms, leather-bound tomes, or arcane legal jargon. It will not even be the dominant model of lawyering, which is one-to-one, consultative professional service by advisers who dispense tailored counsel. To meet the needs of clients, we will need instead to dispose of much of our current cottage industry and reinvent the way in which legal services are delivered. Just as other professions are undergoing massive upheaval, then the same must now take place in law. Indeed, it is already happening. The bespoke specialist who handcrafts solutions for clients will be challenged by new working methods, characterized by lower labour costs, mass customization, recyclable legal knowledge, pervasive use of advanced technology, and more.

20世纪70年代末80年代初，我在法学院读书时，很少有学生认真思考过法律职业的未来。我们理所当然地认为，比如说，25年后，律师的工作会和我们这个时代差不多。事实证明，我们预期的变化不大是正确的。相比之下，展望25年后，我认为情况会……期望律师和法院继续像现在这样运作是荒谬的。仅仅因为技术的力量和应用不可阻挡地增长——仅举几个变革驱动因素之一——我们肯定应该期待一些明显超出温和调整的事情。

When I was at law school, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, few students gave much thought to what the future might hold for the legal profession. We took it for granted that the work of lawyers in, say, 25 years’ time would be much as it was in our time. It transpired that we were right to expect little change. In contrast, in looking 25 years ahead from now, I argue it would be absurd to expect lawyers and courts to carry on operating as they do now. If only because of the inexorable rise in the power and uptake of technology—to pick one of several drivers of change—we must surely expect something manifestly more than modest adjustment.

那么为什么要听我的？

So Why Listen to Me?

你或许会认为，法律界的众多资深人士目前正在深入思考律师和法律体系的长远前景。但你原本以为会掌舵的那些人——政客、律所高级合伙人、政策制定者、法学教授、高级法官、专业机构的领导人——却很少有人真正着眼于未来几年以外的未来。在如此艰难的时期，眼前的困境似乎已经够让人头疼的了。

You might think that hordes of senior people in the legal profession are currently thinking deeply about the long-term prospects for lawyers and the legal system. But very few of the people whom you might expect to be at the helm—politicians, senior partners in law firms, policy-makers, law professors, top judges, leaders of professional bodies—are actually looking much further than beyond the next few years. In these difficult times, the here-and-now seems to be providing headache enough.

事实上，在法律界，全世界只有几百名律师和教授将他们的全部职业生涯奉献给长期理论和规划（本书的“延伸阅读”部分引用了他们的一些著作）。我就是其中之一，并且从事写作、演讲和未来咨询的时间比大多数人都要长。我的职业生涯始于1981年，当时我是格拉斯哥大学法学院三年级本科生。此后，我在牛津大学获得了法学和计算机博士学位，并在“四大”会计师事务所之一工作了数年，然后在20世纪90年代的大部分时间里在一家国际律师事务所工作，并在该事务所担任了三年的董事。我曾担任法学教授三十多年来，我一直担任国际律师事务所、各国政府、企业法务部门和世界各地司法机构的独立顾问，至今已有25年。自1998年以来，我一直担任英格兰和威尔士首席大法官的技术顾问。

In truth, in the legal community there are only a few hundred lawyers and professors around the world who are devoting their full working lives to theorizing about and planning for the long term (some of their works are referenced in the Further Reading section of this book). I am one of them and have been writing, speaking, and advising on the future for longer than most. I started my journey in 1981, as a third-year undergraduate law student at the University of Glasgow. Since then, I have written a doctorate in law and computers at Oxford University, and worked for several years with one of the ‘Big 4’ accounting firms and then for much of the 1990s with an international law firm, on whose board I sat for three years. I have been a law professor for more than three decades, and, for 25 years, an independent adviser to international law firms, national governments, in-house legal departments, and judiciaries around the world. And I have been Technology Adviser to the Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales since 1998.

即使对我最激烈的批评者也不得不承认，过去35年来，在我众多的书籍和报纸专栏中，我的预测正确的次数远多于错误的次数。因此，我想说：如果我所预测的那个彻底变革的法律世界很有可能成为现实，那么花几个小时思考其影响是值得的。如果我的预测能够持续下去——而且我现在对自己预测的信心比上世纪90年代更高——那么继续阅读或许会有所收获。我希望读者不会以为自己是辩护者（“我们如何才能阻止这种情况发生？”），而是能从中找到令人兴奋的新选择和机遇（“我想成为先驱者之一”）。

Even my fiercest critics will concede that in my numerous books and newspaper columns over the last 35 years I have been right more often than wrong in my predictions. So, I say this: if there is a better than even chance that the radically transformed legal world I predict here will come to be, then it should be worth spending a few hours contemplating its implications. If my winning run continues—and my confidence in my predictions is greater now than in the 1990s—then it might pay dividends to read on. And my hope is that readers will not respond defensively (‘how can we stop this happening?’) but will find exciting new options and opportunities in these pages (‘I want to be one of the pioneers’).

本书的组织结构

How the Book is Organized

本书主要分为三个部分。第一部分是对我对法律服务未来发展的看法的更新和简化重述，这些观点已在其他四部著作中提出—— 《法律的未来》（1996年）、《法律的变革》（2000年）、《律师的终结？》（2008年）以及《律师职业的未来》（2015年，与丹尼尔·萨斯坎德合著，2022年更新）。我力求从这些著作中挑选并突出关键主题。我会介绍法律市场变革的主要驱动力，并解释变革的原因和方式。这些将引导律师以不同的方式工作，并将鼓励新的服务提供商以新颖的方式进入市场提供法律服务。在此过程中，我会思考疫情对法律界的影响，然后概述我认为会颠覆律师传统工作实践的一系列技术。为了帮助理解这些系统，我提供了一个框架，用于以结构化的方式思考法律科技的影响。与往常一样，我在这里的重点主要（但绝非唯一）是商业律师事务所的民事工作。对于那些已经熟悉我其他书籍中的观点的读者，我恳请你们不要跳过第一部分，因为自从我上次撰写这些内容以来，市场和我的想法都发生了重大发展。

The book is divided into three main parts. The first is an updated, simplified restatement of my views on the future of legal services, as presented in four other works—The Future of Law (1996), Transforming the Law (2000), The End of Lawyers? (2008), and The Future of the Professions (2015, co-authored with Daniel Susskind and updated in 2022). I have tried to pick out and highlight the key themes of these books. I introduce the main drivers of change in the legal market and explain why and how these will lead lawyers to work differently and will encourage new providers to enter the market with novel approaches to legal service. Along the way, I consider the impact of the pandemic on the legal world and then outline a wide range of technologies that I believe will disrupt the traditional working practices of lawyers. To help put these systems in context, I provide a framework for thinking in a structured way about the impact of legal technology. My focus here, as throughout, is largely, but by no means exclusively, on civil work in commercial law firms. For readers who are already familiar with my ideas from my other books, I urge you not to skip Part One, because there have been significant developments in the market and in my thinking since I last wrote about these.

接下来，在第二部分中，我将勾勒出我所预期的新法律格局。我将探讨律所的未来、内部律师面临的挑战以及蓬勃发展的法律科技初创企业的兴起。我会以摘要的形式，对我预期的转变提出一些时间点。我还将阐述如何通过各种在线法律服务克服“司法救助”问题。我还对法官和法院的工作以及视频听证会、在线法院和在线争议解决的前景做出了一些预测。本文借鉴了我最新的新作《在线法院与司法的未来》 ，该书最初出版于2019年底，但由于疫情带来的变化，于2021年进行了更新。我还借此机会重温了我1996年出版的《法律的未来》一书的研究成果，我在书中对法律界的未来做了一些20年的预测。

Next, in Part Two, I sketch out the new legal landscape, as I expect it to be. I discuss the future for law firms, the challenges facing in-house lawyers, and the emergence of a burgeoning lawtech start-up industry. In summary form, I suggest some timings for the shifts I anticipate. I also lay out some of the ways in which ‘access to justice’ problems will be overcome through a variety of online legal services. I offer some predictions too about the work of judges and the courts, and the promise of video hearings, online courts, and online dispute resolution. Here I draw on my most recent new work, Online Courts and the Future of Justice, published originally in late 2019 but, such were the changes wrought by the pandemic, updated in 2021. I also take the opportunity to revisit the findings of my book, The Future of Law (1996), where I made some 20-year predictions about the legal world.

最后，在本书的第三部分，我更加具体地关注了年轻律师的前景。我问了哪些新的工作和未来将会有哪些新的雇主，以及下一代律师将接受哪些培训以及如何培训。我相信，我对这些问题提供了乐观且鼓舞人心的答案。我还为年轻律师准备了一些深入的问题，让他们可以向现任和未来的雇主提出。然后，我会就“创新”提出一些想法，这是许多律师，尤其是他们的营销顾问经常谈论的话题。最后，我展望了长远发展，尤其是人工智能（AI），并向世界各地（内心）的年轻律师提出了一项挑战。

Lastly, in Part Three of the book, I focus more specifically on the prospects for young lawyers. I ask what new jobs and new employers there will be, and for what and how the next generation of lawyers will be trained. I believe that I provide optimistic and encouraging answers to these questions. I also equip young lawyers with some penetrating questions to put to their current and prospective employers. I then offer some thoughts on ‘innovation’, a topic on the lips of many lawyers and certainly their marketing advisers. Finally I look to the long term, not least at artificial intelligence (AI), and I put down a challenge for young (in heart) lawyers everywhere.

韦恩·格雷茨基，或许是史上最伟大的冰球运动员，他有句名言：“滑向冰球即将去往的方向，而不是它曾经去过的地方。” 同样，当律师们思考未来时，无论是律师事务所还是法学院，他们都应该为法律市场的未来发展而不是过去的现状做规划。用冰球的术语来说，我担心大多数律师仍在滑向冰球曾经去过的地方。因此，我的目的就是展示冰球最有可能最终落在哪里。

Wayne Gretzky, perhaps the finest ice hockey player of all time, famously advised to ‘skate where the puck’s going, not where it’s been’. Similarly, when lawyers are thinking about the future, whether about their law firms or law schools, they should be planning for the legal market as it will be and not as it once was. In ice hockey terms, I worry that most lawyers are still skating to where the puck used to be. My purpose, then, is to show where that puck is most likely to end up.

第一部分

PART ONE

法律市场的根本性变化

Radical Changes in the Legal Market

1变革的三大驱动力

1 Three Drivers of Change

法律市场正处于剧烈的变革之中。新的法律服务模式不断涌现，新的服务提供商在市场中逐渐站稳脚跟，法院的运作方式也正在发生变革。如果不适应这种变革，许多传统的法律业务将会失败。另一方面，在这个瞬息万变的时代，一系列新的机遇正向富有创业精神和创造力的年轻律师展现。

The legal market is in a remarkable state of flux. New ways of delivering legal services are emerging, new providers are becoming firmly established in the market, and the workings of our courts are being transformed. Unless they adapt, many traditional legal businesses will fail. On the other hand, in these fluid times, a whole set of new opportunities are presenting themselves to entrepreneurial and creative young lawyers.

我认为这种变化主要由三大驱动力推动。我称之为“少花钱多办事”的挑战、自由化和技术。其他评论员可能会指出不同的因素，例如多样性和包容性、人口结构变化、气候变化、心理健康、战争威胁和全球化。我并不否认这些因素至关重要，但我在此特别关注的是法律服务提供方式将会发生的变化；我所有的研究和咨询工作，以及我在其他行业的观察，都使我坚信，在法律工作的开展方式方面，我提出的三大驱动力值得关注。让我依次介绍一下。

I believe there are three main drivers of this change. I call these the ‘more-for-less’ challenge, liberalization, and technology. Other commentators may point to different factors, such as diversity and inclusion, shifting demography, climate change, mental health, threat of war, and globalization. I do not deny that such factors are hugely significant but my specific focus here is on the changes that we will see in the way in which legal services are delivered; and all my research and advisory work, as well as what I have seen in other professions, lead me to the conviction that, in relation to how legal work is undertaken, my three drivers are the ones to watch for. Let me introduce each in turn.

“少花钱多办事”的挑战

The ‘More-for-Less’ Challenge

律师的客户多种多样。他们包括大型机构内部的律师，在需要解决重大纠纷或达成大型交易时，会花费巨资寻求法律咨询（每年超过10亿美元的法律预算并不罕见）。他们也包括中小型企业的经理，需要租赁房产、聘用员工，并遵守各种法规。此外，还有普通公民，他们可能需要法律帮助处理诸如搬家、处理债务或提起人身伤害索赔等事宜。尽管这些客户的性质各不相同，但他们目前面临着一个共同的巨大挑战——通常，他们无力承担以传统方式提供的法律服务。

Clients of lawyers come in many different forms. There are in-house lawyers, who work within large organizations and who spend mightily on legal advice when they have major disputes to resolve or large deals to conclude (annual legal budgets north of US$1 billion are not unusual). There are managers within small or medium-sized businesses, who have properties to rent, employees to engage, and all manner of regulations with which to comply. And there are individual citizens, who may need legal help with matters such as moving house, coping with debt, or pursuing some personal injury claim. Although diverse in nature, these clients currently share a big challenge—generally, they cannot afford legal services when delivered in the traditional way.

总法律顾问，即管理公司内部法律部门的个人，总是说他们面临三个问题。首先，由于经济形势严峻，他们面临着减少团队律师人数的压力。其次，首席执行官、首席财务官和董事会要求他们减少在外部律所的支出。然而，与此同时，第三，他们表示，他们要承担的法律和合规工作比以往任何时候都多，而且风险也更大。许多总法律顾问告诉我，他们被要求将整体法律预算削减30%到50%。从表面上看，这是不可持续的。这些来自大型公司和金融机构的客户正面临着工作量增加，而法律资源却减少的局面。在这方面肯定需要做出一些让步。我把这个问题称为“少花钱多办事”的挑战——客户如何与外部法律服务提供商合作，交付……以更低的成本提供更多的法律服务？显然，客户的平台正在燃烧，尽管合伙人声称领先律师事务所的情况并非如此。

General Counsel, the individuals who run in-house legal departments, invariably say that they face three problems. First of all, because of difficult economic conditions, they are under pressure to reduce the number of lawyers in their teams. Second, they are being asked by their chief executives, chief finance officers, and boards to reduce the amount they spend on external law firms. And yet, at the same time, third, they say they have more legal and compliance work to undertake than ever before; and that the work is riskier too. Many General Counsel tell me that they are being required to reduce their overall legal budgets by between 30 per cent and 50 per cent. On the face of it, this is unsustainable. These clients from major companies and financial institutions are facing the prospect of an increasing workload and yet diminishing legal resources. Something surely has to give here. I call this problem the ‘more-for-less’ challenge—how can clients, working with their external legal providers, deliver more legal services at less cost? It is clear that clients’ platforms are burning, even if partners proclaim the same is not so of leading law firms.

“多多益善”的挑战不仅仅是公司内部律师面临的难题。小型企业也面临着类似的困境。这些商家没有自己的专业内部律师，每当他们需要重要的法律帮助时，他们现在都必须求助于外部律师事务所。然而，在这个充满挑战的时代，许多商人坦言他们无力聘请律师，而且常常不得不冒着缺乏法律指导的风险。对于消费者而言，尽管法律是我们所有人生活的中心，但公共法律援助的急剧减少实际上意味着，只有极其富有或极其贫穷的人才能负担得起律师服务。公民也面临着“多多益善”的挑战。

The more-for-less challenge is not just a conundrum for in-house lawyers. Small businesses face a similar dilemma. These traders do not have their own specialist in-house lawyers, and whenever they are in need of serious legal help, they must currently turn to external law firms. In these demanding times, however, many business people confess that they cannot afford lawyers and often have to run the risk of working without legal guidance. As for the consumer, although the law is central to all of our lives, dramatic decreases in public legal aid mean, effectively, that only the very rich or the very poor any longer have the means to afford the services of lawyers. Citizens face the more-for-less challenge too.

我相信，少花钱多办事的挑战将成为未来十年法律服务业的基石。我预计，这一挑战将不可逆转地改变律师的工作方式。需要明确的是，没有人能够理智地断言在可预见的未来，对法律援助的需求将会减少。相反，在一个监管日益严格、日益复杂的世界里，对法律援助的需求正在增长。最大的问题是——如何才能最好地满足这种日益增长的需求？是由传统的律师和律师事务所，还是由其他服务提供商？

I believe the more-for-less challenge will underpin the next decade of legal service. This challenge will, I expect, irreversibly change the way that lawyers work. To be clear—no-one can sensibly contend that the foreseeable future will be one in which there will be less need for legal help. On the contrary, in an increasingly regulated and complex world, the demand for legal help is increasing. The big question is—how will this growing demand best be met? By traditional lawyers and law firms or by alternative providers?

自由化

Liberalization

变革的第二个主要驱动力是自由化。这里先介绍一些背景知识应该会有所帮助。在大多数国家，从历史和一般来说，只有合格的律师才被允许为客户提供法律服务，而且即使如此，也只能来自特定类型的组织（通常是合伙企业）。法律法规规定了谁可以成为律师或法律专业人士，谁可以经营和拥有法律业务，以及他们可以提供哪些服务。不同国家对此的界定也有所不同。在英格兰和威尔士，关键概念是“保留的法律活动”，即只有合格的法律专业人士才被允许从事的工作。在美国，核心概念是“未经授权的执业”，通过排除，将更多服务划归为律师的专属领域。无论地方规则如何差异，大多数司法管辖区中律师专属权背后的原则都是相似的；主要理由是，那些为客户提供法律咨询的律师应该经过适当的培训并拥有丰富的经验，这符合客户的利益。正如我们不希望任何乔为我们做脑外科手术一样，同样，我们也不应该希望同一个乔在法庭上代表我们。

The second main driver of change is liberalization. A little background should help here. In most countries, historically and generally speaking, only qualified lawyers have been permitted to provide legal services to clients, and, even then, only from specific types of organization (typically from partnerships). Laws and regulations have stipulated who can be a lawyer or legal professional, who can run and own a legal business, and what services they can provide. Different countries draw lines in different places. In England and Wales, the key concept is ‘reserved legal activities’, that is, work that only qualified legal professionals are permitted to undertake. In the US, the central concept is the ‘unauthorized practice of law’, which, by exclusion, carves out many more services as the sole province of lawyers. Whatever the disparity in local rules, the principles underlying the exclusivity of lawyers are similar in most jurisdictions; and the main justification is that it is in clients’ interests that those who advise them on the law are suitably trained and experienced. Just as we would not want any Joe performing brain surgery on us, then, similarly, we should not wish that same Joe representing us in the courtroom.

但一个大问题是，这个封闭的法律专家群体似乎并没有为消费者提供足够的选择。几十年来，这导致批评人士和改革者声称，法律行业是一种不合理的垄断，其做法具有限制性和反竞争性。因此，许多人呼吁放宽那些规定谁可以提供法律服务以及哪些类型的企业提供法律服务的法律法规。这其实是在呼吁自由化。（请注意，自由化与放松管制并非一回事。大多数自由化倡导者仍然希望对律师进行监管；事实上，他们也希望对新类别的法律服务提供商进行监管。）

But one big problem here is that this closed community of legal specialists does not seem to offer sufficient choice to the consumer. For decades, this has led critics and reformers to claim that the legal profession is an unjustifiable monopoly and that its practices are restrictive and anti-competitive. In turn, many have campaigned for a relaxation of the laws and regulations that govern who can offer legal services and from what types of business. This is a call for liberalization. (Note that liberalization is not the same creature as deregulation. Most campaigners for liberalization still want lawyers to be regulated; and indeed they want new categories of legal service providers to be regulated as well.)

在英格兰和威尔士，这些活动家的呼吁早在2004年就得到了回应，当时发表了一份独立审查报告，即如今被称为《克莱门蒂报告》。大卫·克莱门蒂爵士（一位会计师，而非律师）受大法官任命，负责审查法律服务的监管框架。为了回应人们对法律市场限制性做法的担忧，他建议进行大规模的自由化。这直接导致了《2007年法律服务法》的出台。该法除其他诸多条款外，还允许设立被称为“替代性商业结构”（ABS）的新型法律企业，以便非律师人士可以拥有和经营法律企业；它允许外部投资者将私募股权或风险投资等外部投资注入法律企业；并且允许非律师人士成为律师事务所的所有者。《2007年法律服务法》还允许律师事务所从私有制转变为在公开证券交易所发行股票（在全球范围内，第一家上市的律师事务所是2007年在澳大利亚的史莱特与高登律师事务所）。

In England and Wales, the call of these campaigners was answered as long ago as 2004, with the publication of an independent review, now known as the Clementi Report. Sir David Clementi (an accountant and not a lawyer) had been appointed by the Lord Chancellor to review the regulatory framework for legal services. Meeting and responding to concerns about restrictive practices in the legal marketplace, he recommended considerable liberalization. This led directly to the Legal Services Act 2007 which, amongst many other provisions, permits the setting up of new types of legal businesses called ‘alternative business structures’ (ABSs), so that non-lawyers can own and run legal businesses; it allows external investment, such as private equity or venture capital, to be injected into legal businesses by outside investors; and it lets non-lawyers become owners of law firms. The 2007 Act also permits law firms to move from being privately owned to issuing shares on a public stock exchange (globally, the first law firm to go public was Slater & Gordon in Australia in 2007).

这一自由化进程在英格兰和威尔士持续展开。新的所有权规则于2011年10月生效，ABS的许可发放工作于2012年3月开始。自此，已有1500多张许可证获得批准。四大会计师事务所巨头（毕马威、普华永道、德勤和安永）位列其中，这表明他们对法律市场的兴趣日益浓厚（参见第17章）。几家历史悠久的律师事务所（例如Reed Smith、Irwin Mitchell和Weightmans）已获得ABS许可，此外还有无数规模较小的律师事务所、替代性法律服务提供商（参见第17章）和初创公司（参见第10章）。一些律师事务所已上市（例如DWF、Knights和Keystone Law）。

This story of liberalization continues to unfold in England and Wales. The new ownership rules came into force in October 2011 and the licensing of ABSs began in March 2012. More than 1500 licences have since been granted. The Big 4 accountancy giants (KPMG, PwC, Deloitte, and EY) are amongst the recipients, one of many signals of their increasing interest in the legal market (see Chapter 17). Several long-established law firms (e.g., Reed Smith, Irwin Mitchell, and Weightmans) have been licensed as ABSs, as have innumerable smaller firms, alternative legal providers (see Chapter 17) and start-ups (Chapter 10). A few law firms have floated (e.g., DWF, Knights, and Keystone Law).

这些发展合在一起意义深远，代表着对传统法律服务的重大突破。并非所有举措都直接由《法律服务法》引发，但这项立法——重点在于此，而非具体举措的细节——正在英国法律市场孕育更强劲的创业精神。即使在没有正式自由化的地方，我们也看到人们正在摆脱法律服务提供方式的狭隘思维束缚。法律市场上出现了新的服务提供商——新的竞争对手。没有人知道这最终会把我们引向何方。这就是市场的本质。我相信，我们唯一可以肯定的是，重大变革正在席卷我们。私募股权公司、风险投资公司、企业家和其他专业服务提供商都意识到，英国价值370亿英镑的法律市场远未达到高效水平，以全新、成本更低、更客户友好、更商业化的方式提供法律服务存在着巨大的机遇。

In combination, these developments are of profound significance and represent a major departure from conventional legal services. Not all of the moves were triggered directly by the Legal Services Act but this legislation—and here is the key point rather than the details of particular initiatives—is engendering a stronger entrepreneurial spirit in the legal market in the UK. Even where there is no formal liberalization, we are seeing a liberation from the constraints of narrow thinking about the way in which legal services can be delivered. There are new providers—new competitors—in the legal marketplace. No-one knows where this will eventually lead us. That is the nature of the market. All we can be sure of, I believe, is that major change is enveloping us. Private equity houses, venture capital firms, entrepreneurs, and other professional providers together are recognizing that the UK’s £37 billion legal market is far from efficient and there are great opportunities for offering legal services in new, less costly, and more client-friendly and business-like ways.

关键在于此。该领域涌现出一些新参与者，他们并不墨守成规。例如，他们不认为法律工作应该由在昂贵城市中心昂贵建筑中工作的高薪律师来承担。他们不像许多传统律师那样坚持认为，法律工作最好按小时计费。他们不受旧有运作方式的束缚。他们热衷于变革，而且他们往往比大多数律师更善于管理，因为大多数律师往往在实际经营商业企业方面几乎没有接受过培训。随着时间的推移，法律界受到（比如）最优秀的零售商和科技公司的影响，受到其管理方法的影响，这必将发生巨大的变化。并得到成熟的外部投资者的支持。

Here is the nub. There are new players in the field, and they are not committed to traditional ways of working. They do not believe, for example, that legal work should be undertaken by expensive lawyers working in expensive buildings in expensive city centres. They do not insist, as many traditional lawyers still maintain, that legal work is best undertaken on an hourly-billing basis. They are not constrained by old ways of operating. They are passionate about change, and they are often better business managers than most lawyers, who tend to have had little training in the actual running of commercial concerns. How different the legal world will surely be when influenced over time by, say, the best retailers and tech companies, by the management methods of corporate boards, and with the backing of sophisticated external investors.

市场力量正在席卷英国的法律行业，这将给传统律师事务所带来新的激烈竞争压力，也为需要法律指导的组织和个人带来更多选择。自由化对律师事务所的影响程度是当前争论的焦点。例如，一些大公司坚持认为，所有这些只对那些承接大宗低利润业务（即大量法律工作但价值不高）的高街律师事务所有意义和威胁。这些公司表示，例如，他们不需要外部投资。然而，他们应该记住，自由化已经帮助吸引四大会计师事务所重返英国法律市场，这将带来竞争和投资能力。大公司可能不觉得他们需要额外的现金来像过去一样继续执业，但目前尚不清楚他们是否有足够的能力支持新的服务机会，例如开发技术平台（第 6 章）或大型人工智能 (AI) 系统（第 22 章），或为主要客户设立共享服务中心（参见第 3 章）。

Market forces are sweeping through the legal profession in the UK and these will bring intense new competitive pressures for traditional law firms and greater choice for organizations and individuals who need legal guidance. The extent of the impact of liberalization on law firms is a matter of considerable current debate. Some major firms, for example, maintain that all of this is of relevance and threat only to High (Main) Street law firms that undertake high-volume, low-margin work (i.e., large quantities of legal work of modest value). These firms say, for instance, that they have no need for external investment. However, they should bear in mind that liberalization has helped entice all the Big 4 accounting firms to return to the English legal market with all the competition and investment capability that this will bring. The large firms may not feel they need extra cash to continue practising as they have in the past but it is not clear that they can comfortably afford to back new service opportunities, such as developing technology platforms (Chapter 6) or substantial artificial intelligence (AI) systems (Chapter 22), or setting up shared services centres for major clients (see Chapter 3).

尚未实现自由化的国家（大多数国家）的律师通常会因为其他原因而对自由化现象不屑一顾——他们认为这只是少数误入歧途的司法管辖区的怪癖。然而，我预计，当这种自由化催生出能够更好地应对客户日益增长的“少花钱多办事”挑战的法律业务和法律服务时，这将在全球范围内产生连锁反应。受益于自由化制度下新服务形式的跨国企业总法律顾问不会无理要求类似的服务。在自己的国家。传统市场的律师事务所可能会发现自己处于竞争劣势，例如无法为雄心勃勃的新项目筹集资金。

Lawyers in countries yet to have been liberalized (which is most countries) will often dismiss the phenomenon of liberalization for a different reason—they regard this as a quirk of a small number of misguided jurisdictions. I anticipate, however, that when this liberalization gives rise to legal businesses and legal services that better meet clients’ growing more-for-less challenge, then this will have a ripple effect around the world. General Counsel of global businesses who benefit from new forms of service in liberalized regimes will not unreasonably ask for similar service in their own countries. Law firms in traditional markets may find themselves at a competitive disadvantage, unable to raise funds for ambitious new ventures, for example.

当然，其他司法管辖区是否以及如何正式回应自由化的可能性仍有待观察。澳大利亚率先通过了这一程序。英格兰和威尔士进行了有力的改革。它们并非孤例。例如，新西兰、爱尔兰和苏格兰的法律市场都已在一定程度上自由化。在美国，许多相关问题受到了地方律师协会的深入审查，在我看来，其中许多协会对变革持相当乐观的态度。美国律师协会在其道德20/20委员会（2012年报告）中持保守态度，在其法律服务未来委员会（2016年）中则持更为开放的态度。此后，取得了重大进展：2020年8月，犹他州成为第一个授权ABS的州（尽管试行了两年）；次月，亚利桑那州最高法院宣布将永久允许ABS；而同年早些时候，加利福尼亚州律师协会的一个工作组也朝着同样的方向发出了一些令人鼓舞的声音。

Of course, whether and how other jurisdictions formally respond to the possibility of liberalization remains to be seen. Australia was first past the post. England and Wales have reformed emphatically. They are not alone. For example, the legal markets of New Zealand, Ireland, and Scotland have liberalized to some extent. In the US, many related questions have been under deep scrutiny by local bar associations, many of which seem to me quite bullish for change, and by the American Bar Association, conservatively in its Ethics 20/20 Commission (reporting in 2012) and more open-mindedly in its Commission on the Future of Legal Services (2016). Since then, there have been significant developments: in August 2020, Utah was the first state to authorize ABSs (albeit as a two-year trial); in the following month, the Supreme Court of Arizona announced that ABSs would be allowed on a permanent basis; while earlier that year, a task force of the State Bar of California made some encouraging noises in the same direction.

在我看来，美国的大坝正在开始决堤。我预测，在经历了剧烈的痛苦和各种方向的转变之后，到2020年代，西方大多数主要司法管辖区（包括美国大部分地区）以及许多新兴司法管辖区也将像英国那样实现自由化。即使它们没有这样做，一些国家的自由化也会给其他大多数国家带来解放。

In the US, in my view, the dam is beginning to burst. I predict that, through the 2020s, after intense agonizing and various changes of direction, most major jurisdictions in the West (including much of the US) and many emerging jurisdictions too will have liberalized in the manner of England. And, even if they do not, liberalization in some countries will bring liberation in most others.

我仍然对那些抵制自由化的司法管辖区持批评态度。我担心那些抵制这种变革的人那些以保护客户为名行事的人往往言不由衷。律师的生存和发展应该源于他们为社会带来其他人无法创造的价值，而不是因为他们将其他人排除在行业之外。

I remain broadly critical of jurisdictions that resist liberalization. I am afraid that those who resist this change in the name of protecting their clients are too often being disingenuous. Lawyers should survive and thrive because they bring value to society that others cannot, and not because they regulate others out of the field.

技术

Technology

过去40年来，我的大部分工作都致力于思考和撰写关于科技（我指的是信息或数字技术）对律师和法院的影响的文章。我也曾就此问题为无数律师事务所、公司内部部门和政府提供咨询。法律界通常不会迅速接受新系统，但如今，他们越来越发现，在科技浪潮的冲击下，难以回避。

Much of my work over the past 40 years has been devoted to thinking and writing about the impact of technology (by which I mean information or digital technology) on lawyers and the courts. I have also advised innumerable law firms, in-house departments, and governments on this same subject. The legal profession has not generally been swift to embrace new systems but it is increasingly finding it impossible to avoid the technology tidal wave.

如今，科技已渗透到我们的世界。想想手机或其他电子设备的用户数量（超过50亿）、互联网用户数量（也超过50亿）、电子邮件用户数量（约40亿）以及Facebook用户数量（接近30亿）。

Technology is now pervasive in our world. Consider the number of users of mobile phones or devices (more than 5 billion), the Internet (also over 5 billion), of email (around 4 billion), and of Facebook (approaching 3 billion).

想想数据。2010年，谷歌时任董事长埃里克·施密特曾表示，“我们每两天创造的信息量就相当于从文明诞生到2003年的总和”。按照这个观点，每两天——更正一下：现在是每小时左右，因为施密特十多年前就这么说过——我们创造的数据量超过5千万亿（5×10^ 18）字节。

Think about data. In 2010, Google’s then chairman, Eric Schmidt, said that every two days, ‘we create as much information as we did from the dawn of civilisation up until 2003’. Every two days, on this view—correction: every hour or so today, because Schmidt was saying this more than a decade ago—we create more than 5 quintillion (5 × 1018) bytes of data.

数字技术并非昙花一现。相反，得益于云计算，数据存储和处理能力正日益成为一种公共设施，如同水和电一样。然而，许多律师在缺乏相关经验的情况下方式，仍然告诉我技术被过度炒作了。一些人甚至仍然指出互联网泡沫的破灭，并声称——谁知道基于什么——技术的影响正在放缓，最近关于法律中人工智能的所有讨论都将被证明是空谈。这是对趋势的荒谬误解。很少有律师听说过摩尔定律：这不是一项国家法则，而是英特尔联合创始人戈登摩尔在 1965 年做出的一个预测。他当时预测（简化）每两年左右计算机的处理能力就会翻一番，而其成本会减半。当时的怀疑论者声称这种趋势只会持续几年，不会再长了。事实上，它仍然在强劲发展，并且鉴于材料科学、量子计算和芯片架构的进步，在可预见的未来它可能会继续有增无减。

Digital technology is not a passing fad. On the contrary, courtesy of cloud computing, data storage and processing power are increasingly being made available as a utility, in the manner of water and electricity. And yet, many lawyers, in an untutored way, still tell me that technology is over-hyped. A few even still point to the bursting of the dotcom bubble and claim—based on who knows what—that the impact of technology is slowing down and that all recent talk of AI in the law will prove to be hot air. This is grotesquely to misunderstand the trends. Too few lawyers have heard of Moore’s Law: not a law of the land but a prediction made in 1965 by Gordon Moore, the man who co-founded Intel. He projected then (to simplify) that every two years or so the processing power of computers would double, and yet its cost would halve. Sceptics at the time claimed that this trend would last for a few years and no more. In the event, it is still going strong and—given advances in material science, quantum computing, and chip architecture—it is likely to continue unabated for the foreseeable future.

在他那本令人敬畏的著作《奇点临近》中，富有先见之明的雷·库兹韦尔用实际案例阐述了摩尔定律（如果该定律继续有效）在未来将产生何种后果。库兹韦尔预测，到2050年，普通台式电脑的处理能力将超过全人类的总和。你可以说我激进，但在我看来，如果我们真的能看到普通台式电脑的处理能力超过全人类的总和的那一天，那么律师或许就该反思一下他们的工作方式了，至少是反思一下自己的一些做法。科技将彻底改变我们经济和社会的方方面面，而法律工作却丝毫没有受到影响，这简直令人难以置信。

In his formidable book, The Singularity is Near, the prescient Ray Kurzweil gives a practical illustration of the future consequences of Moore’s Law, if it continues to hold. By 2050, according to Kurzweil, the average desktop machine will have more processing power than all of humanity combined. You can call me radical, but it seems to me that if we can see the day in which the average desktop machine has more processing power than all of humanity combined, then it might be time for lawyers to rethink at least some of their working practices. It is simply inconceivable that technology will radically alter all corners of our economy and society and yet somehow legal work will be exempt from any change.

还要注意的是，处理能力的这种（字面上的）指数级增长反映在技术的大多数其他方面，从芯片上的晶体管数量，到硬盘容量、计算机内存、带宽等等。最引人注目的是，库兹韦尔在其合集《After Shock》中写道，神经网络（当前人工智能的主导技术）的性能现在不是每两年翻一番，而是每 3.5 个月翻一番，“六年内增长了 30 万倍”。

Note too that this (literally) exponential growth in processing power is mirrored in most other aspects of technology, from the number of transistors on a chip, to hard disk capacity, computer memory, bandwidth, and more. Most arrestingly, in his contribution to the collection, After Shock, Kurzweil recently claimed that the performance of neural nets (the dominant technique underlying current AI) is now doubling not every two years but every 3.5 months, ‘an increase of 300,000 fold in six years’.

技术的性质和作用也在发生变化。如果你是1997年的互联网用户（当时大约有4000万或5000万用户），你只能被动地接收网站提供商发布或传播的任何信息。十年后，我们进入了一个新时代——普通人（而非计算机专家）能够直接在网络上贡献和参与。用户成为信息提供者，读者成为作者，接收者成为参与者。用户可以做出贡献。我们找到了全新的信息生产和协作方式，无论是作为博主、社交网络用户，还是维基百科和YouTube等共享在线资源的贡献者。毫无疑问，故事的下一章将致力于Web3（基于区块链的去中心化网络版本——不必担心细节），以及虚拟现实和元宇宙，在这些领域，用户可以更加完全地沉浸在在线世界中。

The nature and role of technology is also changing. If you were a user of the Web in 1997 (when there were around 40 or 50 million users) you would have been the passive recipient of whatever information website providers chose to publish or broadcast in your direction. A decade later we moved into a new era—ordinary human beings (not computer specialists) were able to contribute and participate directly on the Web. Users became providers. Readers became authors. Recipients became participants. Users were able to contribute. We found radically new ways to produce information and to collaborate with one another, whether as bloggers, users of social networks, or contributors to shared, online resources such as Wikipedia and YouTube. The next chapters of the story, no doubt, will be devoted to Web3 (a decentralized version of the Web, based on blockchain—do not worry about the details) and to virtual reality and the metaverse, where users become much more fully immersed in online worlds.

想到科技发展没有终点线，既令人兴奋又令人不安。我们的机器和系统正变得越来越强大。除了底层技术和赋能技术持续不断的根本性变革之外，每天都有无数新的应用涌现。想到几年后，我们的网络生活很可能会被如今鲜有人知、甚至可能尚未发明的系统所主导，这真是匪夷所思。不妨想想TikTok，一款视频托管服务。它于2016年推出。如今，用户已超过10亿。然而，即使拥有如此庞大的用户群，我总感觉律师们仍在翘首以盼TikTok的腾飞。在抵制或否认新兴系统的重要性时，我们常常会目睹一种我称之为“非理性拒绝主义”的现象——对怀疑论者没有亲身体验过的技术进行教条式的、本能的排斥。“在线法院”（参见第14章）就是众多例子之一。令人尴尬的是，许多律师在花时间了解其实际含义或亲眼目睹其实际运作之前，就直接拒绝了这个想法。

It is exciting and yet disconcerting to contemplate that there is no finishing line for technology. Our machines and systems are becoming increasingly capable. Aside from the ongoing and radical changes in the underlying and enabling technologies, innumerable new applications emerge on a daily basis. It is bizarre to think that in a few years’ time, our online lives will likely be dominated by systems that very few of us have heard of today, or indeed that may not yet have been invented. Consider TikTok, the video hosting service. It was launched in 2016. Today, more than 1 billion people are users. And yet, even with that number, I always get the sense that lawyers are waiting for TikTok to take off. In resisting or denying the relevance of emerging systems, we are often witnessing a phenomenon that I call ‘irrational rejectionism’—the dogmatic and visceral dismissal of a technology with which the sceptic has no direct personal experience. One of many examples here is ‘online courts’ (see Chapter 14). An embarrassing number of lawyers reject the very idea before taking the time to absorb what is actually involved, or seeing them in action.

我再说一遍——我们的机器正变得越来越强大。这意味着，许多我们长期以来认为只有人类才能完成的任务和活动，随着时间的推移，将由有能力的系统自主承担，或者在这些系统的支持下，由不太熟练的人类承担。

I say again—our machines are becoming increasingly capable. This means that many of the tasks and activities that we have for long felt could only be undertaken by humans will, over time, be taken on autonomously by capable systems, or by less expert humans with the support of these systems.

举几个例子有助于说明这一点。我一直以来最喜欢的是IBM的计算机系统沃森（Watson）取得的成就。早在2011年，沃森就参加了美国电视常识问答节目《危险边缘》（Jeopardy!）的现场直播。沃森击败了该节目史上最优秀的两位人类选手。这是一项非凡的技术壮举，融合了人工智能、高级自然语言理解、信息检索、知识处理、语音合成等多种技术。非凡的谷歌可以帮我们检索可能相关的信息，而沃森则展示了未来几年基于人工智能的系统如何真正与我们对话，并解决我们的问题。

A few examples help hit the point home. A long-standing favourite of mine is the achievements of Watson, IBM’s computer system that competed—in a live broadcast back in 2011—on the US television general knowledge quiz show Jeopardy! Watson beat the show’s two finest ever human contestants. This is a phenomenal technological feat, combining various techniques of AI, advanced natural language understanding, information retrieval, knowledge processing, speech synthesis, and more. While the remarkable Google retrieves information for us that might be relevant, Watson shows how AI-based systems, in years to come, might actually speak with us and solve our problems.

机器学习领域正在取得的进步与沃森一样引人注目，甚至更加引人注目。我最喜欢的例子AlphaGo 是由谷歌 DeepMind 设计的围棋系统。围棋的走法比宇宙中的原子还要多，人工智能专家长期以来一直怀疑，即使在中期内，任何系统都无法击败伟大的围棋选手。然而，在 2016 年初，AlphaGo 以四比一的战绩击败了世界顶级围棋选手。该系统使用“深度神经网络”，通过“监督学习”（基于人类专家过去的比赛）和“强化学习”（基于数百万次自我对弈并从这些单独的比赛中不断改进）进行训练。AlphaGo 的一步著名棋步（第二局的第 37 步）竟然被一位人类冠军描述为“漂亮”。令一些人感到不安的是，这个系统展现出了人类所特有的“创造性”或“创新性”特征。当然，AlphaGo 的许多棋局和走法都远远超出了系统设计者的想象。这个故事的后续发展更是令人瞠目结舌。2017 年，该系统的下一个版本，即 AlphaGo Zero，以 100 比 0 的成绩击败了之前的系统。这个新版本没有使用人类棋局的过往数据进行训练，而是学习了游戏规则，并在三天的自我对弈后击败了之前的系统。

As remarkable as Watson, if not more so, is the progress that is being made in the field of machine learning. My favourite example is AlphaGo, a system designed by Google DeepMind to play the board game, Go. There are more possible moves in Go than there are atoms in the universe and AI specialists have for long doubted that any system, even in the medium term, could beat a great player. And yet, in early 2016, AlphaGo trounced the world’s top Go player by four games to one. Using ‘deep neural networks’, the system was trained by a mixture of ‘supervised learning’ (based on past games of human experts) and ‘reinforcement learning’ (based on playing itself millions of times and improving from these solitary contests). One celebrated move by AlphaGo (the 37th move in the second game) was apparently described by a human champion as ‘beautiful’. Disconcertingly for some, here is a system that displays characteristics that in a human being we would describe as ‘creative’ or ‘innovative’. Certainly, many of the games AlphaGo played and the moves it made were well beyond the contemplation of those who designed the system. The sequel to this story is even more jaw-dropping. In 2017, the next version of the system, known as AlphaGo Zero, beat the original system by 100 games to 0. This new version was not trained on past data from human games. Instead, it was given the rules of the game and after three days of playing itself, it vanquished its predecessor.

现在让我们来思考一下 GPT-3（生成式预训练 Transformer 3），这是一个同样运用深度学习技术的语言模型。该系统由 OpenAI 开发，于 2020 年发布，能够生成类似人类的文本。它接受了 2000 亿个单词的文本训练，能够以多种格式阅读和撰写任何主题的文章。GPT-3 可以执行我们过去认为是人类专属的任务。它可以撰写和总结文档，回答问题提问，并参与流畅的对话。它可以写故事、创作诗歌、设计剧本。它甚至可以撰写关于自己的学术论文。而且它的写作水平高得令人望而生畏：例如，在最初的研究论文中，据报道，人类识别 GPT-3（而非人类）撰写的文章的概率只有 52%——与随机概率无异。

Now contemplate GPT-3 (Generative Pre-trained Transformer 3), a language model that also uses deep learning technology. Developed by OpenAI and released in 2020, this natural language processing (NLP) system generates human-like text. It was trained on 200 billion words of text, and can read and write in a wide range of formats, on any subject. GPT-3 can perform tasks that we used to think were the exclusive preserve of humans. It can compose and summarize documents, answer questions, and take part in flowing conversation. It writes stories, creates poetry, devises screenplays. It can even draft an academic paper about itself. And it writes at a dauntingly high standard: in the original research paper, for instance, human beings were reported to be able to identify articles written by GPT-3 (as opposed to humans) just 52 per cent of the time—no better than random chance.

最后，在我列举机器能力不断增强的例子时，我必须提到情感计算，它专注于开发能够检测和表达人类情感的系统。例如，有一个系统可以扫描人类的笑容，并且比人类更准确地判断其真假。请记住，这些系统以及所有其他系统都在不断改进。还要记住，大多数律师从未听说过Watson、AlphaGo、GPT-3和情感计算。

Finally, in my canter through examples of the increasing capability of machines, I must mention affective computing which focuses on the development of systems that can both detect and express human emotions. There is a system, for instance, that scan human smiles and, more accurately than humans, determine whether they are fake or genuine. Remember of these systems, as of all others, that they are only getting better. Remember too that most lawyers have never heard of Watson, AlphaGo, GPT-3, and affective computing.

法律科技

Lawtech

我们正生活在一个技术进步空前迅猛、速度空前的时代，在一个经济和社会生活被技术改变的时代，这对法律界意味着什么？随着机器能力的不断提升，认为法律实践和司法行政将在很大程度上免受技术进步的影响是错误的。更有可能的是，在这个信息和文档最密集的行业之一，我们将见证根本性的、普遍的、不可逆转的变革。

What does it mean for the world of law that we are living at a time of greater and more rapid technological progress than humanity has ever witnessed, in an era in which our economic and social lives are being transformed by technology? As our machines become increasingly capable, it is wrong-headed to believe that legal practice and the administration of justice will be largely unscathed by technological advance. It is more likely, in what is one of the most information-intensive and document-intensive industries of all, that we will see fundamental, pervasive, and irreversible change.

平心而论，大多数律师现在确实承认科技会影响他们。但他们预计，科技的主要影响将在于他们现有工作的自动化。他们将科技视为精简、优化，有时甚至能增强现有工作方式的工具。诚然，法律科技（我常将“法律科技”或“法律技术”交替使用）的前65年几乎完全致力于自动化，即将科技嫁接到传统律师工作上。几十年来，科技一直被用来支持和增强传统的法律活动，而不是改变它。太多律师忽视了创新的可能性和可能性，我特指科技能够让我们完成以前不可能（甚至无法想象）的任务的方式。这里需要转变思维方式。在思考科技时，律师面临的挑战不仅仅是将低效的现有工作方式自动化，这往往只会给我们带来“事倍功半”的麻烦。相反，2020 年代及以后的挑战将是创新——以过去无法做到的方式实践法律、提供司法途径和管理法院。

In fairness, most lawyers do now accept that technology will affect them. But they expect its main impact will be in automation of what they already do today. They regard technology as a tool for streamlining, optimizing, and sometimes perhaps turbocharging their current ways of working. It is true that the first 65 years of lawtech (a term I use interchangeably with ‘legal technology’ or ‘legaltech’) were almost entirely devoted to automation, that is, to grafting technology onto traditional lawyering. Technology has been used over the decades to support and enhance conventional legal activity rather than to change it. What too many lawyers miss is the possibility and likelihood of innovation, a term I use in a specific way to refer to the way that technology can enable us to perform tasks that previously were not possible (or even imaginable). A mindset shift is needed here. When thinking about technology, the challenge for lawyers is not just to automate inefficient current working practices, which often gives us little more than ‘mess for less’. The challenge, rather, for the 2020s and beyond, will be to innovate—to practise law, to offer access to justice, and to run our courts in ways that we could not have done in the past.

然而，我们必须认识到，许多创新技术将具有颠覆性（参见第六章）。这意味着它们不会与传统的运营方式和谐共存，并使其永久延续。相反，它们将从根本上挑战和改变传统习惯。这些无处不在、呈指数级增长的创新技术将颠覆法律界。毫无疑问，在疫情的催化下，它们将改变客户体验，在很大程度上从在玻璃堡垒或老旧联排别墅中的面对面会议转变为丰富、沉浸式的在线互动。它们将推动从咨询式法律咨询服务向在线服务的转变。产品和解决方案，以及将合规性和执行力嵌入企业运营。它们将支撑在线法院的开发和交付。它们将为无力聘请律师的人们（大多数人都是）提供自助系统。这些都是下文将要讲述的故事的要素。

We must recognize, though, that many of these innovative technologies will be disruptive (see Chapter 6). This means they will not sit happily alongside and perpetuate conventional ways of operating. Instead they will fundamentally defy and change conventional habits. These ubiquitous, exponentially growing, innovative technologies will upend the legal world. Catalysed no doubt by the pandemic, they will change the client experience, shifting largely from in-person meetings in glass citadels or tired townhouses into rich, immersive online interactions. They will fuel a move from consultative legal advisory service to online products and solutions, and to embedding compliance and execution in the operations of businesses. They will underpin the development and delivery of online courts. They will deliver self-help systems for people who cannot afford lawyers (which is most people). These are elements of the story that is told in the pages that follow.

值得警惕的是，我们仍处于法律技术变革的初级阶段。全球在法律科技上的支出约为100亿至200亿美元。这听起来可能很多，但全球法律市场本身正悄然逼近1万亿美元。相对而言，金融服务和医疗保健领域的技术支出要大得多。同样重要的是（尽管尚未得到广泛讨论），（据我估计）全球法律科技支出的90%以上来自律师事务所；只有一小部分支出用于内部律师自建系统，而供非律师用户直接使用的系统（例如面向公民的自助服务）则更是少之又少。

It is sobering to note, by way of orientation, that we are still at the foothills of technological change in law. The global spend on lawtech lies somewhere between $10 billion and $20 billion. Which may sound a lot, but the global legal market itself is creeping towards $1 trillion. Relatively speaking, much more is spent on technology in financial services and in healthcare. As important, if not widely discussed, is that (on my estimation) more than 90 per cent of that global spend on lawtech is by law firms; only a small fraction of the expenditure is by in-house lawyers for their own systems, and a tinier fraction still is on systems for direct use by users who are not lawyers (such as self-help services for citizens).

更深入地讲，根据我为律师事务所提供咨询的经验，超过90%的法律科技支出都用于后台系统（笔记本电脑、服务器、数据中心、软件许可证等等）。如今，大多数法律科技（请原谅我，90%的90%）都位于律师事务所的“引擎室”里，这实在是平淡无奇。相比之下，关于法律科技的讨论大多集中在如何利用科技来提升和改变客户服务。现在是时候从空谈转向行动了。

To drill down a little deeper, it is my experience from advising law firms that more 90 per cent of that lawtech spend is itself on back office systems (laptops, servers, data centres, software licences, and the rest). Unglamorously and prosaically, most lawtech today (90 per cent of 90 per cent, if you will forgive me) sits in the engine room of law firms. Most of the chatter about lawtech, in contrast, is about using technology to enhance and change client service. It is time to move from talk to action.

技术带来的许多变化，尤其是社交网络带来的变化，对于法律界的年轻人来说应该很熟悉，因为他们是数字一代的正式成员（我将其定义为那些不记得（这听起来像是一个前互联网时代）。然而，有趣的是，许多年轻律师尚未将科技的社交用途与其在工作中的引入和潜力联系起来。参与人工智能和机器学习的人就更少了。

Many of the changes brought by technology, not least by social networking, should be familiar to younger members of the legal profession, as full-fledged members of the digital generation (which I define as those people who cannot remember a pre-Internet world). Interestingly, though, many young lawyers have not yet made the connection between their social use of technology and its introduction and potential in their working lives. Still fewer are engaged by AI and machine learning.

总而言之，为了将本章的思路串联起来，我认为“少花钱多办事”的挑战、自由化和技术将共同推动律师工作方式发生巨大且不可逆转的变革。一场完美的风暴正在酝酿之中。自由化和技术本身就能带来（并促成）改革，但“少花钱多办事”的挑战，这一由严苛的市场条件驱动的必然趋势，才是并将继续成为影响2020年代法律业务的主导力量。

In conclusion, to pull together the strands of this opening chapter, I am suggesting that the more-for-less challenge, liberalization, and technology will together drive immense and irrevocable change in the way that lawyers work. There is a perfect storm brewing here. Liberalization and technology on their own would bring (and enable) reform but it is the more-for-less challenge, this imperative driven by demanding market conditions, that is and will continue to be the dominant force affecting the business of law in the 2020s.

2疫情的影响

2 Impact of the Pandemic

在本书的导言以及第二版和第三版的前言中，我提到了本书首次出版时我做出的一个预测——法律界在未来二十年内的变化将比过去两个世纪的变化还要大。粗略地说，我指的是2012年至2032年这段时间。

In the Introduction and in the prefaces to the second and third editions of this book, I mention a prediction that I made when this book was first published—that the legal world would change more in two decades than it had in the past two centuries. Roughly speaking, I was referring to the period from 2012 to 2032.

如果我现在试图辩称，由于新冠疫情，我们已经看到了这种程度的变化，至少在争议解决领域和律师的工作习惯方面是如此，律师和预言家们或许都会感到不安。然而，这的确是事实。我承认，声称因新冠疫情而取得任何成功确实有些不妥。我也承认，我通常不应该将自己未曾预料到的事件归功于自己。另一方面，新冠疫情带来的许多变化确实是我预见到的。实际上，新冠疫情加速了我多年来在工作中讨论过的众多技术进步。

Lawyers and prophets alike might well be uneasy if I now tried to argue that, because of COVID, we have already seen this extent of change, at least in the world of dispute resolution and in the working habits of lawyers. It is true, nonetheless. I accept there is something unsavoury about claiming any success because of COVID. And I concede that I ought not generally to take credit for events that I had not anticipated. On the other hand, many of the changes wrought by COVID are ones that I did indeed foresee. COVID, in effect, accelerated numerous technological advances that I have discussed in my work over the years.

我可以就此打住，但这样做未免过于简单——现在就对法律领域的远程工作得出明确的结论还为时过早；我们还没有收集和分析足够的数据迄今为止的影响，有证据表明，COVID 既减缓了法律技术的采用，也加速了其采用。

I could leave it there but to do so would be to oversimplify—it is too soon to draw definitive conclusions about remote working in law; we have not gathered and analysed sufficient data about the impact so far, and there is evidence to suggest that COVID has decelerated as well as accelerated the uptake of legal technology.

初步反应

Initial Response

就连法律界的一些科技怀疑论者现在也表示，他们绝不会回到过去的老路，病毒促使他们采用科技。律师们经常通过视频与客户会面，法学院学生在线学习，许多法庭听证会也远程进行。如果在2020年初提出这些设想，会显得荒谬至极。这是否意味着法律界已经不可逆转地全面拥抱了科技？这种进步令人瞩目，但夸大其词也存在风险。

Even some techno-sceptics in the law are now saying they will never return to their old ways, that the virus catalysed their adoption of technology. Lawyers are routinely meeting clients by video, law students are learning online, and many court hearings are being conducted remotely, all to an extent that would have seemed ludicrous if proposed at the start of 2020. Does this mean the legal profession has irreversibly and comprehensively embraced technology? The advance has been remarkable but there is a danger here of exaggeration.

我们不应将那些仓促拼凑的临时系统（例如将律师、学生和法官转​​移到 Zoom 上）误认为是这些早期努力的全面工业化。要大规模安装安全可靠的系统，需要大量的额外投资。无论是在律师事务所、法学院还是法院，转向可持续的长期远程办公都需要建立新的管理架构，更加注重健康和安全合规性，提供卓越的网络连接，并为未来十年可能频繁居家办公的数百万人提供更好的设备。当然，对某些人来说，他们的家庭环境可能不适合作为永久或半永久的办公场所。这种转变并非适合所有人。

We should not mistake the temporary systems that were stitched together in haste—putting lawyers, students, and judges on, say, Zoom—with the full-scale industrialization of these early efforts. To install secure and robust systems at scale will require formidable further investment. Whether in the law office, law school, or law courts, the move to sustainable, long-term remote working will call, for example, for new management structures, greater attention to health and safety compliance, superior connectivity, and better equipment for the millions who look likely this decade to be stationed frequently at home. For some, of course, their home environment may not be suitable as a permanent or semi-permanent base. The move will not work for everyone.

与此同时，法律界和其他领域一样，旧习难改。公开承认这一点或许并不时髦，但一些（即便不是很多）反动的律师、法学教授和法官一直在悄悄地坚守阵地——一边等待病毒风暴过去，一边怀念他们过去的工作方式。

Meanwhile, in law as elsewhere, old habits die hard. It may not be modish to confess to this in public, but some if not many reactionary lawyers, law professors, and judges have been unobtrusively hunkering and hankering—hunkering down until the viral storm passes, while hankering after their old ways of working.

不定期飞行员

Unscheduled Pilot

从某种意义上说，我们正在经历一场重大的、计划外的试点，一场运用一系列技术维持法律和法院服务正常运转的实验。在许多情况下，这都是一种概念验证。新冠疫情带来了一种紧迫感。它开启并改变了许多人的想法。它催生了务实可行的解决方案，并由此证实了最佳实践可能成为良好实践的敌人。过去，律师和法院的系统过于具体、过度设计，导致实施时间过长。

In a sense, we have been living through a major unscheduled pilot, an experiment in the use of a range of technologies that have been keeping legal and court services operational. In many cases, this has been a proof of concept. COVID created a sense of urgency. It opened and changed many minds. It gave rise to pragmatic, workable solutions and in so doing confirmed that best practice can be the enemy of good practice. In the past, systems for lawyers and the courts have been over-specified and over-engineered and have taken much too long to implement.

与此同时，我们一直将面对面沟通视为黄金标准。然而，现实是，我们无法承担所谓的在所有场合都最好的面对面服务。疫情让我们认识到，足够好通常就足够了，而且肯定比没有强。

At the same time, we have regarded in-person engagement as the defining gold standard. In reality, however, we cannot afford the alleged best on all occasions—the face-to-face service. The pandemic has helped us to recognize that good enough is frequently good enough and certainly better than nothing.

但这些只是非常早期的初步结论。如果我们真的将应对疫情视为一项实验，我们就应该像我们的科学家在寻找治疗方法和疫苗时一样，严格而系统地分析其结果。我们必须收集有关数量、时间、技术、应用、用户及其体验的数据。我们需要新的方法来评估数据并进行未来的试点。我们需要在法律上相当于随机对照试验，被认为是评估和比较医疗干预的最佳技术。

But these are very early and tentative conclusions. If we indeed regard the response to the pandemic as an experiment, we should be as rigorous and systematic in analysing its results as our scientists were in their searches for treatments and vaccines. We must gather data about volumes, timings, technologies, applications, users and their experiences. And we need new methods for evaluating the data and for future piloting. We need in law the equivalent of the randomized controlled trials that are regarded as the best techniques for assessing and comparing medical interventions.

事实上，在维持组织正常运转的忙碌中，关于技术影响的数据收集工作一直参差不齐。无论是律师事务所还是法院服务机构，都对远程办公室和法院中哪些措施行之有效、哪些措施行不通都缺乏足够的了解。当我们设法收集到足够多关于成功和不足的数据时，我们就可以以此为基础——而不是基于轶事和猜测——做出明智的决策，决定哪些措施应该在疫情后保留，哪些应该回归传统方法。反过来，我们关于法院彻底变革的政策制定以及律师事务所战略的制定，也可以真正以证据为基础。

In truth, in the flurry of keeping organizations operational, the collection of data about the impact of the technology has been patchy. Neither law firms nor court services know enough about what has worked well and what has not in our remote offices and courts. When we do manage to capture enough data about successes and shortcomings, we can then use this—rather than anecdote and speculation—as the basis of informed decisions about what should be preserved post-COVID and when we should revert to traditional methods. In turn, our policy-making about radical change in courts and our strategy formulation in law firms can be genuinely evidence-based.

收集到的数据应该成为法律和司法创新思维的基础。天知道，我们需要一些新的、有创意的想法。早在病毒出现之前，我们的司法系统就已经摇摇欲坠——费用高昂、陈旧过时，而且对于非律师来说总是难以理解。疫情使我们面临的挑战更加突出。

The data gathered should be the basis of innovative thinking in law and justice. And goodness knows, we need some new, creative ideas. Long before the virus appeared, our justice system was creaking—unaffordable, antiquated, and invariably unintelligible to those who are not lawyers. The pandemic brought our challenges into sharper relief.

关于数据，我们虽然说了这么多，但也要记住，现状——我们的法律职业和法院目前的运作方式——并非我们有意识选择的基于证据的选项。这只是我们自身造成的现状。

With all of that said about data, we should also remember that the status quo—how our legal profession and our courts currently operate—is not an evidence-based option that we have consciously chosen. It is simply what we have become.

暂停中断

Disruption on Hold

然而，我们也要明确一点，在厨房餐桌上工作并不构成长期以来对律师的商业模式。无可争辩的是，我们见证了一些技术的加速部署，但其中大多数技术本质上支撑着我们应用和传递法律知识的传统方式——通过面对面的交流。

Let us also be clear, however, that working from the kitchen table does not constitute the long-hailed disruption of the business models of lawyers. Uncontestably, we have witnessed an accelerated deployment of some technologies, but most of these have essentially propped up our conventional ways of applying and delivering legal knowledge—through in-person engagement.

在我看来，这并不是等待我们的巨变，那时律师的许多活动及其交付的成果将由越来越强大的系统来承担，这些系统可以自主运行或为非专家用户提供支持。这种转变在很多方面都是本书的重点，但新冠疫情无疑减缓了这种转变的速度。例如，对于大多数法律专业人士来说，疫情期间人工智能被搁置，而我们则紧急建立了在无法面对面会面时进行沟通和协作的方法。大多数法律组织将更具雄心和变革性的技术搁置一旁。总之，用第一章的话来说，疫情加速了法律领域的自动化，减缓了创新。

This is not, in my view, the seismic transformation that awaits us, which is when many of the activities of lawyers and the outcomes they deliver are themselves undertaken by increasingly capable systems operating autonomously or in support of non-expert users. That transformation, in many ways the focal point of this book, has surely been decelerated by COVID. For most legal professionals, for example, artificial intelligence was put on hold during the pandemic, while we urgently put in place methods of communicating and collaborating when unable to meet physically. The more ambitious and transformational technologies were put on back burner by most legal organizations. In summary, in the language of Chapter 1, the pandemic accelerated automation and decelerated innovation in the world of law.

疫情过后，为了克服我们当前法律和法院服务的诸多缺陷（正如第一部分和第二部分所讨论的），我们面临的挑战将不再局限于将技术嫁接到传统的运营实践上。我们将再次致力于开发能够取代而非自动化我们旧有工作方式的系统。

Post-pandemic, to overcome the many shortcomings of our current legal and court service (as discussed across Parts One and Two), the challenge will be to move beyond grafting technologies onto traditional operating practices. We will turn again to the development of systems that will replace rather than automate our old ways of working.

总而言之，在法律市场转型的宏大弧线中，我认为疫情本身并非变革的驱动力。诚然，疫情影响了我三大基本原则之一的步伐。驱动因素——技术——是技术进步的加速器（和减速器），但并非技术进步的总体方向。疫情的影响令人震惊，影响深远，但我预计历史将证明，它并没有改变第一章中提出的总体发展方向。

In all, in the grand arc of transformation in the legal market, I regard the pandemic not as a driver of change in its own right. To be sure, it has affected the pace of one of my three fundamental drivers—technology—as an accelerator (and decelerator), but not the general course of technological advance. The pandemic’s effect has been shocking and its impact far-reaching, but I expect history to confirm that it did not change the overall direction of travel set out in Chapter 1.

成功的三大策略

3 Strategies for Success

第一章介绍的三大变革驱动力，正促使全球律师事务所的领导者思考法律市场过去几乎从未面临过的机遇与威胁。随着客户面临成本压力，商业环境瞬息万变，各地审慎的律师事务所正努力制定有力的应对措施，以应对新的市场环境。换句话说，律师事务所正在投入大量时间和精力，思考未来几年及更远未来的战略。

The three drivers of change introduced in Chapter 1 are urging law firm leaders around the world to contemplate opportunities and threats that the legal market has had little reason to confront in the past. With clients under cost pressures and the business environment changing rapidly, prudent law firms everywhere are trying to develop compelling responses to the new market conditions. In other words, law firms are spending much time and effort in thinking through their strategies for the next few years and beyond.

减少收费

Charging Less

人们或许会认为，应对“少花钱多办事”挑战的最佳方式就是降低收费。对于那些在2007年之前的20年里，以及经济衰退后的十多年里，利润和营业额几乎每年都在增长的企业来说，降低收费的建议通常不会受到热烈欢迎。尽管如此，律师事务所还是喜欢表现出愿意这样做，所以许多人向客户提出“替代收费安排”（有时称为AFA）。律师们心目中的“替代”方案是“按小时计费”，这种计费方式自20世纪70年代中期以来一直是法律服务收费的主要方式。事实上，按小时计费不仅仅是一种法律工作的定价和计费方式；它是一种思维方式和生活方式。律师按他们的时间收费——按他们的投入而不是他们的产出收费。而且，直到不久前，大多数客户似乎都对这种收费方式感到满意。

It might be thought that the best way to meet the more-for-less challenge would be for law firms simply to charge less. For businesses that enjoyed almost uninterrupted yearly growth in profit and turnover for the 20 years leading up to 2007, and then again for more than a decade after the downturn, the suggestion of charging less is not normally greeted with unbridled enthusiasm. Nonetheless, law firms like to show willing and so many propose ‘alternative fee arrangements’ (sometimes known as AFAs) to their clients. The ‘alternative’ that lawyers have in mind is to ‘hourly billing’ which has been the dominant way of charging for legal services since the mid-1970s. In truth, hourly billing is not simply a way of pricing and billing legal work; it is a mindset and a way of life. Lawyers charge for their time—for their input and not their output. And, until not long ago, most clients have seemed comfortable with this approach.

我女儿的一件往事很好地说明了按小时计费的弊端。她12岁的时候，问我要一份暑期工作。我需要做一些行政工作，她同意了。她问我打算付给她多少钱，我不假思索地回答说，我想每小时付给她一定的金额。她想了几秒钟，笑了笑，然后说：“好吧，那我慢慢来。” 如果一个12岁的孩子都能看到按小时计费的弊端，那么让我感到困惑的是，大型跨国公司竟然看不到这里的问题。按小时计费是一种制度化的效率抑制因素。它奖励那些比更有条理的同事花费更长时间完成任务的律师，惩罚那些行动迅速高效的法律顾问。很多时候，律师事务所花费的时间与它带来的价值几乎没有关系。一名初级律师在一项任务上花费 50 个小时，有时其提供的价值远低于经验丰富的从业者（凭借其一生的经验）半小时的工作。

The shortcomings of hourly billing are well illustrated by an old anecdote involving my daughter. When she was 12, she asked me for a summer job.
