I needed some administrative work carried out and she agreed to take on the task. She asked me how much I intended to pay her and I responded, unreflectively, that I thought I would pay her a certain amount per hour. She thought about that for a few seconds, smiled, and then said: ‘Well, I’ll take my time then.’ If a 12-year-old can see the shortcomings of hourly billing, then it puzzles me that major international corporations cannot also see the problem here. Hourly billing is an institutionalized disincentive to efficiency. It rewards lawyers who take longer to complete tasks than their more organized colleagues, and it penalizes legal advisers who operate swiftly and efficiently. All too often, the number of hours spent by a law firm bears little relation to the value that is brought. A junior lawyer who expends 50 hours on a task can sometimes provide much less value than half-an-hour of the work of a seasoned practitioner (drawing on his or her lifetime of experience).

然而，许多大型商业律所的主流文化仍然是律师尽可能多地投入可收费的工时。这种做法的背后是几十年来一直统治着专业律所的商业模式——理论上和实践上，理想的做法是建立一个金字塔结构，其顶端是律师事务所的股权合伙人（所有者），其下是初级律师，他们的努力为事务所带来的收入远超其工资收入。按照这种模式，金字塔的底部越宽，事务所的利润就越高。因此，例如，在美国的一些大型律所，许多律师预计每年的可收费工作时长将远超2500小时。这种结构虽然能确保律所获得丰厚的利润，但客户却越来越不满意。

The dominant culture in so many major commercial firms, however, is still for lawyers to churn out as many chargeable hours as possible. Underlying this practice is a business model for professional firms that has ruled for several decades—the ideal, in theory and practice, is to have a pyramidic structure at the top of which is the equity partner (the owner) of a law firm, beneath whom are junior lawyers whose efforts bring far more revenue to the firm than they are paid as salary. On this model, the broader the base of the pyramid, the more profitable is the firm. And so, in major US firms, for example, many associates are expected to work well over 2,500 chargeable hours each year, a set-up that ensures great profitability for law firms but one with which clients are increasingly disillusioned.

顺便提一下费率和收入。在那些大型商业律所，合伙人的时薪轻松超过1000英镑，而其律师的收费约为其一半，这为这些合伙人带来了非常可观的利润。全球有超过100家律所，其中许多合伙人的年薪超过100万英镑，有些律所的年薪甚至比这高出许多倍。许多合伙人坦言，他们进入法律界时从未想过能有如此高的收入，他们选择法律作为职业并非因为它的报酬丰厚。相比之下，如今许多实力雄厚的法律毕业生正是因为渴望获得丰厚的财富才进入法律界的。他们可能会失望。尽管少数几家全球律所可能会继续提供丰厚的收入，但许多律所的黄金时代可能已经过去。随着时间的推移，少花钱多办事的挑战将压低盈利能力。

In passing, I might add a word or two about rates and incomes. In those large commercial firms where partners’ hourly rates comfortably exceed, say, £1,000 per hour and their associates’ charges are about half of this, this yields very significant profits for these partners. There are north of 100 firms in the world in which many of the partners earn over £1 million per year and in some, their take is numerous multiples greater than this. Many of these partners confess that when they entered the law they never dreamt of such incomes and that they had not chosen the law as a career because it would be well remunerated. In contrast, many high-powered law graduates today enter the law precisely because of the promise of considerable wealth. They may be disappointed. Although a handful of these global practices are likely to continue earning very substantial incomes, it may well be that the golden era for many law firms has almost passed. Over time, the more-for-less challenge will drive down profitability.

上述收入水平自然会导致媒体和公众将律师描述为“富翁”。然而，全球绝大多数律师的收入远低于此。在大多数大型司法管辖区，大约30%到40%的律师事务所由个体执业者经营，约75%的律师事务所合伙人人数不超过四人。这些律师事务所的利润相当低，与公共部门高级职员的利润相当，而非私人银行家的利润。

The scales of income just mentioned understandably give rise to media and public characterization of lawyers as ‘fat cats’. However, the overwhelming majority of lawyers around the world earn much more modestly. In most large jurisdictions, approximately 30 to 40 per cent of the law firms are run by sole practitioners and about 75 per cent have four partners or fewer. In these practices, the profits are considerably lower, in line with senior public sector workers rather than private bankers.

替代费用安排

Alternative Fee Arrangements

回到收费这个棘手的问题，正如前文所述，近年来，许多律师事务所为了满足客户对降低费用的需求，提出了不以时间为基础的收费方式。越来越多的建议采用固定成本或封顶收费（即约定费用上限）。其他律所则走得更远，提出了一些更具创新性的方法，例如“价值计费”，即以各种方式按已完成工作的价值而非所花费的时间收费；或者，作为一种变体，按节省的时间和成本而非所花费的时间收费。

Returning to the vexed issue of charging, many law firms, as said, have sought in recent years to meet clients’ demands for lower fees by proposing methods of charging that are not time-based. There has been an upsurge of proposals for work being undertaken on a fixed-cost basis or on a capped basis (where an upper limit to the fees is agreed). Others have gone further and put forward more exotic approaches such as ‘value billing’, which involves, in a variety of ways, charging for the value of the work undertaken rather than the time expended; or, a variant on this, charging for time and cost saved rather than time spent.

这些建议通常由公司内部律师提出，迫于成本压力，他们正式邀请律师事务所提交关于其服务定价的“新”或“创新”建议。这些请求通常是更广泛的遴选流程的一部分，遴选流程由所谓的“律师事务所小组”组成。本质上，小组是由一组获得优先考虑的律师事务所组成的。遴选过程非常正式，通过名为RFP（项目建议书征求书）或ITT（招标邀请书）的繁琐文件进行。越来越多的公司内部律师开始与更有经验的专业采购人员合作，或者被他们取代，因为后者在降低外部供应商成本方面更有经验。

These proposals have generally been prompted by in-house lawyers who, under cost pressures, have formally invited law firms to submit ‘new’ or ‘innovative’ suggestions for the pricing of their services. These requests have often been made as part of a broader process of selection of what are known as ‘panels’ of law firms. A panel, essentially, is a group of preferred firms. The selection process is quite formal, undertaken through byzantine documents, entitled RFPs (requests for proposals) or ITTs (invitations to tender). Increasingly, in-house lawyers have also been working alongside, or been displaced by, professional procurement people who are more experienced in driving down the cost of external suppliers.

对这些专家组和采购专业人士的支持和反对意见都很多，但目前，关键在于要把握的是，这种竞争性招标流程似乎并没有带来客户所期望的节省。替代性收费安排似乎未能为客户带来显著的节省，至少有两个原因。首先，大多数替代性收费方案都源于按小时计费的思维——例如，在计算固定费用时，许多律师事务所的起点是按传统按小时计费的收费金额。因此，固定费用通常只是按小时计费的微小差异。其次，更重要的是，很少有律师事务所在提出替代性收费方案时是为了降低盈利能力；因此，如果他们不打算改变工作方式（而且他们很少这样做），那么替代性收费方案通常只不过是对原始（成本过高）方案的重新包装。我收到的反馈以及我查阅的私人研究持续表明，竞争性招标及其由此产生的替代收费安排方案，正在为客户带来约10%的法律服务成本总体降低。对于需要将法律预算削减一半的客户来说，无论是大型机构还是消费者，残酷的现实是，差异化定价不足以应对他们“少花钱多办事”的挑战。我认为，现在有必要从差异化定价转向差异化运营。

There is much to be said both for and against these panels and procurement professionals, but, for now, the crucial point to grasp is that this competitive tendering process does not seem to be yielding the savings that clients require. Alternative fee arrangements seem to be failing to deliver significant savings for clients for at least two reasons. The first is that most AFAs are derived from hourly billing thinking—in calculating fixed fees, for example, the starting point of many law firms is the amount that would have been charged on a conventional, hourly billing basis. Fixed fees, therefore, often represent but a slight variation on hourly billing. Second, and more importantly, very few firms when proposing AFAs do so with the intention of becoming less profitable; and so, if they do not propose to change the way they work (and rarely do they), then the alternative fee proposal is often little more than a repackaging of the original (too costly) proposition. The feedback I am hearing and the private research I have examined continue to suggest that competitive tendering and the resulting proposals for alternative fee arrangements are delivering to clients an overall reduction in the cost of legal services of about 10 per cent. Whether they are major organizations or consumers, the harsh reality for clients who need to slash their legal budgets in half is that pricing differently will not be sufficient to meet their more-for-less challenge. I believe it is now necessary to move from pricing differently to working differently.

两种制胜策略

The Two Winning Strategies

在我看来，法律界只有两种可行的策略来应对“少花钱多办事”的挑战。我称之为效率策略和合作策略。简而言之，效率策略主张我们必须找到降低法律服务成本的方法，而合作策略则主张客户应该共同分担某些法律服务的成本。效率策略在未来几年可能会更受青睐，而合作策略将在长期内占据主导地位。

In my view, there are only two viable strategies available to the legal world to help it cope with the more-for-less challenge. I call these the efficiency strategy and the collaboration strategy. In short, the efficiency strategy maintains that we must find ways of cutting the costs of legal service, while the collaboration strategy suggests that clients should come together and share the costs of certain forms of legal service. The efficiency strategy is likely to be favoured over the next few years, whereas the collaboration strategy will come to dominate in the longer term.

许多律所领导听到我谈到效率策略时，立即表示同意需要降低法律成本。他们随后可能会继续讨论如何削减管理费用，通常是通过减少技术、市场营销和人力资源等后台职能的支出。这些措施或许有助于精简机构，但这并不是我倡导效率策略时所指的成本削减。相反，我的观点是，律师服务本身的成本已经过高。大多数客户告诉我，他们不介意为经验丰富的律师支付高昂的费用，但他们越来越愤慨地反对，例如，以高昂的时薪聘请相对初级的律师从事他们认为是例行重复的工作。这才是问题的关键所在。

Many law firm leaders, when they hear me speak of the efficiency strategy, agree immediately that legal costs need to be reduced. They may then go on to discuss how their overheads should be trimmed, often by spending less on back-office functions such as technology, marketing, and human resources. It may be that such measures are appropriate in running a leaner machine, but these are not the cost reductions to which I am referring when I advocate the efficiency strategy. Instead, my claim is that the cost of lawyering itself has become too high. Most clients tell me that they do not mind paying significant rates for experienced lawyers but they do object, with increasing indignation, to paying, for example, high hourly rates for relatively junior lawyers to undertake what they perceive as routine and repetitive work. This is the crux of the matter.

在我访问或提供咨询的每一个法律业务中，我都发现年轻律师承担了大量行政或流程相关的工作。这些工作需要的更多是流程而非判断，需要的是程序而非策略或创造力。例如，诉讼中的文件审查、尽职调查、基本合同起草以及初步的法律研究。这正是变革的绝佳机会。它能够识别出哪些工作可以常规化、更高效地完成，无论是由资质较低、成本较低的人员完成，还是通过计算机化。这自然而然地引导我们走向法律工作的“商品化”（参见第四章），以及我所说的法律工作的“分解”和“多源化”（第五章）。这些并非天马行空的理论概念。它们是我现在遇到的大多数公司内部律师以及许多律师事务所领导关注的主要问题。

In every legal business I visit or advise, I find significant amounts of work being undertaken by young lawyers that is administrative or process-based. The work requires more process than judgment, procedure instead of strategy or creativity. Examples are document review in litigation, due diligence work, basic contract drafting, and rudimentary legal research. Here is the great opportunity for change. It is to identify work that can be made routine and undertaken more efficiently, whether by less qualified, lower-cost human beings, or through computerization. This leads us naturally down a path towards the ‘commoditization’ of legal work (see Chapter 4) and to what I have termed the ‘decomposing’ and ‘multi-sourcing’ of legal work (Chapter 5). These are not fanciful theoretical notions. They are a principal preoccupation of most of the in-house lawyers with whom I now meet and of many law firm leaders too.

至于合作策略，则更为激进，许多律师乍一看似乎难以信服。其理念依然是，为了应对“少花钱多办事”的挑战，客户可以而且愿意共同承担某些类型法律服务的费用。该策略可以与效率策略同时实施，也可以替代效率策略。合作策略最引人注目的例子是我曾一段时间向大型银行倡导的策略。它适用于他们的监管合规工作。大型银行每年在合规方面花费数亿英镑。许多金融机构在100多个国家/地区开展业务，每个国家/地区都有不同的法律法规，每个国家/地区不仅要求遵守各自的规则，还要求定期向监管机构提交文件和表格。及时了解新法规和旧法规的变化，教育成千上万的人了解他们的义务，了解当地的做法和监管机构的偏好，引入支持文件准备和提交的标准流程——这些都是合规专家面临的任务。

As for the collaboration strategy, this is more radical and, at first sight for many lawyers, may seem implausible. The idea, once more, is that to meet the more-for-less challenge, clients can and will come together and share the costs of certain types of legal service. This strategy can be pursued in conjunction with, or instead of, implementing the efficiency strategy. The most dramatic example of the collaboration strategy is one I have advocated for some time for major banks. It applies to their work in regulatory compliance. Major banks spend many hundreds of millions of pounds each year on compliance. Many of these financial institutions operate in well over 100 countries, each with different legislation and regulations, and each requiring not only compliance with their respective rules but also regular submissions of documentation and forms to their regulatory bodies. Keeping up to date with new regulation and changes in old regulation, educating tens of thousands of people on their obligations, understanding the local practices and preferences of regulators, introducing standard processes for supporting the preparation and submission of documentation—these are the tasks facing compliance specialists.

多年来，我的简单主张是，一些银行可以联合起来，分担它们共同承担的许多合规工作的成本。当然，对于以下合规任务来说，这并不合适：是敏感的、机密的或竞争性的；但许多合规工作是行政性的、非竞争性的，银行业中重复劳动的数量巨大，且成本不必要地高昂。因此，我的建议是，各银行联合起来，建立共享服务中心等，这将有助于它们以大幅降低的成本开展至少部分合规活动。这将比有时已经实行的联合法律咨询更进一步。对于目前通过轮流为各家银行提供合规工作咨询而获益的律师事务所来说，这种“合规流程外包”（我称之为）将是一个严峻的形势。他们将无法再在各个客户之间重复完成大量工作。相反，客户将与数量更少的支持性律师事务所合作。我预计，如果一两家律师事务所直接参与支持银行合作群体，将会获得巨大的商业成功。

My simple contention for some years has been that some banks could come together and share the costs of undertaking many of the compliance jobs that they have in common. This would not be appropriate, of course, for compliance tasks that are sensitive, confidential, or competitive; but much compliance work is administrative and non-competitive and the duplication of effort across the banking world is massive and unnecessarily costly. My suggestion, therefore, is that banks club together and set up, for example, shared services centres, which would help them to undertake at least some compliance activities at vastly reduced cost. This would be going a step further than syndicating legal advice, as is sometimes already done. For law firms that currently benefit from advising each bank in turn on their compliance work, this ‘compliance process outsourcing’ (as I call it) would be a grave development. No longer would they be able to recycle much of their work across their various clients. Instead, clients would collaborate with a smaller number of supporting firms. I expect that one or two law firms would enjoy great commercial success if directly involved in supporting the collaborating groups of banks.

客户还可以合作开发系统。早期的案例研究是 Rulefinder，这是一款由国际律师事务所安理国际律师事务所 (Allen & Overy) 开发的在线法律风险管理工具。该服务提供与国际股权披露相关的规则和实践方面的帮助。这是一个复杂且经常变化的监管领域，影响着所有主要金融机构。该系统的创新之处在于，在最初开发时，六家领先的银行联合起来，与安理国际律师事务所合作，共同分担了系统开发成本。

Clients can also collaborate in the development of systems. An early case study here was Rulefinder, an online legal risk management tool developed by the international law firm Allen & Overy. This service offers help with the rules and practices relating to international shareholding disclosure. This is a complex and frequently changing area of regulation that affects all major financial institutions. Innovatively, when the system was first developed, six leading banks came together and collaborated with Allen & Overy and so shared the costs of producing the system.

但合作策略并非仅适用于大型金融机构。例如，几年前，在英国，一些地方政府的内部法律部门召开会议，以类似的方式分担共同法律事务的成本。工作。这种理念同样可以扩展到小型企业和个人——新面貌的法律企业无疑将涌现，为法律用户群体提供服务，而不是仅仅为个人或组织提供服务。

But the collaboration strategy is not just for large financial institutions. Some years ago, in England, for example, the in-house legal departments of a number of local authorities convened and in a similar way shared the costs of common legal work. This philosophy could equally extend to small businesses and individuals—new-look legal businesses will no doubt spring up to serve communities of legal users rather than individuals or organizations on their own.

2008年，我在《律师的终结？》（The End of Lawyers? ）一书中首次提出了合作策略的想法。当时，公司内部律师对此表示初步认可，而一些领先的律所则对此表示怀疑。最近，我经常通过视频访问北美和欧洲大陆，听到总法律顾问们对这种可能性的兴趣日益浓厚，并借助专门构建的在线平台进行了探讨。合作运动正在悄然但稳步地加速发展。

I first floated the idea of the collaboration strategy in 2008, in my book, The End of Lawyers? The suggestion was met with tentative approval by in-house lawyers and sceptical incredulity by leading law firms. In my recent travels (often by video) in North America and continental Europe, I have heard General Counsel speaking with growing interest about this possibility, supported by purpose-built online platforms. Quietly but steadily, the collaboration movement is gathering pace.

4法律商品化

4 Commoditizing the Law

正如上一章所介绍的，效率与协作策略的核心，以及“差异化工作”这一普遍理念的核心，是一个看似粗俗却又至关重要的术语——“商品化”。在法律界，“商品化”一词已被滥用，而且，令人不快的是，它经常被随意滥用，缺乏精准性。许多律师在谈到“商品化”时，往往带有悲观和轻蔑的语气——他们深感遗憾地吟诵道，商品化的法律工作是我们无法再从中赚钱的工作。这里的重点是，曾经手工完成的工作现在可以被常规化，并快速完成，几乎不需要律师的干预。相反，从客户的角度来看，这种向常规化的转变往往是一件好事，因为它可以大大降低法律工作的支出。

Central to the efficiency and collaboration strategies, as introduced in the previous chapter, and also to the general idea of working differently, is a term that is vile and yet vital—that of ‘commoditization’. This has become a rather overused notion in the legal world and, unhelpfully, it is a word that is often bandied about with little precision. When many lawyers speak of commoditization, they are prone to do so in bleak and dismissive terms—commoditized legal work, it is intoned with deep regret, is work from which we can no longer make money. The thrust here is that work that was once handcrafted can now be made routine and disposed of quickly with little need for lawyers’ intervention. In contrast, from the client’s point of view, this shift towards routinization tends to be a good thing, because it leads to much lower expenditure on legal work.

错误的二分法

A False Dichotomy

商品化的法律工作（大致如此）通常与我所说的“定制”法律工作有所区别。我我多年来一直使用“定制”（bespoke）一词，但后来意识到，在英国以外，这个词有时需要一些解释。不妨想象一下服装。定制西装是指根据佩戴者的具体轮廓和体形量身定制的服装。它是手工制作的，专为个人量身定制。类似地，我相信许多律师认为法律工作是高度定制的。他们客户的情况各不相同，每个客户都需要针对具体问题进行精心设计或打造解决方案。这种法律问题解决的概念在许多法学院的学生中根深蒂固，他们似乎认为所有摆在他们面前的问题都具有独特的特点，可能需要最高法院的关注。这也是我们文学作品和戏剧中常见的法律服务模式，律师们孜孜不倦地寻找确凿的证据和法律漏洞。

Commoditized legal work (loosely so called) is often distinguished from what I term ‘bespoke’ legal work. I have used the word ‘bespoke’ for many years but have come to realize that, beyond England, it sometimes requires some explanation. Think about clothing for a moment. A bespoke suit is an outfit that has been customized, made to measure, and tailored for the precise contours and topography of its owner. It is handmade, handcrafted, and cut specifically for one individual alone. By analogy, I believe that many lawyers regard legal work as highly bespoke. Their client’s circumstances are unique and each requires the handcrafting or fashioning of a solution, honed specifically for the individual matter at issue. This is the conception of legal problem-solving that is impressed upon law students in many law schools, where it seems that all problems put before them have features so distinctive that they could require the attention of the Supreme Court. It is also a model of legal services that is found in our literature and theatre, when lawyers look assiduously for smoking guns and loopholes.

我认为，将法律工作视为定制工作，本质上是一种徒劳无功的——尽管常常是浪漫的——幻想。我承认，有些法律问题确实需要运用敏锐的法律思维，并量身定制解决方案。但我相信，真正需要定制化处理的法律工作，远比许多律师希望客户相信的要少得多。更重要的是，我认为，在很多情况下，采用定制化技术无异于采用家庭作坊式的作法，因为如今已经有大规模生产和大规模定制技术来提供成本更低、质量更优的服务。

I take the view that regarding legal work as bespoke in nature is an unproductive—if often romantic—fiction. I accept that some legal issues that arise do call for the application of acute legal minds and the handcrafting of tailored solutions. But I believe much less legal work requires bespoke treatment than many lawyers would have their clients believe. More than this, I contend that deploying bespoke techniques in many instances is to adopt cottage-industry methods when mass production and mass customization techniques are now available to support the delivery of a less costly and yet better service.

另一个令人困惑的根源在于思维上的过度简化，这种思维认为工作要么是定制的，要么在某种模糊的意义上被商品化了。这种二分法促使许多律师坚持认为，如果他们想要避免非盈利性的商品化他们必须专注于定制化工作。他们认为这是仅有的两个选择。

A further source of confusion here is the oversimplification in thinking which concludes that work is either bespoke or in some vague sense commoditized. This dichotomy urges many lawyers to insist that if they are to avoid non-profitable commoditized work, they must then focus only on bespoke endeavour. They believe these are the only two options.

法律服务的演变

The Evolution of Legal Service

我认为，这种对定制化和商品化法律服务的二元区分是一种错误的二分法。法律服务实际上正在经历四个不同的阶段，我称之为定制化、标准化、系统化和外部化，如图4.1所示。（第一版的读者）（如果您阅读本书的版本，您会注意到我已经放弃了那里提出的五阶段模型。修订后的模型更好地反映了我们在法律科技领域实际看到的发展，并且我希望它能够更有效地解释商品化的概念。）

I maintain this binary distinction between bespoke and commoditized legal work is a false dichotomy and that legal services are in fact evolving through four different stages which I call bespoke, standardized, systematized, and externalized, as depicted in Figure 4.1. (Readers of the first edition of this book will recognize that I have moved away from the five-stage model presented there. The revised model better reflects the developments we are actually seeing in lawtech and, I hope, more helpfully explains the concept of commoditization.)

图 4.1法律服务的演变。

FIGURE 4.1 The evolution of legal service.

实践中，优秀律师的许多工作并非以定制的方式进行。诚然，我想再次强调，确实会出现一些需要定制化关注的难题；但更常见的是，律师被要求处理与他们过去面临的问题非常相似的问题。事实上，客户选择某位律师而不是另一位，或选择某家律所而不是另一家律所的原因之一，恰恰是他们认为该律师或律所以前做过类似的工作。大多数客户一想到他们交给律所的每一项新工作都是一张白纸，从头开始，都会感到震惊，尤其是在按小时计费的情况下。相反，客户期望一定程度的标准化。

In practice, much of the work of good practitioners is not undertaken in a bespoke manner. To be sure, and I want to stress this again, difficult problems do arise that undoubtedly require bespoke attention; but, far more frequently, lawyers are asked to tackle problems which bear a strong similarity to those they have faced in the past. Indeed, one of the reasons clients select one lawyer over another, or one firm over another, is precisely that they believe that the lawyer or firm has undertaken similar work previously. Most clients would be horrified to think, especially if they are being billed on an hourly basis, that each new piece of work they pass to law firms is set about with a fresh sheet of paper and embarked upon from scratch. On the contrary, clients expect a degree of standardization.

以雇佣合同为例。如果采用定制化的方式，每一份雇佣协议都需要从零开始重新起草。然而，除非雇佣安排的情况特别特殊，否则知情的客户会期望合同以两种形式实现标准化。首先，他们会设想合同中会采用某种标准流程——例如清单、剧本或程序手册。其次，他们会预期律师会以某种标准模板或先例作为起点。在大多数信誉良好的律师事务所，这种流程和内容的标准化都被广泛接受。客户没有兴趣为重复劳动付费。

Take an employment contract as an example. If a bespoke approach were adopted, each employment agreement would be drafted afresh, starting with a blank canvas. However, unless the circumstances of the employment arrangement were particularly unusual, informed clients would expect standardization in two forms. First, they would imagine some form of standard process would be in play—perhaps a checklist, playbook, or procedure manual. Second, they would anticipate that their lawyers would use some kind of standard template or precedent as a starting point. In most reputable law firms, this kind of standardization, both of process and substance, is widely embraced. Clients have no interest in paying for re-invention of the wheel.

但法律服务的演变并非止步于标准化。随着技术的进步，法律服务可以更进一步，走向系统化。这可以延伸到将清单或程序手册计算机化，形成所谓的工作流系统。这类系统通常用于保险行业，该行业需要自动化处理大量、通常价值较低的任务和活动。如果涉及的任务、活动和人员众多，但流程可以程序化，自动化工作流程可以大大提高法律工作的效率。然而，系统化也可以延伸到文件的实际起草。再次以雇佣合同为例，文档自动化是一种技术，要求用户在屏幕上回答一系列问题（例如，员工姓名、入职日期、工资等等），在完成在线表格后，会生成一份相对完善的初稿。实现这一目标的主导底层技术自20世纪80年代初就已存在——它是一种基于规则的决策树，因此，对特定问题的回答会导致根据具体情况插入或删除某个段落、句子或单词。文档自动化往往具有额外的优势，即回答问题的用户无需是法律专家，甚至无需是律师。

But the evolution of legal service does not stop at standardization. With the advent of technology, a further step can be taken—that of systematization. This can extend to the computerization of checklists or procedure manuals into what are known as workflow systems. These are commonly used in the insurance industry where there is automation of high-volume, often low-value, tasks and activities. Where there are many tasks, activities, and people involved, and yet the process can be proceduralized, automated workflow can greatly enhance the efficiency of legal work. Systematization can also extend, however, to the actual drafting of documents. To use the employment contract example again, document automation is a technique that requires users to answer a series of questions on screen (for example, the name of the employee, the starting date of employment, salary, and so forth) and after completion of an online form, a relatively polished first draft is compiled and emerges. The dominant underlying technology for this has been in existence since the early 1980s—it is a kind of rule-based decision tree, so that answers to particular questions cause a paragraph or sentence or word to be inserted or deleted, as the case may be. Document automation tends to have the added advantage that the user answering the questions need not be a legal expert or even a lawyer.

我知道有一家公司十多年前就将内部文件起草流程系统化，并声称这种新的效率是他们在市场上脱颖而出的关键因素。然而，一位精明的客户敏锐地问道：如果起草雇佣合同（至少对大多数员工而言）只需在线填写表格，那么为什么不能由人力资源部门直接完成呢？在客户组织内部？这种思路自然而然地导致了法律服务的“外部化”。律师将自身经验预先打包，并通过在线平台提供给客户，这便是实现这一目标的途径。它提供了一种全新的利用律师专业知识的方式。外部化过程中，可以采用不同的所有权和收费模式。服务可以以收费模式提供（商业律师事务所的首选），有时免费提供（政府机构和慈善机构青睐的方式），偶尔也会以公共资源模式提供（秉承维基百科和开源运动的精神），但这种模式正在逐渐普及。

I know of one firm that systematized its document drafting internally more than a decade ago and claimed that this new efficiency was a key differentiator for them in the market. However, one savvy client perceptively inquired: if drafting employment contracts, at least for the majority of employees, involves no more than completing a form online, then why can this not be done directly by the human resources department within the client organization? This line of thinking leads naturally to the ‘externalizing’ of legal services. This occurs when lawyers pre-package and make their experience available to clients on an online basis. It offers an entirely new way of tapping into lawyers’ expertise. Different ownership and charging models can be used when externalizing. The service can be made available on a chargeable service (the favoured option for commercial law firms), sometimes at no cost (an approach preferred by government bodies and charitable organizations), and occasionally but increasingly on a commons basis (in the spirit of Wikipedia and the open source movement).

我现在认为，这整个从定制服务向外包服务的转变，可以恰当地称之为法律服务的“商品化”。有时，一些律师将我所谓的“标准化”称为“商品化”，而另一些律师则将商品化等同于无成本的外包。然而，即使律师事务所或其他服务提供商对其在线服务收费，这仍然意味着客户的服务成本将大幅降低，而对于律师事务所来说，这提供了一个即使在他们睡觉时也能赚钱的机会——这与按小时计费的模式截然不同，因为律师的专业知识被使用时不会直接占用他们的时间。

I now think that this entire transition—away from bespoke service towards externalization—can usefully be termed the ‘commoditization’ of legal service. On occasions, some lawyers refer to what I would call ‘standardization’ as ‘commoditization’ whereas others equate commoditization with no-cost externalization. However, even when law firms or other providers charge for access to their online services, this can still mean dramatically lower costs of service for the client, while for the law firm it offers the opportunity to make money while they sleep—this is a radical departure from the hourly billing model, because the lawyers’ expertise is used without any direct consumption of their time.

多年来，我一直为德勤的税务业务提供咨询服务，这里我们找到了一个早期的商品化案例。从2000年左右开始，他们的税务合规工作（帮助客户准备和提交公司纳税申报表）沿着一条与本章介绍的类似的演进路径发展。起初，这是一项手工作业，但他们稳步地沿着这个方向发展。在英国，他们将约250名税务专家的集体专业知识提炼成一个系统，供客户直接使用。通过这种方式将税务知识外部化并出售，他们从根本上改变了商业模式。他们创建了一项服务，旨在降低客户成本，并且由于拥有众多用户，德勤的利润将高于传统的定制服务。有趣的是，德勤在2009年将这项服务出售给了汤森路透。

For many years, I have advised the tax practice of Deloitte, and here we find an early case study of commoditization. From around 2000, they progressed along an evolutionary path in respect of their tax compliance work (helping clients to prepare and submit their corporate tax returns) that is similar to the one introduced in this chapter. In the beginning, this was a handcrafted activity but they moved steadily along the spectrum and, in the UK, they distilled the collective expertise of around 250 of their tax specialists into a system for clients to use directly. In externalizing their tax knowledge in this way and selling it, they fundamentally changed their business model. They created a service that they intended would be of lower cost to clients and, because they have so many users, more profitable for Deloitte than the traditional bespoke offering. Interestingly, Deloitte sold that service to Thomson Reuters in 2009.

从客户的角度来看，在我的进化道路上从左到右的论据是令人信服的——当我们从左到右时，法律服务的成本下降，价格变得更加确定，完成工作所需的时间减少，而质量——令一些人感到惊讶——上升（许多专业人士的集体专业知识总是胜过最有才华的定制个人表演）。

From the client’s point of view, the arguments in favour of moving from left to right on my evolutionary path are compelling—as we move from left to right, the cost of legal service comes down, the price becomes more certain, the time taken to complete work reduces, and the quality—surprisingly for some—goes up (the collective expertise of many professionals invariably outclasses even the most talented bespoke solo performance).

许多律师对将法律服务外包为在线服务的想法不屑一顾。他们说，他们上法学院不是为了打包或外包知识，他们不是出版商，当然也不是软件工程师。我看待世界的方式截然不同。我认为，如果我们能够找到新的、更便宜、更便捷、更轻松的方式来提供法律服务，那么我们就应该调整我们的工作方式，并采用这些新技术。我们的重点应该放在帮助客户应对“少花钱多办事”的严峻挑战上，而不是固执地坚持过时、低效的工作方式。

Many lawyers respond dismissively to the idea of externalizing legal services as online offerings. They say that they did not go to law school to package or externalize their knowledge, they are not publishers, and they are certainly not software engineers. I look at the world very differently. I think if we can find new, cheaper, more convenient, and less forbidding ways of delivering legal services, then we should be adapting the way we work and adopting these new techniques. Our focus should be on helping our clients to meet their formidable more-for-less challenge rather than obstinately holding on to outdated, inefficient working practices.

然而，不可否认的是，我的模型表明，一些法律资源将在网上免费提供，甚至可能以共享的形式提供，这对律师来说是一个不祥之兆。任何人都可以贡献，任何人都可以从中汲取的资源。我承认，律师不会从这些法律服务的商品化中获得商业利益，但我敦促，这些外部化形式将发挥根本性作用，从根本上增加那些目前无力承担法律服务的人们获得司法服务的机会。

There is no denying, however, that my model suggests, rather ominously for lawyers, that some legal resources will become readily available online at no cost, perhaps even as a shared resource to which anyone can contribute and from which anyone can draw. I acknowledge that lawyers will not benefit commercially from the commoditization of legal services in these ways, but I urge that these forms of externalization will be fundamental in radically increasing access to justice for those who cannot currently afford legal services.

5工作方式不同

5 Working Differently

我急于在上一章关于法律服务演变的讨论中补充一点澄清。我的意思并非是，对于任何一项法律工作——比如一笔交易或一场纠纷——都会出现这样的问题：这项法律事务应该放在我的六个“盒子”中的哪一个？我指的是比这更微妙的事情，即对于任何交易或纠纷，无论大小，都可以将其分解，将其“分解”成一系列构成任务。而针对每一项任务，而不是整个工作，我们可以提出这样的问题：开展这项工作最有效的方式是什么？这些任务应该分配到六个“盒子”中的哪一个？

I am anxious to add one point of clarification to my discussion of the evolution of legal services in the previous chapter. What I am not saying is that for any piece of legal work—say, a deal or dispute—the question that arises is as follows: in which of my six boxes does that legal matter sit? I am saying something subtler than this, namely, that for any deal or dispute, no matter how small or large, it is possible to break it down, to ‘decompose’ the work, into a set of constituent tasks. And it is in respect of each of these tasks, not the job as a whole, that one can ask: what is the most efficient way of undertaking this work, and to which of the six boxes should the tasks be allocated?

如果我在本书中的第一个主要观点是法律市场面临着以少赚多的挑战，那么我的第二个观点就是法律工作可以以不同的方式分解和获取。

If my first major point in this book is that the legal market faces the more-for-less challenge, then my second is that legal work can be decomposed and sourced in different ways.

分解

Decomposing

我想说的是，交易和纠纷等法律事务并不是单一、不可分割的专业事务，所有工作都必须以单一方式获取和执行。相反，我们可以将工作分解（其他人会称之为“分解”或“拆分”）成各种任务，并且我建议尽可能高效地完成每一项任务。我所说的并非要贬低质量。相反，我的主张是，有一些方法可以处理单独的法律任务，从而提供与传统法律服务一样高的质量（有时甚至更高），但成本却低得多。

Legal engagements such as deals and disputes, I am saying, are not monolithic, indivisible professional engagements that must all be sourced and undertaken in one way. Instead we can decompose (others would say ‘disaggregate’ or ‘unbundle’) work into various tasks and should discharge each, I propose, in as efficient a manner as possible. None of what I say is to betray quality. Rather, my claim is that there are ways of undertaking individual legal tasks that will deliver quality as high as conventional legal service (and sometimes even higher) but at far lower cost.

当我在会议上谈到法律工作的分解时，会后常常会有律师与我见面，他们会非常友好地告诉我，我的发言非常有趣，并同意法律界需要一次重大变革。这位律师会进一步承认，我关于商品化和分解的说法适用于法律实践的所有领域……除了一个领域。然后这位律师会告诉我，为什么我所说的不同工作方式不适用于他或她自己的法律工作领域。尤其坚持认为每个纠纷都是独一无二的，不存在分解之类的余地的诉讼律师。这反映了我在 20 世纪 90 年代的经历，当时我在一家领先的诉讼律师事务所（梅森律师事务所，现为品诚梅森律师事务所）工作多年。诚然，当时争议处理工作并未分解，在我们擅长的大型建筑和技术争议中，几乎所有工作环节都通常全部交给律所处理。然而，后来我逐渐意识到，我们和其他律所当时承担的任务，并非现在都最好由律所来处理。因此，为了向持怀疑态度的人进行论证，我建议将诉讼程序划分为表5.1中列出的十项任务。我并非暗示这是唯一可行的方案。分解诉讼的方式，但我希望它能让人们了解我的方法。

When I speak at conferences about decomposing legal work, I am often met afterwards by a lawyer who will, quite amicably, tell me that my remarks were enjoyable and will agree that the legal world is in need of a considerable shake-up. The lawyer will go further and concede that what I say about commoditization and decomposition applies to every area of legal practice . . . except one. And the lawyer will then tell me why it is that what I say about working differently does not apply to his or her own area of legal work. Particularly insistent are litigators who will maintain that every dispute is unique and that there is no scope for decomposing and the rest. This reflected my experience of the 1990s, when I worked for many years with a leading firm of litigators (Masons, now Pinsent Masons). It was true, at the time, that dispute work was not decomposed and it was common, for the large construction and technology disputes in which we specialized, for almost all aspects of the work to be handed over to the firm in their entirety. However, I have since come to see that not all of the tasks that we and other firms then undertook are any longer best discharged by law firms. And so to the sceptics by way of demonstration, I suggest that the conduct of litigation can be divided into the ten tasks that are laid out in Table 5.1. I am not suggesting that this is the only way of decomposing litigation but I hope it gives a sense of my approach.

表 5.1 诉讼（分解）

TABLE 5.1 Litigation, decomposed

文件审查
法律研究
项目管理
诉讼支持
（电子）披露
战略
策略
预言
谈判
倡导

多年来，我曾正式或非正式地向世界顶级律所的诉讼律师提出过这样一个问题：在这十项任务中，您最有资格承担哪一项？在英国，这个问题的答案总是“两项”（战略和战术），而在美国，答案往往是“三项”（战略、战术和辩护）。对于这两三项任务，客户仍然希望获得经验丰富的律师的直接建议和指导。然而，我越来越多地听到总法律顾问表示，现在其他服务提供商可以以比传统律所更低的成本和更高的质量承担剩余的任务。

Over the years, formally and informally, the question I have asked litigators in the finest of the world’s law firms is this: which of these ten tasks are you uniquely qualified to undertake? In the UK, the answer to this query has invariably been ‘two’ tasks (strategy and tactics) and, in the US, the answer has tended to be ‘three’ (strategy, tactics, and advocacy). And for these two or three tasks, clients will continue to want the direct advice and guidance of skilled lawyers. However, I am increasingly hearing from General Counsel that alternative providers can now take on the remaining tasks at lower cost and to a higher quality than traditional law firms.

以文件审查为例。传统上，律师事务所会派遣初级律师以相当高的小时费率处理大量文件（有时多达数百万份），通常只是对这些文件进行索引或强制执行一些非常基本的法律分类。暂且不论技术解决方案，在印度等低成本国家，可以将人工文件审查外包给第三方专业供应商，并以大约七分之一的成本获得更高质量的服务。

Take, for example, document review. Traditionally, junior lawyers are deployed by law firms, at significant hourly rates, to work through large bodies of documents (sometimes many millions of them), often simply to index them or to impose some very basic legal classification. Leaving technological solutions to one side for now, manual document review can be outsourced to third party specialist providers, in low-cost countries such as India, and undertaken to a higher quality for around one-seventh of the cost.

再举个例子，项目管理。许多诉讼律师向我吐露，他们不再是律师，而是项目经理。我有时会询问他们接受过多少项目管理培训，他们经常一本正经地告诉我，三年前参加过一个为期两天的培训课程。我通常会反驳说，如果一个项目经理对律师说，自己参加了一个为期三天的法律培训课程，现在成了律师，那这位项目经理肯定会被人误认为是被误导了。项目管理本身就是一门重要的学科，拥有自己的技术、方法、体系和学位课程。当我深入大型会计师事务所、咨询公司和建筑公司时，我发现项目管理非常复杂。而律师事务所的项目管理似乎通常只需要买几把新的文件，然后打开一包新的黄色贴纸。作为律师，我们集体自负地认为，一个周末就能搞定一个相邻的学科。我们做不到。客户现在意识到，他们能找到最好的项目经理并非在律师事务所，而是在其他服务商那里。我坚信，项目管理将成为未来成功处理大型纠纷（和交易）的关键。但如果律师没有接受足够的这方面培训，其他行业和领域的竞争对手就会取代他们承担这项工作。

Consider a further illustration, that of project management. Many litigators confide in me that they are no longer lawyers; they are now project managers. I sometimes inquire about the extent of their training in project management and am often told, with a straight face, that they went on a two-day training course three years previously. I tend to quip in response that if a project manager said to a lawyer that he or she was now a lawyer, having undertaken a three-day training course in the law, that project manager would be dismissed as misguided. Project management is a significant discipline in its own right, with its own techniques, methods, systems, and degree courses. When I look inside major accounting firms, consulting practices, and construction companies, I find sophisticated project management. In law firms, on the other hand, project management often seems to involve little more than buying some new lever-arch files and cracking open a new pack of yellow stickers. It is our collective arrogance as lawyers that we feel we can take on a neighbouring discipline over a weekend. We cannot. And clients now recognize that they will find the best project managers not in law firms but within other providers. I strongly believe that project management will be central to the successful conduct of large-scale disputes (and deals) in the future. But if lawyers are not sufficiently trained in this discipline, competitors from other professions and sectors will undertake this work in their stead.

我可以对诉讼中其他不再由律师事务所胜任的任务进行类似的分析。这些任务中很多都是例行重复的，主要是行政性的，现在可以从不同的途径获得。同样，我可以将交易工作细分为类似的任务列表，如表5.2所示（同样，我并非将其作为最终列表，而只是为了让我大致了解一下我的想法）。

I can undertake similar analysis of each of the other tasks in litigation for which law firms are no longer uniquely qualified. Many of these tasks are routine and repetitive, largely administrative, and can now be sourced in different ways. Equally, I can subdivide transaction work into an analogous list of tasks, as in Table 5.2 (again, not put forward as definitive but included simply to give a taste of what I have in mind).

表 5.2 交易分解

TABLE 5.2 Transactions, decomposed

尽职调查
法律研究
交易管理
模板选择
谈判
定制起草
文档管理
预言
法律咨询
风险评估

替代采购和多方采购

Alternative Sourcing and Multi-Sourcing

当我说不同的定价方式是不够的，律师必须转向不同的工作方式时，我指的是采用一种或多种替代的方法来获取法律工作。过去，当客户面临一项法律工作时，他们只有一个简单的选择：是内部承接，还是将其交给第三方。外部律师事务所（或许两者兼而有之）。法律界已经发生了变化，因此现在出现了新的法律服务替代来源。我已确定了16种法律服务外包方式，如表5.3所示。在这本入门书中，我只能对每种方式略作介绍。

When I say that pricing differently is not enough and that lawyers must move towards working differently, I have in mind the adoption of one or more alternative ways of sourcing legal work. In the past, when confronted with a legal job, a client had a simple choice: to undertake it internally or to pass it out to an external law firm (or perhaps a blend of the two). The legal world has changed, so that new alternative sources of legal service are now available. I have identified 16 ways of sourcing legal work, as laid out in Table 5.3. In this introductory book I can give but a hint of each.

表 5.3 法律服务来源

TABLE 5.3 Sources of legal service

内部采购
解除律师职务
搬迁
离岸外包
外包
分包
合作采购
近岸外包
租赁
家居采购
开源
众包
计算机化
单独采购
知识管理采购
无采购

内部外包是指律师利用自身内部资源自行承担法律工作。例如，公司内部法务部门决定在内部进行所有谈判和文件起草工作，无需任何外部建议或协助。

In-sourcing is when lawyers undertake legal work themselves, using their own internal resources. This could be, for example, when an in-house legal department decides to conduct all of its negotiation and drafting internally, without any external advice or assistance.

“去律师化”是我不太雅致的术语，指的是将法律任务交给非律师人员处理的过程。许多任务不需要合格律师的专业知识和成本，可以由其他在法律行业工作、技术娴熟、知识渊博的人员承担。

De-lawyering is my inelegant term for the process by which a legal task is handed over to a non-lawyer to discharge. Many tasks do not require the expertise and cost of qualified lawyers and can be taken on by other skilled and knowledgeable individuals now working in the legal sector.

迁移是指一家公司将部分法律业务转移到成本更低的地区，但仍在其主要业务已经开展的国家/地区开展业务。早期的案例是美国国际律师事务所奥睿律师事务所 (Orrick)，它在西弗吉尼亚州惠灵市设立了一个全球运营中心。

Relocating involves an organization moving some of its legal work to less costly locations, but still within countries in which the main business already has a presence. An early illustration here was the US-based international law firm Orrick, which established a global operations centre based in Wheeling, West Virginia.

离岸外包是指将法律工作转移到劳动力和房地产成本较低的国家。许多大型银行已通过这种方式将部分法律业务（例如印度和马来西亚）转移到它们已经将其他职能（例如呼叫中心或财务职能）转移至的地区。在这种模式下，离岸的法律资源仍属于银行。

Off-shoring is the transfer of legal work to countries in which labour and property costs are lower. Many large banks have off-shored some of their legal activities in this way—for example, to India and Malaysia—to places where they have already moved other functions, such as their call centres or their finance functions. On this model, the off-shored legal resource remains part of the bank.

相比之下，外包则是指由第三方供应商进行法律工作。这通常被称为“法律流程外包”或“LPO”。诸如文件审查之类的常规法律任务会交给这些专业支持公司，而这些公司通常位于成本较低的地区。

Outsourcing, in contrast, entails the conduct of legal work by a third party provider. This is often referred to as ‘legal process outsourcing’ or ‘LPO’. Routine legal tasks, such as document review, are handed to these specialist support companies, which, again, are usually in low-cost locations.

分包是律师事务所的一种选择。通过这种方式，法律工作会被转交给其他（通常规模较小的）律师事务所，这些律师事务所的运营成本要低得多。因此，一些总部位于伦敦的大型律师事务所会将工作分包给在南非和新西兰工作的持有英国执业资格的律师，而其他一些律师事务所则会聘请英国境内成本较低的地区性律师事务所。分包可以将某些法律任务的成本减半。

Subcontracting is an option open to law firms. On this approach, legal work is passed to other (usually smaller) law firms, which carry much lower overheads. Thus, several large London-based law firms subcontract work to English qualified lawyers working in South Africa and New Zealand, while others engage lower-cost regional firms within the UK. Subcontracting can halve the costs of certain legal tasks.

合作外包是指各组织合作提供某些法律服务，通常通过一些共享服务设施进行。正如第三章所述，英格兰地方政府内部法律部门的合作，以及一些银行计划利用公共设施开展合规工作，就是有力的例证。

Co-sourcing occurs when organizations collaborate in the delivery of some legal service, often through some shared services facility. Powerful illustrations of this, as noted in Chapter 3, are the cooperation of the in-house legal departments of local authorities in England and the plans of some banks to use common facilities for the conduct of their compliance work.

近岸外包与离岸外包类似，但工作是在邻近的低成本司法管辖区进行的，这些司法管辖区与负责分配法律任务的律师事务所或内部部门位于更近的时区。领先的国际律师事务所安理国际律师事务所 (Allen & Overy) 和赫伯特·史密夫·弗里尔律师事务所 (Herbert Smith Freehills) 均已在北爱尔兰贝尔法斯特设立机构，处理日常法律工作，从而实现了近岸外包。

Near-shoring is similar to off-shoring but the work is carried out in a neighbouring, low-cost jurisdiction that is in a closer time zone to the law firm or in-house department that is parcelling out the legal tasks. Allen & Overy and Herbert Smith Freehills, leading international law firms, have both near-shored by setting up facilities in Belfast, in Northern Ireland, for the disposal of routine legal work.

租赁是指聘用律师进行有限期的聘用，通常以项目为基础。这些律师不属于传统的律师事务所，而是通过管理其职位的代理机构提供服务。Axiom 就是此类代理机构的先驱。该公司成立于 2000 年，最初的业务目标是将律师主要租赁给企业客户，通常是为了帮助他们满足高峰需求。事实证明，这种方法对于缩减规模的企业内部部门特别有用，因为他们需要定期提升自身能力，而 Axiom 律师的收费大约是传统律所律师的一半。值得注意的是，英国的几家律师事务所也建立了类似的租赁机构——Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner（2008 年）推出了其按需律师服务，品诚梅森律师事务所（2011 年）推出了 Vario 服务，安理国际律师事务所（2013 年）推出了 Peerpoint 服务。

Leasing is the engagement of lawyers for limited periods and often on a project basis. These lawyers do not belong to conventional law firms. Instead, they are made available through agencies that manage their placement. Axiom was a pioneering example of such an agency. Founded in 2000, the original premise of this business was to lease lawyers largely to corporate clients, often to help them to meet peaks in demand. This approach has proven particularly useful for in-house departments that downsize, because they will periodically need to boost their own capability and Axiom lawyers can be about half the price of those from conventional firms. Significantly, though, several law firms in England have set up similar leasing facilities—Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner (in 2008) with its Lawyers on Demand service, Pinsent Masons (in 2011) with Vario, and Allen & Overy (in 2013) with Peerpoint.

在家招聘的法律人才目前不在主流法律工作场所，但通常兼职，来自选择在家工作的律师。当然，在疫情期间和之后，在家办公已经变得司空见惯。在很大程度上，得益于不断改进的通信和协作技术，大部分时间在家办公的律师（无论是受雇还是独立律师）能够加入和使用与他们合作的律师事务所和内部部门的网络。在家办公不仅使法律行业在疫情期间得以生存，还提供了一种完全不同的生活方式，尤其是对于那些既想工作又想在一天中的大部分时间陪伴年幼孩子的父母来说。

Home-sourcing embraces legal talent that is not currently in the mainstream legal workplace and yet is available, often on a part-time basis, from lawyers who choose to work from their own homes. During and after the pandemic, of course, home-sourcing has become commonplace. Enabled to a large extent by ever-improving communications and collaboration technologies, lawyers who work to a large extent from home (whether on an employed basis or as independents) are able to join and use the networks of law firms and in-house departments with whom they are working. Home-sourcing not only enabled the legal profession to survive during the pandemic but it offered a taste of an entirely different lifestyle, not least for parents who wish both to work and to be available for their young children for much of the day.

开源是指在公共网站上免费提供各种法律资料（标准文件、指南、程序、意见、案例研究、实践经验等等）。如果以维基百科（任何用户都可以编辑和添加内容的在线资源）的形式组织起来，效果可能最佳。

Open-sourcing is the provision, at no charge, of all sorts of legal materials (standard documents, guidelines, procedures, opinions, case studies, practical experience, and more) on publicly accessible websites. This is likely to be most effective if organized in the form of a wiki (an online resource that any users can edit and add to).

众包是指利用大量个人的集体智慧，让他们贡献部分时间来承担特定类别的法律任务。例如，一种方法是将一个法律问题广播给一大群素不相识的志愿者。这些志愿者——也就是众人——会提出他们提出的法律解决方案。在律师事务所，执业律师经常会走到同事的门口，就他们正在处理的问题询问他们：“有人见过这种东西吗？” 未来，律师和客户将能够向大量网络用户提出类似的问题。人们在线提问，并将律师或过去获得过建议的人的答案分享给其他用户，这将成为常态。

Crowd-sourcing involves harnessing the collective talents of large groups of individuals who make some of their time available to undertake certain categories of legal task. On one approach, for instance, a legal problem might be broadcast to a large, unknown group of volunteers. And these volunteers—the crowd—respond with their proposed legal solutions. In law firms, practitioners often pop their heads around doors and ask colleagues in relation to an issue they are handling, ‘has anyone seen one of these before?’ In the future, lawyers and clients will be able to ask similar questions of large bodies of Web users. It will be commonplace for people to ask questions online and for the answers given by lawyers or perhaps the recipients of past advice to be shared with other users.

计算机化，虽然这个术语听起来有些过时，但它是一个广泛的采购类别，我认为它包括第四章介绍的系统化和外部化两类。一般来说，计算机化是指应用技术来支持或取代某些法律任务、流程、活动或服务。

Computerizing, although the term is beginning to sound dated, is a wide category of sourcing which I take to include the two categories of systematizing and externalizing, as introduced in Chapter 4. In general terms, computerization refers to the application of technology to support or replace some legal tasks, processes, activities, or services.

单独外包是指聘请个人专家，例如法学教授或（在英国很常见的）大律师，负责具体的、分解的法律工作。例如，由学者进行的研究和法律顾问撰写的意见书。

Solo-sourcing is the engagement of individual specialists, such as law professors or (as is common in England) barristers to conduct specific, decomposed packages of legal work. Illustrations of this are research conducted by academics and opinions written by KCs.

知识管理外包 (KM-sourcing) 是指运用知识管理领域的各种技术，将日常实践中获取的内容、流程、专业知识、资源、想法以及其他诸多信息进行再利用，并将其精准保存，以便日后回收利用。客户通常期望并始终倾向于律师使用过去在类似情况下成功运用的材料。

KM-sourcing is the use of a variety of techniques from the field of knowledge management to reuse content, process, know-how, sources, ideas, and much else that have been captured from daily practice, and preserved precisely for later recycling. Clients often expect and invariably prefer lawyers to use materials that have worked successfully in the past in similar circumstances.

不外包是我的最后一类，指的是选择完全不承担法律任务，因为他们认为该任务本身的风险不足以进行任何形式的法律外包。举例来说，公司内部律师通常会对法律工作的某些部分发表意见，并认为他们所需的时间和费用在商业上是不合理的。如果工作按照本章前面描述的方式分解，他们通常会发现更容易做到这一点。

No-sourcing is my final category, and is the option of choosing not to undertake a legal task at all, on the informed view that the task itself is not sufficiently high risk to merit any form of legal sourcing. As an illustration, in-house lawyers often take a view on certain portions of legal work and decide that the time and expense that they would require is not commercially justified. They often find this easier to do when work has been decomposed in the manner described earlier in this chapter.

虽然这16种技巧如果单独运用，都能为法律任务的外包提供强有力的替代方法，但将它们视为不同的选择是目光短浅的。我预计，未来对于任何重要的法律工作，将相关事项分解为可管理的任务，确定每项任务最有效的外包方式，并结合采用几种替代方法。我称之为“多方外包”。因此，对于特定的交易或争议，少数甚至众多的来源都可能对最终结果有所贡献。为了实现这一点，我们可能会发现将生产线或制造业的思维方式和方法应用于法律服务的交付会很有用：例如，使用即时物流和全球供应链技术（以技术为基础）。在这种模式下，一个独立的组织——一家律师事务所，或者一家新面貌的法律公司——可能会接管已完成的多方外包服务的全部交付责任（就像建筑项目中的总承包商所做的那样）。

Although each of these 16 techniques, if deployed in isolation, can provide powerful alternative ways of sourcing legal tasks, it is short-sighted to view them as distinct options. In the future, for any substantial piece of legal work, I expect that it will become common practice to decompose the matter in question into manageable tasks, to identify the most efficient way of sourcing each task, and to adopt several of the alternative approaches in combination. I call this ‘multi-sourcing’. Thus, for a particular deal or dispute, a few if not many sources might contribute to the final product. To achieve this, we may find it useful to apply production-line or manufacturing mentality and methodology to the delivery of legal services: using, for example, just-in-time logistics and global supply chain techniques (underpinned by technology). On this model, one individual organization—a law firm or perhaps a new-look legal business—is likely to take over all responsibility for the delivery of the completed, multi-sourced service (as a main contractor will do in a building project).

我并非认为多方外包简单易行。经验表明，律师事务所和法务部门在实践中很难将工作分解并外包给其他供应商。改进方法将使这些律师受益。我也不是说所有多方外包都必须涉及多家供应商——有些客户担心“厨师”太多，但喜欢由单个法律供应商在其组织内部进行多方外包的想法。这种方法鼓励律师事务所或其他供应商分解工作，而不是与其他供应商合作，而是从内部进行多方外包。

I am not suggesting that multi-sourcing is straightforward. Experience suggests that law firms and legal departments find it hard in practice to disaggregate and farm out to alternative providers. These lawyers would benefit from improved method. Nor am I suggesting that all multi-sourcing must involve multiple suppliers—some clients are nervous about having too many cooks but like the idea of individual legal providers multi-sourcing inside their organizations. On this approach, law firms or alternative providers are encouraged to decompose work but rather than to collaborate with others, to multi-source from within.

无论如何，我坚决不提倡某种法律服务的大规模生产模式。我承认客户的情况永远不会完全相同。但我并不认为法律项目生命周期的所有阶段都需要人类法律从业人员，即使最终结果需要定制。相反，我认为多源采购和技术部署将引领大规模定制——利用标准流程和系统能够满足客户的特定需求，同时又能达到与大规模生产相当的效率。一个很好的例子就是文档自动化，如第四章所述。我所描述的这种起草系统并非简单地打印一份标准文档。相反，它会根据用户对其特定情况的具体问题的回答，生成无数（通常是数百万）种可能排列组合中的一种。最终结果是由先进系统而非人工提供的定制解决方案。这才是法律服务的未来。

In any event, I am emphatically not advocating some kind of mass production model for legal service. I accept that the circumstances of clients are never identical. But I do not concede that human legal practitioners are needed at all stages across the lifecycle of a legal project, even if the final output is tailored. Rather, I regard multi-sourcing and the deployment of technology as leading towards mass customization—using standard processes and systems that can meet the particular needs of clients and yet with a level of efficiency that is akin to that of mass production. A good example is document automation, as described in Chapter 4. A drafting system of the kind I describe does not simply print out a single, standard document. Instead, based on a user’s answers to specific questions about his or her particular circumstances, the document generated will be one output of countless (often millions of) possible permutations. The end result is a tailored solution, delivered by an advanced system rather than by a human craftsman. That is the future of legal service.

六大颠覆性法律技术

6 Disruptive Legal Technologies

在管理理论中，借鉴克莱顿·克里斯坦森颇具影响力的著作《创新者的窘境》，人们通常将维持性技术与颠覆性技术区分开来。广义上讲，维持性技术是指那些支持和增强企业或市场当前运作方式的技术。相比之下，颠覆性技术从根本上挑战和改变了企业或行业的运作方式。前者的一个例子是计算机化会计系统，它维持和增强了以前在纸质账簿上劳作的人们的工作。后者的一个例子是数码相机技术，它对柯达公司造成了重大破坏，并在一定程度上导致了柯达公司的最终倒闭，因为柯达的业务基于上一代技术（化学印刷）。

In management theory, drawing on Clayton Christensen’s influential book, The Innovator’s Dilemma, a distinction is commonly drawn between sustaining and disruptive technologies. In broad terms, sustaining technologies are those that support and enhance the way that a business or a market currently operates. In contrast, disruptive technologies fundamentally challenge and change the functioning of a firm or a sector. An example of the former category is computerized accounting systems, which sustained and enhanced the work of those who previously laboured over paper ledgers. An illustration of the latter is digital camera technology, which famously disrupted and led in part to the eventual downfall of Kodak, whose business was based on an earlier generation of technology (chemical printing).

颠覆性技术理论有两个方面值得关注。首先，正如柯达的例子所示，颠覆性技术甚至可以推翻甚至导致市场领导者的衰落。其次，在颠覆性技术发展的早期，市场领导者及其客户常常认为新系统肤浅且难以推广。然而，随着当它们获得认可时，客户通常会迅速转向基于新技术的服务，而供应商除非是早期采用者，否则通常会太晚认识到这些技术的真正潜力，并且永远无法重新获得市场。

Two aspects of disruptive technology theory are noteworthy. First, as the Kodak example illustrates, disruptive technologies can help to unseat and bring about the demise even of market leaders. Second, in the early days of disruptive technologies, market leaders as well as their customers often dismiss the new systems as superficial and unlikely to take off. Later, however, as they gain acceptance, customers often switch quickly to services based on the new technology, whereas providers, unless they are early adopters, are often too late to recognize their real potential and never manage to regain ground.

正如丹尼尔·萨斯坎德和我共同在《职业的未来》一书中所言，对于专业工作者而言，“颠覆”一词应谨慎使用。虽然专业人士确实可能会因本文所讨论的各类变革而感到颠覆，这可以理解，但我们永远不应忘记客户，即法律服务的接受者。本文设想的许多变革应该会为客户提供更优质、更低成本或更便捷的服务。这些受益者不太可能丝毫感到颠覆。相反，他们甚至可能感到更加强大或更加自由。对于法律服务的购买者而言，这种颠覆通常无疑是个好消息。一个人的颠覆可能成为另一个人的救赎。

In relation to professional workers, as Daniel Susskind and I say in The Future of the Professions, the term ‘disruption’ should be handled with care. While it is understandable that professionals may indeed feel disrupted by the types of changes discussed in these pages, we should never forget the client, the recipient of legal services. Many of the changes envisaged here should result in better or lower-cost or more convenient service for clients. It is unlikely that these beneficiaries will feel in the least disrupted. Instead, they may even feel empowered or liberated. For the buyer of legal services, this disruption is often very good news indeed. One person’s disruption can be another’s salvation.

律师们可以从中汲取的教训远不止颠覆性的问题——务必考虑你服务的接受者。在考虑某种创新时，要设身处地为那些你本应帮助的人着想。这对他们意味着什么？

There is a lesson here for lawyers that reaches beyond the issue of disruption—always give thought to the recipient of your services. When considering some kind of innovation, put yourselves in the shoes of those you are meant to be helping. What will it mean for them?

话虽如此，鉴于本书主要面向服务提供商，坚持使用“颠覆”的语言也合情合理。我的目标之一正是挑战法律市场的供给侧，即思考科技可能给律师事务所和其他法律服务提供商带来的潜在破坏。

That said, given this book is largely directed at providers, it makes sense to stick with the language of disruption. One of my purposes is precisely to challenge the supply side of the legal market, that is, to contemplate the potential havoc that technology might well unleash among law firms and other legal service providers.

更具体地说，我认为法律领域至少存在15种颠覆性技术（见表6.1）。这些现有和新兴系统将分别挑战和改变法律的运作方式。哪些特定的法律服务得以提供。它们将共同改变整个法律格局。接下来，我将对这些颠覆性的法律技术进行简要介绍（请注意，其中一些类别之间存在重叠）。

To be more specific, I claim there are at least 15 disruptive technologies in law (see Table 6.1). Individually, these existing and emerging systems will challenge and change the way in which certain legal services are delivered. Collectively, they will transform the entire legal landscape. In what follows, I offer very brief introductions to each of these disruptive legal technologies (and please note that there are overlaps between some of these categories).

表 6.1 颠覆性法律技术

TABLE 6.1 Disruptive legal technologies

文档自动化
持续的连接
电子法律市场
电子学习
网上法律指导
合法开源
封闭的法律社区
工作流程和项目管理
嵌入式法律知识
区块链
网上争议解决
文档分析
机器预测
自然语言处理
合法平台

文档自动化

Document Automation

这些系统，如第 4 章所述，会生成相对完善和定制的文档版本，以响应向用户提出的问题。20世纪80年代，该领域的早期研究主要致力于遗嘱生成系统。此后，同样的技术被应用于更为宏大的领域，例如为大规模银行交易生成贷款文件。因此，文档自动化可用于法律业务，或提供在线服务。这对收费律师来说是一个颠覆性的改变，因为它可以在几分钟内生成文件，而在过去，生成文件需要花费数小时。

These systems, as described in Chapter 4, generate relatively polished and customized versions of documents, in response to questions asked of their users. Much of the early work in this field, in the 1980s, was devoted to systems that could generate wills. Since then, the same technology has been applied in far more ambitious contexts such as the production of loan documentation for large-scale banking transactions. Document automation can therefore be used within legal businesses or made available online, and is disruptive for lawyers who charge for their time, because it enables documents to be generated in minutes whereas, in the past, they would have taken many hours to craft.

那些为用户提供基本文档模板的在线服务，远不如全面的自动化文档组装系统那么复杂。这便是LegalZoom最初的业务，这家美国公司致力于为那些无力聘请律师或希望在法律问题上节省开支（这才是颠覆性之处）的公民和企业提供法律文件。LegalZoom及其主要竞争对手Rocket Lawyer如今已服务了数百万客户，其品牌在美国的知名度甚至超过了大多数律师事务所。他们的服务越来越多地借助科技的力量，但他们早期的成功证明，即使是模板，只要在网上提供一些指导，也能发挥作用，并成为一项曾经专属于律师的服务。

Not quite as sophisticated as full-scale automated document assembly systems are those online services that provide users with basic document templates. This was the original business of LegalZoom, a US-based company that makes legal documents available to citizens and businesses who cannot afford lawyers or wish to spend less (and here is the disruption) on their legal issues. LegalZoom and its main competitor, Rocket Lawyer, have now served many millions of customers and their brands are better known in the US than most law firms. Their service has become increasingly enabled by technology but their early success confirms that even templates, when available online with some guidance, can be useful and constitute a service that used to be the exclusive preserve of lawyers.

持续连接

Relentless Connectivity

这是指防止律师完全脱离其客户和工作场所的制度。这些技术包括手持设备、平板电脑、无线宽带接入、高清视频会议、即时通讯、社交媒体和电子邮件，所有这些技术都因处理能力和存储容量的不断提升而更加强大。当这些技术结合在一起，并且各种机器（无论何种类型）都处于开启状态时（现在似乎无时无刻不在开启），律师的“存在”就会越来越容易被他们的人脉网络所察觉。反过来，客户和同事将能够并且期望能够立即联系到律师。这可能会扰乱律师的工作和社交生活。同样令人警醒的是，我们似乎注定会变得更加紧密，而不是更加疏远，因此持续不断的连接所带来的干扰可能会加剧而不是减少。

This refers to systems that together prevent lawyers from entirely disengaging from their clients and the workplace. The technologies include handheld devices, tablets, wireless broadband access, high-definition video conferencing, instant messaging, social media, and email, all bolstered by increasing processing power and storage capacity. When these technologies combine, and the machines (of whatever kind) are switched on, which seems now to be all of the time, the ‘presence’ of lawyers is increasingly visible to their network of contacts. In turn, clients and colleagues will have and expect to have immediate access to lawyers. This can be disruptive for the working and social lives of lawyers. It is a sobering thought too that we seem destined to become more and not less connected, so that the disruption of relentless connectivity is likely to intensify rather than diminish.

在新冠疫情期间，Zoom 之类的服务既是福音，也是负担——它提供的即时联系服务比电话更有效，让法律界得以维持运转。但律师们从未感到如此“随叫随到”。无论如何，越来越明显的是，这种互动形式（不可避免地被过度渲染）从现在起将成为客户体验的基石。对于那些受益于能够按差旅时间收费的律师来说，这又一次带来了进一步的干扰。

During COVID, services like Zoom proved to be a boon and a burden—in offering immediate availability so much more usefully than by phone calls, the legal world was kept afloat. But lawyers have never felt more ‘on call’. In any event, it is becoming clear that this form of interaction (inevitably much embellished) will, from now on, be fundamental to the client experience. For lawyers, who benefited from being able to charge for travel time, again there is further disruption here.

电子法律市场

Electronic Legal Marketplace

我使用这个术语来包括在线信誉系统，该系统允许客户在线分享他们对律师的表现和服务水平的看法（就像酒店和餐馆的顾客一样）；价格比较系统，该系统将不同法律顾问和法律服务提供者的各自价格和费率放在一起。律师事务所可以通过简单的网站进行交易；以及在线法律拍卖，其概念与eBay类似，但更适合常规且重复的法律工作。对于那些过去常常利用客户不知道自己有哪些替代方案而获利的律师来说，这些技术无论单独使用还是组合使用都极具颠覆性。如今，这些系统——某种意义上的社交网络——仍处于早期阶段。用不了几年，它们就会像过去25年来一直用于对律师和律师事务所进行排名的、颇具影响力的印刷名录一样普及。

I use this term to include online reputation systems, which allow clients to share their views, online, on the performance and levels of service of their lawyers (as customers of hotels and restaurants do); price comparison systems, which put the respective prices and rates of different legal advisers and law firms on simple websites; and online legal auctions, not unlike eBay in concept, but best suited to legal work packages that are routine and repetitive. For lawyers who used to benefit from their clients not knowing what alternatives were open to them, these technologies in isolation and together are highly disruptive. Today, these systems—social networks of a sort—are still in their early incarnations. In not too many years, they will be as pervasive as the influential printed directories that have ranked lawyers and law firms for the last 25 years or so.

电子学习

e-Learning

用于支持法律学习和培训的在线设施的开发正在取得显著进展。正如第十八章所讨论的，这些设施将挑战并取代大多数传统的法律讲座，更广泛地说，将促使法学院传统教学方法的彻底改革。所涉及的技术远不止在线讲座和网络研讨会，还包括模拟法律实践和虚拟法律学习环境的使用。疫情无疑再次加速了相关发展。

Remarkable progress is being made on the development of online facilities to support legal learning and training. As discussed in Chapter 18, these will challenge and replace most conventional law lectures and, more broadly, will precipitate an overhaul of the traditional teaching methods of law schools generally. The techniques involved extend well beyond online lectures and webinars to the use of simulated legal practice and virtual legal learning environments. Again, the pandemic has no doubt accelerated related developments.

除了正规教育之外，在线学习还将改变律师事务所提供和整合其培训及专业知识功能的方式。我们将见证从“以防万一”的课堂培训（教授科目，以防万一所提供的见解在以后的实践中可能需要）转向“即时”学习（利用交互式多媒体工具，现场提供有针对性的定制培训）。

Beyond formal education, e-learning will also transform the way that law firms provide and integrate their training and know-how functions. We will see a move from ‘just-in-case’ classroom training (teaching subjects, just in case the insight provided might be needed in practice at some later stage) to ‘just-in-time’ learning (interactive, multimedia tools which can supply focused and tailored training on the spot).

在线法律指导

Online Legal Guidance

这些系统可以在线提供法律信息、法律指导，甚至法律咨询。它们可能是基于订阅的，也可能不是。有些系统可能适用于低价值但高流量的工作领域，例如最初由学生开发的帮助驾驶员挑战停车罚款的系统（该系统已演变为DoNotPay）；有些系统可能适用于大多数人几乎无法获得律师服务的司法管辖区，例如乌干达的Barefoot Law；有些系统可能适用于复杂的商业工作，例如安理国际律师事务所（Allen & Overy）的在线法律服务，该服务每年从超过650个订阅用户那里获得超过2200万英镑的收入。

These are systems that can provide legal information, legal guidance, and even legal advice on an online basis. They may or may not be subscription-based. Some can be in low-value but high-volume areas of work, such as the system originally developed by a student to help drivers challenge parking fines (this has evolved into DoNotPay), some can be in jurisdictions where access to lawyers for most people is almost non-existent, such as Barefoot Law in Uganda, and some can be in complex, commercial work, such as Allen & Overy’s online legal services, which annually generate more than £22 million from over 650 subscriptions.

这对传统律师的威胁和颠覆显而易见：如果客户能够在线获取法律指导和法律文件，那么这可能会成为那些依靠传统咨询式面对面咨询服务谋生的律师的低成本竞争对手。而且，用第四章的术语来说，如果强大可靠的法律帮助被商品化并免费提供给用户，那么至少在某些情况下，很难想象客户为什么会愿意向传统的人工顾问支付高额费用。

The threat and disruption to conventional lawyers here is clear: if clients can secure legal guidance and legal documents on an online basis, then this may come to be a low-cost competitor to lawyers whose living is made from traditional, consultative, face-to-face advisory service. And, in the terminology of Chapter 4, if robust and reliable legal help is commoditized and available at no cost to users, then it is hard to imagine, at least in some circumstances, why clients would prefer to pay good money to traditional human advisers.

合法开源

Legal Open-Sourcing

与开源运动总体一致，我在此设想在法律领域持续进行大规模的在线合作——一场致力于建立大量面向社区的公共法律材料，例如标准文件、清单和流程图。这也是一种商品化形式（参见第四章），对律师来说具有颠覆性意义，因为曾经作为律师服务一部分收费的法律内容，现在再次免费提供。康奈尔大学法学院的法律信息研究所就是这一现象的一个长期例证。自1992年以来，该研究所一直免费在线发布法律内容，并创建帮助人们理解法律问题的资料。他们有时被称为领先的“非法律”公共法律信息提供商。在医疗领域，拥有超过85万用户的网站< http://www.patientslikeme.com >有力地展现了专业服务的合作接受者如何有效地分享见解和经验。类似地，我们应该期待一个名为“ www.legalclientslikeme.com ”的网站很快会出现（请注意，似乎还没有人拥有该域名）。

Consistent with the open-source movement generally, here I envisage sustained online mass collaboration in the field of law—a movement devoted to building up large quantities of public, community-oriented legal materials, such as standard documents, checklists, and flowcharts. This is also a form of commoditization (see Chapter 4) and is disruptive for lawyers because, once again, legal content that once was chargeable as part of lawyers’ service is now available for no fee. A long-running illustration of this phenomenon is the Legal Information Institute at Cornell University Law School, where, since 1992, they have been publishing law online at no charge and creating materials that help people to understand legal issues. They are sometimes referred to as a leading ‘law-not-com’ provider of public legal information. In health, the website <http://www.patientslikeme.com>, with over 850,000 users, is a powerful illustration of how collaborating recipients of professional service can usefully share insights and experience. By analogy, we should expect a site with some such name as ‘www.legalclientslikeme.com’ to emerge soon (take note that no one seems to own that domain name yet).

封闭的法律社区

Closed Legal Communities

其理念是让志同道合、兴趣相投的律师聚集在一起，在私人社交网络上进行在线协作；这有点像领英和维基百科的结合体，但仅供律师群体使用，用户可以在其中积累集体知识和经验。类似的理念在医疗行业也取得了相当大的成功：Sermo，一个面向医生（不包括患者或制药公司）的在线社区，已经拥有超过拥有来自约150个国家的130万用户（“经过验证和认证的医生”）。法律领域中这一现象的最佳例证是Legal OnRamp的初版，它最初被描述为一个面向内部法律顾问的协作系统。外部律师和第三方服务提供商也参与其中。上线后不久，来自40多个国家的律师就活跃起来，既活跃于通用在线社区，也活跃于可以建立的私人子社区。在初版中，它并没有像Sermo那样取得成功。在我看来，它来得太早了，但这是一个值得关注的领域。

The idea here is for restricted groups of like-minded lawyers with common interests to come together and collaborate online in private social networks; a cross between LinkedIn and Wikipedia, but solely for the use of groups of lawyers, where users can build up bodies of collective knowledge and experience. A similar concept, again in the medical profession, has enjoyed considerable success: Sermo, an online community for doctors (no patients or pharmaceutical companies), has over 1.3 million users (‘verified and credentialized physicians’) from around 150 countries. The best example of this phenomenon in law was the first version of Legal OnRamp, originally described as a collaboration system for in-house counsel. Outside lawyers and third party service providers also participated. Quite quickly after launch, lawyers from over 40 countries were active, both in the general online community and in private sub-communities that could be set up. In its first iteration, it did not fly like Sermo. It came too early, in my view, but this is a space to watch.

为了推行第三章所述的合作策略，公司内部律师对这些封闭社区表现出浓厚的兴趣——这些社区既是他们可以分担某些法律服务成本的平台，也是鼓励和促成其所青睐的律师事务所之间更紧密合作的工具。对于那些执着于各自为政、各自服务客户的律所来说，这构成了相当大的威胁。

In pursuit of the collaboration strategy described in Chapter 3, in-house lawyers are expressing serious interest in these closed communities—as platforms upon which they might share the costs of certain legal services and also as a tool to encourage and enable closer collaboration amongst their preferred law firms. For firms that are wedded to the notion of servicing their clients separately, this poses a considerable threat.

工作流程和项目管理

Workflow and Project Management

对于大量重复的法律工作，工作流系统就像自动化的清单，驱动着从始至终的标准流程。另一方面，项目管理系统更适合那些更复杂、结构化程度更低但仍然更易于处理的法律任务和活动，而不是许多律师事务所和内部部门常见的临时性工作。对于那些按小时收费、历史上一直受益于低效的案件管理和不称职的交易管理的律师事务所来说，工作流项目管理系统代表着新的效率，进而带来降低费用的前景。

For high-volume, repetitive legal work, workflow systems are like automated checklists that drive a standard process from start to finish. Project management systems, on the other hand, are better suited to legal tasks and activities that are more complex, less structured, and yet still amenable to more disciplined handling than the ad hocery that is found in many law firms and in-house departments. For law firms that charge by the hour and so have historically benefited from ineffective case management and inept transaction management, workflow and project management systems represent new efficiencies and, in turn, the prospect of reduced fees.

嵌入式法律知识

Embedded Legal Knowledge

我预测，未来几年，在我们社会和工作生活的诸多领域，法律规则将深深植根于我们的系统和流程之中。有些人将这种说法称之为“规则即代码”。

In years to come, in many dimensions of our social and working lives, I predict that legal rules will be deeply embedded in our systems and processes. Some people talk in this context of ‘rules as code’.

想象一下，一辆汽车会警告驾驶员和乘客，除非使用并通过内置的酒精测试，否则点火装置将无法工作。这不需要汽车用户了解法律的具体细节，然后行使适用法律的选择权。相反，禁止血液中酒精含量过高驾驶的法律将被嵌入汽车本身。另一个例子是“智能”建筑，它根据健康和安全法规规定的水平监测温度和其他环境条件。如果超过某些规定的限值，警报可能会响起，或者在紧急情况下，电脑屏幕甚至可能会被禁用。同样，这不需要人们了解法律并监督遵守情况。相反，法规将嵌入建筑物中。而建筑物可以了解自身的安全水平，并据此做出一些决定。这里的颠覆之处在于，在嵌入规则的地方，律师不再需要提醒客户注意具有法律意义的情况。同样，可能通过区块链技术实现的自动执行合同将能够启动行动并自动执行流程和规定，无需直接涉及律师。

Consider a car that warns its drivers and passengers that the ignition will not work until a built-in breathalysing test is used and passed. This would not require car users to know the precise details of the law and then exercise the option of applying the law. Instead, the law that prohibits driving with excessive alcohol in the bloodstream would be embedded in the car itself. Another example would be an ‘intelligent’ building that monitors the temperature and other environmental conditions by reference to levels established in health and safety regulations. In the event of some stipulated limit being exceeded, alarms might sound or, in emergency situations, computer screens might even be disabled. Again, this would not require people to know the law and monitor compliance. Rather, the regulations would be embedded in the building. And the building would, as it were, know about its own safety levels and make some decisions accordingly. The disruption here is that, where rules are embedded, lawyers are no longer needed to draw clients’ attention to circumstances of legal significance. Likewise, self-executing contracts, possibly enabled through blockchain technology, will be able to initiate actions and automatically execute processes and provisions, without directly involving lawyers.

区块链

Blockchain

区块链技术引发的争议甚至比人工智能还要大。一些人认为它比互联网本身更为根本。另一些人则认为其支持者严重夸大了其潜在影响。虽然常识介于两者之间，但大多数律师在寻求区块链的清晰解释时却感到困惑。没有人能够真正理解区块链是一种“去中心化分布式账本”，或者它包含“一系列以加密方式连接在一起的区块，每个区块都有一个加密的哈希值”。或者，请原谅我的双关语，这些词都带有隐晦的含义。这简直是技术术语的极致体现，而对于律师来说，这种对晦涩定义的狂热追求掩盖了一个重要的现实——广义上讲，区块链技术首先能够使数据和文档以一种几乎不可能更改或伪造的方式存储；其次，能够在用户之间共享，不受任何个人或机构的控制。对于法律工作来说，这具有相当重要的意义，因为这项技术可以使用户高效可靠地存储和共享合同、记录财产和资产所有权、自动结算交易、完成付款、无需人工干预即可执行协议条款和条件（所谓的智能合约）等等。

Even more so than artificial intelligence, blockchain technology gives rise to great contention. Some regard it as more fundamental than the internet itself. Others believe its likely impact is hugely overstated by its proponents. While common sense sits somewhere in the middle, most lawyers are bewildered when they seek clear explanations of what the blockchain is all about. No-one is much the wiser to learn that blockchains are a type of ‘decentralized distributed ledger’ or that they contain ‘a series of blocks, connected together cryptographically, each with a cryptic hash’. Or, if you will forgive the pun, cryptic words to that effect. This is technobabble at its worst and for lawyers this cult-like fondness for obscure definition conceals an important reality—that blockchain technology, in broad terms, enables data and documents, first, to be stored in a way that makes it all but impossible to change or falsify and, second, to be shared amongst users with no single person or authority in control. For legal work, this is of considerable significance because this technology can enable users, efficiently and reliably, to store and share contracts, to record ownership of property and assets, to settle transactions automatically, to complete payments, to execute terms and conditions of agreements without human intervention (so-called smart contracts), and much more.

这里的主要观点是，区块链是一种去中介化技术，这意味着它消除了业务流程和供应链中人为干预的环节。如果这些人是律师（这种情况越来越多），区块链显然是一种颠覆性的法律技术。

The main takeaway here is that blockchain is a disintermediating technology, which means it removes human beings for business processes and supply chains. Where these humans are lawyers, as is increasingly the case, blockchain is clearly a disruptive legal technology.

网上争议解决（ODR）

Online Dispute Resolution (ODR)

当实际解决法律纠纷的过程，尤其是解决方案的制定，完全或大部分通过互联网进行时，我们就有了某种形式的在线争议解决（业内称为ODR——更多详情和示例请参阅第十四章）。对于那些以传统的、基于实体法庭的审判程序为工作的诉讼律师来说，ODR——无论是以在线法庭、电子谈判还是电子调解的形式——都对其业务核心构成了挑战。

When the process of actually resolving a legal dispute, especially the formulation of the solution, is entirely or largely conducted across the Internet, then we have some form of online dispute resolution (known in the trade as ODR—see Chapter 14 for more detail and some examples). For litigators whose work is premised on the conventional, physical court-based trial process, ODR—whether in the form, for example, of online courts, e-negotiation, or e-mediation—is a challenge to the heart of their business.

文档分析

Document Analysis

律师们花费大量时间仔细审阅文件，尤其是在准备诉讼时。多年来，在准确率和召回率方面，经过适当调优的系统在审查大量文件并提取相关内容时，表现已经超越了律师助理和初级律师。

Lawyers spend much of their time ploughing through documents, not least in preparation for litigation. For some years now, in terms of precision and recall, properly primed systems have been able to outperform paralegals and junior lawyers when reviewing large bodies of documents and isolating those of relevance.

最近，法律领域采用了一系列新技术，这些技术借鉴了机器学习、大数据和预测分析等学科。尽管机器学习的一些最具影响力的方面很少在法律实践中得到部署（例如可以编写程序的计算机、深度神经网络和强化学习算法），但很明显，这些新兴系统正在证明其越来越令人印象深刻，无论是分析文档集还是总结或提取合同中的关键条款。

More recently, a new set of techniques have been adopted within law, drawing from disciplines known variously as machine learning, Big Data, and predictive analytics. Although some of the most impactful dimensions of machine learning have scarcely been deployed in legal practice (such as computers that can write programs, deep neural networks, and reinforcement learning algorithms), it is clear that these emerging systems are proving increasingly impressive, whether analysing documents sets or summarizing or extracting key provisions from contracts.

这些搜索和机器学习功能具有颠覆性的意义，不仅对那些依靠人工处理大量文书工作（无论是交易、争议相关项目还是合同审查）而获利的律师事务所，而且对目前提供类似服务的法律流程外包商也同样如此。无论人力成本多么低，这种系统一旦建立，成本必然会更低。这无疑解释了为什么在该领域开拓创新的年轻律师事务所会在整个法律界引起巨大兴趣。

These search and machine learning capabilities are disruptive, not simply for law firms that have profited from employing human beings to wade through roomfuls of paperwork (whether on transactions, dispute-related projects, or contract reviews) but also for legal process outsourcers who currently offer similar services. No matter how low human labour costs might be, a system of this kind, once set up, will invariably be less costly. That is no doubt why young law companies that are pioneering in the field are generating great interest across the legal profession.

机器预测

Machine Prediction

机器学习技术的另一个重要用途是进行预测。越来越复杂的方法正在发展，用于检测大量数据中的模式和相关性。在法律领域，正如丹尼尔·卡茨（Daniel Katz）在美国最高法院的开创性工作所表明的那样，计算统计学（粗略地说，就是处理大量数据的算法）通常能够比从事传统法律研究和推理的律师更准确地预测法院可能采取的行为。请记住独一无二的奥利弗·温德尔·霍姆斯 (Oliver Wendell Holmes) 说过：“我所说的法律就是对法院实际上将做什么的预言，而不是更自命不凡的东西。”

Another vital use of machine learning techniques is in making predictions. Increasingly sophisticated methods are being evolved to detect patterns and correlations in large quantities of data. In law, as the pioneering work of Daniel Katz showed in relation to the US Supreme Court, computational statistics (crudely, algorithms working on large bodies of data) can often yield more accurate predictions of the likely behaviour of courts than the predictions of lawyers engaged in traditional legal research and reasoning. Bear in mind the words of the inimitable Oliver Wendell Holmes: ‘prophecies of what the courts will do in fact, and nothing more pretentious, are what I mean by the law’.

许多法律工作都涉及预测，无论是预测胜诉或达成和解的可能性，还是预测交易被放弃或完成的可能性。律师事务所系统中保存的数据以及可公开访问的数据无疑将成为未来预测此类问题的基础。此外，通过汇总数据集，我们很快就能发现哪些法律问题和担忧正在困扰特定群体；通过分析监管机构的工作，我们或许能够以全新的方式预测合规结果；通过收集大量商业合同和电子邮件往来，我们或许能够洞察特定行业面临的最大法律风险。这里的颠覆性之处在于，法律实践和法律风险管理中的关键洞察可能主要由基于海量数据的算法生成，而无需主流律师的参与（除非他们选择与数据科学家合作）。

Much legal work involves prediction, whether of the likelihood of winning a case or negotiating a settlement, or of a deal being abandoned or completed. The data held within law firms’ systems, along with publicly accessible data, will no doubt form the basis of future predictions in relation to such issues. More than this, by aggregating data sets, we will soon be able to find out what legal issues and concerns are troubling particular communities; by analysing the work of regulators, we may be able to predict compliance outcomes in entirely novel ways; and by collecting huge bodies of commercial contracts and exchanges of emails, we might gain insight into the greatest legal risks that specific sectors face. The disruption here is that crucial insights in legal practice and in legal risk management might be generated largely by algorithms operating on large bodies of data without needing to involve mainstream lawyers (unless they choose to collaborate with data scientists).

自然语言处理

Natural Language Processing

粗略地说，人类和机器讲着不同的语言——分别是人类语言和代码。直到最近，机器还无法“理解”人类语言，因为（除其他原因外）人类语言结构不够清晰，也缺乏歧义。从事自然语言处理 (NLP) 的科学家试图开发能够处理人类语言及其所有特质的系统，并不合逻辑。对于律师来说，这里有两个重要的项目。第一是使人类能够通过人类语言而非代码直接与系统沟通（指导和交互）；第二是设计能够处理（总结、解释、分析）以自然人类语言编写的文档的系统。在本章前面，我给出了后者的例子，例如法律文件的分析。

Humans and machines, in crude terms, speak different languages—human language and code respectively. Until recently, machines have not been able to ‘understand’ human language, because (amongst many other reasons) it is not sufficiently structured or free of ambiguity. Scientists who work on natural language processing (NLP) try to develop systems that can handle human language with all its idiosyncrasies and illogicalities. For lawyers, there are two important projects here. The first is to enable humans to communicate (instruct and interact) directly with systems through human language and not code, while the second is to design the systems that can handle (summarize, interpret, analyse) documents written in natural human language. Earlier in this chapter, I give examples of the latter, such as the analysis of legal documents.

前者的一个重要例证是“问答”（QA），它是计算机科学的一个分支，致力于开发能够自动回答人类用户用日常（自然）语言提出的问题的系统。我最喜欢的问答示例仍然是IBM的沃森（Watson），该系统是为了参加美国电视智力竞赛节目《危险边缘》（Jeopardy!）而开发的。2011年，在该节目的直播中，沃森公开击败了两位有史以来最优秀的人类选手（参见第一章）。在法律领域，法律问答——一种自然语言处理的形式——将极大地提升公民获取日常法律信息的渠道。秉承沃森的精神，这可以采取一种在线服务的形式，其中包含大量结构化和非结构化法律资料（一手资料、二手资料以及法律分析），这些资料可以理解用自然语言提出的法律问题，分析和分类这些问题中固有的事实模式，得出结论并提供法律建议，甚至可以用计算机模拟的声音（也许是用户选择的口音）表达这些指导。这种系统不仅会颠覆执业律师的世界，还会颠覆我们对法律程序的普遍认知。这还需要几年时间才能实现，但蓬勃发展的新兴技术可能会比怀疑论者预想的更快地将这种自然语言处理技术引入日常法律领域。

An important illustration of the former is known as ‘question answering’ (QA), which is a branch of computer science devoted to the development of systems that automatically respond to questions put by human users in everyday (natural) language. My favourite example of QA is still IBM’s Watson, a system built to compete on the US TV quiz show Jeopardy! In 2011, on a live episode of that show, Watson very publicly beat the two best ever human competitors (see Chapter 1). In law, legal QA—a form of natural language processing—will greatly increase citizens’ access to everyday law.
