In the spirit of Watson, this could take the form of an online service that contains vast stores of structured and unstructured legal materials (primary and secondary sources, and legal analysis) that can understand legal problems spoken to it in natural language, that can analyse and classify the fact pattern inherent in these problems, that can draw conclusions and offer legal advice, and that can even express this guidance in some computer-simulated voice (in an accent of the user’s choosing, perhaps). This kind of system will disrupt not just the world of practising lawyers but also our common perception of the legal process. This is some years away yet but emerging technologies, developing exponentially, may bring this form of natural language processing to everyday law sooner than sceptics believe.

自然语言处理和机器预测是人工智能在法律领域应用的常见例子。我将在第22章继续讨论这个主题。

Natural language processing and machine prediction are common examples of the use of artificial intelligence in law. I return to this subject in Chapter 22.

法律平台

Legal Platforms

“法律平台”的概念在法律科技领域相对较新。直到几年前，大多数法律技术专家还认为，在市场上脱颖而出的方法是开发领先于市场的系统或解决方案。然而，大多数系统和解决方案都很容易被复制，在法律科技领域，真正的先发优势相对罕见。相比之下，法律平台的提供商有可能成为某些法律服务、产品或解决方案的主导提供商，从而颠覆性地排挤竞争对手。我们在社交媒体上见证了这种主导地位——比如Facebook、LinkedIn和Twitter。我们也在在线交易和零售领域见证了这种主导地位——比如亚马逊和eBay。这些企业并非各自市场中唯一的参与者。但它们都建立了庞大的互联用户社区，这些用户几乎没有理由转向其他平台。在法律领域也是如此。我们可以很容易地想象出类似的主导平台：也许是内部法律顾问的在线社区，或者是行业标准文档自动化的提供商，又或者是私营部门的在线争议解决服务。如果此类法律平台占据主导地位，成为默认资源，那么其他法律服务提供商可能会陷入困境。

The concept of ‘legal platforms’ is a relative newcomer to the world of lawtech. Until a few years ago, most legal technologists felt that the way to differentiate in the market was to develop a system or solution ahead of the market. However, most systems and solutions can be easily replicated and genuine first-mover advantage in lawtech was relatively rare. In contrast, the provider of a legal platform could potentially become the dominant provider of certain legal services, products, or solutions and in so doing disruptively exclude competing providers. We have seen this dominance in social media—think of Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter. We have also seen this in online trading and retail—think of Amazon and eBay. None of these businesses is the only player in their markets. But each has built huge communities of connected users, for whom there is little reason to switch to alternatives. So too in law. We can easily envisage similarly dominant platforms: perhaps an online community for in-house counsel, or a provider of industry-standard document automation, or a private-sector online dispute resolution service. If such legal platforms came to dominate, if they became the default resources, they could leave other legal providers high and dry.

7网格

7 The Grid

20世纪90年代末，正值互联网时代的巅峰时期，执业律师开始对会计系统、文字处理和内部电子邮件以外的技术产生兴趣。律所领导层意识到“互联网”甚至可能在法律界流行起来，他们突然对法律科技的潜力产生了好奇，并渴望了解这一切意味着什么。为了激发资深律师的兴趣，帮助他们理解这个领域，我当时给自己设定了一个任务，即创建某种框架，以便我能够快速、通俗易懂地概述IT（我们当时的称呼）对律师事务所产生影响的基本方式。

In the late 1990s, at the peak of the dotcom era, practising lawyers began to take an interest in technologies other than their accounting systems, word processing, and internal email. Sensing that ‘this Internet thing’ might even catch on in the world of law, leaders in firms suddenly became curious about the potential of legal technology and were keen to understand what it all meant. To whet the appetite of senior lawyers and help them make sense of the field, I set myself the task at that time of creating some kind of framework that would allow me—rapidly and in plain terms—to provide a simple snapshot of the fundamental ways in which IT (as we then called it) would have impact on law firms.

我提出的框架如今已在世界各地使用了20多年。它最初出现在我2000年出版的《法律变革》一书的开篇。该框架本质上是一个网格，提供了一种粗略的理解和谈论律师事务所技术的方式。过去几年，为了考虑到新技术和新工艺，我对这个网格进行了改进和完善，本章旨在以概要的形式介绍它。

The framework I came up with has now been used for more than 20 years around the world. It first appeared in the opening chapter of my book, Transforming the Law, published in 2000. The framework is basically a grid. It offers a rough and ready way of understanding and speaking about technology in law firms. Over the last few years, to take account of new techniques and technologies, I have refined and improved the grid and my purpose in this chapter is to introduce it in outline form.

基本网格

Basic Grids

我的出发点是一个通用的网格版本。暂且不论律师和律师事务所，在任何组织的基本网格上，如图7.1所示，横轴代表了“数字化”范畴下提供的广泛设施——从一端的基础技术（管道）到另一端的知识系统。纵轴区分了数字设施的内部使用（线下）和外部使用（线上）。如图所示，这在任何组织中形成了技术的四种基本用途：技术的内部使用、知识的内部管理、外部技术链接以及访问权限的提供。知识。随着故事的展开，每个概念的范围将变得更加清晰。

My starting point is a generic version of the grid. Forgetting lawyers and law firms for a moment, on the basic grid for any organization, as depicted in Figure 7.1, the horizontal axis represents the broad range of facilities provided under the heading of ‘digital’—from basic technology (the plumbing) at one end of the spectrum to knowledge systems at the other. The vertical axis distinguishes internal use of digital facilities (below the line) from external use (above the line). As shown, this creates four fundamental uses of technology in any organization: internal use of technology, internal management of knowledge, external technology links, and provision of access to knowledge. The scope of each will become clearer as this story unfolds.

图 7.1 通用网格。

FIGURE 7.1 Generic grid.

如果我们将顶部的标签从“外部”更改为“客户”，就会得到“律师事务所网格”，如图7.2所示。这是一个可以用来分析任何律师事务所或法律服务提供商的工具。至关重要的是，它表明法律科技实际上有四个基本类别。首先，在左下象限（内部，专注于技术），我们有支持日常运营的基本后台系统。其次，在右下象限（内部，专注于知识），我们有用于在公司内部共享知识的系统。第三，在左上象限（外部，专注于技术），我们有能够与客户沟通和协作的系统。最后，在右上象限（外部，专注于知识），我们拥有可以在线向客户提供知识、经验和专业知识或嵌入到客户的系统和流程中（关于嵌入式系统，请参阅第 6 章）的系统。

If we change the label at the top from ‘external’ to ‘client’, this gives us the ‘law firm grid,’ as laid out in Figure 7.2. This is a tool that can be used in analysing any law firm or legal provider. It shows, vitally, that there are really four basic categories of lawtech. First of all, in the bottom-left quadrant (internal and focused on technology), we have basic back-office systems that support everyday operations. Second, in the bottom-right quadrant (internal and focused on knowledge), we have systems for sharing knowledge within a firm. Third, in the top-left quadrant (external and focused on technology), we have systems that enable communication and collaboration with clients. Finally, in the top-right quadrant (external, and focused on knowledge), we have systems that make knowledge, experience, and expertise available to clients on an online basis or embedded in clients’ systems and processes (on embedded systems, see Chapter 6).

图 7.2 律师事务所网格。

FIGURE 7.2 Law firm grid.

当资深律师接触到这个网格时，我有时会恍然大悟。法律科技不再是一些无定形、模糊、通用、难以理解且价格昂贵的工具。它也不再是琳琅满目的系统和应用程序。相反，我们只有四个基本类别。这个简单的模型可以帮助管理人员制定战略、确定优先级、规划和预算。更重要的是，它提供了一个通用的词汇表，所以我很快就能听到律师们说：“我们需要在右上角做更多工作”或“我们的大部分支出都在左下角”。

When senior lawyers are introduced to this grid, I sometimes detect an ‘aha’ moment. No longer is lawtech some amorphous, vague, general purpose bucket of unintelligible and costly bits of kit. Nor is it a bewildering range of systems and applications. Instead, we have but four basic categories. This simple model helps managers when strategizing, prioritizing, planning, and budgeting. More, it provides a common vocabulary so that, quite quickly, I hear lawyers say things like, ‘we need to do more in the top right’ or ‘most of our spend is in the bottom left’.

示例

Examples

一些示例让律师事务所网格栩栩如生。如图 7.3所示，左下角是多年来律师事务所运营的基本系统。我们过去称之为“办公自动化”。右下角是使事务所能够捕获、整理和重复使用其集体知识的系统。左上角是通过使用各种形式的通信技术和共享数据来支持传统法律服务交付的系统。右上角是各种系统，使事务所能够以……的形式提供内容、材料、文档、指南、诊断和建议。数字服务。据我估计，令人惊讶的是，大多数律师事务所在技术方面的支出仍有90%以上处于左下角。

Some examples bring the law firm grid to life. In the bottom-left, as can be seen in Figure 7.3, there are the basic systems that have been used to run law firms for many years. We used to call this ‘office automation’. In the bottom right are systems that enable firms to capture, codify, and reuse their collective knowledge. In the top left are systems that support the delivery of conventional legal service by using various forms of communication technologies and by sharing data. And, in the top right are various systems that enable firms to make content, materials, documents, guidance, diagnostics, and advice available as a digital service. In my estimation and strikingly, more than 90 per cent of most law firms’ spend on technology still belongs in the bottom left.

图 7.3 示例。

FIGURE 7.3 Examples.

以上所述，使我们能够对法律科技的网格结构以及法律科技进行更简单的概括——见图7.4。法律科技提供了驱动业务发展的引擎（左下角）、帮助律所分享知识的工具集（右下角）、律所提供数字化客户体验的渠道（左上角），以及通过在线服务或嵌入内容（右上角）提供产品和解决方案的能力。

What I have said so far allows us to a create an even simpler summary of the grid and, in turn, of legal technology—see Figure 7.4. Legal technology provides as with an engine room that drives the business (bottom left), a set of tools to help firms share their knowledge (bottom right), channels through which law firms provide a digital client experience (top left), and the ability to deliver products and solutions, either through online service or by embedding content (top right).

图 7.4 总结。

FIGURE 7.4 Summary.

影响

Impact

图7.5显示，四类法律科技为律师事务所和法律服务提供商带来了截然不同的商业效益。左下角关注的是维持业务运转、规避系统故障风险以及维护稳健的基础设施。右下角则侧重于充分利用律所律师的综合知识——避免重复劳动并重复利用最佳经验。左上角则增强了传统的法律服务，确保在工作期间和工作间隙保持密切联系。右上角则代表了法律服务的转型，即从收取律师时间费用转向授权律所知识：即使你睡觉也能赚钱。

Figure 7.5 shows that the four categories of lawtech bring quite different business benefits for law firms and legal providers. The bottom left is about keeping the business running, avoiding the risks of systems failure, and maintaining robust infrastructure. The bottom right focuses on making the most of the combined knowledge of the firm’s lawyers—avoiding duplication of effort and reusing the best experience. The top left enhances traditional legal service, ensuring close relationships while working on jobs and between jobs. The top right represents a transformation in legal service, a move away from charging for lawyers’ time to licensing a firm’s knowledge: making money while you sleep.

图 7.5 商业利益。

FIGURE 7.5 Business benefits.

客户自身对客户网格应该抱有怎样的期望？如图7.6所示，他们可以合理地要求左下角有坚实的基础设施（系统和数据的可靠性和安全性）；右下角有竞争力的专业知识（通过知识管理或托管服务，以合理的成本获得深度知识）；透明度和便利性（在线跟踪和协同工作工具）；以及创新（商品化法律）。

What should clients themselves expect across the client grid? As Figure 7.6 suggests, they can reasonably ask for solid infrastructure in the bottom left (reliability and security of systems and data); competitive expertise in the bottom right (deep knowledge at sensible cost, via knowledge management or managed services); transparency and convenience (online tracking and collaborative working tools); and innovation (commoditized law).

图 7.6 客户期望。

FIGURE 7.6 Client expectations.

在社交媒体、会议和法律媒体上，一些技术（如图 7.7粗略绘制）经常被誉为当前最激动人心的发展。值得注意的是，这些“热门技术”中的大多数都位于横轴或横轴上方。这意味着它们是具有以下特征的系统：对客户产生直接影响。这代表着法律科技领域的重大转变——在该领域的前五十年，直到大约五到十年前，人们谈论的大部分技术都是在律师事务所内部使用，而不是在客户身上。尽管如上所述，全球法律科技支出的大部分仍然集中在左下角，但现在人们普遍认识到，差异化将由线下服务提供商实现。

On social media, at conferences, and in the legal press, a few technologies, plotted in rough terms in Figure 7.7, are often hailed as the most exciting current developments. It is significant that the majority of these ‘hot technologies’ are on or above the horizontal axis. Which means that they are systems that have direct impact on clients. This represents a major shift in the world of lawtech—in the first five decades of the field, until about 5 to 10 years ago, the bulk of the talked-about technologies were for use within law firms and not with clients. Although most of the overall global spend on legal technology is still, as noted, in the bottom left, there is now broad recognition that differentiation will be achieved by providers above the line.

图 7.7“热门技术”。

FIGURE 7.7 ‘Hot technologies’.

另一个影响可以在网格上绘制出来——新冠疫情的影响。人们普遍认为，这场疫情加速了律师事务所对技术的采用。正如我在第二章中所解释的，这种说法过于简单。从网格的角度来看，新冠疫情实际上要求律师事务所投资并部署系统，而这些系统主要集中在左上角。但这场危机对右上角的影响却微乎其微。远程办公和居家办公（视频会议、电子邮件、协作系统）都位于左上角，并由左下角支撑。这些并非新技术，但它们确实证明了它们对于律师事务所和法律业务在2020年至2022年期间的生存至关重要。然而，值得注意的是，这些新冠疫情应对系统并没有改变律师事务所的商业模式——它们在疫情期间继续提供历史悠久的咨询服务。这与我在第二章中所说的内容相关：在法律界疫情期间，我们看到了自动化的加速发展，但创新却在减速（这在我们预期中大致体现在右上角）。

Another impact can be plotted on the grid—that of COVID-19. It is commonly claimed that the pandemic has accelerated the uptake of technology by law firms. As I explain in Chapter 2, this is an over-simplification. In grid terms, COVID-19 in fact required law firms to invest in, and roll out, systems very largely in the top left. But the crisis has had little impact in the top right. Remote-working and home-working (video meetings, email, collaboration systems) all belong in the top left, supported by the bottom left. These are not new technologies but they did prove necessary for the survival of law firms and legal businesses from 2020 to 2022. Significantly, though, these COVID response systems have not changed the business model of law firms—they continued during the pandemic to deliver the age-old advisory service. This relates to what I say in Chapter 2: during the pandemic in the legal world, we saw an acceleration of automation but a deceleration in innovation (which we would expect largely in the top right).

客户端网格

Client Grid

像图 7.8中那样更改南北标签，我们可以使用类似的客户网格来解释内部法务部门对技术的使用。在这里，法务部门成为服务提供者，而企业本身成为服务的接受者。左下象限和右下象限的系统类型与律师事务所相同，但内部律师通常必须接受后台使用的任何业务范围的系统，而且他们在知识系统上的投资往往远低于律师事务所。左上象限是内部律师用来与自己的客户沟通并提供建议的公司关系系统。企业。右上象限是在线法律支持服务，主要是法律自助工具，由公司内部律师直接向其企业提供。客户网格是一个帮助公司内部律师思考如何使用技术并规划未来的工具。

Changing the north and south labels as in Figure 7.8, an analogous client grid can be used to explain the use of technology by in-house legal departments. Here, the legal department becomes the provider and the business itself becomes the recipient of services. The bottom-left and bottom-right quadrants play host to the same types of systems as in law firms, except that in-house lawyers generally have to accept whatever business-wide systems are used in the back-office, and they tend to invest far less than law firms in their knowledge systems. In the top-left quadrant, these are the corporate relationship systems that in-house lawyers use to communicate with and advise their own businesses. In the top-right quadrant are online legal support services, largely legal self-help tools, that in-house lawyers make available directly to their businesses. The client grid is a tool to help in-house lawyers to think about the way they use technology and plan for the future.

图 7.8 客户端网格。

FIGURE 7.8 Client grid.

更广泛地说，法律科技的新兴故事是两个网格的故事。律师事务所及其客户并非孤立地工作——他们通过技术连接在一起。当律师事务所在其左上象限提供信息（例如，在交易室或在线报告中）时，客户越来越有兴趣将这些数据拉入他们自己的系统，即他们的左下象限。同样，当律师事务所提供知识服务和在线法律服务（其右上象限）时，高级客户希望能够在一个地方（在其右下象限）集中访问这些服务。通过这种方式，律师事务所和客户网格正在融合在一起，如图7.9所示。

More generally, the emerging story of lawtech is a tale of two grids. Law firms and their clients do not work in isolation—they are connected by technology. Increasingly, when law firms make information available in their top-left quadrant—for example, in deal rooms or as online reports—there is interest amongst clients in pulling this data into their own systems, that is, into their bottom-left quadrant. Likewise, when knowledge services and online legal services are provided by law firms (their top-right quadrant), advanced clients want to have access to these collectively in one place (in their bottom-right quadrant). In this way, the law firm and client grids are coming together, as shown in Figure 7.9.

图 7.9 网格的收敛。

FIGURE 7.9 Convergence of grids.

律师事务所由此得到的教训是，大多数客户很快就会希望获得其数据和知识资源，而这些客户也希望获得其竞争对手的类似资源。通过拥有优于竞争对手的数据和知识资源，或者利用使特定律所的数据和知识更易于访问的技术，可以确保竞争优势。这里也可能存在一个平台机会（参见第六章）。特定领域或更广泛的律所可以提供（并主导）行业标准的数据和知识共享平台。

The lesson here for law firms is that most clients will soon want to gain access to their data and knowledge resources, and these clients will also want to do similarly with the firms’ competitors. Competitive advantage can be secured here either by having data and knowledge resources that are superior to the competition, or by using technologies that make a given firm’s data and knowledge more easily accessible. There may also be a platform opportunity here (see Chapter 6). Law firms in given fields or more generally could make available (and then dominate) industry-standard platforms for the sharing of data and knowledge.

然而，最终结果可能不是律师事务所或法律服务提供商更有效地共享数据和知识与竞争对手相比，一些公司更倾向于聘请内部法律顾问。相反，一些公司可能会寻求将部分法律知识资源（法律指导和解决方案、文档自动化、产品等）直接提供给企业的最终用户（见图7.10）。这通常涉及将日常法律工作商品化，从而释放内部律师的资源，使其专注于自己的专业领域。从表面上看，这似乎意味着外部法律服务提供商正在绕过内部法律职能。然而，还有一种更具吸引力和更圆滑的可能性——领先的外部法律业务可以与内部律师合作，提供这些直接访问的工具。

The end game here, however, may not be with law firms or legal providers sharing data and knowledge more impressively with in-house counsel than their competitors. Instead, some might seek to provide some of their legal knowledge resources (legal guidance and solutions, document automation, products, and so on) directly to end-users in businesses (see Figure 7.10). Often this will involve commoditizing everyday legal work, and so releasing in-house lawyers to focus on their specialties. Superficially, this might look as though the in-house legal function is being bypassed by external providers. However, there is a more attractive and diplomatic possibility—that leading external legal businesses work in collaboration with in-house lawyers to provide these direct-access tools.

图 7.10 一局终局。

FIGURE 7.10 One end-game.

第二部分

PART TWO

新景观

The New Landscape

8律师事务所的未来

8 The Future for Law Firms

本书第一部分提出了一个核心问题：使用其他工作方法，律师的工作能在多大程度上以不同的方式开展——更快速、更廉价、更高效，但质量更高？这是当今的一个关键问题。如第三章所述，多年来，律师一直在从事例行工作，他们的资历过高，因此收费过高。在经济繁荣时期，在卖方市场，成功的律师事务所几乎不需要受到以新的、更高效的方式提供服务的挑战的阻碍。然而，今天，随着来自客户的成本压力不断加大，随着新的服务提供商出现，随着新技术的部署，任何律师事务所如果不思考如何以不同的方式开展工作都是不明智的。

One central question emerges from the first part of this book: to what extent can lawyers’ work be undertaken differently—more quickly, cheaply, and efficiently, but to a higher quality—using alternative methods of working? This is a key question of the day. As noted in Chapter 3, lawyers have for many years performed routine work for which they have been over-qualified and for which, in turn, they have been over-charging. In boom times, in what has been a sellers’ market, there has been little need for successful law firms to be detained by the challenge of delivering services in new and more efficient ways. Today, however, as cost pressures from clients continue to intensify, as new service providers emerge, and as new technologies are deployed, it is unwise for any firm to avoid thinking about how it should work differently.

尽管如此，我发现许多传统律师事务所并没有做出太大的改变，尽管有人声称并评论创新（参见第21章）。大多数律师事务所尚未采用替代的工作方式。这在一定程度上是变革管理的问题，因为律师事务所往往忙于服务客户并实现自身的财务目标，以至于几乎没有时间进行变革。是时候进行内部改革了——在行驶的汽车上换个轮子可不是件容易的事。从某种程度上来说，这也是一个结构性问题，因为大多数实践仍然追求第三章提到的老式教科书式的、基础广泛的金字塔结构，而其他采购方法则要求修改（甚至拒绝）该模型。而且，坦率地说，许多公司的主流合伙人仍然不愿意相信他们真的需要改变。换句话说，人们倾向于坚持旧的工作方式，希望很快出现稳健的经济复苏（从衰退、英国脱欧或其他原因中复苏），并恢复正常业务。

Nonetheless, I find that many traditional law firms are not changing much, despite claims and commentary about innovation (see Chapter 21). Most are not yet adopting alternative methods of working. This is partly an issue of change management in that law firms tend to be so busy serving clients and meeting their own financial targets that they allow little time for internal reform—it is not easy to change a wheel on a moving car. It is also, in part, a structural matter, because most practices still aspire to the old textbook, broad-based pyramidic structure mentioned in Chapter 3, whereas alternative methods of sourcing call for a revision, if not rejection, of that model. And, if we are honest, there is also still reluctance amongst mainstream partners in many firms to believe that they really need to change. There is an inclination, in other words, to cling on to the old ways of working in the hope that there will soon be a solid economic recovery (from recession, Brexit, or whatever) and normal business can be resumed.

律师事务所的前景

Prospects for Law Firms

然而，如果本书第一部分的分析和预测属实，那么未来十年及以后，律师事务所将在客户的不懈推动下降低成本。这正是“少花钱多办事”挑战的核心（参见第一章）。尽管大多数律所目前仍犹豫不决，但我预测，这最终将促使它们部署和执行替代性资源战略（第五章）。反过来，我们将见证杠杆的终结——在最好的情况下，金字塔（合伙人位于顶端，经验不足的律师位于底部）将从宽基变为窄基。律所将不再渴望组建庞大的初级律师团队作为盈利基础。用西奥多·莱维特（在其开创性文章《营销短视》中）那句令人难忘的话来说，“为了生存”，律师“将不得不策划淘汰目前赖以生存的资源”。

However, if the analysis and predictions of Part One of this book are sound, then law firms in the coming decade and beyond will be driven relentlessly by their clients to reduce their costs. This is the heart of the more-for-less challenge (see Chapter 1). For most firms, despite their current hesitancy, I predict that this will lead eventually to the deployment and execution of alternative sourcing strategies (Chapter 5). And, in turn, we will witness the end of leverage—at best the pyramid (with partners at the top and less experienced lawyers at the base) will move from being broad based to narrow based. No longer will firms aspire to building large teams of junior lawyers as the basis of their profitability. ‘To survive’, in the memorable words of Theodore Levitt (in his seminal article, ‘Marketing Myopia’), lawyers ‘will have to plot the obsolescence of what now produces their livelihood’.

例如，一些律所可能会适时裁掉初级律师和实习律师，或停止招聘他们。届时，他们可能会组建一支由高素质合伙人组成的团队，每个合伙人配备一名律师和一套强大的系统；日常工作将由律所以外的机构提供资源。其他律所可能会选择建立自己的替代资源能力，例如内部组建律师助理团队，或者建立自己的离岸法律服务机构。还有一些律所将通过开辟此前不存在的市场或介入法律供应链的不同环节（例如，更早地介入客户业务的生命周期），寻找新的法律服务机会（参见第十六章）。

In due course, some firms may, for example, choose to strip away their junior and trainee lawyers, or stop recruiting them. They might then operate with a team of high-powered partners, each supported by, say, one associate and capable systems; and the routine work will be resourced beyond the firm. Others may elect to build their own alternative sourcing capacities, such as internal teams of paralegals, or maybe through the establishment of their own off-shored legal facilities. Still others will find opportunities for novel legal services (see Chapter 16), by creating markets that formerly did not exist or by inserting themselves in different places in legal supply chains (e.g., by becoming involved far earlier in the lifecycles of their clients’ business dealings).

尽管这些变化将影响所有律所（无论大小），但一些大型律所可能会辩称，对于“高端工作”，诸如商品化、分解和多方外包等概念并不适用。然而，仔细研究就会发现，“高端工作”这一概念本身就是一种迷思——即使在全球规模最大的交易和纠纷中，也有大量工作可以常规化并采用不同的外包方式。那些坚持只承接定制化工作的大型律所，这与声称只承接高端工作（定制化是高端工作的一个子集，通常规模较小）截然不同，可能会面临风险。例如，它们可能会被降级为其他机构的分包商，由这些机构承担大型交易和纠纷的项目管理。与此同时，其他供应商可能会接手这些律所之前分配给初级律师的工作。

Although these changes will impact on all firms (large and small), some larger firms will want to argue that, for ‘high-end work’, notions such as commoditization, decomposing, and multi-sourcing are of little relevance. On examination, however, it transpires that this concept of ‘high-end work’ is something of a myth—even in the world’s largest deals and disputes there are substantial components of work that can be routinized and sourced differently. And large firms that insist they only undertake bespoke work, which is a very different claim from asserting that they only do high-end work (bespoke being a subset, often small, of high-end), may find themselves at risk. They may be relegated, for instance, to the role of subcontractor to other organizations that step forward to undertake the project management of sizeable deals and disputes. At the same time, alternative providers may take up the work that these firms previously assigned to their junior lawyers.

全球精英？

A Global Elite?

话虽如此，全球范围内或许确实存在一批精英律所，目前大约有20家，他们坚持认为自身无需做出太大改变。这些律所将继续享有巨大的商业成功。他们会强硬地辩称，对于孤注一掷的交易和纠纷，客户仍然希望获得与过去大致相同的服务。这些律所会表示，对于真正高额的项目，董事会层面能够容忍的品牌屈指可数（遵循“没有人会因为收购IBM而被解雇”的原则），而且，无论如何，当一家公司的未来岌岌可危时（无论是面临威胁还是期待着一项伟大的新事业），法律工作对价格并不敏感（遵循“百万美元多少，从宏观角度看无关紧要”的原则）。如果所有这些精英律所都相信这一点，并继续像过去一样运作，那么他们很可能是对的。而且，要让一群百万富翁相信他们的商业模式已经崩溃，将非常困难。

That said, there may well be a global elite of law firms, around 20 in number today, which insist that they do not need to change much. These will be firms that continue to enjoy great commercial success. With some force, they will argue that for bet-the-ranch deals and disputes, clients will still want the services delivered, more or less, as in the past. These firms will say that for really big ticket assignments, there is only a handful of brands that will be tolerated at board level (the ‘no-one ever got fired for buying IBM’ principle) and that, in any event, when the future of an organization is in the balance (whether under threat or in anticipation of a great new venture) legal work is not price sensitive (the ‘1 million dollars here or there makes no difference in the broader scheme of things’ principle). If all of these elite law firms believe this and continue to work as they have in the past, then they may well be right. And it will be hard to convince a group of millionaires that their business model is broken.

然而，他们不应过于自信，用莱维特的话来说，“行业主流产品无可替代”。因此，如果出现一股新兴力量（例如“四大”会计师事务所），并向市场带来新的主张——例如，一个价格仅为竞争对手一半的可靠品牌——那么这可能会从根本上不可逆转地改变市场，不仅对精英事务所，而且对整个行业都产生影响。精英事务所的领导者应该暂时放下对这种情况的疑虑，因为主要客户前所未有地普遍表示，他们正在寻找一些伟大事务所传统模式的替代方案。许多人认为这些律所的成本过高，有时甚至过于傲慢。例如，一些客户正在分解公司业务，将常规环节（例如尽职调​​查）交给成本较低的区域律所、法律流程外包或托管服务提供商，并邀请精英律所只专注于工作中最具挑战性的部分。这可能会打击大型律所的核心盈利模式，因为它们依赖于初级律师来完成这些常规工作。

However, they should not be over-confident in their belief that, in Levitt’s words, ‘there is no competitive substitute for the industry’s major product’. So, if a major new force (such as a ‘Big 4’ accounting firm) emerges, and brings a new proposition to the market—a credible brand at half the price of its competitors, for example—then this could fundamentally and irreversibly change the market, and not just for the elite firms but across the entire profession. Leaders of the elite firms should suspend their likely incredulity at this scenario, if only because major clients, as never before, are commonly saying that they are looking for alternatives to the traditional ways of some of the great firms whom many regard as too costly and sometimes too arrogant. Some clients, for example, are decomposing corporate work and passing the routine elements (such as due diligence) to lower cost, regional firms or to legal process outsourcing or managed service providers, and inviting the elite firms only to focus on the most challenging elements of the work. This can strike at the heart of the profit model of large firms, who rely on their junior lawyers doing these routine tasks.

精英律所也应警惕其中一家公司打破常规——2016年我们就见证了这一点。当时，安理国际律师事务所（Allen & Overy）与德勤（Deloitte）合作推出了一个名为MarginMatrix的在线系统，帮助银行应对全球衍生品市场新规带来的文件编制挑战。该系统彻底打乱了许多精英律所的计划，他们原本希望以定制化的方式为客户解决这一监管负担。

Elite firms should also beware of one of their number breaking rank—we saw an example of this in 2016, when Allen & Overy, in collaboration with Deloitte, launched an online system, MarginMatrix, to help banks cope with the documentation challenges arising from the new rules governing the global derivatives markets. This system pulled the rug from under the feet of many elite firms who had expected to tackle this regulatory burden for their clients in a bespoke manner.

与此同时，其他总部位于伦敦的“魔力圈”律所（高伟绅律师事务所、年利达律师事务所、富而德律师事务所和司力达律师事务所）也在投资新的劳动模式和面向客户的技术。在美国，佳利律师事务所和威尔逊·桑西尼律师事务所等领先律所也在不断突破传统界限。这些律所或其他大型律所是否会做出更彻底的变革，仍有待观察。

Meanwhile, the other ‘magic circle’ law firms based in London (Clifford Chance, Linklaters, Freshfields, and Slaughter and May) have also been investing in new labour models and client-facing technology. In the US too, leading firms like Cleary Gottlieb and Wilson Sonsini have been stretching the conventional boundaries. Whether these or other major firms will make more radical changes remains to be seen.

至于中型律所，我认为大多数律所为了生存和发展，都需要进行合并并寻求外部投资，以便从现有模式转向新的、可持续的、长期的商业模式。这其中蕴藏着机遇——他们应该认识到，客户对一些领先律所的不满，正为他们带来前所未有的机遇，让他们成为值得信赖的替代选择。为此，他们必须找到建立声誉、品牌和能力的方法。

As for medium-sized firms, to survive and thrive I suspect most will need to merge and seek external investment to enable the changes from their current approach to a new, sustainable, longer-term business model. There is a window of opportunity here—they should recognize that clients’ dissatisfaction with some of the leading firms throws up an unprecedented opportunity to be recognized as credible alternatives. To do this, they must find ways of building their reputations, brands, and capabilities.

我相信，在未来很多年，拥有明显专业技能的中小型律所仍将拥有市场。即使是规模最大的机构的总法律顾问也常常表示，即使来自规模较小的律所，他们也欢迎深厚的专业知识和个性化服务。通常，吸引他们的是特定律师的才能，而不是特定律所的才能。

I believe there will be a market for many years yet for small to medium-sized firms with demonstrable, niche expertise. General Counsel of even the largest of organizations often indicate that they welcome deep expertise and personal service even if offered from modest-sized firms. Usually, it is the talents of a particular lawyer rather than of a particular firm that is the attraction here.

至于那些规模小得多、合伙人很少的律所，除了那些也提供真正专业或个性化服务且部分市场愿意付费的律所外，我很难想象这些法律业务如何长期生存，除非它们进行根本性的变革。威胁将来自各个方向，尤其是来自在线法律服务提供商。在自由化法律体制下的商业街（主街），零售商和银行也将与个体执业律师和小型律所竞争日常法律服务（例如产权转让、遗嘱认证和人身伤害案件）。但这些由外部投资驱动、由经验丰富的业务经理推动的替代性业务结构，很可能将使法律服务标准化、系统化和外部化（参见第四章），并带来传统小型律所无法比拟的成本节约、效率提升和经验积累。这将是那些以家庭手工业方式执业的律师的末日。我认为，在2020年代，大多数在自由化体制下的传统小型律所将没有多少发展前景。

As for much smaller firms with very few partners, aside from those which also offer a genuinely specialist or personal service that some market is prepared to pay for, I find it hard to imagine how these legal businesses will survive in the long run unless they change fundamentally. The threats will come from various directions, not least from online legal services providers. On the High (Main) Street, in liberalized legal regimes, retailers and banks will also compete with sole practitioners and small firms for everyday legal services (such as conveyancing, probate, and personal injury work). But it is likely that these alternative business structures, fuelled by external investment and driven by experienced business managers, will standardize, systematize, and externalize legal services (see Chapter 4) and bring cost savings, efficiencies, and experience that traditional, small law firms will find impossible to match. This will be the end of lawyers who practise in the manner of a cottage industry. I do not see much of a future as we move through the 2020s for most traditional small firms in liberalized regimes.

在本书第一版中我提出的所有观察中，我对小公司的悲观态度似乎引起了最大的反感。我得说，我并不反对小公司。我只是不明白，面对那些所谓的“超市”，无论是大型企业还是在线服务，这些街角小店该如何生存下去。

Of all the observations I made in the first edition of this book, my pessimism about small firms seemed to cause greatest offence. I should say immediately that I have nothing against small firms. I just cannot see how these corner shops will manage to keep afloat in the face of the metaphorical supermarkets, whether larger businesses or online services.

另一种看待这个问题的方式是，小型律所的合伙人可以问自己这个问题——在2020年代，作为一家小型法律企业，我们能带来什么独特的价值？以下是一些符合要求的答案：我们的客户明确地告诉我们，他们不希望我们改变；我们的社区需要广泛的法律服务，而且我们的传统服务没有明显的竞争对手；我们是公认的专家，虽然规模不大，但我们和其他人一样专业；虽然我们是律师，但客户选择我们，是因为我们是他们的一般业务顾问；由于我们规模较小，我们可以以比其他任何法律企业低得多的成本提供高质量的服务；我们的客户选择我们，是因为他们愿意为高接触度的面对面服务支付额外费用。一些小型律所可能认为他们确实能够提供这样的答案，但这样的律所并不多。

Another way to look at this is for partners in small firms to ask themselves this question—in the 2020s, what unique value can we bring as a small legal business? Here are a few answers that pass muster: our clients have told us unequivocally that they do not want us to change; our community requires a wide range of legal services and there are no obvious competitors to our traditional offering; we are acknowledged specialists and, although small, we are as expert as anyone; although we are lawyers, our clients come to us because we are their general business advisers; because we are smaller, we can offer a high-quality service at significantly lower cost than any other legal businesses; our clients come to us because they are prepared to pay extra for a high touch, face-to-face service. Some small firms may feel they can genuinely provide such answers, but not many.

出庭律师和大律师

Trial Lawyers and Barristers

另一群法律专家经常声称他们不会受到经济力量、自由化和技术的影响，他们是英国的大律师和世界各地律师事务所的出庭律师。

Another group of legal specialists who often maintain that they will be unaffected by economic forces, liberalization, and technology are barristers in England and trial lawyers in law firms around the world.

确实，口头辩护律师的大部分工作都是高度定制的，法庭律师的努力和专业知识如何标准化或计算机化。事实上，口头辩护在其巅峰状态或许是定制法律服务的精髓。我毫不怀疑，在可预见的未来，高价值和复杂的法律问题仍将以传统方式在传统法院进行辩论。当出现危及生命的纠纷时，客户将继续寻求最优秀的法律斗士为他们辩护。然而，目前尚不清楚，就低价值或不太复杂的纠纷聘请大律师或出庭律师是否仍将被视为具有商业合理性。除了可能转向调解、合作律师和其他形式的替代性争议解决方式外，新兴的争议控制和争议避免技术（参见第12章）可能会减少在法庭上甚至在法院门口最终结案的案件数量。此外，随着虚拟听证会的普及，出庭次数本身也会减少，而在线法庭和在线争议解决（ODR）无疑将导致许多传统诉讼律师被取代。因此，真正优秀的高级出庭律师和大律师的前景在一段时间内依然光明，但初级民事出庭律师如果希望在未来十年取得成功，可能需要重新思考自己的前景，并为虚拟听证会和在线法庭的日常工作做好准备。

It is true that much of the work of the oral advocate is highly bespoke in nature and it is not at all obvious how the efforts and expertise of the courtroom lawyer might be standardized or computerized. Indeed, oral advocacy at its finest is probably the quintessential bespoke legal service. I have little doubt, for the foreseeable future, that very high-value and very complex legal issues will continue to be argued before conventional courts in the traditional manner. When there is a life-threatening dispute, clients will continue to secure the talents of the finest legal gladiators who will fight on their behalf. However, it is less clear that instructing barristers or trial lawyers for lower value or less complex disagreements will continue to be regarded as commercially justifiable. Quite apart from a likely shift towards mediation, collaborative lawyering, and other forms of alternative dispute resolution, emerging techniques of dispute containment and dispute avoidance (see Chapter 12) are likely to reduce the number of cases that find final closure in courts of law or even on the steps of the courthouse. Moreover, courtroom appearances themselves will diminish in number with greater uptake of virtual hearings, while online courts and online dispute resolution (ODR) will no doubt lead to the displacement of many conventional litigators. The future for truly exceptional senior trial lawyers and barristers looks rosy for some time yet, therefore, but junior civil trial lawyers may need to rethink their prospects and prepare for daily work in virtual hearings and online courts if they wish to prosper in the coming decade.

在英格兰和苏格兰，那些致力于就复杂法律领域撰写意见的律师和辩护律师将比大多数其他法律实践领域受到本书预期的变化的影响较小，因为对于这种真正定制的工作，没有明显的替代来源。

In England and Scotland, those barristers and advocates whose practices are devoted to the writing of opinions on complex areas of law will be less affected by the changes anticipated in this book than most other areas of legal practice, because there is no obvious alternative source for this genuinely bespoke work.

新合伙人提出的问题

Questions Asked by New Partners

在律所内部发生巨大变革和混乱的背景下，我注意到最近新任命的律所合伙人目前感到不安和紧张。过去，我发现年轻的合伙人是一个有趣的群体。这些才华横溢的年轻律师通常三十五六岁，精力充沛，经验丰富，但他们往往期望自己现在拥有股份的律所未来能够像过去一样正常运转和盈利。他们往往充满自信，最近被前辈吸纳为合伙人，这让他们倍感鼓舞，并认为自己付出的努力得到了回报；尽管他们常常会因为发现成为合伙人本身就是一个新的开始，发现自己又跌到了另一个阶梯的最底层而感到不安。

In the context of great change and disruption within law firms, I notice that recently appointed partners of law firms are currently disconcerted and nervous. In the past, I have found young partners to be an interesting breed. Often in their mid-thirties, these bright young lawyers have great energy and considerable experience but have tended to operate on the expectation that the firms of which they are now part-owners are likely to function and profit in the future much as they have in the past. They have tended to be a confident bunch, pumped up by recent admittance into partnership by their seniors, and satisfied that the effort they have expended has been justified; although they have often been unnerved to discover that becoming a partner is of itself a new beginning and to find themselves on the bottom rung of yet another ladder.

然而，过去几年里，我注意到初级合伙人对自己的职位缺乏信心，并且非常担心自己加入的律所的未来。1996年至2006年期间，当我在律所为新合伙人开设入职培训课程时，我感觉到他们对我那些看似天马行空的想法不屑一顾。大多数人更喜欢在我演讲时看着他们（当时的）黑莓手机或草拟文件。这种情况已经彻底改变了。如今，初级合伙人洗耳恭听，总是问我同样的问题，渴望听到我的观点。以下是这些问题，以及我通常的回答。

In the last few years, however, I have noted that junior partners are less confident in their position and worry very deeply about the future of the firms they have joined. When I addressed law firms’ induction courses for new partners between 1996 and 2006, I felt them dismissive of my seemingly outlandish ideas. Most preferred to look at their (then) BlackBerry devices or draft documents during my presentations. This has changed radically. Today junior partners are all ears, consistently asking me the same set of questions, and are anxious to hear my views. Here are these questions, along with the replies I usually give.

我们的公司是否可行且可持续？

Is our firm viable and sustainable?

我在本书第一部分预测的变化已经开始显现。如果企业不接受替代采购尤其是这些策略，我怀疑其中大多数策略是否能够长期有效或持续下去。

The changes I anticipate in Part One of this book are already taking hold. If firms do not embrace alternative sourcing strategies, in particular, I doubt the majority will be viable or sustainable in the long term.

商业模式是否崩溃了？

Is the business model broken?

就其指的是合伙人位于顶端、初级律师在底端负责日常工作的宽基层金字塔而言，我认为从长远来看，这种模式确实会被打破。杠杆将被替代资源所取代。

Insofar as this refers to the broad-based pyramid with the partner at the top and junior lawyers undertaking routine work at the bottom, then, again, I think this model will indeed be broken in the long term. Leverage will be replaced by alternative sourcing.

辉煌的岁月已经过去了吗？

Have the glory years passed?

我认为，许多律所的巅峰时期是在2006年左右。这不仅仅是盈利能力和营业额的问题，因为自那以后，许多律所的盈利能力和营业额都有了显著提升，而在于能否轻松获得工作、能否毫无争议地向客户收取费用，以及投入的人力。一些精英律所和创业型律所将继续享受更辉煌的时代，但对许多律所而言，除非它们进行彻底的变革，否则辉煌岁月已经一去不复返。

For many firms, I believe their peak was around 2006. This is not simply a matter of profitability and turnover, for many have greatly improved these since, but a question of the ease with which work is won, the level of fees that clients can be charged without challenge, and the amount of human effort expended. Some elite firms and entrepreneurial firms will go on to enjoy yet greater times, but for many firms, unless they change radically, the glory years have indeed passed.

我们的固定成本是否太高？

Are our fixed costs too high?

未来几年，律师事务所将需要重新审视其房地产战略，因为在日益网络化、视频会议普遍使用的世界中，昂贵城市的高租金将是一种昂贵的享受；而且大量初级律师的劳动力成本也将过高，主要是因为在成本较低的地区或国家有替代资源。

In the coming years, firms will need to revisit their property strategies, because high rentals in expensive cities will be a costly indulgence in an increasingly networked world with pervasive use of video meetings; and the labour costs of large numbers of junior lawyers will also be excessive, largely because of the availability of alternative sourcing in lower-cost regions or countries.

我们继承了什么？

What are we inheriting?

大多数初级合伙人接手的都是过时、陈旧、低技术含量的企业，这些企业很快就会不再适合其发展目标。这意味着这并不是说企业缺乏高智商或人才，而是这些人才进入市场的方式不再具有竞争力，其安排和定价也不再具有竞争力。

Most junior partners are inheriting outdated, outmoded, low-tech businesses that will soon not be fit for purpose. This means not that there is a lack of great intelligence or talent within the businesses but that the way in which this talent is taken to market is no longer competitively arranged and priced.

高级合伙人是否关心长远利益？

Do senior partners care about the long term?

这是一个至关重要的问题。遗憾的是，我遇到的大多数律所领导只剩下几年的任期，他们希望能坚持到退休，否则我预测的巨额财富将吞噬他们。作为管理者而非领导者，他们更关注短期盈利而非长期战略健康。对于初级合伙人来说，这无疑是个悲剧，因为律所的任何重大革新和重组都必须由高层推动。我发现这与大型会计师事务所形成了鲜明对比，那里的高级合伙人似乎更关心初级合伙人的前景。他们的理念——将自己视为长期且持久机构的临时托管人，而不是在价格合适时想要脱身的短期投资者——可以被律所的更多股权合伙人借鉴。换句话说，高级合伙人是时候更深入地思考如何为继任者留下更丰厚的遗产了。

This is a vital question. Regrettably, most law firm leaders that I meet have only a few years left to serve and hope they can hold out until retirement before much that I predict engulfs them. Operating as managers rather than leaders, they are more focused on short-term profitability than long-term strategic health. For junior partners this is tragic because any major reinvention and re-engineering of law firms has to be driven from the top. I find a contrast here with the large accounting firms, where senior partners seem more concerned about the prospects of their junior partners. Their philosophy—to regard themselves as temporary custodians of long-term and enduring institutions rather than short-term investors who want to bail out when the price is right—is one that could fruitfully be assumed by more equity partners in law firms. In other words, it is time for senior partners to think more deeply about a more generous legacy for their successors.

领导力时刻

Time for Leadership

在律师事务所，经理和领导者的职责不同。经理往往注重短期目标，确保客户服务到位、项目顺利完成、业绩达标，并激励团队。而优秀的领导者则恰恰相反，他们不仅关注短期目标，同时也关注组织的长期战略健康。他们的首要任务应该是了解市场变化、建立持久关系、提升品牌，以及审查和制定战略。从历史上看，从20世纪80年代到经济衰退，大多数律所无需担心领导力。策略很简单——大多数律所年复一年地被要求增加业务量并削减开支。这是一种“顺境管理”，轻松掌控全局。然而，在巨变的时代，需要更强有力的方向指引。要想持久发展，坚定的领导力必不可少。

Managers and leaders have different job descriptions in law firms. Managers tend to focus on the short term, ensuring that clients are served, work is won, the figures are delivered, and the teams are motivated. The best leaders, in contrast, do keep an eye on the short term but at the same time are obsessed with the long-term strategic health of their organizations. Their preoccupations should be with understanding changes in the market, building enduring relationships, enhancing the brand, and reviewing and developing strategy. Historically, from the 1980s through to the recession, most law firms did not need to worry about leadership. The game plan was simple—most practices were invited, year on year, to bring in a bit more work and trim their expenses. This was fair weather management, a light hand on the tiller. In times of immense change, however, much stronger direction is needed. To endure and prosper, firm leadership is required.

未来律所最优秀的领导者不太可能效仿其前辈，以建立共识为主要方式。当变革迅速而普遍时，就没有时间去说服那些怀疑者和落后者了。

The finest leaders in tomorrow’s law firms are unlikely to proceed in the manner of their predecessors, which was by building consensus. When change is rapid and pervasive, there will not be time to convince the doubters and laggards.

归根结底，大多数律师是被证据而非论据说服的。对于每一个论点，一位聪明的律师都能编造出一个巧妙的反驳。相比之下，像某些客户对某个特定系统或创新充满热情这样的新闻证据则更难被驳斥。因此，领导者需要提供支持变革的证据，而不是仅仅空谈。问题在于，如果这些证据来自业务之外，那么律所从定义上来说就已经是一个追随者了。因此，领导者需要从内部获取证据——从试点、实验以及在认同的客户身上测试想法。律所领导者需要一定的回旋余地来开展持续的研究和开发，而无需寻求合伙人中大多数成员的批准。这听起来可能不太像合伙人制或学院制，但无疑更具商业性。

In the end, most lawyers are convinced by evidence and not argument. For every argument, a bright lawyer can concoct a clever counter-argument. In contrast, it is harder to gainsay evidence such as news that some client has enthused about a particular system or innovation. So leaders need to provide evidence in support of change rather than mere rhetoric. The problem here is that if this evidence comes from beyond the business, then the firm is, by definition, already a follower. Therefore, leaders will need to generate evidence from within—from pilots, experiments, and testing ideas out on sympathetic clients. Law firm leaders will need some leeway to undertake ongoing research and development without needing to seek the approval of the majority of the partnership. It may sound less partnerial and collegiate but it is certainly more business-like.

9企业内部律师角色的转变

9 The Shifting Role of In-House Lawyers

我遇到的一些最有成就感的律师都在公司内部工作。这意味着他们属于大型组织内的法律部门。有些这样的部门——例如大型金融机构的部门——可能非常大，拥有多达 2,000 名左右的律师。公司内部律师的职业吸引着那些希望成为其所咨询组织核心的人。如果你在律师事务所工作，你与客户的业务就没有任何关系。如果你在公司内部工作，你就是业务的一部分。大多数法学院学生在考虑未来职业时，倾向于想象自己在律师事务所工作（美国除外，那里许多人渴望成为政府律师）。在许多法学院，很少正式讨论公司内部律师的角色，这很奇怪，因为这些客户可能会对法律服务的未来产生巨大影响。

Some of the most fulfilled lawyers that I meet work in-house. This means they belong to legal departments that sit within large organizations. Some of these departments—for example, in large financial institutions—can be very large, with as many as 2,000 or so lawyers. A career as an in-house lawyer attracts those who want to be at the heart of the organizations that they advise. If you work in a law firm, you are at one remove from the business of your clients. If you work in-house, you are part of the business. Most law students, when contemplating their future careers, tend to imagine themselves working in law firms (other than in the US, where many aspire to being government lawyers). In many law schools, there is little formal discussion of the role of in-house lawyers, which is bizarre because these clients are likely to have an enormous influence on the future of legal services.

法律风险管理

Legal Risk Management

大多数总法律顾问（GC），即内部法律团队的领导者，告诉我，他们的主要工作应该是管理风险；“法律风险管理”应成为公司法务的核心能力和服务。他们经常将自己的实际工作与“救火”工作进行对比——公司法务每天都要面对来自整个组织机构的大量请求、问题和疑问。他们通常认为自己必须做出必要的回应。但实际上，虽然有些问询值得认真的法律关注，但其他一些则不然。大多数法律顾问的希望是，他们能够自我调整，变得更有选择性；能够从过度被动转变为积极主动。换句话说，他们的工作应该是在问题出现之前就预见到它们。重点应该放在避免纠纷和问题上，而不是解决它们。

Most General Counsel (GCs), the leaders of in-house legal teams, tell me that their principal job should be that of managing risk; that ‘legal risk management’ should be the core competence and service of in-house lawyers. They often contrast this with what they actually do, which is fight fires—in-house lawyers are faced, on a daily basis, with a barrage of requests, problems, and questions from across their organizations. And they usually feel they have to respond helpfully. In reality, while some of these inquiries merit serious legal attention, others assuredly do not. The hope of most GCs is that they can organize themselves to become more selective; that they can move from being excessively reactive to being proactive. In other words, their job should be to anticipate problems before they arise. The focus should be on avoiding disputes and problems rather than resolving them.

法律风险可以通过多种方式管理，但重点通常在于防止企业中的非律师人员无意中使其组织承担某种责任（例如，可能因违反某些法规或协议而产生的责任）。这种风险控制可以通过多种方式实现，例如提高法律意识、引入协议或程序、使用标准文件，或让律师更直接地参与组织事务。法律风险管理还可以包括进行审计、风险审查和健康检查，以评估组织的合规管理流程或诉讼准备情况等。毫无疑问，未来的内部律师在风险管理方面将更加系统化和严谨，并需要先进的系统和技术来帮助他们（这里最令人兴奋的机会是使用机器学习技术进行风险诊断）。令人惊讶的是，很少有律师事务所已经意识到其中的商业机会。

Legal risk can be managed in many ways, but the emphasis is usually on preventing non-lawyers in businesses from inadvertently exposing their organizations to some kind of liability (such as might flow from a breach of some regulation or of an agreement). This control of risk can be achieved, for example, by increasing legal awareness, by introducing protocols or procedures, by using standard documents, or by involving lawyers more directly in the affairs of organizations. Legal risk management can also involve the conduct of audits, risk reviews, and health checks to assess, for instance, an organization’s processes for managing regulatory compliance or its preparedness for litigation. There is little question that tomorrow’s in-house lawyers will become increasingly systematic and rigorous in their management of risk and will require sophisticated systems and techniques to help them (the most exciting opportunity here is the use of machine learning techniques for risk diagnosis). Strikingly, very few law firms have yet recognized the commercial opportunities here.

另一个与风险相关的趋势是，内部律师和律师事务所之间将更多地分担风险。如果交易和纠纷未能圆满解决，一些法律总顾问认为，相关律师事务所应该通过降低收费来承担部分损失。律师事务所反驳说，这应该是双赢的，因此，法律项目的成功完成必然会导致收费的上涨。毫无疑问，随着经济压力的增加，关于收费和风险分担的争论在未来几年将会愈演愈烈。新的风险分配方式将不断涌现，旨在以不同的方式激励律师事务所。一个引人注目的例子是，如果内部律师帮助律师事务所避免诉讼，他们会向律师事务所支付奖金。

Another risk-related trend will be towards the greater sharing of risk between in-house lawyers and law firms. If deals and disputes do not conclude satisfactorily, some GCs believe that the law firms involved should suffer some of the downside, by reducing their fees. With some justification, law firms retort that this should cut both ways, so that the successful conclusion of a legal project should surely then result in an uplift in fees. No doubt, these debates on fees and risk-sharing will intensify in years to come, as economic pressures increase. New ways of allocating risks will evolve in attempts to incentivize law firms in different ways. One arresting example of this is when in-house lawyers pay law firms bonuses if they help them to avoid litigation.

知识管理

Knowledge Management

如前所述，使用标准文件是降低法律风险的行之有效的方法：非律师人士和律师都必须使用（并且必须获得许可，有时还要接受监督）经过精心设计的固定格式协议，这些协议会预先考虑众所周知的法律问题和陷阱。强制使用未经律师签字不得更改条款和条件的协议，可能会限制商界人士的谈判。

The use of standard documents, as said, is a well-established technique for reducing legal risk: non-lawyers and lawyers alike are required to use (and only then with permission and sometimes supervision) fixed-form agreements that have been carefully crafted in anticipation of well-known legal problems and pitfalls. Business people can be constrained in their negotiations by imposing the use of agreements with terms and conditions that cannot be altered without sign-off from lawyers.

这些标准文件的实际编制工作属于法律知识管理领域。这是一个收集、培养和分享一群律师的集体知识和专业技能的过程。这样做的目的是避免重复劳动，并建立一种机构记忆，使其胜过任何个人的回忆，无论他们多么有才华。知识管理是专业支持律师的核心工作之一，专业支持律师是一群重要的法律专家，他们在大型律师事务所工作，尤其是在英国。

The actual preparation of these standard documents belongs to the world of legal knowledge management. This is the process of capturing, nurturing, and sharing the collective know-how and expertise of a group of lawyers. The motive here is to avoid duplication of effort and to build an institutional memory that is superior to the recall of any individuals, no matter how talented. Knowledge management is one of the central jobs of professional support lawyers, a key group of legal specialists who work in major law firms, especially in the UK.

值得注意的是，公司内部法务部门很少聘请知识经理和专业支持律师。这里存在一个悖论和矛盾之处。确保知识管理带来的效率显然符合公司内部律师的利益。相比之下，对于按小时收费的律师事务所来说，通过知识循环提高效率的动机并不那么明显。那么，为什么大型律师事务所在知识经理方面投入巨资，而公司内部律师却普遍不愿招聘呢？对于公司内部律师来说，阻碍因素似乎在于聘请专业支持律师的费用——据我所知，很难向首席财务官说明聘请不直接就日常法律工作、纠纷或交易提供咨询的律师的商业理由。至于律师事务所，他们知道他们的客户（在英国如此，但在美国和加拿大则较少）期望他们的外部顾问拥有大量的模板和案例，而知识经理正是专门维护此类专业知识的人。总而言之，大多数内部律师喜欢知识管理的想法，但更希望律师事务所为此付费。

Significantly, in-house legal departments rarely employ knowledge managers and professional support lawyers. There is a paradox and inconsistency here. It would clearly be in the interests of in-house lawyers to secure the efficiencies that knowledge management would bring. In contrast, for law firms that charge by the hour, the incentive to become more efficient through knowledge recycling is less than immediately obvious. Why, then, do in-house lawyers generally hold back from recruiting knowledge managers whereas major law firms have invested heavily? For in-house lawyers, the deterrent seems to be the expense of employing professional support lawyers—it is difficult, I am told, to make the business case to chief finance officers for employing lawyers who do not advise directly on everyday legal work, or on disputes or deals. As for law firms, they know that their clients (in the UK, if less so in the US and Canada) expect their external advisers to have substantial bodies of templates and precedents, and knowledge managers are the people who specialize in maintaining this kind of know-how. In summary, most in-house lawyers like the idea of knowledge management but would prefer law firms to pay for it.

这种情况将会改变。假以时日，公司内部律师将认识到并能够量化专业支持律师所能带来的效益，并设法说服董事会，投资于那些能够通过技术赋能的法律知识来节省成本的人才是明智之举。和流程共享（法律部门内部以及组织之间）。

This will change. In due course, in-house lawyers will recognize and be able to quantify the benefits that professional support lawyers can bring and will manage to convince their boards that it makes sense to invest in people who will bring savings through technology-enabled legal knowledge and process sharing (within legal departments and between organizations too).

对律师事务所的期望更高

Expecting More from Law Firms

抛开风险和知识管理不谈，未来客户将如何选择律师事务所？人们通常认为，一个律师或律师事务所之间的区别在于其实质性专业知识；客户会倾向于那些看起来知识更渊博或更专业的律师。然而，客户常常表示，在众多优秀律师和优秀律师事务所之间几乎没有什么可挑剔的，他们对法律法规和市场惯例的熟悉程度同样令人印象深刻。律师事务所之间的区别，尤其是在提供真正定制化服务的情况下，往往在于律师与其顾问之间的个人关系。（当工作是例行公事时，人际关系就不那么重要了。）

Moving away from risk and knowledge management, how will clients select law firms in the future? It is often assumed that what differentiates one lawyer or law firm from another is their substantive expertise; that clients will gravitate towards lawyers who seem to know more or appear more deeply expert. However, clients often say that there is little to choose between many good lawyers and good law firms, that they are equally and impressively familiar with black-letter law and market practice. What frequently distinguishes law firms, particularly when the work is genuinely bespoke, are the personal relationships that lawyers have with those they advise. (When the work is routine, the interpersonal dimension is of less importance.)

因此，未来要成功经营法律业务，律师仅仅拥有优秀的法律头脑是不够的。未来的律师需要掌握各种软技能，才能赢得新客户并让他们满意。未来的内部律师不仅会对成本、包容性和多样性以及环境问题提出更高的要求，还会更加谨慎地选择与外部律所律师建立的人际关系。这将给律所带来压力，迫使他们充分利用面对面的互动，并利用社交网络系统和视频会议保持定期联系。

To run a successful legal business in the future, therefore, it will not be sufficient for lawyers to be in possession of fine legal minds. Tomorrow’s lawyers will need to acquire various softer skills if they are to win new clients and keep them happy. In-house lawyers of the future will not only be more demanding on costs, inclusion and diversity, and climate issues; they also will be more discerning about the interpersonal relationships they choose to cultivate with lawyers in external firms. This will place pressures on law firms to make the most of face-to-face interactions and to use social networking systems and video meetings to maintain regular contact.

例如，客户对那些对他们持续甚至充满热情的律师事务所已经做出了积极的回应。他们希望感受到，即使没有就某项具体工作进行合作，他们也向其支付了高额费用的律师事务所始终将他们放在心上，并将他们的利益放在心上。他们欣赏那些显然投入时间专门为他们、他们的业务和行业考虑的律师事务所。例如，客户喜欢了解可能与他们相关的已完成交易。他们也希望定期收到可能对他们产生直接影响的趋势和发展简报。对许多律师来说，保持这种持续联系并非易事，而且常常被为其他客户完成的收费工作所压倒。这令人遗憾，因为这种定期互动对于客户如今认为重要的长期关系而言日益重要。

Clients already respond favourably, for example, to law firms that express ongoing, and even passionate, interest in them. They like to feel that the firms to which they pay substantial fees are bearing them in mind and have their interests at heart, even when not working together on a particular job. They appreciate those law firms that have clearly devoted their own time to thinking specifically about them and their business and their industry. Clients like to hear, for instance, about a deal that has been done that may be relevant to them. They appreciate periodic briefings on the trends and developments that may have a direct impact on them. Maintaining this sort of rolling contact does not come naturally to many lawyers and is often trumped by pieces of chargeable work for other clients. This is regrettable because this kind of regular interaction is increasingly vital for the long-term relationships that clients are now deeming important.

年轻律师应该关注的一个相关问题是，律所需要体谅客户。总法律顾问经常发现，他们的外部律所不了解客户，对客户业务的日常动态和运营缺乏洞察力。这并不是说律所没有阅读客户的年度报告（尽管有些律所确实在这方面有所欠缺），也不是说他们不了解客户所在行业的基本情况。相反，存在一个更广泛的担忧：律所没有花足够的时间深入客户的环境，感受在客户业务中实际工作的感受。例如，有人告诉我，大多数律所并不了解特定客户的风险承受能力和偏好、行政管理和官僚机构的规模、内部沟通的重要性、程度和基调，以及至关重要的是，他们所提供建议的交易和纠纷的更广泛的战略和商业背景。

A related issue to which young lawyers should be sensitive is the need for law firms to empathize with their clients. GCs often observe that their external law firms do not understand their clients, that they have little insight into the daily dynamics and operations of their clients’ businesses. It is not that the law firms fail, for instance, to read their clients’ annual reports (although some do fall at this hurdle) or that they are ignorant of fundamentals of the sector in which their clients trade. Instead there is a wider worry: that law firms do not take sufficient time to immerse themselves in their clients’ environments and get a feel for what it is actually like to work in their businesses. For example, it has been suggested to me that most firms do not grasp, in any given client, the tolerance and appetite for risk, the amount of administration and bureaucracy, the significance and extent and tone of internal communication, and, vitally, the broader strategic and business context of the deals and disputes upon which they advise.

简而言之，未来的律师需要更加了解未来的客户。相比之下，如今许多律所的合伙人在与客户会面时，往往只是滔滔不绝地发表意见，而不是倾听客户的真实想法。换句话说，许多律所缺乏同理心。他们未能设身处地为客户着想，从客户的角度看待业务。人们常说，由于律所不愿停下来倾听，他们无法区分客户是需要快速、粗略的指导，还是需要详细、详尽的法律分析。这种缺乏同理心和倾听能力的状况，可能会对律所与客户未来之间的长期关系造成严重损害。

In short, tomorrow’s lawyers will need to be more in tune with tomorrow’s clients. In contrast, when meeting with their clients today, many partners of law firms are said to broadcast and pontificate instead of listening to what is actually on the minds of those they are serving. In other words, many law firms lack empathy. They fail to put themselves in their clients’ shoes and see the business from the clients’ perspective. It is often claimed that, because they do not pause to listen, firms cannot distinguish between those occasions when a client wants quick, rough-and-ready guidance as opposed to detailed and exhaustive legal analysis. This lack of empathy and inability to listen could be deeply prejudicial to long-term relationships between firms and clients in the future.

少花钱多办事的挑战

The More-for-Less Challenge

尽管法律风险管理和知识管理将成为未来公司内部律师的关键战略问题，他们与律所之间关系的质量和基调也将成为重要的运营考量，但如今大多数法律总顾问（GC）的主要管理重点是应对“少花钱多办事”的挑战（参见第一章）。在可预见的未来，这仍是让大多数法律总顾问夜不能寐的一件事。他们如何才能以更低的成本为企业提供更多法律服务？

Although legal risk management and knowledge management will be key strategic issues for tomorrow’s in-house lawyers and the quality and tone of their relationships with firms will be an important operational concern, the dominant management preoccupation of most GCs today is meeting the more-for-less challenge (see Chapter 1). For the foreseeable future, this is one thing that keeps most GCs awake at night. How can they deliver more legal service to their businesses at less cost?

这里最容易实现的目标是降低外部律师的费用。但这里面存在着一个根本性的矛盾，因为客户和律师的利益截然不同。目标。当客户致电律所，告知其业务出现问题时，律所的合伙人往往不会在内心深处希望这是一个大问题，这无疑是一个极其高尚的合作伙伴。对于任何法律工作，客户总是会祈祷他们的法律需求只是例行公事，能够快速轻松地得到处理；而律所通常会渴望更具挑战性的指示，这些指示可能会让团队在复杂的工作中耗费相当长的时间。

The low-hanging fruit here is the possibility of driving down the fees of external lawyers. But there is a primal and fundamental tension here because clients and lawyers have very different objectives. When a client phones a law firm and intimates that their business has a problem, it is an unusually virtuous partner who will not hope, deep down, that it is a big problem. For any piece of legal work, the client will invariably pray that their legal requirements are routine and can be disposed of quickly and painlessly, while a law firm will generally hanker after more challenging instructions that might occupy a team with complex work for quite some time.

按小时计费仍然盛行，这引发了其他相关的矛盾。大多数客户并不想购买专家的时间。他们想要的是结果、解决方案、成果以及切实可行的商业指导。他们还希望获得确定性和可预测的费用，而不是按小时计费通常带来的无限期的空头支票承诺。通常，按小时计费并不能激励律师事务所为客户提供他们真正想要的服务。因此，正如在风险管理方面所提到的，我们将在未来十年看到更复杂的机制来协调律师事务所及其客户的激励机制。

There are other related tensions arising from the still-dominant practice of hourly billing. Most clients do not want to buy the time of experts. They want results, solutions, outcomes, and practical commercial guidance. They also want certainty and predictability of costs, and not the open-ended commitment of the blank cheque that hourly billing often entails. Generally, hourly billing does not incentivize law firms to give clients what they would actually like. Consequently, we will see in the coming decade, as noted in relation to risk management, more sophisticated mechanisms for aligning the incentives of law firms and their clients.

这些机制并非按小时计费的粗暴无效的替代方案。我将在第三章解释这些机制为何普遍令人失望。相反，正如该章所述，公司内部律师会认为，他们所需的成本节约并非仅仅通过不同的定价就能实现。真正的挑战在于以不同的方式开展工作。越来越多的公司内部法律顾问也意识到了这一点，因此他们正在努力寻找各种替代的法律服务采购方式。

These mechanisms will not be crude and ineffectual alternatives to hourly billing. In Chapter 3, I explain why these generally disappoint. Instead, in-house lawyers will come to the view, as discussed in that chapter, that the cost savings they need cannot be secured simply by pricing differently. Rather, the challenge is to work differently. Increasingly, in-house counsel are arriving at this conclusion and so are now wrestling with various alternative ways of sourcing legal services.

这里的基本思路值得重复。历史上，法律工作要么由客户自己承担，要么由外部律师事务所承担。这种做法的问题在于一个问题是，将常规和重复的法律任务交给律所和法务部门处理成本过高。因此，不同的外包方式逐渐兴起：将法律工作外包给低成本国家的第三方供应商；将法律工作外包到企业已经将其他职能转移出去的地方，比如呼叫中心；鼓励律所将业务分包给成本较低地区的律所；或者聘请收费仅为传统律所一半的合同律师。这些都是我在第3章中提到的“效率战略”——降低法律服务成本——的例子。到2020年代，对于那些推行这一战略的人来说，基于技术的解决方案将变得司空见惯。

The underpinning thinking here bears repetition. Historically, legal work has been undertaken either by clients themselves or by their outside law firms. The problem with this is that it is proving too costly for routine and repetitive legal tasks to be discharged within firms and legal departments. And so, different approaches to sourcing such work have gained some traction: outsourcing to third party providers in low-cost countries; off-shoring legal work to locations where businesses have already transferred other functions, such as call centres; encouraging law firms to subcontract to practices in less costly regions; or using contract lawyers who charge about half the price of traditional law firms. These are all instances of what I call, in Chapter 3, the ‘efficiency strategy’—cutting the costs of legal service. In the 2020s, technology-based solutions will become commonplace for those who are pursuing this strategy.

另一种可能性是联合外包，即一些内部部门联合起来，分担某些共同法律服务的成本，例如设立共享服务中心。这是第三章概述的“协作策略”的一个例子，我在其中提到了银行和地方当局已经在进行的合作方式。

Yet another possibility is co-sourcing, which can involve a group of in-house departments coming together and sharing the cost of some common legal service, perhaps by setting up shared services centres. This is an example of the ‘collaboration strategy’ outlined in Chapter 3, where I mention the ways in which banks and local authorities are already cooperating.

毫无疑问，内部社区对这些以及许多其他新的法律工作采购方式的兴趣正日益浓厚。

There is no doubt that the in-house community is becoming steadily more interested in these and many other new ways of sourcing legal work.

合作精神

The Collaborative Spirit

一种不同的合作形式也正在兴起——一些公司内部律师热衷于在其外部律所之间营造一种合作精神。他们将自己的主要律所称为“大家庭”。这样做的目的是，律所之间相互信任而非竞争，并且他们的集体的力量应该用于支持客户，而不是争夺下一批工作的位置。结果应该是一支更高效、更文明的律师团队。从这个角度来看，一个组织的法律能力是内部职能部门和外部律所的结合。律所的律师应该像一个大家庭一样一起工作——不是功能失调、争吵不休的家庭，而是一个分享并始终专注于更大共同目标的家庭：客户的利益。

A different form of cooperation is also emerging—some in-house lawyers are keen to engender a collaborative spirit amongst their external law firms. They speak of their primary law firms as their ‘extended family’. The intention here is that firms trust rather than compete with one another, and that their collective energies are directed at supporting the client instead of jockeying for position for the next tranche of work. The result should be a more productive, efficient, and civilized group of lawyers. On this view, the legal capability of an organization is the combination of the in-house function and its external firms. The lawyers from the firms are expected to work together as a family—not one that is dysfunctional and constantly bickering but one that shares and focuses relentlessly on a larger common purpose: the interests of clients.

这种管理外部律所的方法尚不普遍。事实上，一些法律总顾问（GC）对律所间的合作持怀疑态度。许多银行似乎也属于这一阵营。他们认为，期望其主要的外部律所合作显然不切实际。精明的律师想要的是市场，而不是社交俱乐部或家庭聚会。因此，一些内部律师积极鼓励其律所之间激烈竞争。在这种更具竞争性的方式下，律所经常被邀请相互竞标，以展示其优势——即他们比其他律所更优秀、成本更低、效率更高或更具创新性。

This approach to managing external law firms is not yet common. Indeed some GCs are sceptical about inter-firm cooperation. Many banks seem to fall into this camp. They maintain that it is plainly unrealistic to expect their principal external firms to collaborate. Hard-nosed lawyers want a market and not a social club or a family outing. Some in-house lawyers therefore actively encourage their firms to compete strenuously with one another. On this more combative approach, firms are frequently invited to bid against one another, and to demonstrate their supremacy—that they are better, less costly, more efficient, or more innovative than the rest.

虽然这里没有正确答案，但我见证了两种学派的实际行动（金融服务业内外），并预测合作阵营最终将胜出。这种方法具有明显的吸引力：可以避免重复劳动；可以消除不对称；更有效地将精力投入到客户身上；工作关系也更加友好。例如，从客户的角度来看，由他们的外部公司协调提供培训服务是完全合理的。一些有趣的机会也随之出现，例如组建由从各个领域精心挑选的最佳律师组成的“梦之队”。律师事务所，并专门为特定交易和纠纷而设立。对于那些重视家族而非世仇的人来说，挑战在于如何将激励机制放在正确的位置，让律师事务所真正想要合作而不是竞争。这里的一半挑战在于客户要确保家族成员律所的工作流基本稳定。在这种协作方式下，参与者采用社交网络技术是明智之举。这些技术将把律所聚集在一个虚拟的屋檐下，鼓励并支持它们在虚拟团队中工作。这可以通过使用领英 (LinkedIn) 等通用服务或 Legal OnRamp 原版等法律工具来实现。与法律实践的许多其他领域一样，内部律师的未来将是数字化的。

Although there are no right answers here, I have seen both schools in action (within and beyond the financial services sector) and predict that the collaboration camp will eventually win out. This approach holds obvious attractions: duplication of effort can be avoided; asymmetries can be eliminated; energies are more efficiently channelled towards the clients; and working relationships are more amicable. It simply makes sense, for example, from the clients’ point of view, for their external firms to coordinate in the provision of training services. Interesting opportunities emerge, such as assembling ‘dream teams’, made up of the best lawyers, hand-selected from across various firms and purpose-built for particular deals and disputes. The challenge for those who favour family over feud is to put the incentives in the right place, so that law firms genuinely want to cooperate rather than compete. Half the battle here is for the client to ensure a more or less steady flow of work for firms who are family members. It will make sense on this collaborative approach for participants to embrace social networking technologies. These will bring firms under the one virtual roof and encourage and enable them to work in virtual groups. This could be done using generic services such as LinkedIn or legal tools like the original version of Legal OnRamp. As in so many other areas of legal practice, the future for in-house lawyers will be digital.

GC 策略

Strategy for GCs

从实际角度来看，法律总顾问（GC）如何为未来做准备，尤其是如何应对“少花钱多办事”的挑战？我无法一概而论地回答这个问题，但我发现目前有四大策略在发挥作用，每种策略的范围和目标各不相同。第一种策略是，法律总顾问主要专注于外部律所，并压低其价格。这是那些将大部分法律工作交给这些外部律所的法律总顾问的首选方法。第二种方法更适合大型内部部门，其重点是重塑内部部门。第三种方法是同时审查内部和外部的能力，并寻求精简两者。第四种策略是最雄心勃勃的——从一张白纸开始，忘记现有的资源（内部和外部），而是对企业进行全面的法律需求分析。分析完成后，接下来的任务就是冷静地确定如何最好地满足所有需求；不仅要依靠传统律师，还要借助其他法律服务提供商。在我看来，最终的策略将在未来为大型企业提供最具成本效益、响应速度最快的法律服务，并在适当的时候成为所有有能力的内部职能部门的首选方法。

In practical terms, how are GCs preparing for the future and, in particular, addressing the more-for-less challenge? I cannot answer that question across the board but I have found that four broad strategies are in play, each differing in its scope and ambition. The first strategy has been for GCs to concentrate largely on external law firms and to drive their prices down. This is the preferred method of GCs who pass much of their legal work to these external law firms. The second approach, better suited to large in-house departments, has been to focus instead on reshaping the in-house departments. The third has been simultaneously to review internal and external capabilities and seek to streamline both. The fourth tack has been the most ambitious—to start with a blank sheet of paper, to forget the current resources (in-house and outside), and instead to undertake a comprehensive legal needs analysis for the business. Once this analysis has been completed, the task then has been to identify dispassionately how best to resource the full set of needs; drawing not just on conventional lawyers but on alternative legal providers too. This final strategy, in my view, is the one that will deliver the most cost-effective and responsive legal services for large businesses in the future and, in due course, will be the preferred approach of all competent in-house functions.

过去十年中一个相关的发展必须引起关注——在公司内部法务部门任命首席运营官 (COO) 或运营总监。广义上讲，这些人负责像经营企业一样运营该部门。许多人专注于战略、替代资源、更高效的采购和技术，而他们的首席运营官则可以自由地做他们最擅长的事情——充当将军的顾问。首席运营官们之间也在合作：最突出的例子是 CLOC，即企业法律运营联盟，这是一个成立于 2014 年的首席运营官社区。CLOC 自称是一个重新定义法律业务的全球专家社区。超过 2,000 人参加了他们 2022 年的大型活动。他们的影响力（以及综合购买力）正在不断增长，而且相当可观。我毫不怀疑，他们将在制定法律行业新标准方面发挥核心作用。

One related development during the last decade must be noted—the appointment of chief operating officers (COOs) or directors of operations in in-house legal departments. These individuals are charged with the task, broadly speaking, of running the department like a business. Many are focused on strategy, alternative sourcing, more effective procurement, and technology, while their GCs are freed to do what they do best—acting as counsel to the generals. The COOs themselves are also collaborating: the most shining example here is CLOC, the Corporate Legal Operations Consortium, a community of COOs set up in 2014. CLOC describe themselves as a global community of experts that is redefining the business of law. More than 2,000 people attended their major 2022 event. Their influence (and combined purchasing power) is growing and considerable. I have little doubt they will play a central role in setting new standards for the legal industry.

内部律师的权力和责任

The Power and Responsibility of In-House Lawyers

我经常发现，有些令人惊讶的是，公司内部律师在考虑未来时表现出缺乏自信。他们经常问我，在经济形势好转、疫情逐渐消退之际，我是否预计律师事务所会恢复以往的工作方式。我总是回答说，这几乎完全取决于他们，作为客户，来决定这个问题的答案。如果公司内部律师不想重蹈覆辙，就必须向外部顾问明确传达这一信息。大客户可以放心，即使是最富裕的精英律师事务所，也无法忽视这一信息。

I often find, somewhat surprisingly, that in-house lawyers betray a lack of self-confidence when contemplating the future. Frequently they ask me if I expect law firms to revert to their old ways of working in rosier economic times and when the pandemic is firmly in the rear-view mirror. I invariably respond that it is almost entirely up to them, as the customers, to shape the answer to that query. If in-house lawyers do not want the reinstatement of bad past habits, they must send that message very clearly to their external advisers. Major clients can be assured that such a message cannot be ignored, even by the most flush elite law firms.

大多数公司法务原则上都会承认变革是必要的，他们应该更加严格地管理，并与供应商进行更艰难的谈判，但大多数人也声称他们似乎没有时间、精力或能力来引入效率或协作解决方案。当我深入探究时，我发现许多法律总顾问更倾向于律师事务所开发的现成解决方案。然而，这在某种程度上形成了一种恶性循环，正如前文所述，律师事务所本身几乎没有动力去支持效率或协作战略。既然客户通常似乎对律所的运营漠不关心，而竞争对手也没有以更低的价格抢占市场份额，律所为什么要用潜在的颠覆性创新来破坏现有业务的稳定呢？

Most in-house lawyers will concede, in principle, that change is necessary and that they should run a tighter ship and drive a harder bargain with their suppliers, but most also claim that they do not seem to have the time, energy, or competence to introduce efficiency or collaboration solutions. When I probe more deeply, it transpires that many GCs would prefer off-the-shelf answers developed by law firms. However, and this is something of a vicious circle, there is, as noted, little incentive for law firms themselves to support either the efficiency or collaboration strategies. Why should law firms destabilize their current businesses with potentially disruptive innovations when their clients often seem indifferent and their competitors are not undercutting them?

内部律师也必须牢记，他们自身也很可能在组织内部受到严格审查。他们不可能仅仅无休止地抱怨律所不愿改变。例如，随着人们逐渐意识到可以通过不同的方式获得法律工作，首席执行官、首席财务官和董事会必然会询问其法律总顾问，他们的部门是否正在适应并利用这些新工作方式带来的机会。为了帮助内部律师集中精力，律师们心目中，我用所谓的“股东测试”来表达这种可能的需求：

In-house lawyers must also remember that they are likely themselves to come under the microscope within their own organizations. It will not be plausible for them simply to complain ad infinitum about law firms’ unwillingness to change. As it becomes widely known, for instance, that it is possible to source legal work in different ways, chief executives, chief finance officers, and boards will inevitably ask their GCs whether their departments are adapting and exploiting the opportunities afforded by these new ways of working. To help focus in-house lawyers’ minds, I express this likely demand in terms of what I call the ‘shareholder test’:

当考虑针对交易或争议进行的成本提案时，熟悉越来越多的替代法律工作采购方式的精明商业股东是否会考虑什么才算是物有所值？

When a costed proposal for the conduct of a deal or dispute is being considered, would a commercially astute shareholder, who was familiar with the growing number of alternative ways of sourcing legal work, consider what is contemplated as representing value for money?

如果公司内部律师允许律所继续沿用其古老的计费和工作方式，那么他们显然不符合股东的要求。很快，法律总顾问（及其首席运营官）将别无选择，只能彻底改革其部门和工作方式：少花钱多办事的压力将达到几乎无法忍受的程度，他们将不得不重新调整甚至重塑内部工作方式以及外部法律服务的采购方式。

If in-house lawyers allow law firms to continue with their age-old billing and working practices, they plainly fail the shareholder test. Soon GCs (and their COOs) will have little choice but to overhaul their departments and working practices: the more-for-less pressure will build to an almost intolerable level and they will have to recalibrate if not re-engineer the way they work internally and how they source external legal services.

内部律师只有能够创造其他法律服务机构无法提供的相关价值，才能蓬勃发展。真正专业、值得信赖、与公司业务息息相关的内部法律顾问，始终是宝贵的资源。但除非法律顾问也准备好推动自身部门内部、律师事务所以及其他服务供应商之间的效率和协作战略，否则他们的未来前景并不明朗。我现在感觉到，内部法律部门平台已经开始捉襟见肘。现在正是迎接变革挑战的时候。

In-house lawyers will flourish only if they can add relevant value that cannot be delivered by competing sources of legal service. The genuinely expert and trusted in-house legal adviser, who lives and breathes the business, should always be an invaluable resource, but unless GCs are also prepared to drive the efficiency and collaboration strategies within their own departments and across law firms as well as other providers that serve them, then their future is far from clear. I sense now that the in-house legal department platform is starting to burn. Now is the time to meet the challenge of change.

他们应该记住（尽管很多人似乎并没有完全理解这一点），他们拥有巨大的购买力。我很难理解为什么法律总顾问没有推动外部律师事务所难度要大得多。全球排名前100的律所很大程度上依赖于全球排名前1000的企业。如果法律总顾问的要求大幅提高，他们将有能力推动这支顶级律所的重塑，进而重新定义整个法律市场。

They should remember (although many do not seem fully to grasp this) that they have immense purchasing power. I struggle to understand why GCs have not driven external law firms much harder. The world’s leading 100 law firms are sustained very largely by the world’s top 1,000 businesses. If and when GCs become radically more demanding, they will have it within their power to urge a reshaping of this top echelon of firms and, in turn, redefine the entire legal marketplace.

10家法律科技初创公司

10 Lawtech Start-ups

法律界的根本性变革不太可能在未来几年由当今的服务提供商推动。只要领先的律师事务所仍在盈利，阻止或转移其盈利渠道通常不符合其商业利益。事实上，正如丹尼尔·萨斯坎德和我在我们合著的《职业的未来》一书的更新版中所报告的那样，我们尚未发现任何一家杰出的专业律师事务所实现了显著的自我颠覆。在技术方面，领先的律师事务所当然在其系统上投入了大量资金，但这些投资的大部分都是为了增强和支持其现有的商业模式，而不是取代它。

Fundamental change in the legal world is unlikely to be driven over the next few years by today’s incumbent providers. So long as leading law firms are trading profitably, it is generally not in their commercial interests to stop or divert their gravy train. Indeed, as Daniel Susskind and I report in the updated edition of our book, The Future of the Professions, we have yet to find any prominent professional firm that has significantly self-disrupted. In relation to technology, the leading legal players are of course spending liberally on their systems but the bulk of this investment is invariably to enhance and support their current business model rather than displace it.

相比之下，会计巨头和其他另类法律服务提供商（第17章）比律师事务所更有可能寻求通过技术实现重大变革。他们是颠覆者，至少部分服务是从零开始构建的，而且主要基于数字化基础。

In contrast, the accounting giants and other alternative legal providers (Chapter 17) are more likely than law firms to seek to effect significant change through technology. They are disruptors and are building at least some of their services from scratch and doing so largely on digital foundations.

然而，更引人注目的可能是蓬勃发展的法律科技初创企业群体所带来的颠覆性影响。在许多其他行业——例如零售、休闲、交通和娱乐——转型并非由现有的真正的挑战者并非那些参与者，而是那些敢于颠覆现状、动力十足的小型新机构。同样，在法律领域，我谨慎地预计，少数几家杰出的初创企业将成为推动普遍而彻底变革的主要推动者。

More dramatic still, however, could be the disruptive impact of the burgeoning community of lawtech start-ups. In numerous other sectors—retail, leisure, transport, and entertainment, for example—transformation has been precipitated not by existing players but by remarkably motivated, small, new outfits that have dared to upend the status quo. Likewise, in law, I cautiously expect that a handful of exceptional start-ups will be prime movers in instigating pervasive and radical change.

初创企业概况

The Start-up Landscape

我在这里使用“初创企业”一词较为宽泛。广义上，我指的是过去十年左右成立或蓬勃发展的法律科技企业。因此，这包括“扩张型企业”、“早期”企业，以及一些较为成熟的公司。

I use the term ‘start-up’ loosely here. In broad terms, I am referring to lawtech businesses that have been founded or have mushroomed in the last decade or so. This will therefore include ‘scale-ups’, ‘early-stage’ businesses, as well as some more mature companies.

我知道风险投资家和其他人在给科技公司贴标签时拥有更丰富的词汇，他们会根据融资类型和时机、管理风格和精神，以及产品开发阶段和完善程度等因素来判断。我的关注点不同。就目前而言，我并不关心这些初创企业的商业运作。我感兴趣的是它们对法律世界的影响，以及那些正在彻底革新思维并在法律市场引入和执行新想法的人。激发我想象力的初创企业与传统供应商（律师事务所、法院、法律出版商、法律数据库提供商以及基本的后台技术供应商）几乎没有关联。我知道许多或大多数法律科技初创企业将无法生存。但少数能够蓬勃发展的企业很可能重新定义法律生态系统。这对于传统律师来说很难接受，但这正是这类初创企业的本质。我预测会发生改变——主流供应商，甚至最好的供应商，都很难想象出当今主流正统观念的替代方案。

I know that venture capitalists and others have much richer vocabularies here for labelling tech companies, based on factors such as their type and timing of financing, the style and spirit of their management, and the phase and polish of their product development. My focus is different. I am not concerned, for current purposes, with the business side of these start-ups. My fascination is with their impact on the world of law, and so with the people who are thinking fundamentally afresh and are introducing and executing novel ideas in the legal market. The start-ups that fire my imagination are the ones that bear little relation to the traditional suppliers (law firms, courts, legal publishers, law database providers, and basic back-office technology vendors). I know that many or most lawtech start-ups will not survive. But the small cohort that do prosper could well redefine the legal ecosystem. This is hard for traditional lawyers to accept but that is the very nature of the kind of change I predict—mainstream providers, even the very best, find it difficult to imagine an alternative to today’s prevailing orthodoxy.

有多少家法律科技初创企业？我找不到任何一份关于这些企业的全球学术研究报告。一个有用的起点是斯坦福大学 CodeX 团队几年前建立的结构良好的数据库。结合其他可用的在线资源，并亲自进行了一项非正式调查（与大约 15 个国家的同事和联系人），我估计目前全球有 3,000 至 4,000 家法律科技初创企业。2012 年我出版本书第一版时，只有几百家。当时，推出一家新公司是一件大事。相比之下，了解新的法律企业、产品或服务对我来说几乎是每天都会发生的事情（无数的电子邮件让我随时了解最新动态；新闻和分析服务“人工智能律师”也是如此）。

How many lawtech start-ups are there? I have not been able to find a single, scholarly global study of these businesses. A useful starting point is the well-structured database assembled a few years ago by the CodeX team at Stanford University. Taking this together with other available online resources and having conducted an informal survey myself (with colleagues and contacts in around 15 countries), I estimate that there are currently between 3,000 and 4,000 lawtech start-ups around the world. When I published the first edition of this book in 2012, there were only a few hundred. At that time, the launch of a new one was a big deal. In contrast, it seems like an almost daily occurrence for me to learn about a new legal venture, product, or service (countless incoming emails keep me up to date; as does Artificial Lawyer, the news and analysis service).

这些法律科技初创企业如今正吸引着大量投资。2022年年中，《金融时报》报道称，法律科技公司“在截至2021年9月的九个月内，风险投资额已超过10亿美元，超过了2019年9.89亿美元的前高”。自2017年以来，投资规模已大幅增长。目前，该领域已涌现出一些估值超过10亿美元的独角兽企业，例如Ironclad、LegalZoom和Clio。分析师预计，未来还会有更多独角兽企业涌现。

These lawtech start-ups are now attracting considerable investment. In mid-2022, the Financial Times reported that lawtech companies ‘had topped $1bn in venture capital investments in the nine months to September 2021, beating the previous high of $989m in 2019’. The scale of investment has increased by an order of magnitude since 2017. There are now a few unicorns (valued at more than $1 billion) in the sector, such as Ironclad, LegalZoom, and Clio. Analysts expect more to follow.

这些数据无疑警醒了一些律所，它们最近对初创企业表现出了更积极的兴趣，而不仅仅是关注它们的进展。有些律所担任初创企业的法律顾问，有些律所指导创始人，还有一些律所进行投资，还有一些律所充当非正式的孵化器和加速器。少数律所已经更进一步。例如，安理国际律师事务所 (Allen & Overy) 在 2017 年推出了其“科技创新中心”Fuse。这家位于伦敦总部的充满活力的机构即将迎来第六届年度法律科技、监管科技和交易科技领域的初创企业。同年，同样在伦敦，Mishcon de Reya 律师事务所宣布成立 MDR Labs，这是一个法律科技孵化器，致力于“致力于变革法律行业的早期公司”。

Alerted no doubt by these figures, some law firms have recently taken a more active interest in start-ups, and not just by monitoring their progress. Some act as their legal advisers, others mentor founders, yet others invest, and a few act as informal incubators and accelerators. A small number of law firms have gone further. In 2017, for example, Allen & Overy launched Fuse, its ‘tech innovation hub’. This lively space in the firm’s London headquarters is shortly to host its sixth annual cohort of start-ups working in lawtech, regtech, and dealtech. In the same year, and also in London, the law firm Mishcon de Reya, announced MDR Labs as a lawtech incubator dedicated to ‘early-stage companies who are trying to transform the legal industry’.

其他领先的专业公司也纷纷效仿：例如，Slaughter and May 有一个名为 Collaborate 的法律科技项目，将开发人员和客户聚集在一起；在西班牙，普华永道和微软最近联手创建了 Springboard，这是一个面向欧洲公司的税务技术和法律科技加速器。
