Other leading professional firms have followed: for example, Slaughter and May has a lawtech programme called Collaborate, which brings developers and clients together, and in Spain, PwC and Microsoft joined forces recently to create Springboard, which is a tax technology and lawtech accelerator for European companies.

在学术界，多伦多都市大学（原瑞尔森大学）的法律创新区核心地带设有一个法律科技孵化器，该孵化器于2015年年中成立。各国政府也对法律科技初创企业表现出积极的兴趣。例如，在英国，LawtechUK是一项由政府资助的计划，旨在推动法律科技的更广泛应用。其“沙盒计划”将初创企业与潜在用户和合作伙伴联系起来，并提供监管和数据源访问方面的帮助。同样，在新加坡，政府支持的未来法律创新计划（FLIP）也致力于孵化和加速法律科技企业的发展。

In the academic world, a lawtech incubator sits at the heart of the Legal Innovation Zone at Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University), set up back in mid-2015. Governments are also taking an active interest in lawtech start-ups. In the UK, for instance, LawtechUK is a government-funded initiative that promotes the greater uptake of legal technology. Its Sandbox Programme connects start-ups with potential users and collaborators. It also offers help with regulation and in securing access to data sources. Likewise, in Singapore, its government-backed FLIP (Future Law Innovation Programme) helps incubate and accelerate lawtech businesses.

范围

Scope

这些法律科技初创公司将为市场带来哪些新系统和服务？以下应用程序（排名不分先后）我认为占主导地位的领域包括法规与合规、在线法律研究、实践管理、电子取证、文档分析、合同生命周期管理、合同起草、电子学习、工作流、法律自助服务、法律诊断、案件管理和交易管理。主要的赋能技术包括人工智能、机器学习、自然语言处理、区块链，以及更通俗易懂的协作和工作流系统。

What new systems and services are these lawtech start-ups bringing to the market? In no particular order, the application areas that I see as dominating are regulation and compliance, online legal research, practice management, e-discovery, document analysis, contract life-cycle management, contract drafting, e-learning, workflow, legal self-service, legal diagnostics, case management, and transaction management. The main enabling technologies are artificial intelligence, machine learning, natural language processing, alongside blockchain and, more prosaically, collaboration and workflow systems.

进一步深入研究，最常见的焦点是合同。这里的术语范围广泛：数字化、自动化和电子化协议；某种意义上“智能”、“更智能”、“自动执行”甚至“智能化”的合同——对合同进行拼接、拆分和定价的新方式。在实践中，这意味着各种系统，用于谈判、共同创作、批准、起草、生成、验证、签名、时间戳、注册、存储、托管、共享、搜索、导航、分析、审查、查询、标准化、模板化、比较、提取、预测、汇总、自助服务、商业化、创建工作流、管理生命周期等等。这些炒作、夸张，甚至语法，或令人欣慰，或令人恼火，这取决于你的角度。然而，无论从哪个角度来看，所有这些都与纸笔和羊皮纸相去甚远。

Dipping down further, the most common focus is on contracts. The terminology here is wide-ranging: digital, automated, and electronic agreements; contracts that are in some sense ‘smart’, ‘smarter’, ‘self-executing’, and even ‘intelligent’—new ways to splice, dice, and price contracts. In practice, this means systems variously for negotiating, co-authoring, approving, drafting, generating, authenticating, signing, timestamping, registering, storing, hosting, sharing, searching, navigating, analysing, reviewing, querying, standardizing, templating, comparing, extracting, predicting, summarizing, self-servicing, commercializing, creating workflows, managing lifecycles, and more. The hype, the hyperbole, and even the grammar are heart-warming or exasperating, depending on your angle. On any view, though, all of this is some distance from quill and parchment.

影响

Impact

为了展现法律科技初创企业的雄心和精神，我过去常说，它们都在试图对法律领域做出亚马逊对图书销售所做的贡献。但现在我认为这种说法并不准确。关于更详细的分析表明，只有一小部分（我估计大约四分之一）的初创企业试图给法律世界带来剧变和变革。用克莱顿·克里斯坦森（Clayton Christensen ）（第六章）的话来说，“维持型”初创企业比“颠覆型”初创企业多得多。我的意思是，大多数法律科技初创企业致力于开发的系统和服务从广义上来说是为了增强而不是取代传统的法律服务。当今大多数法律科技初创企业的目标客户是律师事务所，而且一般来说是规模较大的律师事务所而不是规模较小的律师事务所。这是完全可以理解的。正如我在第一章中指出的那样，法律科技支出的最大份额来自律师事务所，因此，对于创始人来说，开发那些很可能在支出模式成熟的市场中取得成功的系统具有良好的商业意义。

To convey the ambition and spirit of lawtech start-ups, I used to say that each is trying to do to law what Amazon has done to bookselling. I now regard this as inaccurate. On more detailed analysis, it transpires that only a fraction—in my estimation about one-quarter—of these start-ups are seeking to bring upheaval and transformation in the world of law. In the language of Clayton Christensen (Chapter 6), there are still many more ‘sustaining’ than ‘disruptive’ start-ups. By this I mean that most of the lawtech start-ups are working on systems and services that, in broad terms, enhance rather than replace traditional legal service. The target customers of most of today’s lawtech start-ups are law firms and, generally, larger rather than smaller practices. This is entirely understandable. As I note in Chapter 1, the lion’s share of spend on lawtech comes from law firms, and so it makes good business sense for founders to develop systems that are likely to land well in a market with well-established patterns of expenditure.

举几个鲜明的例子——那些为律师事务所提供新工具（例如时间记录、冲突搜索、现金流改进和客户关系管理）的初创公司并没有重新定义法律市场。这些工具可能对用户来说非常宝贵，并且可能获得巨大的商业成功，但它们并非法律界的“亚马逊”。此外，正如上文所述，许多专注于合同的初创公司也推出了系统。这些系统大多数面向律师事务所，很少有系统专供内部法务部门、小型企业和个人使用。同样，我也能理解这其中的商业良知，但当律师事务所使用能够帮助他们更高效地谈判和起草协议的系统时，这是一个自动化案例，而非颠覆性创新（这些术语的具体含义已在第一章中讨论过）。相比之下，一些初创公司提供的系统使企业能够自行处理合同的准备、流程和执行，而无需或尽量减少律师的参与。这些举措具有颠覆性。它们不会延续旧有的做法。它们让我们看到了一个新世界的景象，一个律师参与程度更低的世界，但企业可以自行管理法律风险的世界。

To pick a few clear-cut examples—start-ups that offer law firms new tools for, say, time recording, conflict search, cash flow improvement, and customer relationship management are not redefining the legal market. These tools may be invaluable for their users and may enjoy great commercial success but they are not Amazon-in-law. Consider also the many systems from start-ups that focus on contracts, as discussed above. Most of these are directed at law firms, with far fewer for exclusive use by in-house legal departments, smaller businesses, and individuals. Again, I can see the commercial good sense here, but when law firms use systems that help them negotiate and draft agreements more efficiently, this is a case study in automation rather than disruptive innovation (using these terms in the specific senses discussed in Chapter 1. By contrast, some start-ups are delivering systems that enable businesses to handle their own preparation, flow, and execution of contracts, with no or minimal involvement of lawyers. These are disruptive. They do not perpetuate age-old practices. They offer a glimpse of a new world, a less-lawyered world, but one in which businesses can manage their own legal risks.

法律科技初创企业专注于自动化而非创新，这重要吗？对于创始人和投资者来说，这或许无关紧要，但我预计，成功的颠覆性创新者比那些将技术嫁接到传统法律业务的初创企业更有可能成为未来的法律科技独角兽。颠覆性路线或许风险更大，但它或许是2020年代最有希望获得惊人回报的路线。

Does it matter that lawtech start-ups are automating more than innovating? For founders and investors, it may not, although I expect successful disruptive innovators will stand a better chance of becoming tomorrow’s lawtech unicorns than those start-ups that graft technology onto traditional legal businesses. The disruption route may be riskier but it is probably the most promising route in the 2020s for eye-watering returns.

对我以及我猜想的许多读者来说，关注创新而非自动化还有另一个原因。我们的法律和法院系统摇摇欲坠。有人会说它们已经崩溃——价格高昂且难以使用。我和其他人都希望，最优秀的法律科技初创企业将为我们提供工具，帮助我们解决这些问题。我想到两类能够改变游戏规则的初创企业。首先，会有一些企业真正颠覆并消除对传统律师供应链的需求。本着亚马逊、优步和爱彼迎的精神，我们期待着革命性法律服务的伟大到来。这里的主要目标本身并不是消除律师，尽管这在某种程度上可能是其后果。主要目标，即驱动力，是应对第一章概述的“少花钱多办事”的挑战。主要目标是帮助客户。

For me and, I suspect, for many readers, focusing on innovation more than automation matters for another reason. Our legal and court systems are creaking. Some would say they are broken—unaffordable and inaccessible. And the hope that I and others harbour is that the best of the lawtech start-ups will give us the tools to help us fix these problems. I have in mind two game-changing categories of start-up. First, there will be those that genuinely do disrupt and obviate the need for the traditional supply chain of traditional lawyers. In the spirit of Amazon, Uber, and Airbnb, we await the great coming of revolutionized legal service. The primary aim here is not of itself to eliminate lawyers, although this may to some extent be the consequence. The primary aim, the driving imperative, is to meet the ‘more-for-less’ challenge as outlined in Chapter 1. The primary aim is to help clients.

我再说一遍：大多数主流律师和法官无法想象任何一家初创企业（或者说是新兴企业）会发起一场革命。从根本上说，这是想象力的缺失。

I say again: most mainstream lawyers and judges cannot imagine a revolution being initiated by any start-up (or indeed upstart). At root, this is a failure of imagination.

我的第二类改变游戏规则的法律科技初创企业将有助于解决司法公正问题（见第 12 章）。这里与第一类有一些重叠，因为一些传统的提供商确实在努力提供和增加访问量。但这其中巨大的机遇在于开发当今人类无法获得的法律和法庭服务的系统和服务。这里的挑战在于，我们如何利用互联网、移动技术和人工智能显著且稳步增长的覆盖面，帮助更多的人了解他们的合法权利，并在法律和法庭的支持下行使这些权利？我们需要能够提供各种在线法律指导的技术，以及能够通过视频听证和异步流程（参见第14章）在​​线远程开展司法工作的技术。我相信一些初创企业将满足这些需求，他们的系统和服务反过来将解放“潜在的法律市场”（第15章）。

My second category of game-changing lawtech start-ups will help solve the access to justice problems (see Chapter 12). There is some overlap here with the first category, in that some traditional providers do indeed strive to offer and increase access. But the gargantuan opportunity here is to develop systems and services where today legal and court service is beyond the reach of humanity. The challenge here is to ask how can we use the remarkable and steadily increasing reach of the internet, mobile technologies, and artificial intelligence to help many more people to understand their legal rights and enforce these with the backing of the law and courts? We will need technologies that can provide online legal guidance of various sorts as well as technologies that can enable the conduct of judicial work remotely on an online basis—by video hearing and by asynchronous processes (see Chapter 14). I have confidence that some start-ups will meet these needs and their systems and services will in turn liberate the ‘latent legal market’ (Chapter 15).

我确实非常相信初创企业能够提供这些颠覆性的解决方案。就企业精神而言，我认为法律科技初创企业群体是法律界最具活力和启发性的领域。摆脱传统的束缚，创始人应该能够构想出与当今截然不同的法律服务。他们可以挑战传统的假设。他们可以在尊重法律的同时打破现有的界限。最重要的是，他们可以以需要法律帮助和支持的人的需求为驱动力，而不是以现有的服务提供商为驱动力。

I do put much of my faith in start-ups to deliver these game-changing solutions. In terms of ethos, I find the lawtech start-up community to be the most energetic and inspiring corner of the legal world. Free from the shackles of tradition, the founders should be able to imagine legal services that are quite unlike today’s. They can challenge conventional assumptions. They can disrespect current boundaries while maintaining respect for the law. Above all, they can be driven by the needs of those who need legal help and support rather than by those who are the incumbent providers.

我并不认为法律领域会出现单一的 Uber 或 eBay（法律领域有太多的分支和服务类型，无法简化为一个系统或应用程序），但我确实预计各种突破将结合起来改变法律市场。

I do not expect there will be a single Uber or eBay in law (the legal field has too many branches and service types to be reduced to one system or app), but I do expect that a variety of breakthroughs will in combination transform the legal market.

11变革的时机

11 The Timing of the Changes

我经常被问及我预测的变化可能在何时发生。一些评论员和律师认为，这些变化已经到来，法律界将在几年内发生巨变。另一些人则认为，这些转变将以更缓慢的速度推进，革命的完成还需要几十年的时间。我相信，我们既不会目睹一场大爆炸式的革命，也不会经历一场缓慢的演变。相反，我一直预计变革将逐步展开，分为三个阶段——否认、重新获取资源和颠覆（见图11.1）。

I am often asked to indicate the likely time scales of the changes that I predict. Some commentators and lawyers believe these changes are already upon us and that the legal world will have transformed within a couple of years. Others maintain that the shifts will progress at a more plodding rate and that it will be some decades before the revolution is complete. I believe that we will witness neither a big bang revolution nor a slow burn evolution. Instead I have always expected an incremental transformation to unfold, in three stages—denial, re-sourcing, and disruption (see Figure 11.1).

我并非暗示所有律所和内部法务部门都会齐头并进地经历这三个阶段。一些先驱者会取得更快的进展，而许多落后者则需要更长的时间才能取得进展。与所有模型一样，这个模型也是一种简化。其目的是大致了解大多数大型律所和内部法务部门的前进顺序。它们的前进速度无法精确预测；这在很大程度上取决于经济状况、客户需求强度、……的影响等因素。市场上是否有新的竞争对手，以及是否有少数公司在改变法律服务提供方式方面发挥积极带头作用。

I am not suggesting that all law firms and in-house legal departments will move evenly through these three stages in concert. Some pioneers will progress far more rapidly, while there will be laggards aplenty who will take much longer to advance. Like all models, this one is a simplification. Its purpose is to give a broad sense of the order in which most large law firms and in-house legal departments will move forward. The speed with which they move cannot be predicted with precision; this will depend largely on factors such as the state of the economy, the intensity of the demands made by clients, the impact of new competitors on the market, and whether or not a few firms take a positive lead in changing the way that legal services are delivered.

图 11.1变化的三个阶段。

FIGURE 11.1 The three stages of change.

第一阶段——否认

Stage 1—Denial

这一阶段大约从2007年持续到2016年。在此期间，大多数律师，无论是律所律师还是法务律师，都希望回到2006年。然而，到了2016年，我遇到的法律界领袖中，很少有人否认根本性变革正在发生。人们普遍认为，过去的时代已经过去了——那个许多律师事务所的工作量超出了他们的能力，而且还有一个额外的好处，那就是对价格不敏感。

This stage ran from around 2007 to 2016. During this period, most lawyers, both in firms and in-house, wished it were 2006 again. By 2016, however, very few legal leaders with whom I met were denying that fundamental change was afoot. It was widely acknowledged that the old times had passed—the era when many law firms had more work than they could handle, with the added benefit that it was not price sensitive.

至于内部法务部门，尽管在全球经济衰退（2007-2009年）之前，有迹象表明他们需要考虑勒紧裤腰带，但他们在组织内部通常并没有面临巨大的削减开支压力。金融危机之前，那是一个物资充裕的时期。那是一个卖方市场，而买方的钱包鼓鼓（至少表面上如此）。

As for in-house legal departments, although there were hints before the global recession (2007–2009) that they would need to think about tightening their belts, they were generally not under great pressure within their organizations to spend less. Before the financial crisis, it was a time of abundance. It was a sellers’ market and the buyers’ purses were brimming (or so it seemed).

2007 年，随着经济衰退和随后的危机，如第一章所述，少花钱多办事的挑战明显拉开帷幕，我们也开始了近十年的否认。许多总法律顾问 (GC) 的最初反应是寻求降低法律费用，但不是通过从根本上改变自己的内部运营和采购策略，而是要求外部律师事务所大幅降低费用。在许多情况下，这是通过竞争性招标程序相当正式地完成的。因此，大多数律师事务所提出了各种替代费用安排 (AFA)，同时也裁减了许多律师（从初级律师到合伙人）和支持人员，并减少了在技术和营销等后台职能上的支出。

In 2007, with the economic downturn and then crisis, came the clear start of the more-for-less challenge, as introduced in Chapter 1, and we were also at the beginning of almost a decade of denial. The initial response of many General Counsel (GCs) was to seek to reduce their legal expenses, not by fundamentally changing their own internal operations and sourcing strategies but by asking their external law firms for significant reductions in fees. This was done fairly formally in many cases through competitive tendering processes. In turn, most law firms proposed a variety of alternative fee arrangements (AFAs) while also making many lawyers (from junior lawyers through to partners) and support staff redundant, and spending less on back-office functions such as technology and marketing.

事实上，在这一否认阶段，大多数内部法律部门和律师事务所都渴望安然度过这场风暴，避免发生重大动荡：内部律师希望维持其员工人数，而律师事务所则努力通过（非基本）削减来维持其盈利能力。

In truth, most in-house legal departments and law firms were eager during this stage of denial to weather the storm without major upheaval: in-house lawyers hoped to maintain their headcount, while law firms strove, through (non-fundamental) cuts, to maintain their profitability.

在第一阶段，一些律所采取了一种象征性的做法——他们参与了一些规模不大的替代采购，但主要是为了做做样子。他们的目的是构建一个可信的叙述，以便传达给那些询问其成本削减策略的客户。更深层次的目的是为了时间。这是一种拖延策略，希望市场能够复苏，客户不再迫切需要减少律师事务所的开支。

During this first stage, some law firms engaged in tokenism of a kind—they partook of some modest alternative sourcing, but largely as a matter of show. Their purpose was to construct a credible narrative to relay to those clients who inquired as to their cost-cutting strategies. The deeper purpose was to play for time. This was a stalling strategy, adopted in the hope that the market would return and clients would no longer have an urgent need to spend less on law firms.

与此同时，一些内部律师认为，对他们来说，解决办法是扩大内部部门的规模，理由是内部律师的成本低于律所的法律专家。事实证明，这种做法在策略上存在缺陷。这种方法会对内部律师的繁忙程度做出不切实际的假设。此外，供给通常会增加需求，因此招聘一名内部律师通常会导致该律师要求一名助理，然后是一个团队。而且，无论如何，扩大内部律师的能力通常都回到了过时的观点，即只有两种法律工作来源——在部门内部或通过律所——从而忽略了其他来源的可能性。

At the same time, some in-house lawyers argued that the answer for them was to increase the size of their in-house departments on the ground that in-house lawyers cost less than legal specialists in law firms. This often proved to be tactically flawed. It is an approach that can make unrealistic assumptions about how fully occupied the in-house lawyers will be. Also, supply often increases demand so that recruiting one in-house lawyer often leads to that person asking for an assistant and then a team. And, in any event, growing the in-house capability is often to fall back on the outmoded view that there are only two ways of sourcing legal work—within a department or through a law firm—and so ignores the possibility of alternative sourcing.

总而言之，在第一阶段，大多数（但绝非全部）律师否认法律市场正在发生根本性和结构性变化。他们假设，或者祈祷，当经济形势好转、业务改善时，法律界会恢复到2006年左右的运作模式。但这并没有发生，主要是因为那些经营客户业务的人发现，法律成本可以得到更严格的管理，法律工作可以以不同的方式、更高效地开展，因此他们不希望回到过去那种低效的状态。

In summary, in this first stage, most (but by no means all) lawyers denied that fundamental and structural changes were at play within the legal marketplace. They assumed, or prayed, that when the economic tide turned and business improved, the legal world would return to its modus operandi of around 2006. This did not happen, largely because those who were running client businesses saw that legal costs could be managed more tightly, that legal work could be undertaken differently and more efficiently, and so they had no appetite for a return to the old inefficiencies.

第二阶段——重新采购

Stage 2—Re-sourcing

在拒绝阶段，首席执行官和董事会注意到，法律成本并不总是按预期大幅下降。尽管法律顾问曾乐观地向首席财务官谈到降低小时费率并采用替代收费方案后，显然承诺的降低并未兑现。无论是公司内部律师还是律所律师，都意识到他们需要从差异化定价转向差异化工作方式。这是从第一阶段向第二阶段的转变。大多数法律机构仍处于第二阶段，而有些机构正逐步迈向第三阶段。

During the stage of denial, chief executives and boards noticed that legal costs did not always plummet as requested. Although GCs had spoken optimistically to chief finance officers about reductions in hourly rates and alternative fee arrangements, it became clear that the promised reductions were not materializing. Lawyers, both in-house and in firms, recognized that they needed to move from pricing differently to working differently. This was a move from the first to the second stage. Most legal organizations are still in this second stage, while some are edging towards the third.

在第二阶段，法律总顾问仅仅忽视自己部门的低效率是不够的。正如他们要求律师事务所寻找其他方式来承接过去由初级律师以高小时费率完成的常规工作一样，他们也需要在自己的法律业务中应用同样的方法。因此，律师事务所和公司内部法律部门都分析了他们的法律工作，并确定了最直接、程序性和行政性活动和任务可以以不同方式承接的方法，无论是通过外包、离岸外包、使用律师助理、计算机化还是部署第5 章中列出的各种承接策略。公司内部部门也开始表现出更多彼此合作的兴趣，以合作策略中预期的方式分担法律服务成本（第 3 章）。

It has not sufficed, in this second stage, for GCs to ignore the inefficiencies in their own departments. Just as they have asked law firms to find alternative ways of sourcing the routine work that used to be done at high hourly rates by junior lawyers, so too they have needed to apply this same approach within their own legal businesses. Both law firms and in-house legal departments have therefore analysed their legal work and identified ways in which the most straightforward, procedural, and administrative-based activities and tasks could be sourced differently, whether by outsourcing, off-shoring, using paralegals, computerizing, or deploying any of the various sourcing strategies laid out in Chapter 5. In-house departments have also begun to show an interest in collaborating more with one another, in sharing the costs of legal services in the manner anticipated in the collaboration strategy (Chapter 3).

此外，在这一阶段，法律行业的替代性服务提供商——法律流程外包商、出版商、律师事务所、会计师事务所、私募股权支持的初创企业等等——在法律服务的提供中扮演着更重要的角色。虽然从未出现过转折点，但我们已开始见证律师事务所新一轮竞争的加剧。

Also during this stage, the alternative providers of services to the legal profession—legal process outsourcers, publishers, law companies, accounting firms, private equity-backed start-ups, and many more—have come to play a more significant role in the delivery of legal services. There has never been a tipping point, but we have begun to witness an upsurge in new competition for law firms.

此外，在第二阶段，许多律师事务所和公司内部部门已经找到了以更低成本运营自身后台部门（例如技术和会计）的方法。有些公司甚至采用了业务流程外包或共享服务设施。

Additionally, in this second stage, many law firms and in-house departments have found ways of running their own back offices (technology and accounts, for example) at far lower cost. Some have resorted to business process outsourcing or shared services facilities.

在第二阶段，企业内部法务部门对法律需求分析和法律风险管理的兴趣也日益增长。企业所有者和领导者希望更清楚地了解其紧急且不可避免的法律支出，并将法律支出限制在这些支出上。

In this second stage, there has also been a growing interest by in-house legal departments in legal needs analysis and legal risk management. Owners and leaders of businesses have wanted to have a far clearer sense of their urgent and unavoidable legal expenses and to move towards confining their legal spend to these alone.

第三阶段——颠覆

Stage 3—Disruption

在第二阶段，替代性外包通常是通过要求法律工作由成本较低的劳动力来完成的。实际上，这是一种劳动力套利，并带来了显著的成本节约。然而，让成本较低的人员通过剧本或基本的自动化来承担法律工作，肯定不是法律市场演变的最终结果。

In Stage 2, alternative sourcing has generally been achieved by requiring legal work to be undertaken by lower-cost labour. Effectively, this has been a form of labour arbitrage, and it has resulted in notable savings. However, having less costly people undertake legal work, with playbooks or basic automation, is certainly not the end-game in the evolution of the legal marketplace.

一些更先进的律所和部门已进入第三阶段，这将带来更为彻底的转型。这将是2020年代大多数成功法律企业所走的道路，并将通过引入功能日益强大的系统来实现。总的来说，这些技术将具有颠覆性，也就是说，它们将挑战并取代过去传统的法律工作方式。

Some more advanced firms and departments have moved into Stage 3, which will bring much more radical transformation. This will be the path followed by the majority of successful legal businesses of the 2020s, and will be brought about by the introduction of increasingly capable systems. In the main, these technologies will be disruptive, that is, they will challenge and displace the traditional way in which legal work has been done in the past.

许多律师和评论员未能意识到，诸如法律流程外包 (LPO) 和法律管理服务等服务（它们主要使用低成本劳动力）注定只是权宜之计，而非长远之计。如果我们思考一下，除了律师事务所和法务部门之外，还有两类通常被认为适合外包的服务——诉讼中的文件审查和基本合同起草——这两类服务最终都会被性能超越初级律师和行政人员的高效系统所取代。这些法律工作领域的特点使其适合外包——它们可以被分解成易于管理的部分，并且可以在详细程序或剧本的帮助下由训练有素但相对缺乏技能的人员完成——也正是这些工作的特点使其易于应用技术。因此，用于电子披露的技术辅助审查可以轻松胜过许多在诉讼中进行文件审查的人员。 （广义上讲，电子披露或电子披露涉及争议各方让对方知道相关的电子存储文件的存在。）同样，文档自动化已经比经验不足的律师和管理人员更可靠、更高效地运行。

Many lawyers and commentators fail to recognize that services such as legal process outsourcing (LPO) and managed legal services, where they largely use low-cost labour, were always destined to be temporary measures and not long-term solutions. If we think of two classes of service that are typically considered to be suitable for outsourcing beyond law firms and legal departments—document review in litigation and basic contract drafting—both of these will in due course be replaced by capable systems that can outperform junior lawyers and administrative staff. The very features of these areas of legal work that make them suitable for outsourcing—that they can be broken down into manageable parts, and that they can be discharged by well-trained but relatively unskilled human beings with the assistance of detailed procedures or playbooks—are also precisely the features of work that make them amenable to the application of technology. Thus, technology-assisted review used for electronic disclosure can comfortably outperform many human beings who conduct document review in litigation. (Electronic disclosure, or e-disclosure, broadly speaking, involves parties to a dispute letting one another know about the existence of relevant, electronically stored documents.) And, likewise, document automation already operates more reliably and efficiently than modestly experienced lawyers and administrators.

颠覆性技术的广泛部署代表着法律服务的终结，尽管即便如此，正如第一章所述，科技世界也永无止境。长远来看，越来越多的法律工作能够、也将会由高性能系统承担，而其用户则将进行少量的监督。这将是未来律师职业和工作生活的背景和背景。

The widespread and pervasive deployment of disruptive technologies represents the end-game for legal service although, even then, as noted in Chapter 1, there is no finishing line in the world of technology. In the long run, increasing amounts of legal work can and will be taken on by highly capable systems, with light supervision by the human beings who are their users. This will be the context and backdrop of the careers and working lives of tomorrow’s lawyers.

这些颠覆性技术不仅将主导实体法律工作，还将主导法律服务提供商（包括人工和系统）的选择方式。比价系统、信誉系统和法律服务在线拍卖（参见第六章）将被频繁使用，从而创建一个与数十年来一直存在的传统法律交易基础截然不同的电子法律市场。

These disruptive technologies will come to dominate not just in substantive legal work but also in the way that providers of legal services (both humans and systems) are selected. Price comparison systems, reputation systems, and online auctions for legal services (see Chapter 6) will be used frequently, creating an electronic legal marketplace quite unlike the traditional basis of legal trading that has endured for decades and more.

这并不意味着到2020年代中期，强大的系统就会取代所有法律工作。当然不会。但从那时起，所有规模庞大且成功的法律企业都将逐步将其业务流程从人工操作转变为更加复杂、更强大的基于技术的流程，这将成为整个法律行业的普遍现象。我们已经在经济的许多其他领域见证了类似的变化，因此没有理由认为法律应该免受技术的影响。如果类似的技术能够改变医疗和审计的实践，那么律师也应该对类似的变革持开放态度。

It is not that capable systems will replace all legal work by, say, the mid-2020s. Of course not. But around that time and from then on it will become commonplace across the legal profession for all substantial and successful legal businesses to be converting their business processes from human handcrafting to ever more sophisticated and capable technology-based production. We have seen such changes in many other sectors of our economy and there is no reason to think that the law should be immune from technology. If analogous technologies can transform the practice of medicine and audit, then lawyers should be open to similar overhaul.

一个与当今截然不同的法律世界即将出现。大多数年轻律师都将步入这个世界。对于那些渴望拥有与父母那一代律师类似的职业的有抱负的律师来说，他们将会感到失望。对于那些寻求新机遇并希望参与实现我在本书中预测的进步的人来说，我相信这是一个前所未有的激动人心的时刻。

A legal world will emerge that is manifestly different from today’s. And it is into this world that most young lawyers will be stepping. For those aspiring lawyers who hoped for a career akin to that enjoyed by lawyers of their parents’ generation, they will be disappointed. For those who seek new opportunities and wish to participate in bringing about the advances that I predict in this book, I believe there has never been a more exciting time.

12司法救助和在线法律服务

12 Access to Justice and Online Legal Services

2000年，我在《法律转型》一书中预测，五年内，英国能够访问互联网的人数将超过能够获得司法公正的人数。不幸的是，事实证明我是正确的。今天，正如我稍后将要解释的，只有不到3%的英国人实际上被排除在互联网之外，而英格兰和威尔士的大多数公民无力承担大部分律师和法院的服务费用。正如我长期以来所宣称的，好消息是，技术将在克服日益严重的司法公正问题中发挥关键作用。我在本章中的目的就是展示这将如何实现。

In 2000, in my book Transforming the Law, I predicted that within five years, more people in the UK would have access to the Internet than access to justice. Unfortunately, I was proven correct. Today, as I explain shortly, less than 3 per cent of British people are effectively excluded from the Internet, whereas the majority of citizens in England and Wales are unable to afford most of the services of lawyers and of the courts. The good news, as I have for long claimed, is that technology will be pivotal in overcoming many of the growing problems of access to justice. My aim in this chapter is to show how this might come to pass.

获得司法公正

Access to Justice

弗朗茨·卡夫卡在《审判》中以令人难忘的场景为背景。他讲述了一位守门人莫名其妙地拒绝让一个人接触法律的故事。这位不幸的乡下人并没有料到会遇到任何问题。毕竟，他认为“法律应该随时随地为所有人所用”。人们或许会这么想，但几年前在英格兰和威尔士进行的一项研究得出的结论是：每年约有100万个民事司法问题得不到解决。这种法律排斥或法律需求得不到满足是一个严重的社会问题，被笼统地称为“司法救助”问题。

Franz Kafka sets the scene hauntingly in The Trial. He tells of a gatekeeper who inexplicably refuses to grant a man access to the law. This unfortunate man from the country had not expected any problems. After all, he thinks, ‘the law should be accessible to everyone at all times’. So it might be thought, but research in England and Wales conducted a few years ago concluded that around 1 million civil justice problems go unresolved each year. This legal exclusion or unmet legal need is a grave social problem and is loosely referred to as the ‘access to justice’ problem.

放眼更广阔的视野，如今除了法律体系中一些细枝末节之外，无人能自诩精通其他任何事物。然而，法律规定，我们每个人都被认为掌握了所有影响自身的法律条文。鉴于大多数公民并不了解大部分法律，也无力承担传统的法律咨询费用，我们似乎处于一种相当危险的境地。当人们考虑通过法院系统采取行动时，这个问题或许最为突出。从外行人的角度来看，法院不仅费用高昂，而且耗时耗力，争执不休，程序和语言也莫名其妙地晦涩难懂。正是考虑到这些问题，时任上议院法官、后来担任英格兰和威尔士首席大法官的伍尔夫勋爵于1995年和1996年发表了两份关于民事司法体系未来的开创性报告《司法途径》。伍尔夫勋爵的职责范围仅限于争议的解决。自此以后，对许多法官和政策制定者来说，改善司法途径的理念就意味着改善和加快法庭解决纠纷的方式。

Thinking more widely for a moment, no-one today can pretend to have mastery over anything other than small parts of our legal system. And yet every one of us, under the law, is taken to have knowledge of all legal provisions that affect us. Given that most citizens do not know most of the law and cannot afford to obtain conventional legal advice, we seem to be in a rather parlous state. The problem perhaps comes most sharply into focus when people contemplate taking an action through the court system. From a lay perspective, as well as appearing to be unaffordable, the courts seem to be excessively time-consuming, unjustifiably combative, and inexplicably steeped in opaque procedure and language. It was with such problems in mind that in 1995 and 1996, Lord Woolf, then a Law Lord and later the Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales, published ‘Access to Justice’, his two seminal reports on the future of the civil justice system. Lord Woolf’s terms of reference confined his attention to the resolution of disputes. And for many judges and policy-makers since, the idea of improving access to justice has come to mean improving and accelerating the way disputes are resolved in courts.

我的观点更为宽泛。我认为，在追求正义的过程中，如果完全甚至实质性地专注于争议解决，就会错失许多我们应当对法律体系抱有的期望。我认为，更便捷的司法途径不仅应该包括争议解决方面的改进，还应该包括我所说的争议控制、争议避免和法律健康促进方面的改进。

I take a wider view. To be entirely or even substantially focused on dispute resolution in our pursuit of justice is, I claim, to miss much that we should expect of our legal systems. It is my contention that better access to justice should embrace improvements not just to dispute resolution but also to what I call dispute containment, dispute avoidance, and legal health promotion.

争议控制的重点在于防止已发生的分歧过度升级，律师和当事人本身都需要受到控制。避免争议是公司内部律师经常向我提出的一个话题：他们谈论法律风险管理，或者用我的话说，与其在悬崖边放救护车，不如在悬崖顶上建一道篱笆。我还没见过哪个普通人，无论是首席执行官还是消费者，宁愿让大型争议由律师妥善解决，也不愿一开始就不发生。法律健康促进的范畴不仅限于预防性地通过律师避免争议，还包括确保人们即使没有出现任何问题，也能了解并能够利用法律所能带来的诸多益处、改进和优势。

Dispute containment concentrates on preventing disagreements that have arisen from escalating excessively, and it is lawyers as well as the parties themselves who need to be contained. Dispute avoidance is a theme that in-house lawyers often raise with me: they speak of legal risk management or, as I put it, putting a fence at the top of a cliff rather than an ambulance at the bottom. I have yet to meet a regular human being, whether a chief executive or a consumer, who would prefer a large dispute well resolved by lawyers to not having one in the first place. Legal health promotion extends beyond the preventative lawyering of dispute avoidance to ensuring that people are aware of and able to take advantage of the many benefits, improvements, and advantages that the law can confer, even if no problem has arisen.

认可、选择和服务

Recognition, Selection, and Service

考虑到司法公正获取途径的这些不同维度，当我们反思非律师群体的困境时，故事情节会变得更加复杂。（顺便提一下“非律师”这个词，因为人们对这个标签非常不满。我完全同意，在律师事务所里，把整个员工群体归类为二等贡献者，这通常是不可接受的，也是令人不齿的。）

With these various dimensions of access to justice in mind, the plot thickens somewhat when we reflect on the plight of the non-lawyer. (Parenthetically, a word about the term, ‘non-lawyer’ because people get very exercised about the label. I wholly agree that it is generally disparaging and unacceptable within a law firm to pigeon-hole an entire community of employees in terms that suggest they are second-class contributors. Categorizing humans

（主要指他们不具备法律知识，这是不好的做法。）然而，在更广泛的语境下，超越法律组织的范围来谈论非律师，可以有力且不失尊重地强调，它所指的群体（大多数人）并不了解法律。）

primarily in terms of what they are not is bad practice. However, to speak of non-lawyers in a much wider context, beyond the confines legal organizations, can be a powerful and not disrespectful way of highlighting that the group to which it refers (most of humanity) are not knowledgeable about the law.)

对于非律师（后一种意义上的）来说，第一个障碍是认知，即毫无法律知识的人意识到自己可以从法律援助中受益的过程。有时这很明显——比如收到索赔，或者决定搬家。但非律师通常可能不知道自己正处于需要解决、控制或避免法律问题的境地，或者需要获得某种利益。矛盾的是，似乎只有成为一名律师才能知道自己是否以及何时可以从法律援助中受益。

The first obstacle for the non-lawyer (in this latter sense) is recognition, the process by which someone with no legal insight realizes that he or she would benefit from legal help. Sometimes it is obvious—when a claim arrives through the letterbox or a decision has been made to move house. But often non-lawyers may not know that they are in a situation in which there is a legal problem to be resolved, contained, avoided, or that there is some benefit to be secured. Paradoxically, it seems you need to be a lawyer to know if and when you would benefit from legal help.

第二个挑战是，即使我们的非律师已经认识到他或她将从法律帮助中受益，也要选择最佳的法律指导来源，无论是寻找合适的律师还是其他类型的顾问，甚至是在线帮助。

The second challenge, even if our non-lawyer has recognized that he or she would benefit from legal help, is to select the best source of legal guidance, whether that be finding a suitable lawyer or some other kind of adviser or even online help.

第三个维度是法律服务本身的提供。在这里，我们发现人们在所谓的多源环境中面临着广泛的选择（参见第五章）。关于这第三个挑战，我认为传统律师事务所的传统律师并不总是为客户提供最佳或最经济指导的最佳人选。公共法律资金的持续削减（部分原因是经济状况）似乎不可避免地会导致法律和法庭服务的价格越来越低，获取难度也越来越大。一项重大而紧迫的社会挑战是找到提供法律援助的新途径，尤其是向公民和小型企业提供法律援助。

The third dimension is the delivery of legal service itself. And here we find the wide range of options that people now face in what I call a multi-sourcing environment (see Chapter 5). In relation to this third challenge, I do not believe that conventional lawyers in traditional law firms are always the best placed or most affordable sources of guidance for clients. It seems almost inevitable that ongoing cuts in public legal funding, brought about in part by economic conditions, will lead to legal and court services that are steadily less affordable and less accessible. A major and urgent social challenge is to find new ways of providing legal help, not least to citizens and to small businesses.

在线法律服务

Online Legal Services

律师提供法律援助的一个明显替代方案是，由受过培训且通常自愿的非律师为人们提供建议他们的问题、权利和责任。例如，在英国，公民咨询服务正是这样做的，但它也面临资源匮乏的问题。另一个选择是为公民和企业提供在线法律资源，以便他们能够自行处理部分法律事务；或者，当需要指导时，他们可以更有效地与法律顾问合作。如果我们能够拥有国家提供的在线服务，提供广泛的医疗指导（例如，访问< http://www.nhs.uk >），那么为什么不在法律领域也提供类似的服务呢？

One clear alternative to the provision of legal help by lawyers is for trained and often voluntary non-lawyers to advise people on their problems, rights, and responsibilities. In the UK, for instance, the Citizens Advice service does precisely this but it too suffers from lack of resources. Another option is to provide citizens and businesses with online legal resources so that they can take care of some of their legal affairs on their own; or, when guidance is needed, they can work more efficiently with their legal advisers. If we can have state-provided online services that provide broad medical guidance (e.g., at <http://www.nhs.uk>) why not have something similar for law?

持怀疑态度的人应该记住，在线服务通常已不再仅仅局限于少数高科技人士。相反，互联网如今已成为英格兰和威尔士大多数家庭和企业生活的中心。大多数研究表明，目前约有95%的英国人口都是各种类型的互联网用户。剩下的5%当然也很重要，但正如牛津互联网研究所（其“英国互联网”研究）所指出的，这些非互联网用户（或前互联网用户）中，只有一小部分“肯定不认识”可以帮助他们的人。实际上，这意味着目前只有不到3%的人无法获得帮助——不到三十分之一的人是无人可以代其使用在线服务的非互联网用户。这个比例比通常认为的要小。

Sceptics should bear in mind that online services generally are no longer just for a high-tech minority. On the contrary, the Internet is now central to the lives of the majority of families and businesses in England and Wales. Most studies suggest that around 95 per cent of the British population are now Internet users of one sort or another. The remaining 5 per cent are, of course, important, but as research at the Oxford Internet Institute (its ‘Internet in Britain’ studies) has pointed out, only a fraction of these non-users (or ex-users) ‘definitely don’t know’ someone who could assist them. In practice, this means less than 3 per cent are currently out of reach—fewer than one in 30 people are non-users who have no-one who can use online services on their behalf. This is a smaller percentage than is often supposed.

至于在线法律设施，目前主要有三种形式：第一，各种商业和非营利组织提供的免费网络服务；第二，传统律师事务所提供的订阅式工具；第三，其他企业提供的收费服务，如替代商业结构或法律出版商。

As for online legal facilities, these currently come in three main forms: first, as free Web-based services, provided by a variety of commercial and not-for-profit organizations; second, as subscription-based tools from conventional law firms; and, third, as chargeable offerings from other businesses, such as alternative business structures or legal publishers.

那么，在实践中，在线服务究竟如何才能在我所提到的各个方面真正帮助确保获得司法公正呢？首先，为了解决前面提到的最初障碍，技术可以并且将继续发挥作用，帮助非律师人士认识到他们可能从某种法律意见中受益。一种方法是让人们登记他们的社会和工作利益，当有新的法律出台或旧法发生变化时，法律警报会自动发送给他们。另一种方法是在线分类——当公民有某种申诉时，一个简单的在线诊断系统可以询问一系列问题，要求勾选一些方框，然后就可以识别用户是否有法律问题，如果有，则识别出是哪种类型的问题。

In practice, then, how might online services actually help to secure access to justice in all the various aspects I note? In the first instance, addressing the initial obstacle noted earlier, technology can and will continue to be of use in assisting non-lawyers to recognize that they might benefit from some kind of legal input. One approach will be for people to register their social and working interests and for legal alerts to be delivered automatically to them when there are new laws or changes in old law that apply to them. Another tack will be online triage—when a citizen has a grievance of some sort, a simple online diagnostic system could ask a series of questions, require some boxes to be ticked, and could then identify if the user has a legal issue, and if so, of what sort.

第六章提到，另一种可能性是将法律规则嵌入到系统和程序中。以纸牌游戏为例。我小时候，我们用原子（扑克牌）玩这个游戏。使用这些扑克牌时，可以将红色 4 放在红色 5 下面，尽管这显然违反了规则。但这在物理上是可能的。相反，当你在电脑上玩纸牌游戏时，这样的举动是不可能的。任何将红色 4 放在红色 5 下面的尝试都会遭到系统拒绝。这里的区别在于，在电子版中，规则嵌入在系统中。不遵守规定是不可能的。在未来的几年里，我预测，在我们社会和工作生活的许多方面，法律规则也将同样嵌入到我们的系统和流程中。这意味着非律师人员将不再需要担心或承担识别何时需要法律输入的责任。

A further possibility, as mentioned in Chapter 6, will be the embedding of legal rules into systems and procedures. Consider the game of Solitaire. When I was a boy, we played this with atoms (playing cards). It was possible, when using these cards, to place a red 4 beneath a red 5, although this would clearly have been in breach of the rules. But it would have been physically possible. In contrast, when you play Solitaire on your computer, such a move is not possible. Any attempt to place a red 4 below a red 5 will be met with a refusal by the system to do as clicked. The difference here is that, with the electronic version, the rules are embedded in the system. Failure to comply is not an option. In years to come, in many dimensions of our social and working lives, I predict that legal rules will similarly be embedded in our systems and processes. This means that non-lawyers will no longer have to worry about, or have the responsibility of, recognizing when legal input is required.

科技帮助非律师人士识别何时需要法律帮助的最后一种方式是通过我所说的“法律经验社区”。作为一名计算机用户，当遇到一些难以理解的错误信息，你肯定会把它剪切粘贴到谷歌搜索，然后发现已经有人为你的问题提供了解释和解决方案。同样，在法律领域，我相信本着开源和维基百科的精神，大型的法律经验社区将会建立起来，这样人们就能了解影响他们的法律问题，不是通过律师的正式通知，而是通过社交网络非正式地了解。

A final use of technology to help non-lawyers recognize when they need legal help will be through what I call ‘communities of legal experience’. As a computer user, when confronted with some incomprehensible error message, you will no doubt have cut and pasted the message into Google, and found that someone out there has already provided an explanation and solution to your problem. So too in law, I believe that in open source and wiki spirit, large communities of legal experience will build up so that people will learn of legal issues that affect them, not formally through notification by their lawyers but informally through their social networks.

技术也将在帮助客户选择律师和其他指导资源方面发挥作用。正如第六章所述，将会有在线声誉系统，类似于那些提供酒店和餐厅集体反馈的服务，这些系统将提供其他客户对特定律师事务所和律师的体验的洞察。此外，还会有价格比较系统，允许非律师人士评估竞争法律服务提供商的各自价格。此外，还会有法律服务的拍卖——通常不是针对复杂的定制工作，而是针对那些我认为未来将以各种方式获得常规和重复性工作。

Technology will also play a role in helping clients to select their lawyers and other sources of guidance. As explained in Chapter 6, there will be online reputation systems, not unlike those services that offer collective feedback on hotels and restaurants, which will provide insight from other clients into their experiences with particular law firms and lawyers. There will also be price comparison systems that will allow non-lawyers to assess the respective prices of competing legal providers. And there will be auctions for legal services—not generally for complex bespoke work but for the routine and repetitive work that I say will be sourced in various ways in the future.

至于技术在实际法律服务中的作用，越来越多的人将不再向律师寻求程序性和实体性问题的基本指导，而是转向在线法律服务。我们在日常生活中已经使用了如此多的在线信息，因此，特别是对于那些无力承担其他方式的人而言，没有理由不以类似的方式获得法律援助。同样，用户也会转向在线服务来制作标准文件，例如基本遗嘱和房东与租户协议（参见第四章），转向能够明确其权利和义务的诊断系统，以及法律社群。经验来确定同胞过去是如何解决困难的。

As for the role of technology in the actual delivery of legal service, increasingly people will turn for basic guidance, on procedural and substantive issues, not to lawyers but to online legal services. We already use so much online information in our daily lives that there is no reason, especially for those who cannot afford otherwise, why legal help should not be similarly accessed. Equally, users will turn to online services for the production of standard documents, such as basic wills and landlord and tenant agreements (see Chapter 4), to diagnostic systems that can pinpoint their rights and duties, and to communities of legal experience to determine how fellow lay people have sorted out their difficulties in the past.

另一组可能性，如第十四章所述，是在线法院和在线争议解决（ODR）。无论是通过在线提供的公共法院服务，还是通过私营部门提供的替代性争议解决（ADR），例如电子调解和电子谈判，非律师人士都能自行理解并行使自身权益，从而在无需昂贵的律师介入的情况下解决分歧。

Another set of possibilities, as described in Chapter 14, are online courts and online dispute resolution (ODR). Whether through public court services delivered online or via private-sector forms of ADR (alternative dispute resolution), such as e-mediation and e-negotiation, non-lawyers will themselves be able to understand and enforce their entitlements, and so resolve their differences without the costly involvement of lawyers.

另一种可能性是建立律师或法律顾问的社交网络，他们愿意利用自己的时间而不是面对面的方式，以各种方式（直接向公民或间接向咨询工作者）提供在线指导。

Yet another possibility will be to build social networks of lawyers or legal advisers who are willing, in their own time rather than on a face-to-face basis, to provide online guidance, in a variety of ways (either directly to citizens or indirectly to advice workers).

虽然我说很多这样的系统属于未来，但目前已有无数在线法律服务的实际案例。用科幻小说作家威廉·吉布森的话来说，“未来已来，只是尚未均匀分布。”诚然，现在还为时过早，但用不了几年，这些系统就会普及，帮助非律师人士识别何时需要法律帮助，选择最佳的建议来源，并真正为他们提供实用指导。这并非只是一些互联网爱好者的白日梦。值得注意的是，实证研究不断发现，消费者对在线提供可靠的法律支持和建议表现出相当大的热情。

Although I speak of many of these systems as belonging to the future, there are already innumerable examples of operational online legal services. In the words of William Gibson, the science fiction writer, ‘The future has already arrived. It’s just not evenly distributed yet.’ It is early days to be sure, but within a small number of years these systems will be commonplace in helping non-lawyers to recognize when they need legal help and to select the best sources of advice, as well as in actually offering them practical guidance. And this is not just the pipe dream of some Internet enthusiasts. Significantly, empirical research is frequently finding that there is considerable enthusiasm amongst consumers for the online delivery of reliable legal support and advice.

某些在线法律服务的使用将对传统律师事务所产生“颠覆性”影响，这一点将在第六章中讨论。但与此同时，许多此类技术也将使那些原本无法负担法律援助的人也能获得法律服务。我称之为“潜在法律市场”的实现——许多人生活中无数次需要法律援助，并且能够从中受益，但直到现在，他们仍然无法获得这种援助（无论是为了解决、控制或避免问题，还是为了获得某种利益）。正如第十五章和刚才的论述所表明的，在线法律服务正在解放潜在的法律市场。

Some of these uses of online legal services will be ‘disruptive’ for traditional law firms, in the sense discussed in Chapter 6. But, at the same time, many of these techniques will make the law available to people who would otherwise have no affordable sources of legal help. This I call the realization of the ‘latent legal market’—those countless occasions in the lives of many people when they need legal help and would benefit from legal help but, until now, they have been unable to secure this assistance (whether to resolve, contain, or avoid problems, or indeed to afford them some benefit). As Chapter 15 and the arguments just made suggest, online legal service is liberating the latent legal market.

13法官、法院和技术

13 Judges, Courts, and Technology

1981年，我在格拉斯哥大学学习法律期间，撰写了一篇关于计算机与司法程序的本科学位论文。我感兴趣的是，先进的计算机系统能在多大程度上支持甚至取代法官的工作。司法和法院技术的潜力与局限性一直令我着迷。多年来，我有幸能够与多位英国资深法官合作，进一步探索我的思考，尤其是在我自1998年以来担任首席大法官技术顾问期间。

In 1981, while studying law at the University of Glasgow, I wrote an undergraduate dissertation on computers and the judicial process. My interest was in the extent to which the work of judges could be supported or even replaced by advanced computer systems. The potential and limitations of judicial and court technologies continue to fascinate me and I have had the good fortune over the years to be able to explore my thinking further in collaboration with a number of England’s most senior judges, especially in my capacity as Technology Adviser to the Lord Chief Justice, a position I have held since 1998.

法官与技术

Judges and Technology

媒体和小说通常把法官描绘成老派、不谙世事的人。因此，发达地区的司法系统或许是由最后一批新卢德分子组成的，这在意料之中。事实恰恰相反。我与之共事和交流的大多数法官如今都是科技的忠实用户，热衷于拥抱所有能够带来实际益处的基本系统。在他们的日常工作中，例如电子邮件、文字处理和在线研究。

Judges are commonly portrayed, by the media and in fiction, as old-fashioned and otherworldly. It might therefore be expected that judiciaries in advanced jurisdictions are made up of the last of the neo-Luddites. The reverse is so. Most judges with whom I work and speak are now committed users of technology and are keen to embrace all basic systems that offer practical benefits in their everyday work, such as email, word processing, and online research.

除了这些基本的应用之外，科技还能对法官的工作产生多么深远的影响？本章我将重点介绍目前可用且实用的技术，下一章我将探讨一些尖端系统。

Looking beyond these rudimentary applications, how profoundly could technology affect the work of judges? In this chapter, I focus on what is available and practicable today, while in the next I explore some cutting-edge systems.

在深入探讨技术之前，我应该强调，本书中的一些更通用的技术和经验教训既可以应用于法官，也可以应用于其他律师。与第五章介绍的分解和多源思想一致，我看到了很大的发展空间，例如，分析和划分司法工作，将其分解成不同的部分，并在适当的情况下，找到替代的、更有效的方式来完成其中一些任务。法官经常告诉我，他们被要求承担大量的行政管理工作，而其他资历较浅的人可以代他们处理。同时，法官创建的文件（例如指示和命令）至少有部分可以标准化。此外，司法部门显然会受益于文件自动化的使用，因为这些最终文件中出现的大部分内容都是标准措辞，只有细微的变化（见第四章）。

Before delving into technology, I should stress that some of the more general techniques and lessons of this book can be applied to judges as much as to other lawyers. Consistent with the ideas of decomposing and multi-sourcing as introduced in Chapter 5, I see great scope, for example, for analysing and dividing judicial work into separate parts and, where appropriate, finding alternative and more efficient ways of undertaking some of these tasks. Judges frequently tell me that they are called upon to undertake mountains of administration that others, less qualified, could handle on their behalf. At the same time, there is scope for standardization of at least parts of the documents (the directions and orders, for instance) that judges create. More, the judiciary would clearly benefit from the use of document automation, where much of what appears in these final documents is standard wording with minor variations (see Chapter 4).

初步的法律研究也可以以不同的方式进行，正如英格兰和威尔士在上诉法院和最高法院部署司法助理所体现的那样。虽然在整个体系中使用这些初级律师并不可行，但还有其他创新方式，例如利用技术，可以共享专业知识和经验，达到类似的效果。因此，我呼吁至少对……进行认真的、进一步的研究。司法工作分解和多方协作的范围。到目前为止，高级法官们对这一呼吁持开放态度，因此我期待着朝着上述方向做出改变。

Initial legal research could also be conducted in different ways, as has already been demonstrated to some extent in England and Wales by the deployment of judicial assistants in the Court of Appeal and in the Supreme Court. While it would not be feasible to use these junior lawyers across the entire system, there are other innovative ways, using technology, in which know-how and experience could be shared to similar effect. I am calling, therefore, at the very least, for serious, further investigation of the scope for the decomposing and multi-sourcing of judicial work. So far, senior judges have met this call open-mindedly and so I expect change in the direction noted.

令人失望的进展

Disappointing Progress

至于技术，用第六章的措辞来说，大多数现有和新兴的法官系统都是“维持性的” 。它们支持并增强了当前的司法工作方式。在下一章中，我将探讨更具“颠覆性”的技术——它们挑战甚至取代了当今的实践和流程。

As for technology, most current and emerging systems for judges are ‘sustaining’, in the language of Chapter 6. They support and enhance the way that judicial work is currently undertaken. In the next chapter, I look at technologies that are more ‘disruptive’—challenging and even replacing today’s practices and processes.

在大多数司法管辖区，司法系统令人失望的一个领域是“案件管理”这一广义范畴内的应用。该术语的使用方式多种多样，但普遍的不满在于，法官可用的系统通常无法直接支持他们日常的案件和文件管理。

One area in which there is judicial disappointment in most jurisdictions is in applications that fall under the broad heading of ‘case management’. This term is used in many different ways, but the generic grievance here is that the systems that are available to judges do not generally support them directly in the everyday management of their cases and documents.

许多法官以案件管理的名义，渴望“数字案卷”，其理念是将与特定案件相关的所有文件以电子形式提交（电子归档）给法院，法官和官员可以以电子或数字文件包的形式获取这些文件。这并非什么高深的科学，也算不上什么计算机科学。但它应该成为21世纪司法体系中一个普遍存在的、根深蒂固的组成部分。

Many judges, in the name of case management, hanker after a ‘digital case file’, the idea of which is that all documents relating to particular cases are submitted (e-filed) to the courts in electronic form and are available to the judges and officials as electronic or digital bundles. This is not rocket science. It is barely computer science. But it should be commonplace and deeply entrenched in a twenty-first-century justice system.

其他法官理所当然地期望更多——除了数字文件包和文件以便更好地管理文件之外，他们还希望基于技术的工作流程或项目管理系统能够简化和增强标准流程（参见第 6 章），并且从而更加严格、一致、高效地推动案件通过系统处理。

Other judges rightly expect more—as well as digital bundles and files for better management of the documents, they want technology-based workflow or project management systems to streamline and enhance standard processes (see Chapter 6) and so drive cases through the system more rigorously, consistently, and efficiently.

在大多数国家，尽管技术普遍取得了显著进步，但过去20年里，数字化案件管理的进展却十分缓慢。全球法院的大部分工作组织方式仍然是劳动密集型、繁琐且基于纸张的。尽管正在采取补救措施（如稍后所述），但走访英格兰和威尔士的大多数法院，仍然会发现其工作环境效率和自动化程度低于该国大多数普通办公室，无论是公共部门还是私营部门。全国各地的法官都抱怨系统陈旧、工作方式过时、运营成本过高、效率低下、错误频发和延误频发。反过来，法院用户因此受到影响，司法系统的声誉也受到负面影响。

In most countries, despite the remarkable advances in technology generally, progress in the past 20 years in digital case management has been slow. The organization of most of the work of the world’s courts is still labour-intensive, cumbersome, and paper-based. Although remedial action is under way (as discussed shortly), a visit to most courts in England and Wales still reveals a working environment that is less efficient and automated than most ordinary offices in the country, whether in the public or private sector. Across the country, judges complain of antiquated systems, outdated working practices, excessive running costs, inefficiencies, errors, and delays. In turn, court users suffer and the reputation of the justice system is adversely affected.

英格兰和威尔士

England and Wales

伍尔夫勋爵在其《司法便利》报告中，于20世纪90年代中期提出了一系列建议，旨在将英格兰和威尔士民事司法系统中的大部分案件管理工作计算机化。但迄今为止，这些建议鲜有落实。直到最近，这种进展缓慢主要归因于两个因素：政府和财政部投资不足，并未将民事司法视为优先事项；以及司法部在成功采购和交付大型技术项目方面的记录不佳。司法系统内部并不缺乏远见卓识。多年来，许多开明的法官、政客和公务员都大胆表达了对通过技术改造法院和司法系统的见解。简而言之，这是一个全球性的问题：愿景足够，但资金和技术能力不足。

In his ‘Access to Justice’ reports, Lord Woolf made a series of recommendations in the mid-1990s for the computerization of much of the case management in the civil justice system of England and Wales. To this day, few have been implemented. Until recently, this lack of progress was attributable to two main factors: insufficient investment by the government and the Treasury, which did not consider civil justice to be a priority; and the Ministry of Justice’s poor track record of successfully procuring and delivering large-scale technology projects. There was no shortage of vision from within the justice system. Over the years, a number of enlightened judges, politicians, and civil servants have expressed bold views of a court and justice system transformed through technology. In short, and this is a global story, there was sufficient vision but insufficient cash and technological capability.

然而，2014年，英格兰和威尔士迎来了一个新时代。当时，在高级法官、政界人士和官员的带动下，一场大规模的科技浪潮席卷了整个司法系统。2014年和2015年，大量的工作在幕后进行，因此，当英国政府在2015年11月25日宣布将投资“超过7亿英镑，用于法院的现代化和全面数字化”时，许多执业律师都感到震惊。我在推特上对此的反应是：“我等这一天已经等了34年了。” 最终，在经历了无数次资金不足的失败尝试之后，似乎终于出现了升级司法系统的严肃承诺。

However, a new era began to dawn in England and Wales in 2014, when there was a major drive—led by senior judges, politicians, and officials—to embrace technology across the court system. Much work was undertaken behind the scenes during 2014 and 2015, so that it came as a surprise to many practising lawyers when, on 25 November 2015, the British government announced it was to invest ‘more than £700 million to modernize and fully digitize the courts’. My reaction on Twitter ran as follows: ‘I have waited for this day for 34 years’. At last, after innumerable under-funded false starts, there seemed to be serious commitment to upgrading the court system.

据称，这项现代化改革计划不仅仅关乎技术——还计划减少法院建筑数量，并将部分法官工作转移给法务人员。但技术始终是该计划的核心，包括为检察机关和法院创建通用平台的系统（这是过去25年来第四次尝试做类似的事情）；刑事、民事和家事案件管理系统；整个法院和法庭系统的电子归档（见本章后面的内容）；虚拟听证会（同上）、在线法庭（见第14章）以及其他许多内容。旧系统将被废除。未来的法院将建立在技术之上。

The modernization and reform programme, it was claimed, was not just about technology—there were also plans to reduce the number of court buildings and to transfer some work of judges to legal officers. But technology was always at the heart of the initiative, including systems to create a common platform for the prosecution service and courts (the fourth attempt to do something similar in the past 25 years); case management systems for criminal, civil, and family work; e-filing across the entire court and tribunal system (see later in this chapter); virtual hearings (ditto), online courts (see Chapter 14), and much else besides. Old systems were to be scrapped. Tomorrow’s courts were to be built on the back of technology.

这项雄心勃勃的计划在一份题为“变革我们的司法系统”（2016年9月）的联合愿景声明中获得了正式批准。声明宣布双方共同致力于“建立一个公正、适度且人人可及的法院和法庭系统”。事实上，该计划已耗资逾10亿英镑，至今仍未完成，且中期正式审查在不同程度上引发了批评。该计划预计将于2023年完成，但在撰写本文时（2022年中期），尚不清楚系统的最终完整配置将如何，也不清楚这些系统是否能满足用户的期望和需求。

This ambitious programme received formal approval in a joint vision statement by the government and the judiciary, entitled ‘Transforming Our Justice System’ (September 2016). This paper declared a shared commitment to ‘a courts and tribunal system that is just, and proportionate and accessible to everyone’. In the event, the programme has cost north of £1 billion, it has not yet been completed, and interim formal reviews have in varying degrees been critical. It is due to finish in 2023 but it is not clear at the time of writing (mid-2022) what the final and full configuration of systems will look like, nor indeed whether the systems will meet users’ expectations and needs.

未来之路

The Way Ahead

无论英格兰和威尔士的改革方案结果如何，支持改革（以及远超当前改革的改革）的论据依然令人信服，并且普遍适用于所有司法管辖区。我们的司法系统仍然运转不灵。它常常效率低下、行动迟缓、成本高昂，并且超出了非律师人士的理解范围。如第十二章所述，据称英格兰和威尔士每年约有 100 万起民事司法问题未得到解决，而法律援助的削减更是加剧了这种令人震惊的法律排斥程度。“获得司法公正”正面临着成为只有富人才能享受到的福利的严重危险。更重要的是，费用过高的全面民事诉讼常常如同挥舞大锤却无法触及任何目标。

Whatever the outcome of the reform programme in England and Wales, the arguments in favour of change—and change well beyond the current reforms—remain compelling and are of general applicability across all jurisdictions. Our court system continues to creak. Too often, it is inefficient, slow, too costly, and beyond the ken of the non-lawyer. As noted in Chapter 12, around 1 million civil justice problems in England and Wales are said to go unresolved every year and cuts in legal aid have added greatly to this shocking level of legal exclusion. ‘Access to justice’ is in grave danger of being a good that is available only to the rich. More than this, full-scale civil litigation at disproportionate expense is, too often, wielding a sledgehammer to miss a nut.

原则上，如果法院享有其他行业所享有的技术优势，那么劳动密集型、繁琐的纸质法院管理系统将被一套自动化、精简且基本无纸化的系统所取代，该系统成本更低、出错率更低、效率更高、更易于访问。该系统将比现有系统更易于使用，并且大部分以在线方式运行。立案、与法院沟通、文件存储、监控进展、安排听证会以及获取相关支持等流程都将以电子方式进行。

In principle, if the advantages of technology that are seen in other sectors are enjoyed by the courts, the labour-intensive, cumbersome, and paper-based systems for court administration will be replaced by an automated, streamlined, and largely paper-free set of systems that will be less costly, less prone to error, more efficient, and more accessible. This would be a system that is easier to use than today’s and in large part delivered online. The processes of starting a case, communicating with the court, storing documents, monitoring progress, arranging hearings, and receiving support along the way would be conducted electronically.

反过来，一个高效、通俗易懂、设备齐全的法院系统，加上满意的律师队伍，将是一个公众更信赖的体系。这其中也涉及到国际层面。如果英格兰真心渴望成为全球领先的纠纷解决中心，那么就应该拥有最先进的、尖端的系统、流程和基础设施来支持这一目标。

In turn, an efficient, intelligible, and well-equipped court service, populated by satisfied lawyers, would be a system in which the public would have greater confidence. There is an international dimension too. If England seriously aspires to being a leading global centre of excellence for the resolution of disputes, then there should be state-of-the-art, leading-edge systems, processes, and infrastructure in place to support this.

正因如此，我们的政府必须继续资助技术，以支持法院和争议解决。政府当前的当务之急或许是削减成本，而非投资技术，这可以理解。但在当前经济低迷时期，矛盾之处在于，技术投资应该成为政府的解决方案，而不是问题。其回报是光彩夺目的——廉价、迅速、适度且包容的争议解决方案。

That is why our government must continue to fund technology in support of the courts and dispute resolution. The current preoccupation of the state, understandably, may be with cutting costs rather than investing in technology. But the paradox here, in this period of economic gloom, is that investment in technology should be a solution for governments and not a problem. The prize is a glittering one—inexpensive, swift, proportionate, inclusive resolution of disputes.

技术支持的法院

Technology-Enabled Courts

除了后台管理和案件管理之外，法院现在的技术可以实现什么他们自己？（我向那些对本章中的一些技术在二十一世纪的第三个十年还值得一提感到震惊的法律以外的技术专家们表示歉意。）

Looking beyond back-office administration and case management, what is now technologically possible in the courts themselves? (I apologize to any technologists from beyond the law who are horrified that some of the technologies in this chapter are even thought worthy of mention in the third decade of the twenty-first century.)

首先，即使在当事人出庭之前，有一种技术可以立即带来好处——电子归档。这涉及以电子形式向法院提交文件，对于法官和行政人员来说，这比大量纸质文件方便得多，尤其是在电子归档页面相互关联的情况下。过去几年，在英国和其他地方，电子归档越来越受欢迎。

First of all, even before parties assemble in court, there is one technique that can be of immediate benefit—e-filing. This involves the submission of documents to the court in electronic form, which can be so much more convenient for judges and administrators than huge bundles of paper, especially if the e-filed pages are linked to one another. Over the past few years, in the UK and elsewhere, e-filing has become increasingly popular.

其次，在法庭上，一项显而易见但绝非普遍的技术应用是法官在笔记本电脑或台式电脑上记录案件进展。自20世纪90年代初以来，世界各地的法院或多或少地使用了三种更为复杂的技术。第一种是计算机辅助转录（CAT），它使速记员能够记录法庭上所说的话，然后将其转换成文本，几乎可以即时显示在法官和其他参与者的屏幕上。文本可以在显示时进行注释，并创建一个可搜索的诉讼数据库。（CAT被连续语音、独立于说话人、多说话人语音识别系统取代只是时间问题。）

Next, in the courtroom itself, one entirely obvious but by no means pervasive use of technology involves the judge taking notes as cases progress on a laptop or desktop computer. Three further, more sophisticated, technologies have been used, to a greater or lesser extent, in courts around the world since the early 1990s. The first is computer-assisted transcription (CAT), which enables words spoken in the courtroom to be captured by stenographers and then converted into text that appears almost instantaneously on the screens of judges and other participants. The text can be annotated as it appears and a searchable database of the proceedings is created. (It is only a matter of time before CAT is replaced by continuous speech, speaker-independent, multi-speaker voice recognition systems.)

第二是文件显示系统，该系统可确保听证会上的每个人都在同一页面上 - 法院无需等待所有当事人和法官手动查找文件和档案，而是可以通过要求所有参与者查看他们的显示器来将注意力引导到特定页面上，显示器会立即显示相关文件。

Second are document display systems, which ensure that everyone in a hearing is, literally, on the same page—instead of waiting for all parties and judges to locate papers and files manually, the court’s attention can be directed to a particular page by asking all participants to look at their monitors, which instantly display relevant documents.

研究和经验表明，使用 CAT 和文档显示技术可以将听证会的时间缩短四分之一到三分之一。

Research and experience suggest that using CAT and document display technologies reduces the length of hearings by one-quarter to one-third.

第三种技术是数字或电子证据呈现，体现了“一图胜千言”的古老格言。律师不再仅仅依赖口头辩护，而是可以使用各种非语言工具来呈现证据，包括图表、图形、示意图、绘图、模型、3D动画、重建和模拟。这些工具可以在法庭上的个人显示器上显示，也可以投影到超大屏幕上。它们既可用于民事案件，也可用于刑事案件——例如，可以通过将实际时间与预计时间进行比较的动画有力地展示项目延误的程度，或者可以用简单的图形而不是复杂的口头摘要来捕捉资金的复杂流动。

The third technology is digital or electronic presentation of evidence and reflects the old adage that a picture is worth a thousand words. Rather than relying exclusively on oral advocacy, lawyers can present evidence using a wide range of non-verbal tools, including charts, graphs, diagrams, drawings, models, 3D animations, reconstructions, and simulations. These can be displayed in the courtroom on individual monitors or projected onto very large screens. They can be used in both civil and criminal cases—for instance, the extent of a delay in a project can be demonstrated powerfully by an animation that compares actual with projected time taken, or complex movements of funds can be captured in a simple graphic rather than by convoluted oral summary.

随着越来越多的证据本身以数字形式创建或保存，技术的应用范围进一步扩大，用于管理这些电子证据并将其与法庭实践和程序相结合。这包括电子邮件、闭路电视录像以及存储在区块链上的数据。区块链存储和生成的证据具有强大的真实性、完整性和准确性，因此区块链数据的重要性日益凸显。

As more and more evidence itself is created or preserved in digital form, a further use of technology is devoted to managing this electronic evidence and integrating it with court practice and procedure. This includes emails, CCTV footage, and data stored on a blockchain. This last category is increasingly important because evidence stored and generated from a blockchain carries with it powerful claims to authenticity, integrity, and accuracy.

至于计算机辅助审判系统 (CAT)、文件展示系统和数字证据呈现的实际应用，尽管节省了时间和成本，但各法院系统的采用率仍然很低。但也有一些值得注意的例外。早在疫情爆发之前，英国最高法院就已开始使用第二代系统，用于电子归档、文件展示、实时转录、法庭计算机司法应用以及远程证据。各大法庭都拥有令人印象深刻的系统。然而，这些系统在英国却堪称典范。英国大多数审理室（除了笔记本电脑外）基本上没有任何科技设备。

As for actual use of CAT, document display systems, and digital presentation of evidence, here too take-up has been low across court systems, despite the time and cost savings. But there have been a few notable exceptions. Even before the pandemic, the UK Supreme Court was on to its second generation of systems for e-filing, document display, real-time transcription, judicial use of computers on the bench, and remote evidence. And various tribunals have impressive systems. These, however, are exceptional in the UK, where most hearing rooms, aside from laptops, are substantially technology-free.

有趣的是，法院技术在公共调查（用于设置听证室的资源不太受限制 - 但这一类别中最雄心勃勃的是由萨维尔勋爵进行的高科技血腥星期日调查（1998-2010）），大规模商业纠纷（当事方本身拥有大量诉讼预算）和复杂刑事案件（从历史上看，刑事司法系统在技术方面的投资远远超过民事司法系统）中取得了最大的成功。

Interestingly, court technologies have enjoyed greatest success in public inquiries (where the resources for setting up the hearing rooms have been less constrained—still the most ambitious in this category was the high-tech Bloody Sunday Inquiry (1998–2010) by Lord Saville), in large-scale commercial disputes (where the parties themselves have substantial litigation budgets); and complex criminal cases (the criminal justice system has, historically, received much greater investment in its technology than the civil justice system).

将来，许多法庭将会看起来像萨维尔勋爵的调查听证室；与美国宇航局的控制中心没有什么不同。

In the future, many courtrooms will look like Lord Saville’s Inquiry hearing rooms; not unlike NASA control centres.

远程法院

Remote Courts

现在，回到争议解决的核心，在思考法院的长远未来时，一个基本问题至关重要：法院是一种服务还是一个场所？为了解决法律纠纷，当事人及其律师是否需要聚集在一个物理空间，以便向法官陈述论点？更先进的在线争议解决形式又如何呢？

Turning now to the heart of dispute resolution, in thinking about the long-term future of courts, one fundamental question sets the agenda: is court a service or a place? To resolve legal disputes, do parties and their advisers need to congregate together in one physical space, in order to present arguments to a judge? What about more advanced forms of online dispute resolution?

在本书2017年出版的第二版中，我曾写道：“（虚拟）听证会在英国司法系统中仍然相对罕见，但我毫不怀疑，到2020年代，它们将变得司空见惯。” 事实上，疫情带来的变化更早地证实了这一预测。比我预想的要好。在此之前，视频听证技术的使用率极低。在涉及儿童或受恐吓证人的刑事案件中，以及通过监狱和法院之间的联系进行的保释和还押听证会中，视频听证技术的使用率最高。在一些民事案件中，来自英国境外的证人以及原本无法联系到的专家证人也可以远程提供证据。换句话说，在2020年之前，视频听证会一直处于法官、律师和政策制定者的边缘视野之中。

In the second edition of this book, published in 2017, I wrote that, ‘(v)irtual hearings are still relatively rare across the justice system in England, but they will become commonplace in the 2020s, I have little doubt.’ In the event, the pandemic brought about changes that confirmed this prediction much sooner than I had expected. Prior to this, there had been minimal use of video-hearing technology. Take-up had been greatest in criminal cases, with child or intimidated witnesses; and for bail and remand hearings, conducted through links between prisons and courts. And in some civil cases, witnesses from outside the UK had given evidence remotely, as had otherwise inaccessible expert witnesses. In other words, video hearings had been in the peripheral vision of judges, lawyers, and policy-makers until 2020.

随后，新冠疫情爆发。世界各地的法庭都关闭了。面对别无选择，法官、律师和法院官员以惊人的速度和灵活性，转而远程进行听证。2020年3月，我带领团队创建了一个名为“全球远程法院”（Remote Courts Worldwide）的网站（网址： http://www.remotecourts.org），旨在帮助全球司法工作者——法官、律师、法院官员、诉讼当事人、法院技术人员——分享远程听证的经验。2022年年中，“全球远程法院”的记录显示，过去几年中，已有170个司法管辖区开展了远程听证。这种规模在2020年初几乎难以想象。

And then came COVID. Courtrooms around the world closed. Faced with no feasible alternatives, judges, lawyers, and court officials moved with extraordinary speed and agility to conducting hearings remotely. In March 2020, I led a team that put together a website known as Remote Courts Worldwide—<http://www.remotecourts.org>—to help the global community of justice workers—judges, lawyers, court officials, litigants, court technologists—to share their experiences of remote hearings. In mid-2022, Remote Courts Worldwide records that 170 jurisdictions have run remote hearings in the past couple of years. This scale of uptake was scarcely imaginable at the start of 2020.

“远程”一词通常指视频听证会（使用 Zoom 或 Teams 等系统，或定制服务）或音频听证会（本质上是电话会议）。虽然也有混合版本，但在实践中，视频听证会迅速成为疫情期间最受欢迎的选择。参与者不再在实体场所集合，而是通过视频会议进行。法官、律师和程序基本保持不变。

The term ‘remote’ generally refers to video hearings (using systems such as Zoom or Teams, or custom-made services) or to audio hearings (essentially, telephone conference calls). There are hybrid versions too but in practice, the video hearing quickly emerged as the favoured option during the pandemic. Instead of assembling in a physical space, participants convene in a video meeting. The judges, lawyers, and the procedures remain much the same.

到目前为止，我们从远程法院的广泛使用中吸取了哪些教训？我们应该立即认识到，律师和法官在情况需要时是多么灵活和足智多谋。人们常说，法律行业极其保守，难以改变。“全球远程法院”网站上出现的证据却表明并非如此。

What lessons have we learned so far from the widespread use of remote courts? It should be accepted immediately just how flexible and resourceful lawyers and judges can be when circumstances require. The old trope is that the legal profession is deeply conservative and incapable of change. The evidence that appears on Remote Courts Worldwide suggests differently.

总体而言，司法和法律用户对视频听证会的满意度相当高，远高于疫情爆发前被问及远程听证会潜力时所预测的水平。当然，也存在一些问题和不足。例如，对于年长的参与者、需要翻译的人员以及技术有限的法庭用户来说，存在一些困难。此外，人们还对某些视频平台的隐私和安全问题感到担忧。如果法院系统本身仍然以纸质文件为主，那么在视频听证会中处理大量文件将会非常困难。如果要保持严肃的气氛，灯光、背景、服装、语气和姿势都至关重要。低质量的网络连接可能会彻底破坏诉讼程序。

Overall, the level of satisfaction with video hearings amongst judicial and legal users is fairly high and much higher than they would have predicted if asked before the pandemic about the potential of remote hearings. There have of course been wrinkles and problems. There have been difficulties, for example, for elderly participants, for those needing translation, and for court users with limited technology. There have also been concerns about privacy and security on some of the video platforms. It turns out to be difficult to handle large numbers of documents in a video hearing if the court system itself is still largely paper-based. If solemnity is to be maintained, then lighting, background, clothing, tone, and posture matter. Low-quality Internet connection can scupper proceedings entirely.

一些问题仍存在争议，例如关于证人的可信度，以及视频听证会能否充分评估证人的可信度。有人认为，你需要与真人共处一室，才能判断他们是否在说实话。另一些人则坚持认为，远程沟通时，仍然可以直视对方的眼睛。

There remain some issues of debate, in relation to the credibility of witnesses, for instance, and whether this can be adequately assessed in video hearings. Some say you need to be in the same room as humans to determine whether they are speaking the truth. Others insist that you can still look people in the eye when engaging remotely.

人们一致认为，需要开展更多工作来确定哪些类型的案件或问题最适合采用哪种处置方式，无论是通过实体、音频、视频还是其他在线方式（参见第14章）。不过，一些早期的立场正在获得关注。例如，人们普遍认为涉及子女监护权或家庭暴力的家庭纠纷，应尽可能当面审理。同样，在大多数国家，涉及严重犯罪的案件被认为需要进行线下听证。另一方面，某些类型的纠纷正逐渐显现出非常适合远程处理的趋势——临时听证、程序性听证和临时听证；日常家庭事务；小额金钱索赔；轻微刑事犯罪；商业纠纷；行政法庭；民事上诉等等。

There is agreement that more work needs to be done to establish what kinds of cases or issues are best suited to what types of disposal, whether by physical, audio, video, or by other online methods (see Chapter 14). Some early positions, though, are gaining traction. It is widely agreed, for example, that family disputes, involving the custody of children or domestic abuse, should be heard in person if possible. Likewise, in most countries, cases involving serious crime are thought to require physical hearings. On the other hand, particular sorts of dispute are emerging as nicely suited to remote handling—interim, procedural, and interlocutory hearings; routine family work; small money claims; minor criminal offences; commercial disputes; administrative tribunals; civil appeals; and more.

总而言之，我们迄今为止的研究和反馈表明，一些（或许是很多）法律纠纷确实可以通过远程处理，而且通常比传统系统更便宜、更便捷、更快速、更友好。但这只能被视为一个初步假设，必须接受挑战和系统性的检验。

In sum, the research and feedback we have seen so far indicates that some—and probably many—legal disputes can indeed be handled remotely, often more cheaply, conveniently, speedily, and affably than in our traditional system. But this can only be taken as a tentative hypothesis that must be challenged and tested systematically.

尽管如此，许多律师和法官仍然坚持认为，我们绝不能回到过去的模式，并认为向技术驱动的司法转型已经实现。他们声称已经完成了任务。这种说法有些夸大其词。毋庸置疑，从实体法庭到远程听证的飞跃意义非凡，但目前仍处于早期阶段，没有人能够负责任地断言视频适用于所有案件和问题。我坚持认为，我们正处于法院服务转型的初级阶段。目前，各种远程服务包含一系列大胆的临时服务，但要将这些第一代系统产业化，构建可扩展、稳定且至关重要的是，兼顾普通民众和律师使用的法院服务，仍需要投入大量的精力和资金。

Many lawyers and judges are nonetheless insisting we should never return to the old ways, that the shift to technology-enabled justice has been achieved. Job done, allegedly. This is overclaim. Incontestably, the jump from physical courts to remote hearings has been extraordinary, but it is still early days and no-one can responsibly assert that video is suitable for all cases and issues. We are, I insist, at the foothills of the transformation in court services. The current assortment of remote services comprise a brave array of ad hoc services but much effort and capital will be needed to industrialize these first-generation systems to construct court services that are scalable, stable, and, vitally, designed for use as much by lay people as by lawyers.

不仅如此，这些拼凑起来的系统仍然体现了我在第一章中所说的“自动化”而非“创新”。大多数为应对新冠疫情而设立的远程服务，都只是“传统法院。但我们应该清楚——将我们现有的法院系统迁移到 Zoom 并非像某些专家所说的那样是一场“革命”。我们才刚刚触及皮毛。争议解决的未来远不止技术支持的实体法庭和视频听证会。未来将是一个由在线法院和在线争议解决组成的世界，我现在将谈到这一点。

More than this, the systems that have been cobbled together are still illustrations of what I call, in Chapter 1, automation rather than innovation. Most of the remote services that were set up in response to COVID are variations on the theme of conventional courts. But we should be clear—dropping our current court systems into Zoom is not, as some pundits like to proclaim, a ‘revolution’. We have just scratched the surface. The future of dispute resolution lies beyond technology-enabled physical courts and video hearings. The future will be a world of online courts and online dispute resolution, to which I now turn.

14网上法院和网上争议解决

14 Online Courts and Online Dispute Resolution

在视频听证会中，一位或多位法官以传统方式主持审判。与传统的不同之处在于，部分或所有参与者通过视频链接虚拟出席，而非亲自到场。正如上一章所述，这是疫情期间最受欢迎的远程听证形式。

In a video hearing, one or more judges dispense justice in the traditional manner. The break from tradition is that some or all participants appear virtually across some video link rather than in person. This, as noted in the previous chapter, was the most popular form of remote hearing during the pandemic.

如今，在线法院和在线争议解决（ODR）领域的进展已远远超出虚拟听证会。一些专家正在更进一步，思考在虚拟宇宙中进行法律听证会的可能性。在这些崭新的世界中，不再需要传统的法庭。相反，解决争议的过程，尤其是解决方案的制定，将完全或大部分在线进行。法院不再是一个场所，而是一种服务。

Advances are now being made well beyond virtual hearings into the world of online courts and online dispute resolution (ODR). Some experts are going further and giving thought to the idea of legal hearings in the metaverse. In these brave new worlds, no traditional courtroom is involved. Instead, the process of resolving a dispute, especially the formulation of the solution, is entirely or largely conducted online. A court becomes a service rather than a place.

网上法庭

Online Courts

在我写作的同时，在线法院的故事正在展开。它们对日常生活的影响可能比本书讨论的任何其他创新都要大。本章中提到的许多内容都我在《在线法院与司法的未来》一书中对此进行了更详尽的阐述。该书于2019年首次出版，但由于新冠疫情的影响需要更新。修订版于2021年出版。

The story of online courts is unfolding as I write. They may well have greater impact on everyday life than any other innovation discussed in this book. Much that is said in this chapter is laid out at greater length in my book, Online Courts and the Future of Justice, which first appeared in 2019, but required an update in light of COVID. A revised edition appeared in 2021.

在书中，我提出了一个相当详细的在线法院架构。在我看来，在线法院的基本架构包含两个方面。首先，在线审判。这涉及由人类法官裁定案件，但——这是一个根本性的突破——当事人既不在实体法院大楼内开庭，诉讼程序也不通过视频或电话会议进行。相反，辩论和证据通过某种在线平台提交给法官，法官再次通过在线服务做出裁决，但并非在视频听证会或公开法庭上。没有听证会或口头辩论。取而代之的是结构化的在线诉讼流程，类似于持续的电子邮件和附件交换。

In the book, I propose a fairly detailed architecture for online courts. Distilled to its basics, there are two aspects to online courts, as I see them. First of all, there is online judging. This involves the determination of cases by human judges but—and here is a fundamental departure—the parties neither assemble in a bricks-and-mortar court building nor are proceedings conducted by video or telephone conference call. Instead, arguments and evidence are submitted to judges through some kind of online platform and the judges deliver their decisions, again, not in a video hearing or in open court but via the online service. There is no hearing or oral argument. Instead, there is a structured process of online pleading, not unlike an ongoing exchange of emails and attachments.

用技术专家的术语来说，实体法庭和视频听证会的互动是同步的，而在线审判则涉及异步沟通。对于前者，这意味着所有参与者需要同时在场才能使案件进展顺利。相比之下，对于后者，就像短信和电子邮件一样，参与者无需同时在场——证据、论点和判决可以在发送者和接收者不在同一时间或通过视频连接的情况下进行传输和交换。

In the jargon of technologists, interaction in physical courtrooms and video hearings is synchronous whereas online judging involves asynchronous forms of communication. For the former, this means that the participants need to be available at the same time for a case to progress. By contrast, with the latter, as with exchanging text messages and emails, those who are involved do not need to be at hand simultaneously—evidence, arguments, and decisions can be transmitted and traded without the sender and recipient being physically together or connected by video at the same moment.

从同步到异步的法庭服务转变不仅仅是流程改进，它涉及并需要彻底的变革。这比从线下庭审到视频庭审的转变要大得多。尽管批评人士对此深有体会尽管人们对视频听证会心存疑虑，但作为一种争议解决形式，它们与传统法庭属于同一范式。相比之下，在线法院则是一个完全不同的概念。即使在第一代在线法院中，由人类法官裁定案件，在线审判也剥夺了许多人珍视的许多东西——公开听证会、出庭日、与他人的直接接触（稍后会详细介绍）。另一方面，正如我和许多其他人坚信的那样，在线法院可能会使基于国家的争议解决更加便捷和经济实惠，并将与数字一代——那些不记得互联网时代之前的世界的人——产生共鸣。

This move from a synchronous to an asynchronous court service is not mere process improvement. It involves and requires radical change. It constitutes a much greater shift than the swing from physical to video hearings. Although critics have deep misgivings about video hearings, they belong, as a form of dispute resolution, in the same broad paradigm as traditional courtrooms. By contrast, online courts are an entirely different concept. Even in the first generation of online courts, where human judges are determining the cases, online judging removes much that many people hold dear—the public hearing, the day in court, the direct engagement with other human beings (more on which shortly). On the other hand, as I and many others strongly believe, online courts are likely to make state-based dispute resolution much more accessible and affordable, and will chime with the digital generation, those who cannot recall a pre-Internet world.

在线法院的第二个方面更为普遍。我将其称为扩展法院。其理念是，技术使我们能够提供比传统法院范围更广的服务。附加服务包括帮助用户对问题进行分类和归类、了解其权利和义务以及可用的选项和救济措施的工具，以及协助诉讼当事人整理证据和阐述论点的设施，以及提供建议或促成非司法和解的系统。日常技术和科技——应用程序、智能手机、门户网站、短信、视频通话、聊天机器人、实时聊天、网络直播——将支持这些扩展法院设施，帮助非律师人士更轻松地与法院互动。这里的扩展，也是一个重大变化，是这些系统主要面向自诉诉讼当事人，而非律师。这些法庭用户无需律师，就可以自己提交文件、追踪案件、与法庭官员和法官交涉，并使用直观、无术语的系统来处理纠纷。

The second aspect of online courts is more general. I refer to it as the extended court. Here, the idea is that technology enables us to provide a service with much wider remit than the conventional court. The additional services include tools to help users with grievances to classify and categorize their problems, to understand their rights and obligations, and to understand the options and remedies available to them, as well as facilities that assist litigants to marshal their evidence and formulate their arguments, and systems that advise on or bring about non-judicial settlement. Everyday techniques and technologies—apps, smart phones, portals, messaging, video calling, chat bots, live chats, webcasts—will support these extended court facilities, helping non-lawyers interact much more easily with the courts. The extension here, and it is a major change, is that these systems are designed primarily for self-represented litigants rather than for lawyers. And these court users, without lawyers, can themselves file documents, track cases, engage with court officials and judges, and progress their disputes by using intuitive, jargon-free systems.

影响

Impact

正如我所描述的，在线法院可以带来两大益处：增加司法途径（一种更经济实惠、更便捷的服务），并大幅节省个人诉讼当事人和法院系统的成本。正如第十二章所述，对于相应类型的案件，在线法院不仅承诺提供更便捷、更经济的争议解决方式，而且至关重要的是，其扩展的法院设施还能促进争议控制和争议避免。

Two major benefits can flow from online courts as I describe them—an increase in access to justice (a more affordable and user-friendly service) and substantial savings in costs, both for individual litigants and for the court system. In the language of Chapter 12, for appropriate classes of case, online courts not only promise more accessible and affordable dispute resolution but, crucially, their extended court facilities also encourage dispute containment and dispute avoidance.

网上法庭并非科幻小说。它在加拿大（不列颠哥伦比亚省的民事解决法庭是全球最佳案例研究）、美国、中国以及其他地方都已投入运营。

Online courts are not science fiction. They are operational in Canada (the Civil Resolution Tribunal in British Columbia is the best global case study), in the United States, in China, and elsewhere.

在英格兰和威尔士引入在线法院也是第十三章提到的政府改革计划的一部分。我认为，可以公平地说，这方面的动力主要源于民事司法委员会在线争议解决咨询小组的工作（我有幸担任该小组的主席，我们在2015年初提交了报告），以及布里格斯勋爵（现为勋爵）关于民事法院结构的报告（分别于2015年12月和2016年7月）。布里格斯勋爵大力倡导开发和推出在线解决方案。现任卷宗主事官（英格兰和威尔士最资深的民事法官）杰弗里·沃斯爵士已接过重任，正在带头推动现代化和变革。

The introduction of online courts in England and Wales is also part of the government reform programme mentioned in Chapter 13. I think it fair to say that the drive in this direction originated largely from the work of the Civil Justice Council’s Online Dispute Resolution Advisory Group, which I had the privilege of chairing (we reported in early 2015), and from the reports on the structure of civil courts (in December 2015 and July 2016) by Lord Justice (now Lord) Briggs, who forcefully advocated the development and launch of online resolution. Sir Geoffrey Vos, the current Master of the Rolls (the most senior civil judge in England and Wales) has taken up the cudgels and is now spearheading modernization and change.
