举个例子，目前已有近30万起金钱索赔案件通过“在线民事金钱索赔”系统提起。该系统允许用户在网上提出或回应金钱索赔。在秉承同样的精神，我们还将推出两项服务——在线损害索赔服务，用于提出和通知损害索赔；以及在线占有索赔服务，用于帮助用户在租金或抵押贷款被拖欠且租户或抵押贷款持有人不愿支付的情况下收回房产。这些服务及未来服务的管理规则将由根据最近颁布的《2022年司法审查与法院法》成立的新在线程序规则委员会监督。

To give a flavour, almost 300,000 money claims have been made using Online Civil Money Claims, a system that enables users to make or respond to money claims on the Web. In the same spirit, are two further services—Damages Claims Online, for making and notifying damages claims; and Possession Claims Online, for helping users to repossess property when owed money for rent or a mortgage, and the tenant or mortgage holder will not pay. The rules governing these and future services will be overseen by the new Online Procedure Rules Committee, established by the recent Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022.

网上争议解决

ODR

与在线法院重叠的一个研究和活动领域是“在线争议解决”（通常称为“ODR”）。它出现于20世纪90年代，是ADR（替代性争议解决）的一个分支。当时，ODR本质上被视为一种电子ADR，其涵盖许多技术，包括电子谈判、电子调解和电子仲裁。与面对面进行调解和谈判等类似活动不同，人们开发了各种技术，以非正式的方式在线解决各种分歧——从公民之间的争吵到个人与国家之间的冲突，从消费者纠纷到电子商务引发的问题。

A field of research and activity that overlaps with online courts is that of ‘online dispute resolution’, usually known as ‘ODR’. It emerged in the 1990s as a branch of ADR (alternative dispute resolution). At that time, ODR was regarded, essentially, as a form of electronic ADR, with many techniques falling under its umbrella, including e-negotiation, e-mediation, and e-arbitration. Rather than meeting in person to conduct, say, mediations and negotiations, various techniques were developed to help sort out a wide range of disagreements informally and on an online basis—from quarrels amongst citizens to conflicts between individuals and the state, from consumer disputes to problems arising from e-commerce.

例如，当面对面调解在后勤方面存在困难时，例如由于当事人所在地点，或由于争议规模较大，在单一场所进行调解的成本过高，则可以进行在线调解或电子调解。在调解中，调解员作为第三方协助当事人协商和解，通常是以私人方式。并建立在保密的基础上。本着同样的精神，在电子调解中，结合人工调解员和技术手段（通过电子邮件和在线讨论区进行交流），争议各方可以在线解决分歧，而无需在会议室开会。

By way of illustration, an online mediation, or e-mediation, might be undertaken when face-to-face mediation is logistically difficult, perhaps because of the locations of the parties or when, relative to the size of dispute, it is disproportionately expensive to assemble in one forum. In mediation, the mediator, as a third party, assists parties to negotiate settlements, usually on a private and confidential basis. In the same spirit, in an e-mediation, using a mix of human mediators and often technologies—exchanges by email and in online discussion areas—parties to a dispute can settle their disagreements online without convening in a meeting room.

然而，ODR 的先驱们的主要目标并非开发支持人类谈判者和调解员的系统。许多人的目标更加远大。更先进系统的开发者们的核心愿望是，让系统本身以某种方式承担部分争议解决流程。

Amongst ODR pioneers, however, the main aim was not to develop systems to support human negotiators and mediators. Many have been more ambitious. The key aspiration of the developers of more advanced systems is that some of the dispute resolution process is, in one way or another, taken on by the system itself.

一个早期且备受吹捧的例子是 Cyber​​settle，这是一个于 1998 年推出的在线系统。据称，在其第一个版本中，Cyber​​settle 已处理了超过 20 万起索赔，总价值超过 16 亿美元。大多数案件是人身伤害或保险索赔。它采用了一种 ODR 专家经常讨论的被称为“双盲投标”的流程——原告和被告分别提交各自可接受的最高和最低和解金额。这些金额并未披露，但如果两个范围重叠，则可以达成和解，最终金额通常是平分。

An early and much touted example was Cybersettle, an online system launched in 1998. In its first version, Cybersettle was claimed to have handled over 200,000 claims of combined value in excess of $1.6 billion. Most of the cases were personal injury or insurance claims. It used a process, much discussed by ODR specialists, known as ‘double-blind bidding’—a claimant and defendant each submitted the highest and lowest settlement figures that were acceptable to them. These amounts were not disclosed but if the two ranges overlapped, a settlement could be achieved, the final figure usually being a split down the middle.

eBay 使用多种 ODR 技术来解决问题。eBay 用户每年发生约 6000 万起纠纷。很难想象这些纠纷都能在传统法院得到解决。因此，ODR 被广泛使用——快速、高效，并且通常效果良好。

A blend of ODR techniques is used to sort out problems on eBay. About 60 million disputes arise each year amongst eBay users. It is unimaginable that these would all get resolved in conventional courts. Instead, ODR is used—swiftly, efficiently, and generally to good effect.

但即使是这些更雄心勃勃的系统，从技术角度来看也相当原始。我预计，到2020年代，在线法院和ODR服务将具备远程呈现功能；也就是说，它们将广泛使用先进的沉浸式视频和元宇宙（参见本章后面的内容）。这将使法官和调解员能够更轻松地与当事人进行实时沟通。届时将出现基于人工智能的诊断工具，帮助当事人推理案件，以及基于对法院过往行为的统计分析，预测案件可能结果的预测工具（这类似于ADR程序的新版本，被称为“早期中立评估”）。更激进的是，本着博弈论的精神，一些系统将为双方都能接受的协商解决方案提供具体的建议。私营部门无疑将部署众包技术，这将使决策不再由单个法官做出，而是由同行组成的社群做出。

But even these more ambitious systems are fairly primitive, technologically speaking. In the 2020s, I expect that online courts and ODR services will be telepresence-enabled; that is, they will make extensive use of advanced immersive video and metaverse (see later in this chapter). This will allow judges and mediators more easily to communicate with parties in real time. There will be AI-based diagnostic tools to help parties reason about their cases and predictive tools that will make forecasts about the likely outcomes of cases, based on statistical analysis of the past behaviour of courts (this will be like a new version of the ADR process known as ‘early neutral evaluation’). More radical yet, in the spirit of game theory, some systems will make concrete recommendations for negotiated resolutions that are sensible outcomes for both parties. And in the private sector certainly, crowdsourcing techniques will be deployed, which will involve decisions being made not by individual judges but by communities of peers.

混合

Blending

如今，人们经常合理地交替使用“ODR”和“在线法院”这两个表述。但这可能会造成混淆。显然，在线法院必然是国家的产物（假设此处的“法院”指的是公共服务）。然而，“ODR”既有广义，也有狭义。广义上的ODR大致指任何主要通过互联网进行的争议解决程序。这种广义上的描述将“在线法院”纳入了ODR的范畴，即在线法院使用ODR技术的情况。狭义上的ODR更具体地等同于电子ADR（“e-ADR”），即这些系统被视为公共的、基于国家的法院服务的替代方案。

Today, people frequently and reasonably use the expressions ‘ODR’ and ‘online courts’ interchangeably. But this can be confusing. It is clear that online courts must be an emanation of the state (assuming that ‘court’ in this context means a public service). Reference to ‘ODR’, however, is made in both a wide and a narrow sense. In its wide sense, ODR refers, roughly, to any process of resolving a dispute that is largely conducted across the internet. This broad characterization brings ‘online courts’ under the umbrella of ODR, that is, when online courts use ODR techniques. The narrower sense of ODR equates it more specifically with electronic ADR (‘e-ADR’), that is, the systems are regarded as an alternative to public, state-based court service.

一场相关的政策和实践辩论正在酝酿——例如，低价值纠纷的解决是否应该在公共法院系统之外，主要由私营部门的在线服务提供商来解决。事实上，少量的私人服务已经出现，并且很可能在州级在线法院正式启动之前在许多司法管辖区流行起来。一些人声称，市场可能会提供比公共部门更好、更便宜的服务。另一些人则坚持认为，即使在低价值案件中，公民和企业也应该始终能够切实获得由独立法官提供的具有约束力和可执行性的争议解决服务，这是国家的一项基本义务，也是法治的根本。在英格兰和威尔士，我和其他人（包括卷宗主审官和 LawtechUK）正在倡导一种公私合作混合安排，根据该安排，私营部门的企业、慈善机构和其他机构可以设立早期和解的 ODR 机构（上述狭义的），作为公共法院系统的一种“前端”，提供相当于我所说的“扩展”服务的服务。这些 ODR 前端将获得国家认可；并将与法院系统相连，以便未解决的争议可以轻松进入法院系统（或许可以快速通过）；并且达成的和解可以作为法院命令强制执行。

A related policy and practical debate is brewing—whether the resolution of, say, low-value disputes should be resolved beyond the public court system, largely by private sector online service providers. A small crop of private offerings has in fact already sprouted and may well become popular in many jurisdictions before state-based online courts are formally launched. Some claim that the market is likely to provide a better and less costly service than the public sector. Others insist that it is a fundamental duty of the state and fundamental to the rule of law that, even in low-value cases, citizens and business should always have realistic access to binding and enforceable dispute resolution by independent judges. In England and Wales, I and others (including the Master of the Rolls and LawtechUK) are advocating a public/private partnership blended arrangement, under which private sector businesses, charities, and others might set up early-settlement ODR facilities (in the narrow sense above), which act as a kind of ‘front-end’ to the public court system, offering the equivalent of what I call ‘extended’ services. These ODR front-ends would be accredited by the state; would be linked to the systems of the court, so that unresolved disputes could pass easily into the court’s systems (perhaps fast-tracked through); and settlements reached might be enforceable as court orders.

我们看到，州级法院与在线早期和解服务相结合，可能比传统的公共纠纷解决方式更容易获得，也更具预防性。对于那些确实需要法官以传统方式处理的案件，我预计会出现另一种设施组合——不仅仅是实体法院，还有一系列选择，包括视频听证会、音频听证会、混合听证会、异步听证会、弹出式听证会室，甚至虚拟现实听证会。

Emerging here we see a combination of state-based courts and online early settlement services that could be much more accessible and preventative than traditional public dispute resolution. For those cases that do require traditional handling by judges, I anticipate another blend of facilities—not just physical courts, but an array of options, including video hearings, audio hearings, hybrid hearings, asynchronous hearings, pop-up hearings rooms, and even hearings in virtual reality.

可以预见，系统性地脱离实体法院的趋势将面临强有力的挑战，甚至应该受到鼓励——以开放和知情的辩论形式进行。然而，在数字时代，鉴于我们现有法院的不足，可以合理地想象，各种形式的在线法院以及与法院相关的在线争议解决 (ODR) 将逐渐被引入。最富有成果的合法辩论将是关于在多大程度上取代传统听证会。目前一项重要的未完成任务是制定指导方针，确定哪些基于技术的替代技术最适合于哪些类型的争议。

Robust challenge to a systemic shift away from physical courts is to be expected and indeed encouraged—in the form of open-minded and informed debate. In the digital age, however, given the shortcomings of our current courts, it is reasonable to imagine that various forms of online court and court-connected ODR will be introduced over time. The most fruitful legitimate debate will be over the extent of the replacement of conventional hearings. A major outstanding task here is to develop guidelines on what types of technology-based alternative techniques are best suited to what types of dispute.

公平审判？

Fair Trial?

然而，视频听证会、在线法庭和高级在线争议解决 (ODR) 可能会被视为对日常公平审判观念的威胁。例如，犯罪受害者及其家人，以及民事纠纷中受害和受冤枉的当事人，可能会因为缺乏线下会面而感到不公。技术支持的解决方案可能无法提供一些人认为是司法程序核心部分的终结。更普遍而言，诉讼当事人会在法庭上失去胜诉的机会吗？是也不是。如果寻求线下听证会是为了公开辩护，那么在线处理虽然成本较低，但可能达不到要求。然而，如果视频听证会、在线法庭和高级在线争议解决能够更快地解决问题，甚至比司法部门要求的合理审理时间更快，那么这很可能抵消人们对无需亲自辩护。尽管我对此表示质疑，但也可以认为，基于技术的解决方案应该仅限于初步听证，大多数最终审判应该以传统方式进行。

Video hearings, online courts, and advanced ODR may be seen, however, as threatening everyday conceptions of fair trials. For example, victims of crimes and their families, alongside aggrieved and wronged parties in civil disputes, may feel short-changed by a lack of physical meeting. A technology-enabled resolution may not provide the closure that some regard as a central part of the judicial process. Will litigants, more generally, lose their day in court? Yes and no. If a physical hearing is sought for public vindication, then online disposal, although less costly, may fall short. However, if video hearings, online courts, and advanced ODR deliver a much speedier resolution, quicker even than the reasonable time within which justice requires that a case should be heard, then this may well offset the disappointment of not being vindicated in person. It can also be argued—although I contest this—that technology-based solutions should be confined to preliminary hearings and most final trials should be conducted in the traditional manner.

或许存在一个相关的担忧——听证会或审判应该在公开的场所进行，以便任何违法者的行为都能被公开宣告和谴责。ODR 的支持者认为，在线设施最终将提供更高的透明度，而不是更低的透明度，因为法院的运作和裁决将可以通过各种方式在线观察。有趣的是，这种担忧也可能促使人们呼吁对听证会和程序进行电视或广播，这将使其更加公开。这已经在发生——英国最高法院的诉讼程序在天空新闻网站上进行了现场直播。

There may be a related concern—that a hearing or trial should be in a publicly accessible forum, so that any wrongdoer’s acts are publicly declared and denounced. ODR proponents argue that online facilities will, in due course, offer greater rather than less transparency, because the workings and findings of the court will be observable online in various ways. Interestingly, this concern could equally be a call for televising or broadcasting hearings and processes, which would render them radically more public. This is already happening—the proceedings of the UK Supreme Court are broadcast live on the Sky News website.

至于判决的实际公正性，法官或在线调解员在远离部分或所有诉讼当事人、证人和律师的情况下，没有明显的理由表明他们应该缺乏公正性、独立性或公正性。当然，在追求公正的过程中，至关重要的是确保在线判决和裁定的合理性与传统庭审的合理性之间没有实际差异。同样重要的是，在线法院服务不应被视为“经济型”服务，而应为那些能够负担得起传统法院费用的人保留“商务舱”。成本更低、更快捷、更便捷、更易懂的服务是否劣质，这一点并不明显。

As to the actual fairness of decisions, there is no obvious reason why judges or online mediators should be any less impartial, independent, or just when physically remote from some or all litigants, witnesses, and lawyers. It will of course be crucial, in the pursuit of fairness, that there is no actual difference between the soundness of decisions and findings delivered online and those that flow from conventional hearings. It will also be crucial that an online court service is not regarded as an ‘economy’ service, reserving ‘business class’ for those who can afford conventional courts. It is not at all obvious that a service that is less costly, quicker, and more convenient and more intelligible will be the inferior service.

其他重要问题还有很多。远程获取的证据的可靠性和可信度如何？如果法官、陪审团和律师无法……直接注视法庭上证人的眼睛？还是大型高分辨率显示器上的特写三维视频能够更好地进行审查？在混合听证会中，律师应该陪伴客户在摄像机前，还是在靠近法官的听证室？如果远程作证的体验比在实体法庭上作证更令人恐惧（这很可能），那么这是否有助于证据更具说服力或更不具说服力，或者判决更具权威性和更有根据？

Other important questions abound. What about the reliability and credibility of evidence taken remotely? Will judges, juries, and lawyers be at a disadvantage if they cannot look across the courtroom directly into the eyes of witnesses? Or will close-up, three-dimensional video on large, high-resolution monitors permit improved scrutiny? Should lawyers, in hybrid hearings, be with their clients at the camera-end of proceedings or in the hearing rooms near the judges? If the experience of giving evidence remotely is, as is likely, less intimidating than being in a physical courtroom, will this be conducive to evidence that is more or less convincing or decisions that are more or less authoritative and well founded?

更广泛地说，从朱迪思·雷斯尼克和丹尼斯·柯蒂斯在其巨著《代表正义》中的思考来看，如果司法的主要标志之一——法庭——被取代，公众对司法的看法将有何影响？基于以用户为中心的设计思维技术（参见第16章）精心设计的在线法院能否成为争议解决一个更具包容性的新时代的象征？虽然视频听证会、在线法院和先进的ODR对当今的政策制定者和舆论领袖来说可能显得陌生或古怪，但这些人中很少有人来自数字时代。未来的几代人将在线工作和社交视为第二天性，他们的感受可能会截然不同。事实上，对于未来的客户而言，视频听证会、在线法院和ODR可以共同改善司法公正的可及性，并提供其他方式无法提供的争议解决途径。

More generally, flowing from the thinking of Judith Resnik and Dennis Curtis—in their magisterial book, Representing Justice—what will be the impact on public perceptions of justice if one of its main icons, the courtroom, is displaced? Could well-designed online courts—based on user-centric, design thinking techniques (see Chapter 16)—even become symbolic of a new, more inclusive era for dispute resolution? While video hearings, online courts, and advanced ODR may seem alien or outlandish for policy-makers and opinion formers of today, few of these individuals hail from the digital generation. Future generations, for whom working and socializing online will be second nature, may feel very differently. Indeed, for tomorrow’s clients, video hearings, online courts, and ODR together may improve access to justice and offer routes to dispute resolution where none would otherwise be available.

现在就对刚才提出的许多问题做出结论性回答还为时过早。毫无疑问，还需要更多的实证研究和分析。但从表面上看，并不存在任何令人信服的反对意见，也不存在任何压倒性的法律或原则问题，足以阻止法院和争议解决领域持续推进的计算机化进程。

It is too early to answer many of the questions just posed in a conclusive way. No doubt, more empirical research and analysis are needed. But, on the face of it, there are no knockdown objections, no overriding concerns of law or principle, that should call a halt to the ongoing and advanced computerization of courts and dispute resolution.

更普遍地说，批评者在将在线法院和ODR与某些理想化却又难以负担的传统法院服务进行比较时应谨慎。正如伏尔泰无疑会劝诫的那样，“最佳方案是比例的敌人”。应该进行比较的是当今的实际情况——一个成本过高、耗时过长、非律师人士难以理解，从而将许多拥有可信诉求的潜在诉讼当事人排除在外的系统。无论谁来付费，我们都必须找到一种方法，以相对于任何特定案件价值合理的成本，扩大获取途径并减少未满足的法律需求。在在线法院和ODR领域，我们相信我们已经找到了这样的方法。

More generally, critics should be cautious about comparing online courts and ODR with some ideal and yet simply unaffordable conventional court service. As Voltaire would no doubt have counselled, ‘the best is the enemy of the proportionate’. The comparison that should be made is with what we actually have today—a system that is too expensive, takes too long, is barely understandable to the non-lawyer, and so excludes many potential litigants with credible claims. Regardless of who is paying, we have to find a way of widening access and reducing unmet legal need at a cost that makes sense relative to the value of any given case. In online courts and ODR generally, we believe we have found such a way.

正因如此，我预测在线法院和ODR将被证明是一项颠覆性技术，将从根本上挑战传统诉讼律师和法官的工作（参见第六章）。从长远来看，我预计它们将成为解决除最复杂、价值最高的纠纷之外的所有纠纷的主导方式。

This is why I predict that online courts and ODR will prove to be a disruptive technology that fundamentally challenges the work of traditional litigators and of judges (see Chapter 6). In the long run, I expect them to become the dominant way to resolve all but the most complex and high-value disputes.

虚拟现实

Virtual Reality

值得关注的还有一种更遥远的可能性——在元宇宙或虚拟现实（我目前交替使用这两个术语）中进行公开法庭听证。广义上讲，这里的想法是，参与者将进入一个替代的在线世界，并在那里进行诉讼。这些法庭用户将戴上耳机，沉浸在计算机生成的世界中，这个世界可能与传统法庭非常相似，也可能看起来和感觉非常不同。诉讼程序可能遵循传统的法庭程序。规则，或者可以通过简化或改进的流程来管理。无论如何，我认为至少在最初几年，相关程序将基本同步。

A more distant possibility is worthy of note—the conduct of a public court hearing in the metaverse or virtual reality (I use the terms interchangeably for current purposes). In broad terms, the idea here would be that participants would enter an alternative, online world and proceedings would be conducted there. These court users would put on headsets and become immersed in computer-generated worlds, which might closely resemble traditional courtrooms or could alternatively look and feel very different. Proceedings might follow conventional court rules or could be governed by simplified or improved processes. In any event, I am imagining proceedings would be largely synchronous, at least in the early years.

我们为什么要这样做？因为人类常常努力寻找新的方式来实践旧有的习俗。想想另一个职业——神职人员——为什么曾经有一个蓬勃发展的基督教徒社群，在“第二人生”（一个虚拟的在线世界）上经营着一个“圣公会大教堂”，每周举办圣经学习班，每天举行礼拜仪式？丹尼尔·萨斯坎德和我曾在《职业的未来》一书中探讨过这一现象。即使我们中的一些人可能觉得这很奇怪，但相当多的用户发现“第二人生”社区很有用，令人振奋。对于在元宇宙中诉讼的法律用户来说，情况可能也是如此。

Why might we do this? Because human beings often strive to find new ways to conduct old practices. Think of another profession, the clergy—why was there ever a thriving community of Christians running an ‘Anglican Cathedral’ on Second Life, a virtual online world, with a weekly Bible study class and daily worship services? Daniel Susskind and I discuss this phenomenon in The Future of the Professions. Even if some of us might find this bizarre, significant numbers of users found that Second Life Community to be useful and uplifting. The same might be so for legal users of proceedings in the metaverse.

我并非强烈主张就元宇宙举行法庭听证会。我只是建议将其作为一种可能性。或许一些创业型初创企业、颇具创新精神的法院官员或激进的法官可以开发出类似的想法，经过一些设计和开发工作，它或许能够获得认可。

I am not here strongly advocating court hearings on the metaverse. I am simply suggesting them as a possibility. Perhaps some entrepreneurial start-up or notably innovative court official or radical judge might develop a version of this idea and, after some design and development effort, it could gain traction.

所有这些都可以从哲学上得到支持。亚里士多德有一种正义观，它指的是一种盲目的审判方式，法官面对的是案件本身而不是当事人，当事人及其律师的具体特征是无法察觉的。这种程序正义观的倡导者可以倡导建立基于虚拟现实的法庭，在法庭中，当事人可能并非以忠实的自我形象出现，而是以化身的形式出现，隐藏其真实身份。在元宇宙中以某种化身为代表的概念，乍一看可能有些古怪。这难道不会掩盖真正的诉讼当事人，使其远离诉讼程序吗？然而，从另一个角度来看，这正是律师的职责所在。如今，律师代表着客户及其利益，用他们自己的语言和风格，而不是那些聘请他们的人的口吻来陈述案件。如今的律师在某种程度上就像是替身，尽管我承认，当客户提供证据时，法官看到的是他们本来的样子。

Some philosophical support for all of this can be found. There is a conception of justice attributed to Aristotle that speaks of a blind form of judging, when judges are exposed to the case rather than the parties, and the specific characteristics of the parties and their lawyers are not visible. Advocates of this conception of procedural justice could call for virtual reality-based courts in which parties might appear not as faithful renderings of themselves but as avatars, concealing their real identities. The notion of being represented in the metaverse by some sort of avatar may seem outlandish on first encounter. Would this not conceal the real litigant, placing him or her at a distance from proceedings. And yet, in a different way, this is what lawyers are today—a representation of clients and their interests, putting forward cases in their own words and style, rather than in the voice of those who retain them. Today’s lawyers are avatars of a sort, although I concede that when clients give evidence, the judge sees them as they are.

电脑法官？

Computer Judge?

围绕在线法院的诸多争论背后，潜伏着一个极具争议的问题：计算机是否会取代法官。20 世纪 80 年代初，我曾明确指出，计算机承担法官的工作既不可能（从技术角度而言），也不可取（从原则角度而言）。但现在我不那么肯定了。我在《在线法院与司法的未来》一书中详细阐述了我的立场。我仍然认为，疑难案件的司法裁决，尤其是当法官需要处理涉及原则、政策和道德的复杂问题时，远远超出了当前计算机系统的能力。我也仍然认为，至少目前，在解决可能改变人生的问题时，大多数人会更倾向于选择法官而不是机器。我还进一步认为，从更普遍的意义上讲，目前大多数人认为，由机器进行司法裁决，即使不是完全错误，也是在道德上值得怀疑的。

Lurking behind many debates about online courts is the deeply contentious question of whether computers might ever replace judges. In the early 1980s, I came emphatically to the conclusion that it was neither possible (technically) nor desirable (as a matter of principle) for computers to take on the work of judges. I am now less sure. My position on this is explained at length in Online Courts and the Future of Justice. I still accept that judicial decision-making in hard cases, especially when judges are called upon to handle complex issues of principle, policy, and morality, is well beyond the capabilities of current computer systems. I also still accept, for now at least, that most people would prefer a judge to a machine when it comes to resolving potentially life-changing problems. And I accept yet further that most people, in some more general sense, currently regard it as morally questionable if not plain wrong for machines to make judicial decisions.

然而，与年轻时的我不同，我现在可以想象，在某些情况下，我们甚至可能欢迎机器生成具有完全权威性和约束力的法院裁决。我提出这一点，是为了挑衅，而非提出一个全面的建议。我的出发点是这些机构正在讨论的一个问题。页——在许多国家，低额民事诉讼要么积压严重，要么由于各种原因根本无法送达律师和法院。例如，在巴西，其法院系统积压的案件约有7000万起，而在大多数发达司法管辖区，绝大多数人都负担不起律师费。无论是长期拖延还是法律需求未得到满足，现实情况是，这两类案件都不太可能在传统法庭上由法官和律师解决。这个问题需要新的思维和新的解决方案。

However, unlike my younger self, I can now conceive of circumstances in which we might even welcome machines generating fully authoritative and binding court determinations. I put this forward as a provocation rather than a full-scale proposal. My starting point is a problem discussed across these pages—in many countries, low-value civil claims are either stuck in great backlogs or, for a variety of reasons, never reach lawyers and courts at all. In Brazil, for example, the backlog in their court system is around 70 million cases, and in most advanced jurisdictions, lawyers are unaffordable for the great majority of people. Whether characterised as chronic delay or unmet legal need, the reality is that cases in neither category are likely ever to be resolved by judges and lawyers in traditional courtrooms. This problem calls for new thinking and new solutions.

我所指的就是所谓的“预测即裁定”。利用机器学习技术，我们拥有的系统能够越来越准确地预测法官的裁定结果（参见第六章和第二十二章）。原则上，这些系统可以在国家支持下运行，并在当事人同意的情况下，将其写入法院规则：对于特定类型的纠纷，如果系统预测法院裁定有利于原告的概率大于95%，则该裁定将成为法院的正式裁定。

What I have in mind is what I call ‘predictions as determinations’. Using machine learning technology, we have systems that are getting better and better at predicting the findings of judges (see Chapters 6 and 22). In principle, these systems could be put into operation under the auspices of the state and, with the agreement of parties, it could be enshrined in the rules of court that, for particular types of disputes, if the system predicts a court finding in favour of the claimant with a probability factor greater than, say, 95 per cent, then that finding becomes the official determination of the court.

为了帮助当事人继续前进，至少有可能一些诉讼当事人（特别是年轻的诉讼当事人，他们越来越喜欢在线解决问题）可能会说，这种系统——基于与法院过去判决相关的数据生成具有约束力的预测的系统——比僵局的传统法院或根本没有可访问的解决程序要好。

In the interests of helping parties move on, it is at least possible that some litigants (especially young litigants, for whom online problem-solving is increasingly popular) might say that such a system—one that generates binding predictions, based on data relating to past decisions of the court—is preferable to the gridlocked traditional court or to no accessible resolution process at all.

再次强调，这个想法并非虚构。一些司法管辖区——例如巴西、意大利和新加坡——正在积极探索这种可能性。请记住，如果你直觉地认为这很奇怪甚至危险，那么一个关键的测试是问题不在于预测作为决定因素与传统司法决策相比如何；而在于预测是否比什么都没有要好。我再次引用伏尔泰的话。

Again, this idea is not from the realms of fiction. Some jurisdictions—for instance, Brazil, Italy, and Singapore—are actively exploring this possibility. And do remember, if your instinct is that this is bizarre or even dangerous, a key test is not how predictions as determinations compare with traditional judicial decision-making; it is whether they would be better than nothing at all. I refer again to Voltaire.

那些对机器学习有所了解的读者可能会立即提出异议，指出这些系统就像黑匣子，无法解释其推理过程，而且它们所基于的数据很可能存在偏差。在我关于在线法院的书中，我详细回应了这些以及其他担忧。在这种情况下，我一如既往地倾向于务实而非纯粹的前进方向。本着这种精神，我提出一个问题——即使对当前机器学习的危险和局限性进行谨慎或负面的分析，至少在某些情况下，用预测系统来处理案件，而不是让当事人等待永远不会到来的人类司法裁决，难道不是更好吗？对于一些法院使用者来说，问题的最终解决可能比流程的透明度更重要。而当基础数据是过去的司法裁决或关于这些裁决的数据时，偏见可能不会大于先例原则中固有的偏见。

Readers who have dipped into machine learning might immediately object, pointing out that these systems are black boxes and as such cannot explain their lines of reasoning and, more, they are based on data that may well be biased. In my book on online courts, I respond to these and other concerns at length. I lean in this context, as often I do, toward the pragmatic rather than the purist way forward. And in that spirit, I ask this—even on a cautious or negative analysis of the dangers and limitations of current machine learning, would it not be better on at least some occasions to dispose of cases by predictive systems rather than leave parties to wait for the human judicial decision that will never come? For some court users, the finality of an issue settled might well be more important than the transparency of the process. And when the underlying data is past judicial decisions or data about these decisions, the bias may be no greater than that which inheres in any event in the doctrine of precedent.

15 重温法律的未来

15 The Future of Law, Revisited

这本书并非我第一次尝试对法律和法律服务的未来做出20年的预测。1996年，我撰写《法律的未来》时，也曾有过类似的大胆预测。我记得当时觉得2016年似乎还很遥远，但我们已经远远超过了那个里程碑。不知不觉中，2036年就将到来，即使今天听起来，那一年仿佛遥远得像个星球。

This book is not my first attempt to make a 20-year prediction in relation to the law and legal services. I was similarly foolhardy in 1996, when I wrote The Future of Law. I recall thinking at the time that 2016 seemed like a very long way off, and yet we are already a long way past that milestone. Before we know it, 2036 will be upon us, even if that year sounds today like some distant planet.

《法律的未来》出版时，全球只有3500万人上网。如今，互联网用户已超过50亿。1996年，英国只有少数律师真正接触过万维网，几乎没有客户收到过外部法律顾问的电子邮件，手机更是稀罕物。亚马逊才刚刚诞生两年，谷歌也尚未发明，YouTube、Facebook、Twitter、TikTok和维基百科也同样尚未被发明。想到未来20年可能出现的改变生活的系统和服务尚未被构想出来，既令人兴奋又令人不安。

When The Future of Law was published, only 35 million people were online. Now there are over 5 billion Internet users. Back in 1996, only a few lawyers in the UK had actually seen the World Wide Web, scarcely any clients had received an email from an external legal adviser, and mobile phones were a rarity. Amazon was but two years old. Google had not yet been invented. Nor had YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, TikTok, or Wikipedia. It is at once exciting and disconcerting to contemplate that the life-changing systems and services that will likely emerge in the next 20 years have not yet been conceived.

《法律的未来》的副标题是“面对信息技术的挑战”。这份长达300页的呼吁书，可​​以说在英国法律界引起了一些恐慌。世界。这本书充满了稀奇古怪的建议，比如我提倡客户和律师之间更多地使用电子邮件，以及我声称网络将成为法律研究的有力工具。法律界对此感到愤慨。邮政系统怎么了？难道我没有听说过法律图书馆吗？我对现实的把握受到了质疑。

The subtitle of The Future of Law was ‘Facing the Challenges of Information Technology’. It is fair to say that this 300-page call to arms caused some consternation in the British legal world. The book was full of outlandish suggestions, such as my promotion of the greater use of email between clients and their lawyers, and my allegation that the Web would be a powerful tool for legal research. The legal establishment was indignant. What was the matter with the postal system? Had I not heard of law libraries? My grip on reality was called into question.

我坚持那个时代的主流观点。然而，回想起来，有些细节充其量也只是可笑——比如“信息高速公路”之类的说法，现在看来简直荒唐。

I stand by the broad arguments from that era. In retrospect, however, some of the detail is laughable at best—references to the ‘information superhighway’, for example, now seem bizarre.

法律范式的转变

Shift in Legal Paradigm

我这本书的核心主张是，法律范式将会发生转变（回想起来，这个术语的选择令人遗憾，因为“范式”一词如今已被过度使用）。我的意思是，我们关于法律服务本质和法律程序本质的许多基本假设将受到技术和互联网的挑战和改变。换句话说，我们过去一直认为理所当然的许多事情，例如律师的工作方式和非律师人士获得法律指导的方式，都将因为建立在技术基础上的新系统和服务而发生改变。表15.1重现了我在1996年对范式转变的总结。

The central claim of my book was that there was going to be a shift in legal paradigm (a regrettable choice of term in retrospect because ‘paradigm’ has since become rather overused). By this I meant that many of our fundamental assumptions about the nature of legal service and the nature of legal process would be challenged and changed by the coming of technology and the Internet. In other words, much that we had always taken for granted in the past, about the way that lawyers work and the way non-lawyers receive legal guidance, would be transformed because of the new systems and services that would be built on the back of technology. My 1996 summary of the paradigm shift is reproduced in Table 15.1.

表 15.1 法律范式的转变

TABLE 15.1 The shift in legal paradigm

当今的法律范式 未来的法律范式
法律服务 法律服务
咨询服务 信息服务
一对一 一对多
反应式服务 主动服务
按时间计费 商品定价
限制性 赋权
防御 务实
法律焦点 业务重点
法律程序 法律程序
法律问题解决 法律风险管理
争议解决 争议优先
法律公布 法律的颁布
专注的法律职业 法律专家和信息工程师
基于印刷 基于信息技术的法律体系

25 年后我可能不会使用完全相同的术语，但我认为——如果我可以给自己做个作业的话——我所确定的旅行方向基本上已经被采用了。

I may not use precisely the same terminology 25 years on, but I think—if I may mark my own homework—that the direction of travel I identified is largely being taken.

从总体上看，上述第一点和最后一点变化仍然是最重要的。恕我直言，我对放弃咨询服务的举措进行了如下总结：

At a high level, the first and the last of the changes noted remain the most important. If I will be forgiven for quoting myself, I summarized the move away from advisory service as follows:

信息技术最终将使法律服务从一种咨询服务转变为一种信息服务……最终的交付成果将是可重复使用的法律指导和信息服务其一般性水平远高于当今法律咨询工作所特有的重点建议。

IT will eventually enable and encourage legal service to change from being a form of advisory service to a type of information service . . . The ultimate deliverable will be reusable legal guidance and information service pitched at a level of generality considerably higher than the focused advice which characterizes legal advisory work of today.

在最后一页，关于放弃印刷品，我预测：

And, on the final page, in relation to leaving print behind, I predicted that:

在未来的法律范式中，法律实践和司法行政将不再受印刷品和纸张的主导。相反，信息社会的法律体系将在日益强大的信息技术的巨大影响下迅速发展。

legal practice and the administration of justice will no longer be dominated by print and paper in tomorrow’s legal paradigm. Instead, legal systems of the information society will evolve rapidly under the considerable influence of ever more powerful information technologies.

请记住，在1996年，这些主要建议被认为是令人愤慨的，甚至可以说是煽动性的。至于其他的变化，比如三明治的馅料——值得逐一审视。

Do remember that in 1996, these principal suggestions were regarded as outrageous if not plain seditious. As for the other changes, the filling of the sandwich—it is worth taking stock of each in turn.

从法律服务预期的变化来看，从一对一到一对多的转变体现在两个方面：律师对专业知识和案例的获取和再利用，以及在线服务，其内容惠及众多不同的用户。在这两种情况下，法律指导都不再像处理垃圾一样被处理，而是被回收利用。

Starting with the projected changes in legal service, the move from one-to-one to one-to-many legal service has manifested itself in two ways: in lawyers’ capture and re-use of know-how and precedents, and in online service where the content benefits many different users. In both circumstances, rather than handling legal guidance as though it were disposal, it is instead recycled.

关于提高法律服务的主动性，人们说的太多，做的却太多。经验丰富的客户表示，他们从事的是法律风险管理，而不是法律问题解决，而蓬勃发展的合规领域则以规避法律问题而非解决法律问题为前提。我预计，当……时，主动性将成为法律服务的核心。出现了合适的技术来提供帮助（例如机器学习方法可以隔离可以在大量协议或电子邮件中查明的问题）。

There has been much more said than done about greater proactivity in legal service. Sophisticated clients say that they are in the business of legal risk management rather than legal problem-solving, and the ever-burgeoning field of compliance is premised on avoiding rather than resolving legal problems. I expect proactivity will come to the heart of legal service when suitable technologies emerge to help (such as machine learning methods to isolate problems that can be pinpointed in large bodies of agreements or emails).

关于按时计费，几十年来评论员们一直在预测其将走向消亡。如今，似乎确实出现了一种稳步且普遍的转向，以商品为基础的定价模式，即固定费用。律师或许更倾向于按时间收费，但客户更愿意知道他们的法律费用究竟是多少。到2020年代，按小时计费作为主流收费机制的地位将逐渐消失。

In relation to time-based billing, commentators for decades have been predicting its demise. At long last, it does indeed seem that there is a steady and widespread shift to commodity-based pricing, in the shape of fixed fees. Lawyers may prefer to charge for the time they spend, but clients prefer to know how much their legal bills will be. Hourly billing will fade away in the 2020s as the dominant charging mechanism.

随着法律指南在网络上逐渐普及，法律对许多用户来说已不再陌生。任何具备阅读能力且能上网的人都能够轻松掌握日常法律。在某种程度上，这已经使法律不再神秘。随着在线争议解决和在线法院（第14章）的不断引入，公民和小型企业经营者将越来越感受到自身赋能，不再受法律束缚——每个人都将能够理解并行使自己的权利。

As guidance on legal issues has become steadily available on the Web, the law has become less alien for many users. Everyday law is already within the grasp of anyone who can read and is connected. To some extent, this has demystified the law. With the ongoing introduction of online dispute resolution and online courts (Chapter 14), citizens and those who run small businesses will increasingly feel empowered and not restricted by the law—it will be within the grasp of everyone to understand and enforce their entitlements.

2020年代初期，大多数主流律师仍然对自己的法律建议进行资格审查和对冲，通常是因为担心被那些将咨询外部律师视为保险的客户（根据我的经验，这种人是少数）起诉。相比之下，尽管一些在线法律服务附带免责声明，但大多数服务确实以防御性更低、更务实的方式提供和使用。用户似乎明白，网络服务并非人为服务。尽管一些律师兴高采烈地预测，他们将忙于处理那些因依赖有缺陷的法律技术而遭受损失的客户，但我找不到任何证据表明这种情况确实发生过。

Most mainstream lawyers in the early 2020s still qualify and hedge their legal advice, often for fear of being sued by those clients (a minority, in my experience) who regard consultation with external counsel as a form of insurance. In contrast, although some online legal services come with disclaimers, most are indeed offered and used in a less defensive and more pragmatic manner. Users seem to understand that a Web-based service is not a human being and although some lawyers have predicted gleefully that they will be kept busy with clients who have suffered loss from relying on defective legal technology, I can find no evidence of this having happened.

从法律转向商业重点的意义在于，许多问题，无论对于小型企业还是跨国企业而言，都并非简单地被简单地归类为“法律”问题。相反，法律问题总是出现在更广泛的商业环境中，不应脱离这一更广泛的背景。我在1996年就预测，在线服务很可能具有多学科特征。如今，许多政府和行业机构的网站确实如此，这些网站上的法律指导通常与会计和税务咨询等服务相结合。但律师事务所的律师仍然在传统的法律界限内组织他们的业务和咨询服务。值得注意的是，客户因此批评他们，而且四大会计师事务所的法律业务似乎更侧重于商业解决方案，而不是法学院在法律领域中的分支。

The point about shifting from a legal to a business focus is that many problems, for small and global businesses alike, do not come neatly packaged as ‘legal’. Rather, legal questions invariably arise in a broader business context and should not be divorced from that broader setting. I predicted in 1996 that online services would be likely to be multidisciplinary in flavour. This is certainly now true of the websites of many government and trade bodies, where legal guidance is often integrated with, say, accounting and tax advice. But lawyers in law firms still organize their businesses and their advice in conventional legal boundaries. It is significant that clients criticize them for this and that the legal businesses of Big 4 accounting firms seem to be focusing more on business solutions than law school subdivisions of the legal world.

就法律程序的变革而言，从法律问题解决到法律风险管理的转变预示着一个法律问题往往在需要解决之前就被化解的世界。这与从被动服务到主动服务的转变息息相关。这里的愿景是，通过早期的法律洞察，法律问题得到控制，并避免其进一步升级。从历史上看，这需要人类律师提供早期的警示性建议。如今，我们生活在一个许多人通过网络查询自身权利或义务已成为习惯的世界。随着在线法律指导的改进，我们识别和管理法律风险的能力也将不断提升。

Regarding the changes in legal process, the shift from legal problem-solving to legal risk management anticipates a world in which legal problems are often dissolved before needing to be resolved. This links to the swing from reactive to proactive service. The vision here is of a society in which legal problems are contained, prevented from escalating, by the earlier input of legal insight. Historically, this required human lawyers offering early cautionary advice. We now live in a world in which it is second nature for many people to consult the Web to check their rights or obligations. As online legal guidance improves, so too will our ability to identify and manage legal risks.

一个相关的举措是从争议解决到争议优先，这在网络法院的世界中日益明显（参见第12章和第14章）。我们开始在世界各地观察到的拟议改革背后的一个驱动力是倾向于将案件从通过司法途径解决往往更为迅速、更为友好且成本更低。

A related move is that from dispute resolution to dispute pre-emption, which is becoming more visible by the day in the world of online courts (see Chapters 12 and 14). One driving force behind the proposed reforms that we are beginning to observe around the world is an inclination to move cases away from judicial resolution to earlier, often more amicable and less costly handling.

《法律的未来》即将付印之际，人们对法律的不可及性展开了激烈的争论，人们愤怒地认为，购买那些我们理应知晓其约束性内容的立法却要花费高昂的成本。一场名为“自由法律”的运动在鼓励英国政府向互联网用户免费提供立法材料方面发挥了重要作用。正如我在1996年所写，“将会有更多材料变得随时可用且易于获取”。我指的是立法和判例法。两个网站证实了这一说法——< http://www.legislation.gov.uk >（英国主要和次要立法的官方在线数据库）和< https://caselaw.nationalarchives.gov.uk >（一个新的（2022年）英格兰和威尔士法院和法庭判决案例报告存储库）。但是，在我们能够说我们完全颁布法律之前，我们还有一段路要走，也就是说，我们有一个普遍可访问的机制，可以在新法律颁布时告知公众。

When The Future of Law was going to press, there was great debate about the inaccessibility of the law and outrage that it cost a lot to buy the legislation whose binding content we are all assumed to know. A campaign called ‘free the law’ played an important part in encouraging the British government to make legislative materials available to Internet users at no cost to them. As I wrote in 1996, ‘far more materials will be made readily available and easily accessible’. I was referring both to legislation and case law. Two websites corroborate this claim—<http://www.legislation.gov.uk> (the official online database of primary and secondary legislation in the UK) and <https://caselaw.nationalarchives.gov.uk> (a new (2022) repository of case reports of court and tribunal decisions in England and Wales). But we have some way to go yet before we can say that we fully promulgate, that is, that we have a universally accessible mechanism in place for letting the general public know when new laws are enacted.

最后，我在1996年预测了法律界人员的变化——并非专职法律职业的消失，而是新角色的出现，尤其是信息工程师（我们今天倾向于称之为“知识工程师”——参见第十六章），他们与法律专家并肩合作，构建在线法律指导系统和文档自动化服务。事实上，传统律师的数量仍然远远超过新参与者，但法律科技初创企业和技术型资产评估机构（ABS）数量的快速增长，以及高科技大型会计师事务所和法律出版商对法律领域参与度的不断提升，都清晰地表明了新的劳动分工。

Finally, I predicted in 1996 a change in personnel in law—not the disappearance of a dedicated legal profession but the emergence of new roles, and not least the information engineers (we tend today to call them ‘knowledge engineers’—see Chapter 16) who work alongside legal specialists in building online legal guidance systems and document automation services. In truth, conventional lawyers still greatly outnumber the new players, but the swiftly growing numbers of lawtech start-ups and technology-based ABSs, alongside the increasing engagement in law of the high-tech large accounting firms and legal publishers, are all clear signs of a new division of labour.

潜在的法律市场

The Latent Legal Market

更广泛地审视法律范式的转变，我在1996年提出的一个相关主张与“潜在法律市场”有关。当时，这一主张引起了广泛关注。我用“潜在法律市场”来指代这样一种观点：许多人在社会和工作生活中需要法律帮助，并可能从法律指导中受益，但他们缺乏资源，或许仅仅是缺乏勇气，无法获得律师的法律咨询。正如本章所述，自那时以来，情况发生了很大变化——如今，我们拥有丰富的在线资源，人们可以从成千上万的政府网站、众多志愿法律服务机构的网站以及以营销形式提供在线法律帮助的律师那里获得实用且有力的法律指导。潜在的法律市场在很大程度上已经实现。

Looking more broadly again at the shift in legal paradigm, one related claim I made in 1996 concerned the ‘latent legal market’. At the time, this attracted a lot of interest. This was my term for the notion that many people in their social and working lives needed legal help and would have benefited from legal guidance but lacked the resources, or perhaps simply the courage, to secure legal counsel from lawyers. As this chapter suggests, much has changed since then—we now have vast online resources available to people who can indeed obtain practical, punchy legal guidance from thousands of government websites or the many sites of the voluntary legal services sector and also of lawyers who offer online legal help as a form of marketing. The latent legal market has to a significant extent been realized.

总而言之，我承认我20年前预测的范式转变尚未完全实现。但我认为，现在的问题不是转变是否会发生，而是何时发生。我目前的预期是，这场转变将在2020年代完成。在顺利的日子里，相对于我在《法律的未来》一书中的预测，我现在感觉自己大约落后了十年。

In all, then, I accept that the shift in paradigm that I projected 20 years ago has not yet fully come to pass. But I submit that the question now is not whether the shift will happen but when it will transpire. My current expectation is that the transformation will be complete in the 2020s. On a good day, in relation to the predictions in my book, The Future of Law, I now feel I was about ten years out.

第三部分

PART THREE

年轻律师的前景

Prospects for Young Lawyers

律师的16个新职业

16 New Jobs for Lawyers

我预测，未来几年，传统律师在社会中的地位将不如今天。客户将不再愿意为那些可以由经验不足的专业人士在完善的系统和标准流程的支持下完成的工作支付昂贵的法律顾问费用。这一预测并非完全预示着律师的终结，但它确实表明对传统律师的需求将会减少。与此同时，当系统和流程在法律领域发挥更核心的作用时，这将为重要的新型法律服务开辟可能性，并为那些足够灵活、开放、具有创业精神、能够适应不断变化的市场条件的律师提供令人兴奋的新工作。

In years to come, I predict that conventional lawyers will not be as prominent in society as today. Clients will not be inclined to pay expensive legal advisers for work that can be undertaken by less expert people, supported by capable systems and standard processes. This prediction does not signal the end of lawyers entirely but it does point to a need for fewer traditional lawyers. At the same time, when systems and processes play a more central role in law, this opens up the possibility of important new forms of legal service, and of exciting new jobs for those lawyers who are sufficiently flexible, open-minded, and entrepreneurial to adapt to changing market conditions.

值得信赖的专家顾问

The Expert Trusted Adviser

在可预见的未来，两种传统律师仍将存在。当工作无法标准化或计算机化，且定制服务不可避免时，客户仍会寻求“值得信赖的专家顾问”的帮助。这些律师聪明、富有创造力、富有创新精神，能够设计并阐明新的解决方案和策略。为面临复杂或高价值法律挑战的客户（专家要素）。这些律师不仅能够诚信、严格保密地提供指导，还能以高度定制化、个性化和个性化的方式提供指导（值得信赖的要素）。许多律师会说，这正是他们如今所做的。他们会告诉你，他们所有的工作都已经需要专家和值得信赖的处理方式。但许多客户并不这么认为，他们认为律师夸大了这些高超的技艺。然而，最终，那些在竞争对手能够以替代性、可靠且成本更低的方式提供服务时仍然坚持手工操作的律师，很快就会在竞争中失败。

Two kinds of traditional lawyer will still be in play for the foreseeable future. When work cannot be standardized or computerized, and bespoke service is unavoidable, clients will still call upon their ‘expert trusted advisers’. These are intelligent, creative, innovative lawyers who can fashion and articulate new solutions and strategies for clients who have complex or high-value legal challenges (the expert element). These are also lawyers who can communicate their guidance not just with integrity and in strict confidence but in a highly tailored, customized, and personalized way (the trusted component). Many lawyers will say that this is precisely what they do today. They will tell you that all their work already requires expert and trusted handling. Many clients think otherwise and say that lawyers overstate these claims of high craftsmanship. In the end, though, those who handcraft while their competitors are able to source their services in alternative, reliable, and less costly ways will quickly fail to compete.

增强型从业者

The Enhanced Practitioner

此外，还需要“高级执业律师”，即技能娴熟、知识渊博但并非深谙专业之道的律师。他们不会被要求提供定制服务，而是借助标准化和计算机化的现代技术，进一步向我在第四章中描述的进化路径的右侧发展。高级执业律师通常会担任专家级可信赖顾问的法律助理，负责那些需要律师而非高薪专家参与的工作。然而，市场只有在真正需要这类助理或律师经验时才会对其产生需求。

There will also be a need for the ‘enhanced practitioner’, a skilled, knowledgeable but not deeply expert lawyer, who will not be asked to deliver a bespoke service but, enhanced by modern techniques of standardization and computerization, will work further to the right-hand side of the evolutionary path that I describe in Chapter 4. The enhanced practitioner will often act as a legal assistant to the expert trusted adviser for those tasks that require a lawyer but not necessarily a costly specialist. Again, however, the market will only have appetite for these kinds of assistant or associate when their legal experience is genuinely needed.

明日律师

Tomorrow’s Lawyers

尽管大多数传统律师的长期前景比过去更加有限，但我敦促年轻律师不要灰心丧气，因为我相信，对于接受过法律培训的人来说，将会有一系列充满希望的新机遇和新职业。我在表16.1中总结了其中的15个。我相信还会有其他的（例如，参见《职业的未来》中更详细的讨论）。目前，这些工作与本书的论点和主张相符。

Although the long-term prospects for most conventional lawyers are much more limited than in the past, I urge young lawyers not to be demotivated or downhearted, because there will be, I believe, a promising range of new opportunities and new careers for people trained in the law. I summarize 15 of these in Table 16.1. I am confident there will be others (see, for example, the more extended discussion in The Future of the Professions). For now, these are the jobs that flow quite clearly from the arguments and claims of this book.

在律师事务所和公司法务部门演讲时，我经常会展示表格16.1的一个版本，然后问听众：“这些人是谁？” 然后我会听到一片疑惑的表情。我接着说，这些人将设计出取代我们传统工作方式的系统。这些人是这些人将构建未来系统，解决那些目前仅靠传统律师才能解决的问题。因此，我继续说，这些人的系统将解决未来法律客户的许多问题。我总结一下，这些人就是未来的律师。此时此刻，人们的表情变成了怀疑，甚至是愤慨。我继续解释说，我更倾向于将律师定义为致力于帮助法律客户解决法律难题的人，而不是局限于他们最初的培训和随后的职业道路。

When giving talks to law firms and in-house legal departments, I often present a version of Table 16.1 and ask the audience, ‘who are these people?’ I then face a sea of quizzical expressions. These are the people, I go on to say, who will design the systems that will replace our traditional ways of working. These are the people who will build the systems that will, in the future, solve the problems to which conventional lawyers are currently our only feasible answer. These therefore are the people, I continue, whose systems will solve many of the problems of tomorrow’s legal clients. These people, I conclude, are tomorrow’s lawyers. At this juncture, the facial expressions morph to incredulity and even indignance. I go on to explain that I prefer to define lawyers as people whose work is devoted to helping legal clients with their legal difficulties, rather than in the more limited terms of their original training and subsequent career path.

如果这份名单让在职律师感到不安，那我算是尽职尽责了。这真是一个警钟。如今的律师如果想保持竞争力和市场需求，就必须承担起其中一些角色。这方面的挑战被一本关于领导力的畅销书书名巧妙地概括了——《成就你的成功之路》——正是如此。虽然作者马歇尔·戈德史密斯并没有关注律师职业的变迁，但他的书名却为当今执业的合格律师设定了方向。从长远来看，你需要改变才能生存。

If looking at this list unnerves current lawyers, then I am doing my job. This is a wake-up call. Today’s lawyers will themselves have to take on some of these roles if they want to remain relevant and in demand. The challenge here is neatly captured in the title of a bestselling book on leadership—What Got You Here Won’t Get You There. Precisely. Although its author, Marshall Goldsmith, was not focusing on the changing face of the professions, his title sets the agenda for qualified lawyers who are in practice today. In the long run, you will need to change to survive.

表 16.1 律师的新工作

TABLE 16.1 New jobs for lawyers

法律设计思想家
法律知识工程师
合法无编码
法律技术专家
合法混合体
法律程序分析师
法律项目经理
法律数据科学家
法律数据可视化工具
研发人员
数字安全卫士
ODR 从业者
主持人
法律管理顾问
法律风险管理师

现在，让我更详细地介绍一下未来的几位律师。未来某一天，你们或许会成为以下几位律师中的一位或几位。

Let me now introduce you in more detail to some of tomorrow’s lawyers. One day, you may be one or more of the following.

法律设计思想家

Legal Design Thinker

随着越来越多的法律应用程序和解决方案被设计为供缺乏法律知识的人直接使用，至关重要的是法律科技正在摆脱“由律师设计，为律师服务”的思维模式。我们需要借鉴日益流行且成功的“设计思维”——能够帮助识别并满足系统和服务用户特定需求和愿望的技术、方法、流程和技术。我们需要法律设计思想家，他们能够带领我们超越仅仅开发“用户友好型”的系统，尽管用户友好性仍然至关重要。更确切地说，他们将影响这些系统的实际内容和实质。

As more and more legal applications and solutions are built for direct use by people with little legal knowledge, it is vital that legal technology rids itself of its ‘designed by lawyers for lawyers’ mentality. We need instead to draw from the increasingly popular and successful field of ‘design thinking’—techniques, methods, processes, and technologies that can help identify and satisfy the particular needs and wants of the users of systems and services. We need legal design thinkers who will take us way beyond the development of systems that are simply ‘user-friendly’, although user-friendliness will remain of great importance. Rather, they will inform the actual content and substance of these systems.

例如，在构建下一代法院系统时，法律设计思想家将带领我们开发能够引导用户了解复杂法律领域的系统；用更精简的规则取代大量的法庭程序，其中许多规则将对用户隐藏；将流程分解为非禁止性的、可管理的部分；并超越使用文本与用户互动，利用动画、卡通、视频、流程图和其他法律流程的视觉指南。

For example, in building the next generation of court systems, legal design thinkers will lead us to develop systems that can guide users through complex areas of law; replace the great volumes of court procedure with much leaner rules, many of which will be hidden from users; break down the process into non-forbidding, manageable chunks; and reach beyond the use of text to interact with users, taking advantage of animations, cartoons, videos, flowcharts, and other visual guides to legal processes.

我们还需要设计思想家来帮助确保残疾人和弱势用户的需求融入我们系统的原始设计中，而不是事后才想到的。

We also need design thinkers to help ensure that the needs of disabled and disadvantaged users are built into the original design of our systems rather than contrived as an afterthought.

法律知识工程师

Legal Knowledge Engineer

当法律服务走向标准化和信息化时，需要大量优秀的律师来整理和建模大量复杂的法律材料和流程。法律需要被分析、提炼，然后被捕捉为标准的工作实践，并被具体化。在计算机系统中。其结果可能是，例如，在线法律服务，或者法律无缝地嵌入到某个更广泛的系统或流程中（参见第六章）。

When legal service comes to be standardized and computerized, talented lawyers will be required in great numbers to organize and model huge quantities of complex legal materials and processes. The law will need to be analysed, distilled, and then captured as standard working practices and embodied in computer systems. The result of this might be, for example, an online legal service, or it could be that the law is seamlessly embedded in some broader system or process (see Chapter 6).

制定法律标准和程序，并在计算机系统中组织和呈现法律知识，本质上是一项法律研究和法律分析的工作。更重要的是，它通常比传统的法律工作更需要智力投入，主要是因为创建一个能够解决许多问题的系统比找到某个特定问题的答案更费力。许多传统律师认为，标准和系统的开发可以完全交给初级律师、专业支持人员甚至系统分析师，这种想法显然是错误的。如果一家现代法律机构希望凭借其一流的系统在竞争中脱颖而出，那么它必须拥有一流的律师参与构建这些系统。这些律师将成为法律知识工程师。

Developing legal standards and procedures, and organizing and representing legal knowledge in computer systems, is irreducibly a job of legal research and legal analysis. More than this, it is often more intellectually demanding than traditional legal work, largely because it is more taxing to create a system that can solve many problems than to find an answer to a specific issue. It is plainly wrong to imagine, as many conventional lawyers do, that the development of standards and systems is a task that can be handed over in its entirety to junior lawyers, professional support staff, or even systems analysts. If a modern legal business intends to compete on the strength of its first-rate systems, then it must have first-rate lawyers engaged in building them. These lawyers will be legal knowledge engineers.

合法无编码

Legal No-coder

一些（但并非所有）法律知识工程师也无需编程。法律领域“无需编程”的理念可以追溯到 20 世纪 80 年代，当时开发基于规则的专家系统（参见第 22 章）的人们受益于被称为“shell”的工具。类似的系统也可用于文档自动化。​​如果你能够逻辑思考，并将法律或法律流程简化为决策树或流程图，那么“shell”会完成剩下的工作——它们会将你的决策树或流程图转换为交互式诊断或绘图系统。基本上，你不需要成为一名程序员就可以构建可维护的系统（尽管可以说，该过程实际上是一种高级结构化编程）。

Some (but not all) legal knowledge engineers will also be no-coders. The idea of no-coding in law can be traced to the 1980s, when people developing rule-based expert systems (see Chapter 22) were greatly assisted by the availability of tools known as ‘shells’. Similar systems were available for document automation. If you were able to think logically and reduce the law or legal processes to decision trees or flowcharts then the shells did the rest of the work—they converted your tree or chart into an interactive diagnostic or drafting system. Basically, you did not need to be a programmer to build a serviceable system (although arguably, the process was in fact a form of high-level structured programming).

本着同样的精神，法律领域正在涌现出一波新的无代码和低代码工具，使得无需大量软件工程师参与即可开发系统和应用程序。法律领域的无代码人员将成为能够开发自己系统的律师。这些工具在创建试点项目、演示程序和早期版本方面将发挥最大作用，因为通常情况下，一个完全可操作、用户友好的系统也需要主流程序员进行路测、完善和文档编写。

In the same spirit, a new wave of no-code and low-code tools are emerging in law, enabling the development of systems and applications without involving legions of software engineers. The legal no-coder will be the lawyer who can develop his or her own systems. They will be most useful in creating pilots, demonstrators, and early versions, because generally a fully operational, user-affable system will also require road-testing, tightening, and documenting by a mainstream programmer.

法律技术专家

Legal Technologist

法律实践和司法行政已变得高度依赖技术。如果没有系统，法律服务将变得不切实际或难以想象，拥有经验丰富、技术娴熟的人才来弥合法律与技术之间的差距至关重要。直到最近，法律技术领域仍由两类人组成。第一类是由主流技术专家组成，他们进入了法律环境，并竭尽全力去理解律师、法院和客户之间神秘的运作方式。另一类是由对计算机着迷的律师组成——其中一些是业余爱好者，而另一些人则对技术世界有着更深刻的理解。但总体而言，这两个群体中都缺乏专业的法律技术专家，即在法律实践方面受过培训且经验丰富的人员。以及系统工程和技术管理专业。虽然在技术在很大程度上处于向客户提供服务的边缘时，技术专家和爱好者的工作表现已经足够出色，但我们现在需要一批能力出众、资质齐全的新一代法律技术专家，帮助法律职业全面迈入21世纪。仅仅依靠口译员向律师解释技术问题，再向技术专家解释法律问题已经远远不够。我们需要一批能够自给自足的新法律技术专家，他们将对现代社会产生深远的影响——他们将为法律服务的建立奠定基础，并为非律师群体获取法律信息的渠道奠定基础。

The practice of law and the administration of justice have become massively dependent on technology. When legal service becomes impractical or unimaginable without systems, it is vital to have experienced and skilled individuals who can bridge the gap between law and technology. Until recently, two groups have populated the world of legal technology. The first has been made up of mainstream technologists who have found their way into legal environments and have done their best to understand the mysterious ways of lawyers, courts, and clients. The other camp has been occupied by lawyers with a fascination for computers—some were hobbyists, while others attained a more profound appreciation of the world of technology. But neither group, by and large, was populated by professional legal technologists, individuals trained and experienced both in the practice of law and in the profession of systems engineering and technology management. While the technologists and hobbyists worked well enough when technology was largely at the periphery of the delivery of services to clients, we now need a new breed of able and credentialed legal technologists to help take the legal profession fully into the twenty-first century. No longer will it suffice to have mere interpreters, who explain technology matters to lawyers and legal matters to technologists. We require a new cadre of self-sufficient legal technologists whose impact on modern society will be profound—they will lay the foundations upon which legal service is built and the channels through which non-lawyers can access the law.

合法混合动力

Legal Hybrid

未来的律师需要多元化发展才能在行业中立足。如果传统服务将逐渐减少，那么我预计律师将通过日益多元化的领域来拓展自身能力。许多律师已经宣称自己对相关领域拥有深刻的洞察力，并已开始担任战略家、管理顾问、商业顾问、市场专家、交易经纪人、组织心理学家等等。通常，稍加探究就会发现，这些经验是通过短期课程或入门教材习得的。尽管有些律师不这么认为，但通常不可能在几天内就掌握一门新学科。律师是高智商的人（总体而言），他们毫无疑问，他们有能力拓宽自己的专业领域，成为一流的复合型人才。但如果商业律师想成为战略顾问，如果公司律师想成为交易经纪人，如果家庭律师想成为心理学家——我强烈支持这种多元化发展——那么他们必须心甘情愿地接受全面而严格的培训。未来几年，最优秀的复合型法律人才将拥有卓越的专业素养，并毫无疑问地精通新的相关学科，从而能够为其为客户提供的法律服务增添巨大的价值。

Lawyers of the future will need to diversify to stay in business. If it is accepted that traditional service will become less common, then I expect lawyers to extend their capabilities by becoming increasingly multidisciplinary. Many lawyers already assert that they are insightful in neighbouring disciplines, and already act, for example, as strategists, management consultants, business advisers, market experts, deal brokers, organizational psychologists, and the rest. Often, with a little probing, it transpires that this experience has been picked up through a brief course or by dipping into an introductory textbook. Although some lawyers like to think otherwise, it is not generally possible to take on a new discipline in a couple of days. Lawyers are highly intelligent human beings (by and large) who are undoubtedly capable of broadening their domains of expertise and becoming first-rate hybrids. But if commercial lawyers want to be strategy consultants, if corporate lawyers aspire to be deal brokers, and if family lawyers wish to be psychologists—and I strongly support this diversification—then this must be backed up by comprehensive and rigorous training that they undertake willingly. The best legal hybrids in years to come will be formidably schooled and unarguably expert in new related disciplines and, in turn, will be able to add considerable value to the legal services they offer to clients.

法律程序分析师

Legal Process Analyst

我在本书中，尤其是在第五章，相当流畅地谈到了将交易和纠纷分解成其组成任务，并通过众多服务提供商来获取这些任务。然而，分析一项法律工作，将任务细分为有意义且易于管理的部分，并为每个部分确定最合适的服务提供商，本身就是一项需要深厚法律洞察力和经验的任务。这不是普通业务或系统分析师的职业。这是我所说的“法律流程分析师”的工作。这类人通常受雇于内部法务部门，因为组织期望其内部律师能够熟练地找到处理法律工作的最有效方式并非不合理。或者，法律流程分析也可以是由律师事务所或其他第三方服务提供商（例如会计）提供的服务。公司或法律流程外包商。如今，法律流程分析师的数量非常少，但他们的需求量却很大。我合作过的大多数大型律师事务所和公司内部法务部门都非常清楚，他们乐意聘请能够对其核心法律流程进行可靠、富有洞察力、严谨且知情的分析的人员。

I have spoken rather glibly in this book, especially in Chapter 5, about decomposing deals and disputes into their constituent tasks and sourcing these tasks through a multitude of providers. However, the job of analysing a piece of legal work, subdividing the assignment into meaningful and manageable chunks, and identifying the most appropriate supplier of services for each, is itself a task that requires deep legal insight and experience. This will not be an occupation for regular business or systems analysts. It is a job for what I call the ‘legal process analyst’. This individual will often be employed within an in-house legal department, for it is not unreasonable for organizations to expect their internal lawyers to be expert at identifying the most efficient and effective way of handling their legal work. Alternatively, legal process analysis could be a service offered by law firms or other third party providers such as accounting firms or legal process outsourcers. Today, there are very few legal process analysts but they are already in demand. Most of the major law firms and in-house legal departments with which I work are very clear that they would readily engage the services of individuals who could undertake reliable, insightful, rigorous, and informed analysis of their central legal processes.

法律项目经理

Legal Project Manager

一旦法律流程分析师的工作完成，那些已分解并准备进行多方外包的交易或争议将无法自行解决。为了确保多方外包的成功，法律市场需要我所说的“法律项目经理”。法律流程分析师完成规范（分解和拟议的多方外包）后，法律项目经理的职责是将工作分配给一系列合适的供应商，确保他们按时按预算完成分解后的工作包，控制各个工作包的质量，监督和监管产出和交付，并将各个工作包整合成一个为客户提供的无缝服务。这在很多方面与制造环境中的生产经理的角色相似。

Once the work of the legal process analyst is done, the deal or dispute that has been decomposed and prepared for multi-sourcing will not look after itself. To ensure the success of multi-sourcing, the legal market will require what I call the ‘legal project manager’. When the legal process analyst has completed the specification (decomposition and proposed multi-sourcing) it is the job of the legal project manager to allocate work to a selection of appropriate providers, to ensure they complete their decomposed work packages on time and to budget, to control the quality of the various packages, to oversee and supervise the output and delivery, and to pull the various work packages together into one seamless service for the client. This is similar in many ways to the role of the production manager in a manufacturing environment.

我认为，法律项目管理学科应该建立在相关管理学科（例如物流和供应链管理）的理论和经验之上。毫无疑问，法律行业将会发展出自身独特的复杂工具和技术，例如“法律供应链管理”和“法律物流”，这些将成为未来法律项目管理课程的核心内容。

The discipline of legal project management should, in my view, be built upon theory and experience from related management disciplines, such as logistics and supply-chain management. No doubt, the legal sector will come to develop its own sophisticated tools and techniques, such as ‘legal supply-chain management’ and ‘legal logistics’, which will be core subjects in future courses on legal project management.

法律数据科学家

Legal Data Scientist

随着机器学习和预测分析在法律领域的重要性日益提升，对精通捕捉、分析和处理海量信息所需工具和技术的数据专家的需求也将相应增加。“法律数据科学家”将致力于识别法律资源和非法律材料中的关联性、趋势、模式和洞见。他们还将开发能够进行各种法律预测的系统（参见第六章）。同样，他们将是跨学科专家，不仅精通相关系统，还精通法律和法律服务。扎实的数学、编程或自然科学背景将对此有所帮助。

With the growing significance in law of machine learning and predictive analytics, there will be a corresponding need for data experts who are masters of the tools and techniques that are required to capture, analyse, and manipulate great quantities of information. The ‘legal data scientist’ will seek to identify correlations, trends, patterns, and insights both in legal resources and in non-legal materials. They will also develop systems that can make all manner of legal predictions (see Chapter 6). Again, they will be interdisciplinary specialists, with knowledge not only of relevant systems but also of the law and legal service. A strong background in mathematics, programming, or natural sciences will help here.

法律数据可视化工具

Legal Data Visualizer

如果一图胜千言（见第 13 章），那么现在肯定是时候将大量法律文件和复杂的法律语言精简为更易于理解的视觉形式了，例如图表、动画、幻灯片、示意图、地图、图形等等。这是法律数据可视化人员的工作——为法律材料带来前所未有的清晰度。同样，这是一个跨学科的角色，需要制作视觉效果的创造性人才以及理解材料的法律知识。而且风险很高。董事会会议室的语言不再是长篇文件中的文本。而是 PowerPoint。高级管理人员希望通过吸收一页信息图或餐垫来掌握关键问题，而不是费力地翻阅堆积如山的文件。

If a picture is indeed worth a thousand words (see Chapter 13), it is surely time to reduce large bodies of legal documents and complex legal language to more digestible visual forms, such as charts, animations, slides, diagrams, maps, graphs, and so forth. This is work for the legal data visualizer—to bring unprecedented clarity to legal materials. Again, this is an interdisciplinary role, requiring creative talent in producing the visuals as well as legal knowledge to understand the materials. And the stakes are high. The language of the boardroom is no longer text in long documents. It is PowerPoint. Senior executives want to grasp the key issues by absorbing a one-page infographic or placemat, rather than wading through mountains of documents.

研发人员

R&D Worker

正如第20章所述，我们正在见证法律界的巨大变革，这意味着未来成功的供应商，例如当今消费电子和制药行业的供应商，如果想要保持竞争力，就需要具备研发 (R&D) 能力。新服务和解决方案的设计和开发将成为2020年代及以后法律企业商业成功的核心。律师们早已意识到，他们必须紧跟法律和实践的变化。“研发人员”的重点将有所不同——他们专注于开发新的能力、技巧和技术，以便以本书所预测的多种不同方式提供法律服务。研发人员的努力通常比执业律师的日常工作更具探索性。死胡同和错误的开始不会，也不应该被视为研发职能的失败。事实上，没有失败反而表明缺乏冒险精神和天赋。研发人员与当今的典型律师截然不同。

As noted in Chapter 20, the great changes we are witnessing in the legal world mean that the successful providers of tomorrow, like those in today’s consumer electronics and pharmaceutical sectors, will need to have research and development (R&D) capabilities if they want to stay competitive. The design and development of new services and solutions will be at the heart of the commercial success of legal businesses in the 2020s and beyond. Lawyers have for long been aware that they have to keep up to date with changes in the law and practice. The ‘R&D worker’ will have a different focus—on developing new capabilities, techniques, and technologies to deliver legal services in the many different ways anticipated in this book. The efforts of the R&D worker will often be far more exploratory than the daily endeavours of practising lawyers. Dead ends and false starts will not, or should not, be regarded as failures in the R&D function. Indeed absence of failure will suggest a shortage of adventure and flair. The R&D worker will be a very different beast from the typical lawyer of today.

数字安全卫士

Digital Security Guard

随着法律组织对技术和数据的依赖性不断增加，必须有专家来确保其系统和数据的可靠性和安全性，其数据隐私受到保护，其数据不受偏见影响，其算法受到定期审计，并且其系统防御网络攻击。这些是数字安全卫士的基本职责。这些职责范围广泛且意义深远——宕机或数据泄露可能会毁掉一家合法企业。值得注意的是，许多律师事务所和法院似乎没有意识到忽视这些保管人的危险。

As the dependency on technology and data increases in legal organizations, it will be imperative to have specialists who will ensure their systems and data are reliable and secure, their data privacy is protected, their data is cleansed of bias, their algorithms are subjected to regular audit, and their systems are defended from cyber-attack. These are the basic responsibilities of digital security guards. They are wide-ranging and profound—downtime or data leaks could kill a legal business. Remarkably, many law firms and courts seem to be oblivious to the dangers of neglecting to engage these custodians.

ODR 从业者

ODR Practitioner

随着在线法院和高级在线争议解决（ODR，参见第14章）成为解决争议的常用机制，这个新兴世界将对执业人员的需求日益增长。这些专家将为客户提供如何最佳利用在线设施的建议，并将成为解决电子环境中争议的专家。电子谈判和电子调解等服务尚处于起步阶段，但我毫不怀疑，富有想象力的律师随着时间的推移将成为这些系统的高级用户，并将设计出巧妙的新技术，使其指导的对象获得优势。诉讼律师无需出庭或参加视频听证会即可增加价值。但他们需要构建一套新的技能和方法，使参与在线法院和ODR的客户比单独使用这些系统时处于明显更有利的地位。电子谈判员和电子调解员也将迎来新的职业发展，这些人的介入和裁决将需要在ODR流程中进行。在这里，正如本章其他地方一样，所要求的能力将超越黑体法的专业知识。

With the advent of online courts and advanced online dispute resolution (ODR—see Chapter 14) as common mechanisms for the settling of disagreements, there will be call for practitioners in this emerging world. These specialists will advise clients on how best to use online facilities and will be experts in resolving disputes conducted in electronic environments. It is early days for services such as e-negotiation and e-mediation, but I have little doubt that imaginative lawyers will, over time, become superior users of these systems and will devise ingenious new techniques that will bestow advantage on those they guide. Litigators need not appear in courtrooms or in video hearings to add value. But they will need to build a new set of skills and methods which position their clients who are involved in online courts and ODR in a demonstrably better position than if they use these systems on their own. New careers will also open up for e-negotiators and e-mediators, those individuals whose intervention and adjudication will be required in the ODR process. Here, as elsewhere in this chapter, the competences that are called for will extend beyond expertise in black-letter law.

主持人

Moderator

随着法律开源和在线法律社区（参见第六章）的兴起，法律指导的接受者聚集在一起交流经验，对版主的需求将日益增长。问题在于，这些设施及其积累的见解将被普通用户所依赖。这与接受传统律师的建议并依赖他们不同。相比之下，这些法律经验社区的成员并非专业人士，因此在那里收集的帮助和指导可能存在错误、误导、不明确等等。因此，对大部分内容进行某种形式的监督和质量控制至关重要。解决方案是提供版主——具有相关法律经验（或许还有外交经验）的知识渊博的个人。例如，一家律师事务所选择建立一个在线资源，让客户分享对他们有用的经验，那么最好聘请一位版主，充当编辑的角色，识别并纠正错误、不一致和混淆之处。

With the emergence of legal open-sourcing and online legal communities (see Chapter 6), where the recipients of legal guidance convene to exchange their experiences, there will be a growing need for moderators. The problem here is that these facilities and their accumulated insights will be relied upon by lay users. This is not the same as taking advice from and being dependent on traditional lawyers. In contrast, these communities of legal experience are populated by non-experts and so the help and guidance gathered there may be wrong, misleading, unclear, and more. It is important therefore that there is some kind of oversight and quality control of much of the content. The solution is to make moderators available—knowledgeable individuals with relevant experience of the law (and perhaps diplomacy). A law firm, for example, that chooses to set up an online resource through which its clients can share what has worked for them would be well advised to have a moderator, acting as an editor who identifies and corrects errors, inconsistencies, and confusions.

法律管理顾问

Legal Management Consultant

许多公司内部法务部门面临着各种各样的管理挑战（例如，战略制定、重组、团队建设、专业知识开发和技术引进）。然而，大多数总法律顾问和内部律师经验不足。很多律师事务所对自身法律业务中出现的管理问题有着丰富的经验，因此人们经常建议这些律师事务所设立自己的全职咨询业务，为内部法律部门提供咨询服务。有些律师事务所确实这样做了，并且取得了成功，赢得了赞誉。其他地方也有这样的先例：在“四大”会计师事务所中，他们的咨询业务最初是从审计业务中发展起来的；而近年来，税务管理咨询业务则是建立在传统税务事务所工作的基础上的。

Many in-house legal departments face a wide variety of management challenges (including, for instance, strategy formulation, restructuring, team building, know-how development, and the introduction of technology). And yet most General Counsel and in-house lawyers have little experience of management issues and so often seek external help. Today, some law firms offer guidance on various management issues but they generally do so in an ad hoc and reactive fashion. Less frequently, professional management consultants are brought in. Given the considerable experience that many law firms have of management issues that arise in their own legal businesses, it is often suggested that these firms might set up their own full-time consulting practices to advise in-house legal departments. Some have done precisely this, and are enjoying success and receiving plaudits. And there is persuasive precedent elsewhere for such a move: in the world of the ‘Big 4’ accounting firms, their consulting practices originally grew out of their audit businesses; while, more recently, tax management consultancy practices have been built on the back of the work of traditional tax firms.

虽然此类法律管理咨询市场尚处于起步阶段，但未来有望稳步增长，这不仅是律师事务所提升其传统服务价值的一种方式，更将成为一项独立的服务。未来可能提供的服务包括战略咨询（涵盖长期规划、替代资源、运营模式和组织结构、内部部门价值链分析以及法律需求评估等问题）以及运营或管理咨询（例如，招聘、律所选择、专家组管理、财务管控、内部沟通和文档管理）。

While the market for this kind of legal management consultancy is still in its youth, it is likely to grow steadily, not just as a way of law firms adding value to their conventional services but as a service line in its own right. Likely services include strategy consulting (on issues such as long-term planning, alternative sourcing, operating models and organizational structure, value-chain analysis of in-house departments, and legal needs assessment) and operational or management consulting (e.g., on recruitment, selection of law firms, panel management, financial control, internal communications, and document management).

此外，一些法律管理咨询公司会提供法律流程分析服务。我认为律师很难或直观地提供这些服务。非正式的。相反，法律管理咨询将成为一门独特的学科。

Additionally, some legal management consulting providers will offer legal process analysis services. I do not believe that these services can easily or intuitively be provided by lawyers on an informal basis. Instead, legal management consulting will emerge as a distinct discipline.

法律风险经理

The Legal Risk Manager

我为未来规划的最后一类律师或许是最迫切需要、也是最迟应该出现的。如第九章所述，大多数总法律顾问认为其主要职责是法律风险管理。这在我过去十年对公司内部法律界进行的研究中得到了充分体现。总法律顾问与他们所报告的董事会一样，强烈倾向于回避法律问题，而不是解决它们。正如前文所述，他们宁愿选择悬崖顶上的篱笆，也不愿选择悬崖底下的救护车。然而，令人惊讶的是，世界上几乎没有一家律师事务所认识到这种需求，并开发出一系列复杂的流程、方法、技术或系统来帮助其客户识别、评估、量化、对冲、监控和控制他们面临的众多风险。我预计这种情况将会改变，而变革的推动者将是专业的法律风险管理者。传统法律服务本质上是被动的，我指的是律师（无论是律所还是公司内部）大部分时间都在回答客户的问题，而法律风险管理者则会主动出击（更多关于这一区别的介绍，请参阅第15章）。他们的重点是预测客户的需求，控制和预防法律问题。他们关注的不是具体的交易和纠纷，而是潜在的业务面临的陷阱和威胁。法律风险管理经理将承担法律风险审查、诉讼准备评估、合规审计和合同承诺分析等工作。优秀的法律风险管理经理将是精通风险管理学科的律师，并将借鉴战略咨询技术，以及越来越多地借鉴机器学习等新兴的文档分析技术（参见第六章）。这不会只是法律行业的一个插曲。它将从根本上改变客户管理法律事务的方式。而最优秀的法律风险管理经理，在适当的时候，可能有资格担任首席风险官这一更广泛的企业职位。

My final category of lawyer for the future is perhaps the most urgently needed and longest overdue. As noted in Chapter 9, most General Counsel consider their primary responsibility to be that of legal risk management. This comes through overwhelmingly in the research I have undertaken in the last decade within the in-house legal community. General Counsel, like the boards to which they report, have a strong preference for avoiding legal problems rather than resolving them. They prefer, as said before, a fence at the top of the cliff to an ambulance at the bottom. What is striking, however, is that there is scarcely a law firm in the world that has acknowledged this need and developed a sophisticated range of processes, methodologies, techniques, or systems to help their clients identify, assess, quantify, hedge, monitor, and control the plethora of risks that confront them. I expect this to change, and the agents of change will be the professional legal risk managers. Whereas conventional legal service is reactive in nature, by which I mean that lawyers (in firms and in-house) spend most of their time responding to questions put to them by their clients, legal risk managers will be proactive (see Chapter 15 for more on this distinction). Their focus will be on anticipating the needs of those they advise, on containing and pre-empting legal problems. Their preoccupation will not be with specific deals and disputes but with potential pitfalls and threats to the business. Legal risk managers will undertake jobs such as legal risk reviews, litigation readiness assessments, compliance audits, and analysis of contractual commitments. Talented legal risk managers will be lawyers with insight into the discipline of risk management and will draw also on techniques from strategy consulting and, increasingly, on emerging techniques for document analysis, such as machine learning (see Chapter 6). This will not be a side-show for the legal profession. It will fundamentally alter the way that clients administer their legal affairs. And the best legal risk managers may, in due course, be eligible for the much wider corporate role of chief risk officer.

故事的转折

Twist to the Tale

总的来说，我为未来律师们提出的15个新职业，将为那些渴望在法律领域工作数十年的人们提供丰富而激动人心的全新职业机会。我承认，这些工作并非法学院学生在进入法学院时通常所想的。但它们仍然将是能够激发智力、具有社会意义的职业。我知道，一些律师在听到这些新工作时，往往会认为它们不如传统的咨询服务那么有声望和价值（许多手艺人在他们的工作被工业化后无疑也有类似的感受）。我的回应是，那些已经参与这些新角色的人确实认为它们很有价值，也很有挑战性。许多人发现自己正在以不同的方式做出贡献。但仍然是实现改善司法制度这一更高理想的有意义的途径。

Taken together, the 15 new jobs I have identified for tomorrow’s lawyers will provide a rich and exciting new set of career opportunities for those who aspire to work in the law for many decades yet. I accept that these jobs are not those that law students generally have in mind when embarking upon law school. But they will be intellectually stimulating and socially significant occupations nonetheless. I know that some lawyers, when they hear of these new jobs, tend to regard them as less prestigious and worthy than traditional consultative service (many craftsmen no doubt felt similarly when their work was industrialized). I respond by saying that those who are already involved in these new roles do consider them rewarding and challenging. Many find themselves contributing in a different but still meaningful way to the higher ideal of an improved justice system.

然而，这个故事另有隐情。我对那些渴望从事这十五种职业中的一种或多种的律师的指导是，首先，获得传统律师的资格仍然是明智之举。这或许并非必要，但我认为是可取的，这不仅仅是因为拥有合格的事务律师或出庭律师的身份在未来许多年里都会有用，而是因为接触和了解传统的法律服务应该能为任何新的法律职业奠定宝贵的基础。我并不是说，法学院毕业生即使没有律师经验，也不可能成为一流的法律知识工程师或法律项目经理。但我确实认为，拥有主流法律工作的经验会很有帮助。

There is a twist to this tale, however. My guidance to aspiring lawyers who are keen to work in one or more of the fifteen jobs is that it still makes sense, in the first instance, to qualify as a conventional lawyer. This may not be necessary but I think it desirable, not simply because it will for many years yet be useful to enjoy the status of being, say, a qualified solicitor or barrister, but because exposure to and understanding of traditional legal service should provide a valuable foundation upon which to build any new career in law. I am not suggesting that it will not be possible for a law graduate to become a first-rate legal knowledge engineer or legal project manager without having practised as a lawyer. But I do think it would be helpful to have the experience of mainstream legal work.

然而，实习律师应该积极主动，时刻寻找经验，为未来做好准备。我尤其建议借调到客户那里，在不同的国家工作，并密切关注律所的技术发展。

Lawyers in training should be proactive, however; always on the lookout for experiences that prepare them for tomorrow. I particularly recommend being seconded to clients, working in a variety of countries, and keeping close to the firm’s technological developments.

话虽如此，我知道到2022年，许多法学院毕业生很难获得培训合同和实习机会。这引出了另一个问题：无论是作为传统律师还是从事某种新兴的法律工作，未来谁会雇用你？

All of that said, I know how difficult it is for many law graduates, in 2022, to secure training contracts and pupillages. This leads, then, to another question. Whether as a conventional lawyer or in one of the new legal jobs, who will employ you in the future?

17谁将雇用未来的律师？

17 Who Will Employ Tomorrow’s Lawyers?

怀疑论者可能会认为我在上一章中列出的预计的法律职位相当异想天开，尤其是因为他们无法想象今天的律师事务所或内部法律部门会创造和提供我所描述的新职位。

Sceptics may regard my list of projected law jobs in the last chapter as rather fanciful, not least because they cannot imagine today’s law firms or in-house legal departments creating and offering the new roles that I describe.

但现实是，一些先进的律所和部门已经在提供和承担这些工作了。但更大的错误是认为这些新工作总是会注入传统的法律业务中。事情的发展可能并非如此。更有可能的是，许多新职位将由从事截然不同的法律业务的新雇主提供。这将通过自由化（参见第一章）实现，并将由人们越来越接受这样一个事实所驱动：许多法律任务不再需要传统律师的直接参与。并不是说律所不能或不会创造新的工作，而是这样做往往会扰乱它们的传统业务。如表 17.1所示，那些目前能够在一张白纸上设计未来法律服务战略的企业将更容易塑造新的职业和职务。

The reality, however, is that these jobs are already being offered and undertaken in some advanced firms and departments. But the bigger mistake here is to think that these new jobs will always be injected into old legal businesses. This is not how events are likely to unfold. It is more likely that many of these new roles will be offered by a new range of employers who will work in quite different types of legal business. This will be enabled by liberalization (see Chapter 1) and be driven by growing acceptance that many legal tasks no longer require the direct involvement of traditional lawyers. It is not that law firms cannot or will not create the new jobs, but that to do so will often disrupt their conventional businesses. It will simply be easier for new careers and occupations to be fashioned by those businesses, as summarized in Table 17.1, that are currently able to design their future legal services strategy on a blank sheet of paper.

表 17.1 未来的雇主

TABLE 17.1 Tomorrow’s employers

全球会计师事务所
主要法律出版商
法律知识提供商
法律流程外包商
大品牌企业
合法租赁机构
律师事务所
在线法律服务提供商
法律管理咨询
法律科技公司

全球会计师事务所

Global Accounting Firms

大多数年轻有抱负的律师都不会记得21世纪初大型会计师事务所进军法律市场的情景。其中最具雄心壮志的是安达信法律事务所（Andersen Legal），它是安达信（Arthur Andersen）的法律网络，而安达信当时是世界上最大的会计和税务事务所之一。在其巅峰时期，安达信法律事务所的业务遍及30个国家，拥有2500名律师。当时，它是全球第九大律师事务所（按收入计算）。它的规模和声誉都在迅速增长。它的品牌强大，其多学科目标吸引了许多客户。它提供了一个充满活力和令人兴奋的工作环境，在我看来（或许有偏见，因为我是他们的顾问之一），它似乎将重新定义法律市场。

Most young and aspiring lawyers will not remember the foray of the big accounting firms into the legal market in the early 2000s. The most ambitious of these was Andersen Legal, the legal network of Arthur Andersen, then one of the world’s largest accounting and tax practices. At its peak, Andersen Legal had a presence in 30 countries and a total number of lawyers of 2,500. At the time, it was the ninth largest law firm in the world (by revenue). It was growing rapidly, both in size and reputation. Its brand was strong and its multidisciplinary objectives appealed to many clients. It offered a dynamic and exciting working environment, and in my view (biased perhaps, because I was one of their advisers) looked set to redefine the legal market.

值得注意的是，安达信法律事务所倒闭了。然而，与普遍看法相反，它的倒闭并非因为某些根本性的缺陷。战略或商业模式。相反，安达信法律的倒闭是 2001 年美国巨头安然公司倒闭的直接后果，而安达信的母公司安达信（在安然犯下各种会计欺诈行为时，安达信担任外部审计师）的显著崩溃。安达信的崩溃并没有证明会计师事务所不能提供法律服务，但随后出台了一系列新法规，禁止这些事务所为其审计客户提供其他专业服务。这对那些正在考虑继续提供法律服务的会计师事务所来说是一个显著的威慑，尤其是在美国。但是，过去和现在都没有一项全面的全球禁令。

Remarkably, Andersen Legal died. Contrary to the common view, however, it did not fail because of some fundamental defect of strategy or business model. Rather, Andersen Legal’s demise was a direct consequence of the collapse in 2001 of a giant US corporation called Enron and, in turn, the remarkable implosion of the legal network’s parent organization, Arthur Andersen (who were external auditors while Enron perpetrated various accounting frauds). The Andersen debacle did not establish that accounting firms could not provide legal services, but there did follow new bodies of regulations that prohibited these firms from providing other professional services to their audit clients. And this was a notable deterrent, especially in the US, for accounting firms that were contemplating the continuation of their legal services. However, there was not, and is not, a blanket and definitive global prohibition.

无论如何，过去几年里，“四大”（德勤、毕马威、普华永道和安永）已经开始强势回归法律界。事实上，它们从未真正离开，如今大多数公司每年都能从法律服务中获得数亿英镑的佣金收入。自由化常被认为是它们回归法律行业的催化剂或理由，事实上，这四家公司均已在英格兰和威尔士获得授权，成为“替代性商业结构”（参见第一章）。然而，正如本书所强调的，更有可能的吸引力在于，法律市场价值巨大（全球法律市场的价值目前已接近1万亿美元），但同时也处于不断变化的状态。会计师事务所将此视为一个充满机遇的时代——他们相信自己已做好准备，帮助客户应对“少花钱多办事”的挑战，并支持他们持续努力更有效地管理法律风险。

In any event, over the past few years, the ‘Big 4’ (Deloitte, KPMG, PwC, and EY) have begun an emphatic return to the legal world. In fact they never really left and most of them now enjoy many hundreds of millions of pounds worth of annual fee income from their legal services. Liberalization is often said to be a catalyst or justification for their return to the law, and indeed all four have been authorized in England and Wales as ‘alternative business structures’ (see Chapter 1). However, the more likely attraction is that the legal market, as this book stresses, is of immense value (the value of the global legal market is now not far shy of $1 trillion) and yet is one in a state of flux.
