The accounting firms see this as a time of great opportunity—they believe they are well equipped to help meet clients’ more-for-less challenge and to support their ongoing efforts to manage their legal risks more effectively.

四大律师事务所重返法律市场的策略尚不明确。至少在中期内，他们不太可能他们将寻求直接竞争大型律所的定制化服务。相反，他们更有可能专注于领先律所无法提供或难以提供的服务和产品。从这个角度来看，四大将成为最强大的替代性法律服务提供商，在法律管理服务、法律流程外包、法律风险管理、法律知识工程、法律管理咨询和法律科技等领域引领潮流。

The Big 4’s strategies for re-entering the legal market are not yet clear. In the medium term at least, it is unlikely that they will seek to compete directly for the bespoke work of the largest law firms. Instead, they will more likely focus on services and products that leading law firms cannot provide or cannot do so easily. On this view, the Big 4 will be the most formidable alternative legal providers, leading the way in such areas as managed legal services, legal process outsourcing, legal risk management, legal knowledge engineering, legal management consulting, and legal technology.

无论他们选择哪条竞争激烈的道路，这些实力雄厚、资源丰富的雇主都将为未来的律师提供广泛的职业发展机会。普华永道目前拥有超过3500名律师，遍布100多个国家和地区，规模可谓相当可观。

Whatever competitive route they prefer, these formidable and hugely resourced employers will provide a wide range of career opportunities for tomorrow’s lawyers. Already, to give a sense of scale, PwC has more than 3,500 lawyers, working in over 100 different countries and regions.

主要法律出版商

Major Legal Publishers

全球最大的两家法律公司是汤森路透和励讯（前身为励德爱思唯尔）。这两家商业巨头已从传统的印刷出版物生产发展到提供大型且备受欢迎的法律数据库——例如Westlaw和LexisNexis（在律师界以其收集立法和判例等原始资料而闻名）。但多年来，它们也实现了业务多元化，在法律技术、法律知识工程和在线法律服务领域雄心勃勃，积极进取。这些公司雇佣了大批律师和软件工程师。它们是法律界值得信赖的供应商，并且也看到了法律行业中的机遇。动荡的法律世界。他们雄心勃勃，技术先进，并且在开拓新市场方面经验丰富。毫无疑问，未来他们将为众多法学毕业生提供发展空间。我认为他们不太可能提供传统的咨询法律服务，但他们将提供上一章提到的许多其他工作岗位。汤森路透就是一个引人注目的案例研究。为了提供知识和研究服务，他们雇佣了大量合格的律师；他们拥有并经营着一家法律流程外包公司；他们收购并授权了一款领先的文档自动化系统；他们拥有众多技术人员。因此，他们可以在未来的法律领域提供广泛的职业发展机会。

Two of the largest legal businesses in the world are Thomson Reuters and RELX (previously, Reed Elsevier). These commercial giants have evolved from the production of conventional print-based publications to the provision of very large and popular legal databases—such as, respectively, Westlaw and LexisNexis (best known amongst lawyers as collections of primary source materials such as legislation and case law). But they have also diversified over the years and are clearly ambitious and acquisitive in the fields of legal technology, legal knowledge engineering, and online legal services. These businesses employ legions of lawyers and armies of software engineers. They are trusted suppliers to the legal profession, and they too see opportunity in the tumultuous legal world. They are commercially ambitious, high-tech, and experienced in carving out new market spaces. They will, unquestionably, provide homes for many law graduates in the future. I think it unlikely that they will deliver conventional consultative advisory legal services but they will offer many of the other jobs noted in the previous chapter. Thomson Reuters is a compelling case study. To deliver their knowledge and research services, they employ huge numbers of qualified lawyers; they own and run a legal process outsourcing company; they bought and now license a leading document automation system; and they have great multitudes of technologists. Accordingly, they can offer a wide range of careers in tomorrow’s legal sector.

法律专业知识提供商

Legal Know-How Providers

未来律师的另一类潜在雇主是法律知识提供商。这类公司比大型法律出版商更加灵活，也更具创业精神，早期以英国法律公司（最初名为PLC）为代表。该公司自20世纪90年代初成立以来稳步发展，雇佣了数百名律师，在英国和美国广泛运营，并于2013年被汤森路透收购（如上所述）。虽然Practical Law（该公司的现名）已不再独立运营，RELX现在提供类似的服务，名为LexisPSL，但我预计未来将出现更多法律知识提供商。我们甚至可能看到一些律师事务所内部的法律知识部门进行管理层收购。

Another class of potential employer for tomorrow’s lawyers are legal know-how providers. Nimbler and more entrepreneurial than the major legal publishers, this category was best typified in early years by the English-based legal business originally known as PLC. The company grew steadily from its establishment in the early 1990s, employing many hundreds of lawyers, and operating extensively in England and the US, and was bought in 2013 by Thomson Reuters (as just described). While Practical Law (as the business is now known) is no longer independent and RELX now offers an analogous service known as LexisPSL, I expect to see the emergence of many more know-how providers. We may even see some management buy-outs by the know-how functions within law firms.

专有技术企业可以为律师事务所和内部律师提供一系列服务，包括法律研究和更新、市场情报、提供标准文件和实践笔记、专有技术、清单和流程图、剧本，以及一些传统的法律图书馆服务。对市场的建议是，保留这些提供商的律师事务所和内部部门本身不需要维护自己的图书馆、信息和研究服务或专业支持律师。专有技术提供商可能不会直接提供法律建议，但他们从事第 16 章概述的许多工作。从战略上讲，很容易看出他们如何发展以提供更全面的法律知识工程、法律流程分析和法律项目管理服务。

Know-how businesses can provide a range of services to law firms and in-house lawyers, including legal research and updates, market intelligence, the provision of standard documents and practice notes, know-how, checklists and flowcharts, playbooks, alongside some conventional law library services. The proposition to the market is that law firms and in-house departments that retain these providers do not themselves then need to maintain their own libraries, information and research services, or professional support lawyers. The know-how providers may not offer legal advice directly but they are engaged in many of the jobs outlined in Chapter 16. And it is easy to see, strategically, how they might progress to providing fuller ranges of legal knowledge engineering, legal process analysis, and legal project management services.

用第五章的语言来理解这类企业，我们可以将其视为替代性的法律服务提供商，律师事务所和公司内部律师将越来越多地向其分配分解的任务。而且，随着任务分解和多方外包的增加，这些法律专业知识提供商的商业成功和员工数量也将随之增加。

Another way of looking at such businesses—in the language of Chapter 5—is that they are alternative legal providers to which law firms and in-house lawyers will increasingly allocate decomposed tasks. And, as decomposition and multi-sourcing increase, so too will the commercial success and the number of employees of these legal know-how providers.

法律流程外包商

Legal Process Outsourcers

在新兴的另类法律服务提供商中，最引人注目的或许是法律流程外包商 (LPO)，这类公司承接诸如诉讼文件审查和基本合同起草等常规重复性工作。通常，这些公司（例如 Integreon 和 Consilio）在劳动力成本较低的国家/地区设立了基地。成本较低，例如印度。然而，LPO 往往在其客户（律师事务所和内部法律部门）所在的主要司法管辖区拥有强大的能力。

Perhaps the highest profile of the new, emerging, and alternative legal providers has been the legal process outsourcers (LPOs), businesses that undertake routine and repetitive tasks such as document review in litigation and basic contract drafting. Typically, these businesses—for example, Integreon and Consilio—have established bases in countries in which labour costs are low, such as India. However, LPOs also tend to have significant capabilities in the main jurisdictions in which their clients (law firms and in-house legal departments) are themselves located.

这些第三方外包商雄心勃勃，富有创业精神，通常从初创企业迅速发展壮大，不太可能将其服务范围局限于现有范围。因此，我们可以预期，LPO 将承担越来越具有挑战性的工作（而不仅仅是最常规的工作），并由日益复杂的流程和系统提供支持。而且，随着自由化进程的推进，一些公司无疑将提供过去仅由律师事务所提供的服务。通过这种方式，LPO 可能会转型为垂直整合管理服务提供商，如下所述。

These third party outsourcers are ambitious, entrepreneurial concerns that have often grown rapidly from start-ups, and are unlikely to limit the scope of their services to their current boundaries. Thus, we can expect LPOs to undertake increasingly challenging (and not just the most routine) work, supported by ever more sophisticated processes and systems. And, as liberalization allows, some will doubtless position themselves to offer services that used to be the sole province of law firms. In this way, LPOs may transition into providers of vertically integrated managed services, as discussed below.

LPO 正在稳步增长，即便速度不如一些过激评论员预测的那么快。正如第 11 章所述，我预计 LPO 将在法律行业发展的第二阶段达到其当前形态的顶峰。但其中最优秀的 LPO 无疑也会根据市场情况进行调整和发展。

LPOs are growing steadily, if not as rapidly as some overzealous commentators have projected. As suggested in Chapter 11, it is in the second stage of the evolution of the legal sector that I anticipate they will peak in their current form. But the best of them too will no doubt adapt and evolve in response to market conditions.

对于未来的律师来说，LPO 将成为有趣且有回报的雇主，特别是那些热衷于法律知识工程、法律流程分析、法律项目管理和合规流程外包的律师。

LPOs will be interesting and rewarding employers for tomorrow’s lawyers, especially those who are keen on legal knowledge engineering, legal process analysis, legal project management, and compliance process outsourcing.

大品牌企业

Big-Brand Businesses

在我看来，大型跨国企业进入法律领域只是时间问题。大约十年前，私营企业客户（个人而非公司）方面，专家们押注高街（主街）的银行和超市很快就会深度参与到日常法律服务的提供中。他们的论点很有吸引力。这些零售店比传统的律师事务所更方便，也更不令人望而却步。然而，更重要的是，随着银行和其他高街企业进入法律市场，人们希望它们能够带来日常工作的标准化和计算机化，尤其是那些大批量、低价值的工作。这些零售企业预计将成为传统律师事务所，尤其是小型律师事务所的直接竞争对手。

It is only a matter of time, in my view, before huge global businesses move into the law. About a decade ago, for private clients (individuals as opposed to companies), pundits were betting that High (Main) Street banks and supermarkets would soon be heavily involved in the delivery of everyday legal services. Their arguments were attractive. These retail outlets would be more convenient and less forbidding than traditional law firms. More than this, however, as banks and other High Street businesses entered the legal market, it was hoped that they would bring standardization and computerization of routine work, especially high-volume, low-value work. These retail businesses were expected to be direct competitors to traditional law firms, especially small firms.

虽然我们能找到这种零售业发展的例子，但我预计大型保险公司、财务顾问和会计软件供应商更有可能更深入地涉足法律领域，提供与其传统服务相辅相成的法律服务。不太明显的是，我还预计大型科技公司也会适时加入竞争。例如，我认为亚马逊、谷歌或Meta等公司提供日常法律解决方案的想法完全可以想象，而且也令人兴奋。

While we can find examples of this retail development, I expect that major insurance companies, financial advisers, and accounting software suppliers are more likely to move more substantially into law, offering legal services that sit nicely adjacent to their traditional offerings. Less obviously, I also anticipate that big tech companies will in due course enter the fray. I find the idea, for example, of Amazon or Google or Meta offering everyday legal solutions as entirely conceivable, and exciting as well.

虽然许多律师直觉地认为这些新的服务提供商和竞争对手会消除对律师的需求，但现实情况是，大品牌企业提供的法律服务需要由拥有丰富法律经验的人员开发和交付。尽管替代性商业结构和其他结构很可能由非律师人士资助和管理，但它们仍将雇用律师，无论老少。在这方面，与其他地方一样，我们不应预期律师将不再被需要，而应认识到，未来的律师可能会受雇于截然不同的企业。

While the intuition of many lawyers is to regard these new providers and competitors as removing the need for lawyers, the reality is that the legal services provided by big-brand businesses will need to be developed and often delivered by people of considerable legal experience. Although alternative business structures and others may well be funded and managed by non-lawyers, they will still employ lawyers, old and young. Here, as elsewhere, we should not anticipate that lawyers will no longer be needed but recognize that tomorrow’s lawyers may be engaged by quite different businesses.

合法租赁机构

Legal Leasing Agencies

另一种快速兴起的律师之家是法律代理机构，它们为客户提供自由职业律师。我将其比作租赁律师，而提供此类服务的知名老牌提供商是Axiom和LOD（按需律师）。这些公司为不愿受雇于传统律师事务所或内部部门的律师提供了另一条职业道路。对于那些希望一年工作六个月（例如有年幼子女）的律师来说，它们就像一个家。他们建立了一个庞大的临时律师队伍，愿意以合同或项目的方式工作。对客户来说，吸引他们的是，自由职业律师可以安排在其机构内应对紧急需求，但费用往往只有传统律师事务所同等律师费用的一半左右。

Another rapidly emerging home for lawyers are legal agencies who make freelance lawyers available to clients. I liken this to leasing lawyers and well-known, long-standing providers of this service are Axiom and LOD (Lawyers on Demand). These businesses offer an alternative career path for lawyers who do not wish to be employed within conventional law firms or in-house departments. For lawyers who want the flexibility to work perhaps six months of the year, such as those with young children, they provide a home of sorts. They have built up a large pool of temporary lawyers who are prepared to work on a contract and project basis. The attraction for the client is that freelance lawyers can be placed within their organizations to meet urgent demands but will tend to cost about half of their equivalent in conventional law firms.

正如我在第五章中提到的，一些律师事务所已经建立了类似的业务，与传统律所并肩运营。虽然同时以较低的成本提供这些律师服务可能会被视为蚕食律所的传统业务，但正如我常说的“蚕食”现象——如果这种情况真的发生，你应该想成为第一批享用盛宴的人之一。因此，创业型律所将有机会以新颖且富有想象力的方式提供律师的法律经验。对于希望拥有更灵活生活的合格律师来说，这些法律代理机构将成为越来越重要的雇主。

A few legal practices, as I note in Chapter 5, have set up similar businesses that work alongside the traditional firms. Although providing these lawyers in parallel and at lower cost may be seen to cannibalize the firm’s traditional work, as I always say of cannibalization—if it is going to happen, you should want to be one of the first to the feast. Thus, entrepreneurial law firms will see opportunities to make the legal experience of lawyers available in new and imaginative ways. For qualified lawyers who want to live a more flexible life, these legal agencies will become increasingly important employers.

未来的律师（如上一章所定义，并从事其中概述的众多角色）很可能也将按需提供服务。有才华的法律例如，知识工程师或法律数据科学家可能会发现，不完全受雇于一个组织会更加灵活、有利可图、也更有趣。

It is likely that tomorrow’s lawyers (as defined in the previous chapter and engaged in the many roles outlined there) will also be made available on an on-demand basis. Talented legal knowledge engineers or legal data scientists, for example, may find it more flexible, lucrative, and fun not to be fully employed in one organization.

律师事务所

Law Companies

虽然法律流程外包商通常专注于承担常规、重复、行政和流程相关的工作，并避开实质性的法律服务，但一种更具雄心的替代服务提供商已经出现。这些服务提供商通常被称为“法律公司”，提供比法律外包公司（LPO）更垂直整合的服务（将法律、流程、技术和咨询相结合）。

While legal process outsourcers generally focus on undertaking routine, repetitive, administrative, and process-based work and steer clear of substantive legal service, a more ambitious type of alternative provider has emerged. Often called ‘law companies’, they offer a more vertically integrated service (combining law, process, technology, and consulting) than the LPOs.

这里最引人注目的例子是Elevate和Riverview Law（2018年被安永收购）。这些公司以及类似的法律公司的所有者都重新创办了他们的公司，并抛弃了旧的商业模式。这些律所并不寻求复制律师事务所的金字塔式利润结构，也不寻求按小时计费，也不寻求在昂贵的城市办公楼里办公。相反，他们将管理费用保持在非常低的水平，鼓励在家办公（疫情之前也是如此），拥有灵活的资源配置模式，富有创意地运用技术和知识管理，将后台职能外包，并聘请律师助理，所有这些都使他们能够以更低的价格向客户收费，同时仍然保持盈利。这些焕然一新的法律公司可能不会提供传统的合伙人职业发展路径，其盈利能力也可能不如年轻律师对顶级律所的期望。但它们将提供令人兴奋、充满活力和创业精神的环境，许多年轻律师将在这样的环境中蓬勃发展。未来。这些公司将对那些对法律服务革新充满想法的年轻律师持开放态度。他们甚至可能也乐于接受提供培训合同的创新方式。

High-profile examples here are Elevate and Riverview Law (acquired by EY in 2018). The owners of these and similar legal businesses have started their firms afresh, and jettisoned the old business models. The law companies do not seek to replicate the pyramidic profit structure of law firms, or to bill by the hour, or to work from expensive city buildings. Instead, they keep their overheads very low, they encourage home working (and did so before the pandemic), they have flexible resourcing models, they use technology and knowledge management imaginatively, they outsource their back-office functions, they employ paralegals, and all of this enables them to charge clients less and yet remain profitable. These new-look legal businesses may not offer conventional career paths to partnership, and they may not be as profitable as young lawyers have come to expect of the top firms. But they will offer exciting, vibrant, and entrepreneurial environments in which many young lawyers will thrive in the future. These companies will be open to the overtures of young lawyers who come with ideas of how legal services might be revolutionized. It may even be that they will also be receptive to innovative ways of providing training contracts.

与律所的对话往往不同于与传统律所的互动。律所不太墨守成规，更加灵活，而且我期望他们更尊重年轻律师或心态年轻的律师的想法。

Conversations with law companies tend to be different from interactions with traditional practices. They are less hidebound by past practices, more flexible, and more respectful, I expect, of ideas that emanate from lawyers who are young or young in heart.

在线法律服务提供商

Online Legal Service Providers

对于渴望成为法律知识工程师的年轻律师来说，在线法律服务提供商或许是理想的职业选择。无论是提供在线咨询、在线文件制作还是在线争议解决，这些业务都旨在分析和预先打包法律及法律服务，使客户（包括消费者和企业）无需直接咨询真人律师即可获得法律洞见和服务。然而，开发这些系统和服务需要深厚的法律专业知识，未来许多法学毕业生和年轻律师都将在这些业务中找到工作。

For young lawyers who are keen to pursue careers as legal knowledge engineers, a natural home may well be a provider of online legal services. Whether providing online advice, online production of documents, or online dispute resolution, these are businesses that analyse and pre-package the law and legal service, allowing clients (both consumers and businesses) to tap into legal insight and service without direct consultation with human lawyers. Deep legal expertise is required, however, in developing these systems and services, and many law graduates and young lawyers in the future will find employment in these businesses.

尽管少数在线法律服务提供商取得了显著成功（LegalZoom 就是我立即想到的），但大多数公司仍处于起步阶段。然而，在数字社会中，很难想象有些公司不会获得显著的关注。这类公司的职业发展机会各不相同。其影响范围非常广泛，从寻求改变复杂交易中法律文件制作方式的大型企业，到努力以第 12 章所讨论的方式增加获得司法公正机会的慈善组织。

Although a small number of online legal service providers have achieved remarkable success (LegalZoom springs immediately to mind), it is early days for most of them. But it is hard to imagine, in a digital society, that some will not gain considerable traction. The career opportunities here will vary enormously, from large-scale businesses that will seek, for example, to transform the production of legal documentation in complex deals, through to charitable organizations which will strive to increase access to justice in the ways discussed in Chapter 12.

法律管理咨询

Legal Management Consultancies

一些传统的咨询公司和一些专业的法律咨询机构也将为未来的律师提供就业机会。这些公司将专注于法律流程分析、法律项目管理和法律风险管理等，并就如何以最佳方式管理和组织可持续的内部法律职能提供建议。这些专业领域可能与许多年轻有抱负的律师在开始学习法律时所设想的工作有所不同，但它们对法律市场和客户的利益至关重要。

Some traditional consulting firms and some dedicated legal consulting practices will also provide employment for tomorrow’s lawyers. These businesses will specialize, for example, in legal process analysis, legal project management, and legal risk management, as well as in advising on the optimum way of managing and organizing a sustainable internal legal function. These specialties may not look like the work that many young and aspiring lawyers have in mind when starting their study of law but they will be central to the legal market and to the interests of clients, nonetheless.

特别是对法律流程分析师和法律项目经理的需求将会很大，因此，参加过这些领域的课程并拥有相关经验的年轻律师可能会比那些只具备法律常识的律师更容易找到工作。

In particular, the demand for legal process analysts and legal project managers will be considerable, so that young lawyers who have taken courses and profess experience in these fields may find themselves more employable than those who boast knowledge only of black-letter law.

律师们经常对管理顾问轻蔑有加。诚然，许多自称是顾问的顾问，能力和经验远不如他们声称的那样。但也有一群非常受人尊敬、令人印象深刻的管理顾问，我敢说，他们的方法和技巧，在未来几年里，将会被许多成功的法律企业所采用。

Lawyers often speak disparagingly of management consultants. It is true that many advisers who claim to be consultants are less able or experienced than they assert. But there is also a very respectable and impressive body of management consultants whose methods and techniques, I hazard, will be those that many successful legal businesses embrace in years to come.

法律科技公司

Lawtech Companies

如果在 20 世纪 80 年代中期我获得法学和人工智能 (AI) 博士学位时，就有以客户为导向的法律科技公司存在，我会毫不犹豫地选择其中一家。如第十章所述，目前全球有 3,000 到 4,000 家法律科技初创企业，其中许多公司非常适合精力充沛、对上一章所述工作有一定经验或感兴趣的法律专业毕业生。在这些公司工作通常比在律师事务所工作风险更高——毫无疑问，许多公司会失败或苦苦挣扎。但也有少数公司会飞黄腾达，成为其中一员将是令人振奋的。

If client-oriented lawtech companies had existed when I finished my doctorate in law and artificial intelligence (AI) in the mid-1980s, I would have gravitated towards one of them with little hesitation. As noted in Chapter 10, there are now 3,000 to 4,000 lawtech start-ups around the world, many of whom would be well-suited to energetic legal graduates with some experience or interest in the jobs laid out in the previous chapter. Taking employment in these businesses is generally higher risk than working in a law firm—no doubt many will fail or struggle. But a few will fly and it would be exhilarating to be part of one that succeeds.

许多初创企业仍处于起步阶段，就业前景可能（也可能并非）过于不稳定，但也有越来越多更成熟的独立法律科技公司——例如 Ironclad、Neota Logic 和 Litera——它们历史更悠久或资金雄厚，正在不断推出令人兴奋的新产品和服务。这些公司将颠覆法律市场。作为一名年轻律师，如果你渴望颠覆并突破界限，那么这些法律科技公司或许就是你的理想之选。

Many of the start-ups are still at an early stage and may (or may not) seem too precarious a place for employment, but there are also a growing number of more mature independent lawtech businesses—such as Ironclad, Neota Logic, and Litera —that are longer established or well-funded and are forging ahead with exciting new products and services. These are the kind of business that will disrupt the legal marketplace. If you are keen to disrupt and push the boundaries, as a young lawyer, then these lawtech companies may well be your natural home.

您的第一份法律工作

Your First Job in Law

如果目前的趋势持续下去，法学院学生可能会发现，在传统律所获得实习机会或年轻律师的就业机会会越来越困难。正如我在上一章中所说，如果你即将从法学院毕业，我仍然倾向于建议你应该尝试在律师事务所或公司内部法务部门找到工作，以便完成培训并获得律师资格。然而，如果你未能做到这一点——这是我的核心信息之一，我希望是积极的——正如本章介绍的那样，许多其他法律公司可能也对你感兴趣。或者，如果你已经具备资格，并且正在探索律师事务所以外的选择，那么令人兴奋的新业务和新选择正在涌现。

If current trends continue, law students may find it increasingly difficult to secure traineeships or employment as young lawyers in conventional law firms. As I say in the previous chapter, if you are graduating from law school, I am still inclined to suggest that you try to obtain work in a law firm or an in-house legal department, so that you can complete your training and qualify as a lawyer. However, if you fail to do so—and this is one of my central and, I hope, positive messages—there will be many other legal businesses, as introduced in this chapter, that may well be interested in engaging you. Alternatively, if you are already qualified and are exploring your options beyond law firms, then exciting new businesses and new options are emerging.

18培训律师为了什么？

18 Training Lawyers for What?

我仍然对一位美国一所顶尖法学院的学生深表同情。2016年初，在我给他的班级讲课后，他找到了我。当时我的讲座主题是法律服务的未来，内容涵盖了本书的大部分内容。这位学生对我说：“我背负了近50万美元的学生贷款，而你似乎在说我的法学院没有教给我正确的东西。” 值得庆幸的是，作为一名美国法学院毕业生，他的负债额异常高。即便如此，根据美国律师协会（ABA）网站的记录，2020年美国法学院毕业生的平均债务为14.5万美元，这仍然是一个不小的负担。

I still feel deep sympathy for a law student in a leading US law school who approached me in early 2016, after I had spoken to his class. My lecture had been on the future of legal services and I had covered much of the ground laid out in this book. The student said to me, ‘I am almost half a million dollars in student debt and you seem to be saying that my law school is not teaching me the right stuff’. Thankfully, his indebtedness as a US law graduate is unusually high. That said, the average debt of a US law school graduate in 2020, as recorded on the website of the American Bar Association (ABA), was $145,000, which is still a considerable burden.

大多数学生预计自己在法律领域的收入足以偿还贷款。但这其中存在两个问题。首先，许多原本可能倾向于从事低薪公益法律工作的法律系学生，却因为急于尽快还清债务而转向收入更高的传统工作。结果，所谓的第三部门在人才争夺战中往往处于劣势，更普遍的是，债务导致一些毕业生走上别人不想要的职业道路。第二个困难是，并不是所有的法律专业毕业生都能找到合适的工作。

Most students anticipate that their earnings in law will be sufficient to meet their loans. There are two problems here though. The first is that many law students who might otherwise have been inclined towards, for example, lower-paid public-interest legal work are instead nudged by anxiousness to pay off their debt swiftly towards more lucrative conventional employment. In turn, the so-called third sector generally loses in its war for talent and, more generally, debt leads some graduates along unwanted career paths. The second difficulty is that not all legal graduates secure jobs of any suitable sort.

关于后一点，多年来，世界各地的法学院一直因招收的法学院学生数量远远超过律师事务所和其他法律组织的就业人数而受到批评。在美国，布莱恩·塔玛纳哈 (Brian Tamanaha) 在其 2012 年出版的《失败的法学院》一书中非常尖锐地提出了这一观点。他指出，政府统计数据表明，到 2018 年，每年只有 25,000 个新职位提供给年轻律师，而法学院每年培养出约 45,000 名毕业生。这些数字被证明是悲观的，尽管塔玛纳哈可以争辩说，他的工作可能影响了更多负责任的学生被法学院录取。无论如何，今天美国的法学院毕业生比十年前减少了约 10,000 名。虽然顶级法学院的毕业生有很好的机会获得职位，但来自排名较低的学校的学生的就业情况要艰难得多；有些学校的毕业生中，只有不到 50% 的人毕业后能找到法律工作。法学院毕业生过剩的现象在许多其他发达地区也普遍存在。

On this latter point, law schools around the world have for many years been criticized for accepting far more law students than are employable in law firms and other legal organizations. In the US, the point was made very starkly in 2012 by Brian Tamanaha in his book, Failing Law Schools. He pointed to government statistics that suggested there would only be 25,000 new openings for young lawyers each year until 2018 while the law schools were annually producing around 45,000 graduates. These figures proved to be pessimistic, although it would be open to Tamanaha to argue that his work might have influenced more responsible numbers of students being admitted to law schools. In any event, today there are approximately 10,000 fewer law graduates in the US than a decade ago. While graduates of top tier law schools stand an excellent chance of securing positions, those who come from lower-ranked schools have a much rougher ride; from some, less than 50 per cent have law jobs on graduating. This overproduction of law graduates is a disorder that can be observed in many other advanced jurisdictions.

对于那些为了学习法律而背负巨额贷款却找不到称心工作的法学院学生来说，他们感到失望是可以理解的。几年前，一些人甚至试图向法学院提起诉讼，要求退还学费并赔偿损失，理由是法律教育行业存在持续的欺诈行为，可能导致一代法学院学生陷入严重的财务困境。然而，如今学生们再也无法提出这样的论点，因为这个问题已经……已经得到广泛传播，进入法学院的有抱负的律师知道，或者至少应该知道，广泛的趋势。

For law students who take out enormous loans to undertake their legal studies and do not find work for which they are qualified, it is understandable that they might feel disillusioned. Several years ago, some even tried to raise court actions against law schools for the refund of their tuition fees plus damages, arguing that there was an ongoing fraud in the legal education industry that threatened to leave a generation of law students in dire financial straits. However, students cannot with any credibility advance such arguments today because the issue has been widely ventilated and aspiring lawyers entering law schools know, or at least ought to know, the broad trends.

本章关注的一个相关问题是法学院实际教学内容的合理性。我感兴趣的是，教育机构是否充分地帮助法学院学生做好迎接未来法律市场的准备，从而最大限度地提高他们找到好工作的机会。在美国，美国律师协会（ABA）法律教育未来委员会（2017-2019）明确指出了其所谓的“危机”。该委员会认为，美国的法律教育体系“正在为下一代法律专业人士培养昨天而不是明天”。我希望我对这一说法有所启发。我是委员会中唯一的非美国人，多年来一直在强调类似的观点，尤其是在本书的早期版本中。美国法律界是否会对此予以关注尚不清楚。

A related issue is my focus in this chapter—with the appropriateness of what law schools actually teach. My interest is in whether educational bodies are adequately preparing law students for tomorrow’s legal marketplace and so maximizing their chances of finding good work. In the US, the ABA Commission on the Future of Legal Education (2017–2019), was clear on the ‘crisis’, as it put it. The Commission argued that the US system of legal education ‘is preparing the next generation of legal professionals for yesterday rather than for tomorrow’. I hope I had some influence on this claim. I was the only non-American on the Commission and had been banging a similar drum for years, not least in earlier versions of this book. Whether the US legal profession will pay heed is not yet clear.

就我而言，英格兰和威尔士的法律教育与培训评估报告（我们30年来最全面的评估报告）在其2013年的报告中，恐怕在很大程度上未能清晰地阐明法律行业可能存在的教育与培训需求。相反，在我看来，它提供了一个非常详细的模型，用于优化过去律师的培训。我也是这次评估的顾问，但未能成功说服主要研究人员接受本章的核心信息。

Closer to my home, I am afraid the Legal Education and Training Review in England and Wales, our most thoroughgoing assessment for 30 years, in its report of 2013, largely failed to articulate the education and training needs for the legal industry as it is likely to be. Instead, it provided a very detailed model, in my view, for optimizing the training of yesterday’s lawyers. I was also a consultant to this review but did not succeed in convincing the main researchers of the principal messages of this chapter.

一些假设和担忧

Some Assumptions and Concerns

本文并非对教育理论和法律进行详细分析和评估的场所。然而，一些假设我对当前和未来律师培训的看法和担忧，我认为最好明确地阐述这些看法。

This is not the place for a detailed analysis and evaluation of educational theory and law. However, a number of assumptions and concerns underlie my views on the current and future training of lawyers, and I think it best to lay these out explicitly.

首先，我认为法律本身可以成为一门值得追求的学科。当然，在英国等地的大学学习法律与在美国学习法律之间存在差异，因为在英国，法律通常是作为学士学位来攻读的，而在美国，法律的学习通常以研究生学习的形式进行。因此，美国学生在学习法律时更有可能立志将法律职业作为职业。

I assume, first, that the law can be an academic discipline worth pursuing for its own sake. There is a contrast, of course, between studying law at university in, say, England as opposed to the US because in the former, this is usually pursued as a first degree, whereas in the latter, the learning of the law is generally undertaken in the form of graduate study. Accordingly, students in the US are more likely, when studying law, to be committed to the legal profession as a career.

本科阶段学习法律本身就极具启发性——法律是人类最卓越、最复杂的构造之一，是一个全面的知识体系，为人类秩序和行为提供了框架。研究实体规则本身固然有趣，但深入研究法理学（广义上指法哲学）和民法（罗马法）等学科，作为一项独立的知识追求，也能带来巨大的回报。认同法律学术研究本身能够带来成就感，这绝不意味着法律学位应该仅仅专注于理论研究。这也不意味着承认法律学位无法提供接触法律实践的机会，无法洞察法律职业，也无法获得法律从业人员的一些关键技能。

When law is studied at an undergraduate level, it can be profoundly stimulating in its own right—the law is one of humanity’s most remarkable and sophisticated constructs, a comprehensive system of knowledge that provides a framework for human order and behaviour. To study the substantive rules themselves can be interesting, but to be immersed in subjects such as jurisprudence (broadly, the philosophy of law) and civil law (Roman law) can also be immensely rewarding as self-contained intellectual pursuits. To agree that the academic study of law can be fulfilling in and of itself is emphatically not to suggest that law degrees should be devoted solely to matters of theory. Nor is it to concede that there is no place in a law degree for exposure to legal practice, or insight into the vocation of law, or the acquisition of some of the key skills of the practitioner.

我的第二个假设是，攻读法律学位所带来的培训，无论以后是否从事法律职业，都能提供有用的技能和经验。从历史上看，许多学生在寻求广泛的培训，以便在商业领域更好地工作时，往往会选择会计。但法律培训也可能非常有价值——不仅仅是因为法学毕业生不仅掌握了大量的规则和法规，而且良好的法学学位还应培养和提供严谨的思维、清晰的分析、精确的语言、批判性思维的能力、深入研究的能力以及公开演讲的自信。

My second assumption is that the training afforded by the pursuit of a law degree can provide useful skills and experience whether or not a career in law is later taken up. Historically, many students have gravitated towards accounting when seeking a broad training to serve them well for a career in the commercial world. But legal training can also be extremely valuable—not just because law graduates have a grasp of a large body of rules and regulations but for the intellectual rigour, the clarity of analysis, the precision with language, the facility for critical thought, the capacity for intensive research, and the confidence in public speaking that a good degree in law should build and provide.

与此同时，第三，我担心，在大学和专业考试中提供的足以获得资格的法律教育，其要求低于许多其他受人尊敬的职业。我观察了医学、建筑学和兽医学，发现它们的学习课程通常更长、更艰苦。这并不是说在大学学习法律并参加专业考试是一个轻松的选择，但与进入我们许多其他重要的职业相比，获得律师资格肯定更快，至少可以说更容易。

At the same time, third, I am concerned that legal education, delivered in university and in professional exams and sufficient to lead to qualification, is less demanding than that required for many other respectable professions. I look at medicine, architecture, veterinary science, and generally see longer and more arduous courses of study. It is not that studying law at university and taking professional exams is a soft option, but it is certainly quicker and, at least arguably, easier to qualify as a lawyer than to gain entry into many of our other great professions.

我的最后一个问题是，法律行业的学术分支和实践分支之间衔接不够。例如，我怀着无比钦佩，甚至略带羡慕地看着伦敦那些伟大的教学医院。在那里，一位医学教授在同一屋檐下，通常一天之内就能完成诊疗、培训年轻医生和开展研究等工作。在欧洲大陆，大学法学教授也从事法律实践的传统更为浓厚。但在英国，以及在很大程度上在美国和加拿大，法律从业者和法律学者身处不同的世界。在某些司法管辖区，双方都存在着不健康的不尊重：执业律师将法律学者视为脱离现实世界的象牙塔里的理论家，而法律学者则将日常的法律实践视为纯粹的商业建议，而非严肃而实质性的、务实的实践。

My final issue is that the academic and practising branches of the legal profession are insufficiently dovetailed. I look with much admiration, and a little envy, at the great teaching hospitals in London, for example. There, under one roof, a professor of medicine will treat patients, train young doctors, and undertake research, often in the one day. In continental Europe there is a stronger tradition of university law professors also being in legal practice. But in England and to a large extent in the US and Canada, legal practitioners and legal scholars operate in different worlds. In some jurisdictions there is also an unhealthy disrespect in both directions: practising lawyers regard legal academics as ivory-towered theorists divorced from the real world, while legal scholars look upon the daily practice of law as mere business advice rather than serious and substantive black-letter enterprise.

总而言之，如果你正在考虑学习法律，我可以向你保证，这将是一段激动人心的经历，将为你的人生做好准备（前提是教学质量良好）。然而，法学院可能会受到批评，而且经常受到执业人士的批评，因为他们没有为年轻学生做好充分的法律实践准备。

In summary, if you are contemplating the study of law, I can assure you of a stimulating experience that will equip you well for life (assuming it is well taught). However, law schools can be criticized, and often are by practitioners, for not preparing young students adequately for the practice of law.

我们要把年轻律师培养成什么样子？

What Are We Training Young Lawyers to Become?

到目前为止，我对法学院的批评尚未触及一个更为根本的问题。许多执业律师质疑法学院毕业生是否做好了在当今律师事务所工作的准备，这本身就令人担忧。但如果毕业生无法胜任目前的法律实践，那么正如本书前文所预测的那样，他们对未来十年或二十年的法律世界将准备不足。

My own critique of law schools so far has not touched on a far more fundamental concern. It is worrying enough that many practising lawyers question law graduates’ preparedness for working in today’s law firms. But if graduates are not well equipped for legal practice as currently delivered, they are staggeringly ill-prepared for the legal world of the next decade or two, as anticipated in the earlier parts of this book.

因此，我们必须要问：我们培养的大量年轻律师究竟是什么样的人？这是本书最根本的问题之一。我们是在把有抱负的律师培养成传统的一对一、单独、定制化、面对面的咨询顾问，专门研究各个司法管辖区的繁琐法律，并按小时收费？还是在培养下一代律师成为更灵活、更注重团队合作、技术更精湛、商业头脑更敏锐的混合型专业人士，能够超越法律和职业界限，并能运用董事会和市场的语言？我深感担忧的是，法学院和职业培训的重点主要集中在前者，而很少考虑后者。事实上，更深层次的担忧在于，许多法律教育者和政策制定者甚至不知道还有第二种选择。简而言之，我担心的是，我们正在培养年轻律师成为20世纪的律师，而不是21世纪的律师。

It therefore must be asked: what are we training large numbers of young lawyers to become? This is one of the most fundamental questions of the book. Are we schooling aspiring lawyers to become traditional one-to-one, solo, bespoke, face-to-face, consultative advisers who specialize in the black-letter law of individual jurisdictions and who charge by the hour? Or are we preparing the next generation of lawyers to be more flexible, team-based, technologically sophisticated, commercially astute, hybrid professionals, who are able to transcend legal and professional boundaries, and speak the language of the boardroom and the marketplace? My profound concern is that the emphasis in law schools and professional training is overwhelmingly on the former, with little regard for the latter. Indeed, a more profound concern still is that many legal educators and policymakers do not even know there is a second option. My fear, in short, is that we are training young lawyers to become twentieth-century lawyers and not twenty-first-century lawyers.

从另一个角度来看这个问题，按照第 16 章的措辞，我们在培训律师时，重点是培养新一代值得信赖的专家顾问和高级从业人员，但忽略了他们未来可能从事的法律知识工程师、法律技术专家、法律流程分析师、法律项目经理、法律风险经理等职业。

To look at this issue in another way, we are focusing, in the training of our lawyers, in the language of Chapter 16, on incubating a new generation of expert trusted advisers and enhanced practitioners but ignoring their likely future careers as legal knowledge engineers, legal technologists, legal process analysts, legal project managers, legal risk managers, and the rest.

当然，至关重要的是，我们要继续为年轻律师提供必要的条件，使他们能够成为一流的专家、值得信赖的顾问和内部从业人员，但如果课程不改变，如果我们不扩大培训范围以涵盖这些其他新角色，那将是对学生及其未来的客户的忽视。

It is vital, of course, that we continue to equip young lawyers with the wherewithal to function as first-rate expert trusted advisers and in-house practitioners, but if curricula do not change, it will be neglectful of students and their clients of the future if we do not widen our training to encompass these other new roles.

在许多法学院，法律教学内容与20世纪70年代的教学模式大体相同，教授们对不断变化的法律市场缺乏洞察力或兴趣。他们往往很少关注全球化、商品化、技术、商业管理、风险评估、分解和替代采购等现象。因此，我再次强调——如果英国许多法学院毕业生今天还没有为法律工作做好充分准备，那么他们就完全无法胜任未来的工作。

In many law schools, in terms of content, the law is taught much as it was in the 1970s by professors who have little insight into or interest in the changing legal marketplace. Too often, scant attention is paid to phenomena such as globalization, commoditization, technology, business management, risk assessment, decomposing, and alternative sourcing. And so, I stress again—if many law graduates in the UK are not well prepared for legal work today, they are wholly ill-equipped for tomorrow.

那么，我们是否应该扩大法学院的教学范围，将风险管理、项目管理和法律知识管理等其他学科纳入其中？在繁重的法律课程中，未来还有一席之地吗？

Should we, therefore, extend the remit of law schools and colleges to include other disciplines such as risk management, project management, and legal knowledge management? Is there a place for the future in the busy law curriculum?

法律教育的未来

The Place for the Future in Legal Education

我绝不是建议我们应该抛弃合同法、宪法和侵权法等核心法律科目。我更不主张我们不再教授学生法律方法——如何像律师一样思考，如何整理和组织复杂的事实，如何进行法律研究，如何运用法律推理（演绎法、归纳法、类比法），如何解读立法和判例法等等。但我们确实需要思考，在年轻律师的整个培养过程中，如何让他们更充分地为未来几十年的法律实践做好准备。

I am not for a second suggesting that we should jettison core legal subjects such as contract, constitutional law, and tort. Still less am I advocating that we no longer teach students about legal method—how to think like a lawyer, how to marshal and organize a complex set of facts, how to conduct legal research, how to reason with the law (deductively, inductively, analogically), how to interpret legislation and case law, and more. But we do need to think, across the lifecycle of the training of young lawyers, how we can more adequately prepare them for legal practice in the coming decades.

或许有人会说，培养法学院学生掌握我所指的新学科的时间和地点并非法学院，而是研究生课程，例如英格兰和威尔士的法律实践课程和律师专业培训课程。或许还有更强有力的论据，主张在签订培训合同、实习期或某种契约或学徒期的同时，对这些新兴的法律领域进行更深入的培训。但我很清楚，法学院不能忽视未来的实践。事实上，在我看来，这样做是失职。对在线法庭和文档自动化等视而不见，又能找到什么样的辩护理由呢？

It may be argued that the time and place to train law students in the new disciplines that I identify is not law school but in post-graduate courses, such as the legal practice courses and Bar professional training courses in England and Wales. And there may be a stronger argument still for more intensive training in these emerging fields in the law while undertaking a training contract, pupillage, or some kind of indenture or apprenticeship. But it is clear to me that law schools cannot ignore future practice. Indeed, in my view, it is a dereliction of their duty to do so. What kind of defence can be launched in favour of turning a blind eye, say, to online courts and document automation?

因此，我建议我们首先应该为法学院的所有学生（以及他们教育的各个阶段的学生）提供强制性的、正式的、深入的研究法律服务当前和未来趋势的课程（无论是作为独立课程还是作为课程的重要组成部分）；其次，可以选择学习一些21世纪的关键法律技能，这些技能将为未来的法律工作提供支持。我认为这对法学院来说并不算过重的负担，因此我认为法学院学生可以合理地向那些为他们提供充足且适当法律教育而付费的学校提出这样的要求。越来越多的证据表明，法律职业需要超越传统的服务领域，延伸到法律风险管理和法律项目管理等领域。我的观点是：在法律教育的各个阶段，学生都应该接触到关于法律和法律服务未来发展的系统性教学，他们也应该有选择和机会接受这些新技能和新学科的培训。

Accordingly, I suggest that we should provide all law students in law schools (and indeed at all stages of their education) first of all with compulsory formal immersion into the study of current and future trends in legal services (whether as a stand-alone course or as a significant segment of a course), and second, with the option to learn some key twenty-first-century legal skills that will support future law jobs. I do not consider this unduly onerous for law schools, and so I think law students can reasonably demand this of those whom they are paying for the provision of sufficient and appropriate legal education. There is mounting evidence of the need for a legal profession that extends itself beyond traditional service to fields such as legal risk management and legal project management. My case is this: at all stages in the provision of legal education, students should be exposed to systematic teaching about the future of law and legal services, and they should also have the choice and opportunity to be trained in these new skills and disciplines.

让从业人员参与这些选修课程的授课将大有裨益，既能让学生深入了解市场不断发展的经验，又能促进学术界和实践界之间的相互交流。我相信这些课程的参与率会很高。

Involving practitioners in the delivery of these optional courses would be good, both to give students insight into evolving experience in the market and to encourage cross-fertilization between the academic and practising branches of the profession. I suspect that these courses would be very well attended.

我还向全世界的法学教授们提出了一个迫切的请求：积极关注法律服务的未来；开展研究（或许是社会法律研究）以探究该行业的趋势；让学生了解可能的未来；并且避免（用一位加拿大法学院院长的话来说）处于“传统的前沿”。世界各地的法学院不应该只是零星地教授一门课程。相反，他们应该效仿美国的先驱和创新者，例如迈阿密大学法学院（其“无墙法律”（LawWithoutWalls）是一个激动人心、部分线上的国际倡议，旨在改变法律的教学和实践方式）、哈佛大学法学院（其法律职业课程是令人钦佩的研究、教学和学者与实践者之间合作的结合)、乔治城大学法学院 (举办“铁技术律师邀请赛”)、芝加哥肯特法学院 (提供法律创新和技术方面的法学博士证书课程)、密歇根州立大学 (设有法律、技术和创新中心) 和斯坦福大学 (拥有两个相关能力 (CODEX，一个法律信息学中心，以及 Deborah L. Rhode 法律职业中心)。

I also have an urgent request of law professors the world over: to take an active interest in the future of legal service; to undertake research (perhaps socio-legal work) into trends in the profession; to expose students to likely futures; and to resist being (in the words of the Dean of a Canadian law school) at ‘the cutting edge of tradition’. Law faculties around the world should not just teach a course here or there. Instead they ought to follow the lead of pioneers and innovators in the US, such as the University of Miami School of Law (whose LawWithoutWalls is an exciting, part-virtual, international initiative that aims to change the way that law is taught and practised), Harvard Law School (whose programme on the legal profession is an admirable blend of research, teaching, and collaboration between academics and practitioners), Georgetown Law (with their ‘Iron Tech Lawyer Invitational’ competition), Chicago-Kent College of Law (offering a J.D. Certificate Program in Legal Innovation + Technology), Michigan State University (which has a Center for Law, Technology & Innovation), and Stanford University with two relevant capabilities (CODEX, a centre for legal informatics, and the Deborah L. Rhode Center on the Legal Profession).

我认为，欧洲在大学法学院中将技术和法律领域制度化方面已是首屈一指。我指的是成立于1970年的挪威计算机与法律研究中心。然而，我们尚未兑现这一早期承诺。除了一些显著的例外——例如德国的布塞里乌斯法学院——我发现大多数欧洲法学院在应对本书所关注的变革方面略显迟缓。更具体地说，在英国，我怀着沉重的心情写道，很少有法学院能够自豪地宣称自己在法律技术或法律服务未来研究方面持续投入。我对斯旺西大学、牛津大学、阿尔斯特大学、曼彻斯特大学和伦敦南岸大学的举措尤其印象深刻。但英国法学院更广泛接受的法律实践概念与法律服务行业内部对法律服务未来发展的主流观点格格不入。我担心，如果任其发展，许多法学院的变化速度将极其缓慢。我认为，答案是律师事务所和内部法务部门应该与法学院更紧密地合作。最实际的答案是每所法学院都任命一名该领域的专家，可以在内部传播福音并建立理解和支持。

I believe that Europe was first past the post in institutionalizing the field of technology and law in a university law school. I have in mind the Norwegian Research Center for Computers and Law, founded in 1970. We have not, however, followed through on that early promise. With some notable exceptions—for example, Bucerius Law School in Germany—I find most European law schools a little sleepy in their handling of the disruptions that are the focus of this book. In the UK, more specifically, it is with a heavy heart that I write of how few law schools can boast of sustained initiatives devoted either to legal technology or the study of the future of legal services. I am particularly impressed with initiatives at Swansea University, the University of Oxford, Ulster University, Manchester University, and London South Bank University. But the conception of legal practice more widely assumed by the British legal academy is out of step with the prevailing views within the practising branch of the profession on the future of legal service. I fear, if left to their own devices, many law schools will change at a glacial pace. The answer here, I suspect, will be for law firms and in-house legal departments to work more closely with the law schools. The most practical answer is for every law school to appoint a specialist the field, who can evangelize internally and build understanding and support.

最后，本章探讨的思路也为一个老问题提供了新的视角：“如果我想成为一名律师，我应该在本科阶段攻读法律学位吗？”我在这里没有给出明确的答案，但我可以看到，由于未来的法律服务将越来越多地借鉴其他领域，现在比过去有更强有力的理由支持在开始法律职业之前学习其他学科，例如管理学、计算机科学和系统分析。

Finally, the line of thinking explored in this chapter also provides a new angle on an old question: ‘If I want to be a lawyer, should I pursue a law degree as an undergraduate?’ I offer no definitive response here but I can see, because tomorrow’s legal service will increasingly draw on other fields, that there are stronger arguments now than in the past for studying other disciplines—such as management, computer science, and systems analysis—prior to embarking on a legal career.

19更换旧训练场

19 Replacing the Old Training Ground

我在会议上发言时，总会被问到年轻律师未来将如何学习他们的专业技能。我担心的是，根据我的假设，过去由年轻律师处理的大量常规重复性工作很快将以不同的方式被接手，无论是通过法律流程外包、律师助理、技术还是其他方式。如果年轻律师过去赖以成长的基础法律工作现在都由他人承担，那么年轻律师该如何迈出成为专家的第一步呢？

When I speak at conferences, I am invariably asked about the ways in which young lawyers will learn their trade in the future. The concern here is that, according to my hypothesis, a great deal of routine and repetitive work that used to be handled by young lawyers will soon be sourced in different ways, whether by legal process outsourcing, by paralegals, by technology, or the rest. If the basic legal work, upon which young lawyers used to cut their teeth, is to be undertaken by others, how does a young lawyer take the early steps towards becoming an expert?

训练问题

A Training Problem

对于那些倡导替代性资源的人来说，这是一个重要但并非致命的挑战。它并非致命，部分原因是很少有客户会同情这一障碍。本质上，我们面临的是一个培训问题——替代性资源要求律师事务所重新思考其培训律师的方式。如果可以选择，大多数客户都会选择那些不得不彻底改革培训方式的律师事务所提供的低成本法律服务。而这家公司似乎仍然固守着过去的培训方法，并提供高价服务。

This is an important but not fatal challenge to those who advocate alternative sourcing. It is not fatal, in part because this is an obstacle with which very few clients have sympathy. In essence, what we have here is a training problem—alternative sourcing requires law firms to rethink the way they train their lawyers. And most clients, if given the choice, will choose lower-cost legal service from a law firm that has to overhaul its training over a high price service from a firm that seems intransigently wedded to training methods of the past.

问题的根源在于，由于所谓的人才争夺战，许多律所为了吸引最优秀的毕业生而支付高薪。然而，无论这些实习生和有抱负的年轻律师多么有才华，他们在律所最初几年的价值更多地在于他们的潜力，而不是他们能为客户提供的实际服务。不言而喻的现实是，目前的制度通常导致客户为律所里有抱负的年轻律师的培训付费。客户需要为这些实习生支付相当高的小时费率，尽管大部分工作都是基于流程的，而且这些年轻律师是在工作中学习的。他们可能学得很快，但他们的经验或专业知识不足以证明他们被收取的费用是合理的。相比之下，在当今这个瞬息万变、经济形势更加严峻的时代，客户要求以更低的成本获得更多的法律服务，因此他们对于为那些通过处理客户的交易和纠纷来学习业务的初出茅庐的律师支付时间费用的容忍度要低得多。

The root of the problem here is that because of the so-called war for talent, many firms pay very large salaries to attract the most gifted graduates. However, no matter how talented these trainees and aspiring young lawyers might be, their value for the first couple of years in law offices lies more in their potential than in the actual services they can deliver to clients. The unspoken truth is that the current set-up generally results in clients paying for the training of law firms’ aspiring young lawyers. The clients are charged at fairly high hourly rates for the work of these trainees, even though much of the work is process-based and the young lawyers are learning on the job. They may be quick learners but they have insufficient experience or expertise to justify the rates at which they are being charged. Today, in contrast, in changing and more austere times, when clients are demanding more legal service at less cost, they are much less tolerant of paying for the time of budding lawyers who are learning their trade by working on their clients’ deals and disputes.

几年前，在思考这些问题时，我决定采访一些实习律师，了解他们对这个难题的看法。我采访了一些有抱负的律师，他们为了准备诉讼，需要审查成堆的文件，还有一些人正在进行大规模的尽职调查，以支持大型交易。我问他们，如果他们目前的工作要外包给印度，他们将如何学习他们的行业。他们一致回答说，学习如何处理成堆的文件只需要几个小时，而不是几个月。为了更清楚地表达这一点，值得一提的是，我们不应该将培训与剥削混为一谈。认为年轻律师被要求从事日常法律工作主要是为了学习他们的专业技能，这种说法并不诚实。相反，这种委托一直是支撑金字塔盈利模式的支柱之一，这种模式直到最近才获得了如此不容置疑的成功。

Some years ago, when pondering these issues, I decided to interview some trainee solicitors to determine their take on this conundrum. I spoke to aspiring lawyers who were reviewing endless boxes of documents in preparation for litigation and others who were undertaking major due diligence exercises in support of large deals. I asked them how they would learn their trade if the work they were currently doing was to be, say, outsourced to India. Uniformly they responded that it took only a few hours to learn how to work through piles of documents, and not several months. To express this point more provocatively, we should not confuse training with exploitation. It is disingenuous to suggest that young lawyers are asked to undertake routine legal work largely as a way of them learning their trade. Rather, this delegation has been one mainstay in supporting the pyramidic model of profitability that has enjoyed such unchallenged success until recently.

无论如何，有抱负的律师们通过花费数月时间从事以行政为主的工作，最终成为专业律师，这一点并不明显。越来越多的证据表明，年轻律师是通过与法律专家密切合作并观察他们的实际工作来学习他们的技能的。

In any event, it is not at all obvious that aspiring lawyers become expert lawyers by spending months on what is largely administrative work. There is greater evidence that young lawyers learn their trade by working closely with, and observing, legal experts in action.

话虽如此，我确实承认一些其他来源的工作确实提供了有益的培训平台。但目前尚不清楚律师事务所将如何应对客户日益增长的反感，因为他们越来越不愿意为供应商的年轻人支付培训费用。一个可能的选择，尽管对许多律师事务所来说具有挑战性，那就是不再向客户收取培训生和年轻律师的费用，除非他们真正带来价值。这将直接减少那些依赖金字塔结构的律师事务所的利润。这可能会给年轻律师带来两种后果。首先，除了极其有才华的律师外，年轻律师在律所工作的早期获得的报酬可能会比过去更低。其次，也是更有可能的结果是，律所将减少招聘年轻且有抱负的律师的数量。这并不一定意味着所有年轻律师的就业能力都会下降，因为律师和雇主都会有新的工作机会（参见第16章和第17章）。但对于法学院毕业生来说，这确实似乎是一种威胁。

That said, I do recognize that some work that might be alternatively sourced provides a useful training ground. But it is far from clear how law firms might respond to clients’ growing distaste for being charged for the training of their supplier’s young people. One likely option, although challenging for many firms, would be no longer to charge clients for trainees and young lawyers unless and until they genuinely bring value. This would directly reduce the profit of those firms that rely on the pyramidic structure. Two possible consequences might follow for young lawyers. The first is that, with the exception of the supremely talented, young lawyers might come to get paid less in their early years of working in law firms than in the past. The second, and more likely result, is that law firms will recruit young and aspiring lawyers in smaller numbers. This does not necessarily mean that all young lawyers will be less employable, because there will be new jobs for lawyers and new employers to work with (see Chapters 16 and 17). But for law graduates, this does indeed appear to be threatening.

重新思考法律培训

Re-Thinking Legal Training

除了让律师（他们渴望成为传统专家）处理相对简单和常规的法律事务外，还有什么其他的培训方式呢？

What is the alternative to training lawyers (who aspire to being traditional experts) by putting them to work on relatively straightforward and routine legal matters?

如果律所真心致力于培训，我建议未来培训应建立在三个基本基石之上。首先，回归某种学徒模式。研究和经验表明，一旦年轻律师获得纸面资格，与经验丰富的律师紧密合作，是学习如何从书本知识走向实践法律的有效且激励人心的方式。如果年轻律师能够与经验丰富的执业律师同处一室，或者像大型会计师事务所多年来行之有效（现在在律所也步履蹒跚）那样，在开放式办公空间与经验丰富的专业人士共事，他们将能够直接观察和学习与客户沟通和服务的有效方法。如果他们大部分时间都与其他年轻律师待在一起，面对成箱的文件，他们就不太可能见证和吸收最佳实践。我支持面对面的学徒制，这对那些致力于远程办公的人来说是一个挑战。我的方法不需要全职在办公室工作，但肯定需要一定的实际到场。与此同时，我们应该创造性地思考远程学徒制的技术——利用技术使一些学徒制经验能够虚拟地产生。

If law firms are genuinely committed to training, I suggest that it should be founded on three basic building blocks in the future. The first is a reversion to some variant of the apprenticeship model. Once young lawyers have their paper qualifications, research and experience suggest that working closely alongside experienced lawyers is a powerful and stimulating way of learning how to move from the law in books to the law in action. If young lawyers are able to share a room with a seasoned practitioner or, as has worked well for years in large accounting firms (and now, falteringly in law firms), to work in open-plan areas with experienced professionals, they will observe and learn, at first hand, effective methods for communicating with and serving clients. If they instead spend most of their time only with other young lawyers and with large boxes of documents, they are less likely to witness and absorb best practice. My support for an in-person apprenticeship presents a challenge to those who are committed to remote working. My approach does not require full-time attendance in the office but certainly assumes some physical presence. At the same time, we should be thinking creatively about techniques for remote apprenticeship—using technology to enable some of the apprenticeship experience to be engendered virtually.

其次，即使大量的工作来自律所之外，年轻律师仍然可能同时，进行此类工作的抽样调查，一方面是为了学习自身业务，另一方面或许是为了控制外部供应商工作的质量。与过去不同，现在律师事务所需要自行承担此类工作的成本。

Second, it may be that, when significant bodies of work are sourced from beyond the firm, young lawyers may nevertheless, in parallel, undertake samples of this work, partly to learn their trade and partly perhaps as a way of quality controlling the work done by external providers. In contrast with the past, law firms would need themselves to bear the cost of this work.

最后，年轻律师应该受益于现有和新兴的电子学习技术，这些技术在其最先进的形式下可以发挥巨大的作用。这不仅涵盖在线讲座（这些讲座本身就很有用），还涵盖在线模拟法律实践和虚拟法律学习环境。法律行业对技术的采用应该超越办公自动化和客户服务，延伸到我们教育和培训年轻律师的方式。让我再多说几句。

Finally, young lawyers should benefit from existing and emerging techniques of e-learning, which in their most advanced forms can be tremendously powerful. This extends beyond online lectures (which themselves can be useful) to online simulated legal practice and virtual legal learning environments. The legal profession’s adoption of technology should extend beyond office automation and client service into the way in which we educate and train our young lawyers. Let me say a little more about this.

电子学习和模拟法律实践

e-Learning and Simulated Legal Practice

如今，大多数资深律师和法官在个人电脑诞生之前就接受了法律教育。讲座、辅导课以及在布满灰尘的法律图书馆里度过无数个小时，是他们每天的必修课。他们大部分时间都花在记忆大量的案件名称、法规条款以及对其重要性的简要概述上。未来的法学院以及那些提供转学和法律实践课程的大学不应该不加批判地继承这些传统。

Most senior lawyers and judges of today were legally educated before the birth of the personal computer. Lectures, tutorials, and countless hours in dusty law libraries were the order of the day. And much of the time was spent memorizing vast lists of case names and sections of statutes, alongside potted summaries of their significance. None of this should be uncritically inherited by tomorrow’s law schools and by the colleges that offer conversion and legal practice courses.

以传统的一小时讲座为例。如今，基于成本以及课堂实际情况，人们有充分的理由将传统的现场讲座保留在相对罕见的场合，因为这些场合安排了精彩的演讲者，并期待他们带来令人难忘的社交或教育体验。事实是这样的关于英国大多数传统法律讲座的一个问题是——这些讲座通常不是由有天赋的（甚至是受过训练的）演说家主讲的。一些教授含糊不清、东拉西扯，另一些教授只是照本宣科，只有极少数教授能鼓舞人心。难怪出席率低。这种现象在全国无数法学院普遍存在。既浪费资源，又缺乏教育意义。没有理由不用在线讲座取代东拉西扯者和独裁者，在线讲座可以由来自全国各地的优秀鼓舞人心的演讲者进行，他们会将他们的讲座进行网络直播。任何使用过 TED (< http://www.ted.com >) 的人都知道在线演讲有多么强大。当然，在疫情期间，一些学生受益于参加优秀的在线讲座。然而，我怀疑大多数人并没有——精彩的大学讲座很少见；精彩的在线演绎更是少见（很少有教授拥有多年通过视频链接进行交流的经验）。

Take traditional one-hour lectures as an example. There are now compelling arguments, based on cost and on the reality of what actually goes on in a lecture theatre, for reserving conventional live lectures for the relatively rare occasions when wonderful speakers are scheduled and expected to deliver memorable social or educational experiences. Here is the truth about most conventional law lectures in the UK—they are often not given by gifted (or even trained) orators. Some professors mumble and ramble, others simply read from their notes, while only a very few are inspirational. No wonder the attendance is low. And this phenomenon persists across the country in countless law schools. It is wasteful and insufficiently edifying. There is no good reason for not replacing the ramblers and the dictators by online lectures, which can be presented by wonderful and inspirational speakers (selected from across the land) who make webcasts of their lectures available. Anyone who has used TED (<http://www.ted.com>) will know how powerful an online talk can be. During the pandemic, of course, some students have benefited from attending outstanding online lectures. However, I suspect that the majority have not—a great university lecture is rare; a great online rendition is even rarer (few professors have many years of experience of communicating by video link).

或者，某种形式的现场授课可以以实时网络研讨会的形式进行，让学生全程参与并进行辩论。在线资源可以帮助学生准备这些课程。2009年，我受邀对当时的英格兰法学院（现为法学院）的电子学习进行五年期评估，从那时起，我便对混合教学法的潜力深信不疑。我发现，电子教程和在线监督改变了学院法学院学生在法律实践课程上的学习体验。学院开发了400多个“i-tutorials”（在线教程），即由法律专家进行“头肩”式网络直播，并在旁边附有幻灯片。学生们发现这些迷你讲座非常方便，因为它们可以在手持设备和笔记本电脑上停止、开始和重播。学院更进一步并发展了一对一导师指导，采用线上而非线下的方式。这创造了我所说的“电子牛剑”——它保留了传统导师制的许多优势（压力、灵感以及私人专家导师的关注），但却以一种实用且经济的方式实现了。这种模式在疫情期间必然变得普遍，即使并非总是能够无缝执行。现在是时候反思哪些在线学习方式有效，哪些无效，并将第一代在线法律学习方式产业化，并将其与更传统的线下课程相结合。

Alternatively, live lectures of a sort can be given as real-time webinars, which allow students to participate and debate throughout. Online resources can be made available to help students prepare for these sessions. I became convinced of the potential of a hybrid approach in 2009 when I was asked to undertake a five-year review of e-learning at the then College of Law in England (now the University of Law). I found that electronic tutorials and online supervision had changed the learning experience of law students on the college’s legal practice course. More than 400 ‘i-tutorials’ had been developed—online, ‘head and shoulders’ webcasts by legal experts with slides on the side. Students found these mini-lectures highly convenient in that they could be stopped, started, and replayed, on hand-held devices as well as on laptops. The college went a step further and developed one-to-one supervision by tutors, conducted virtually rather than face to face. This created what I called an ‘electronic Oxbridge’—many of the strengths of the traditional tutorial system were secured (the pressure, the inspiration, and the attention of a personal expert tutor) but achieved in a practical, affordable way. This approach, by necessity, became commonplace during the pandemic, even if not always seamlessly executed. It is time now to reflect on what works well online and what does not, and to industrialize this first generation of online legal learning and blend it with more traditional, physical sessions.

然而，在线讲座、网络教程和虚拟监督只是法律教育未来发展的一部分。保罗·马哈格（Paul Maharg）的开创性工作使我们超越了第一代，进入了一个基于模拟的培训和交易学习的世界，正如他在《变革法律教育》一书中所描述的那样。他在斯特拉斯克莱德大学教授的苏格兰法律实践研究生文凭课程中率先采用了这些技术，并为此设计了一个虚构的小镇“阿德卡洛克”，法学院学生在其中扮演虚拟律师事务所律师的角色。作为法律元宇宙的早期例子，学生们在虚拟环境中与充当客户和法官的经验丰富的律师一起实践法律——模拟真实的法律交易和纠纷。各种各样的设施都在网上提供：虚拟办公室、各种机构、专业网络，以及一系列增强真实性的文献资源，包括剪报、照片、遗嘱、银行存折和广告。我毫不怀疑，在这种模拟工作环境中，在执业律师的参与和支持下，学生们能够获得更深刻、更难忘的学习体验，远远超过无人参加的讲座和没有参与性的辅导。

Online lectures, i-tutorials, and virtual supervision, however, are only part of the future for legal education. The pioneering work of Paul Maharg moved us beyond this first generation into a world of simulation-based training and transactional learning, as described in his book, Transforming Legal Education. He pioneered these techniques in the post-graduate Scottish Diploma of Legal Practice taught at Strathclyde University for which he designed a fictional town, ‘Ardcalloch’, in which law students played the role of lawyers in virtual law firms. An early example of a legal metaverse, the students practised law—simulations of actual legal transactions and disputes—with experienced solicitors acting as clients and judges in this virtual environment. All sorts of facilities were made available online: virtual offices, various institutions, professional networks, and with a collection of documentary resources to lend authenticity, including newspaper clippings, photographs, wills, bank books, and advertisements. I have no doubt that students immersed in such a simulated working environment, with practising lawyers participating and supporting, could be exposed to a more profound and memorable learning experience, that greatly outstrips ill-attended lectures and non-participatory tutorials.

这些电子学习技巧只会变得更加强大——律师辩护、法律起草、客户会议、谈判、文件审查、尽职调查等等都将越来越多地通过线上方式进行。如果我们能够开发宇航员飞行模拟器，我们就能够构建出比要求年轻律师审阅无尽文件或死记硬背案件清单更有效的培训设施。而且，这些设施将在很大程度上弥补替代资源带来的资源缺口。

These e-learning techniques will only become more powerful—exposure to advocacy, drafting, client meetings, negotiations, document reviews, due diligence exercises, and much more will increasingly be provided online. If we can develop flight simulators for astronauts, we should be able to put together facilities that will be immeasurably more effective in training young lawyers than asking them to review endless piles of documents or memorize lists of cases. And they will go some considerable way to patching the gaps left by alternative sourcing.

向雇主提出的20 个问题

20 Questions to Ask Employers

在本章中，我将改变重点。如果您是一位正在申请新工作的年轻或有抱负的律师，我现在想为您准备一些问题，以便在您结束一场艰苦的面试后，面对不可避免的问题时提出：“您还有什么想问我们吗？”如果您是一位正在考虑您目前的律所是否值得长期效力的年轻律师，我也建议您提出这些问题。请注意，这些问题与律所领导聘请我担任外部战略顾问时我提出的问题非常相似。它们共同旨在确定一个组织对未来的洞察力及其对变革的渴望程度。

In this chapter, I change emphasis. If you are a young or aspiring lawyer applying for a new job, I want now to equip you with some questions to pose when, at the end of a gruelling interview, you are faced with the inevitable query: ‘Do you have anything you would like to ask us?’ I also recommend these questions to you if you are a young lawyer wondering whether your current firm is one to which you should commit yourself in the long run. Note that these questions are very similar to those that I ask of law firm leaders when they engage me as an external strategy consultant. Together, they seek to determine the depth of an organization’s insight into the future and its appetite for change.

这些问题带有健康警示。这些问题相当多，虽然在求职面试中保持投入、精明和兴趣是件好事，但我并不建议你一次性把所有问题都问出来。在面试中，表现得过于令人反感或具有颠覆性通常会适得其反。此外，我意识到就业市场竞争如此激烈，许多读者都渴望获得任何职位，因此这些问题可能看起来边缘关注。然而，掌握一些深刻的观察总是有益的，这对于未来的律师认真思考一些棘手的问题应该很有帮助，也很有意义。

The questions come with a health warning. There are quite a few of them and, although it is good at a job interview to be engaged, savvy, and interested, I am not suggesting you fire off all the queries at the one sitting. It is generally counter-productive at interviews to appear excessively objectionable or subversive. Also, I am conscious that the job market is so intensely competitive that many readers will be glad to secure any position at all, so that these questions might seem of peripheral concern. However, it is good to be armed with some penetrating observations and it should be helpful and relevant for tomorrow’s lawyers to give serious thought to some difficult issues.

你有长期战略吗？

Do You Have a Long-Term Strategy?

这个简单的问题可能会引发各种各样的生理反应，从紧张的咯咯笑到轻蔑的咕哝。律师事务所的领导通常会回应说，他们实际上并没有在正式文件中写下他们的战略，但所有合伙人都知道他们的战略是什么。这无疑是无稽之谈。在这样的律所，大多数合伙人都会私下承认自己对公司战略一无所知。领导者们要么在掩饰，要么在为自己辩解。战略文件本身并非价值非凡，但缺乏这样的文件通常表明他们缺乏战略思维。

This simple query can prompt all sorts of physical reactions, from nervous giggles to disparaging grunts. Law firm leaders often respond by claiming that they have not actually written down their strategy in a formal document but that all the partners know what their strategy is. Invariably, this is nonsense. In such firms, most partners will confess in private to having no clue as to the strategy of their business. The leaders themselves are either dissembling or rationalizing. It is not that a strategy document in and of itself has great value but an absence of such a document usually betrays an absence of strategic thinking.

警惕那些声称在当前经济环境下必须关注短期利益的律所领导者。正如第八章所强调的，优秀的领导者一方面关注短期问题，另一方面关注组织的长期战略健康。如果高级合伙人专注于“唾手可得的成果”或“快速见效”，就需要深切关注。这往往暴露出他们的短期主义，最终可能导致公司迅速衰落。

Beware of law firm leaders who say that in the current economic climate their focus must be on the short term. As stressed in Chapter 8, the best leaders keep one eye on short term issues and the other on the long-term strategic health of their organizations. Worry deeply if a senior partner is preoccupied with ‘low-hanging fruit’ or ‘quick wins’. This frequently betrays short-termism which can precede rapid decline.

另一种截然不同的应对方式是制作一份厚厚的300页报告。通常情况下，外部管理咨询公司会制作这样的报告。但这本身就存在问题——一家公司战略的构成，以及寻求……的文件决定其未来发展方向是一项极其重要的任务，不应外包给其他机构。此外，阐明一家法律企业的战略，也不应该耗费数百页纸。

A quite different response is the production of a fat 300-page report. An external firm of management consultants will often have produced this. This of itself is problematic—the composition of the strategy of a firm, the document which seeks to determine its very future, is too important a task to outsource to another organization. Moreover, it should not take several hundred pages to articulate the strategy for a legal business.

您不太可能收到一份完整的战略文件，因为该文件会被像“最高机密”一样严加保密。但您可能会收到一份经过审查的摘要。您应该从中寻找的是，这家律所是否对更广泛的商业环境，尤其是法律市场的变化进行了深入思考。文件中应该体现律所的雄心壮志，例如，它希望在五年内达到什么目标，以及为了实现目标必须做出哪些重大改变。它应该表明律所计划开展业务的市场，以及它将如何在这些选定的市场中竞争。您还应该找到律所的核心价值观以及它希望营造的文化。您应该确信，整体战略方向是切合实际的。在这里，您应该寻找的是相对较少的主要优先事项，而不是一堆零碎的举措。

You are unlikely ever to be handed a full strategy document, which will be guarded as though ‘top secret’. But you may get a sanitized précis. What you should look for in this is evidence of a firm that has thought deeply about changes in the broader business environment and in the legal market in particular. There should be a sense from the document of the ambition of the firm, of where it hopes to be in, say, five years’ time, and what major changes it must effect to get there. It should indicate the markets in which it intends to work and how it will seek to compete in these chosen markets. You should also find an indication of the values that are central to the firm, and of the culture it likes to engender. You should be convinced that the overall sense of strategic direction seems realistic. What to search for here is a relatively small number of major priorities, rather than a litany of piecemeal initiatives.

如果不存在包含此类内容的战略文件，那么这不是一个为未来做好明智准备的企业，因此也不可能为未来的律师奠定坚实的基础。

If a strategy document with such contents does not exist, then this is not a business that is preparing wisely for the future, and not a business, therefore, that is likely to provide a firm foundation for lawyers of tomorrow.

2040年的法律服务将会是什么样子？

What Will Legal Service Look Like in 2040?

我之前的问题是关于长期战略的，它测试的是企业对未来五到十年的看法。下一个问题，关于下一代法律服务可能如何变化，是展望20年后。在本书的引言中，我曾指出，20世纪80年代初，我在法学院就读时，与朋友和教授们探讨未来，当时似乎有一种共识，认为25年后，律师的基本日常工作将大致相同。事实证明，我们并没有错。当时，还没有明显且迫在眉睫的变革驱动力，类似于“多多益善”的压力、自由化和技术（本书的主旨）。

My previous question, about long-term strategy, tests the business’s view over perhaps the next five to ten years. This next query, about the way in which legal service might change over the next generation, is looking around 20 years out. In the introduction to this book, I observed that when I was at law school in the early 1980s and was discussing the future with my friends and professors, there seemed to be a shared view that the basic daily work of lawyers would be much the same a quarter of a century hence. In the event, we were not wrong. At that time, there were no obvious and imminent drivers of change, analogous to the more-for-less pressure, liberalization, and technology (the running themes of this book).

尤其从技术角度来看，尽管IBM在我攻读法学学位倒数第二年时就推出了个人电脑，但我们当时尚未生活在一个大规模且可预见的技术变革时代。与此形成鲜明对比的是，鉴于我们正目睹技术的应用和力量呈指数级增长，任何人如果认为2040年的法律服务将与今天大致相同，都将是极其短视的。当然，没有人能够预测那时我们的世界会是什么样子，但在向未来雇主询问遥远的未来时，你不应该寻求明确的、权威的答案。事实上，要警惕任何在任何方向上过于教条的人。如果你被本书的论点和预测所说服，那么你应该选择一家其成员对未来既感兴趣又担忧的公司来发展你的职业生涯。不屑一顾的回应是一种心胸狭隘的回应，与此形成鲜明对比的是，你应该寻找一家思想开放、欢迎讨论未来可能的公司。

Looking at technology in particular, although IBM launched its PC when I was in the penultimate year of my law degree, we did not yet live in a time of massive and foreseeable technological upheaval. In radical contrast, given that we are now witnessing an exponential increase in the uptake and power of technology, it would be remarkably short-sighted for anyone to maintain that legal service in, say, 2040 will be much the same as today. Of course, no one can predict what our world will be like then but in asking a prospective employer a question about the distant future, you should not be looking for a definitive, authoritative response. Indeed, be wary of anyone who is excessively dogmatic in any direction. The kind of firm in which you should want to build your career, if you are convinced by the arguments and predictions of this book, is a firm in which its members express both interest and concern about the years ahead. A dismissive response is a narrow-minded response, and you should be looking, in stark contrast, for a firm that is open-minded and welcoming of debate about possible futures.

您是否因其他公司缺乏进步而感到安慰？

Are You Comforted by Other Firms’ Lack of Progress?

如果变革不可避免，那么优秀律所的优秀律师通常会迅速有效地适应。他们别无选择。如果存在某种燃烧的平台，他们别无选择，只能跳下去。由于缺乏这种紧迫感，大多数律所，即使是最优秀的律所，往往更害怕落后于竞争对手，而不是渴望超越竞争对手。换句话说，律所的动力更多地来自于避免竞争劣势的需求，而不是获得竞争优势的渴望。这与消费电子等许多其他行业截然不同，在这些行业，驱动他们的激情是不断超越和智胜竞争对手。在与律所领导会面时，我发现激励他们的最简单方法就是谈论他们最接近的竞争对手的显著成就。

If change is unavoidable, then bright lawyers in impressive law firms will usually adapt promptly and effectively. They have no choice. If there is a burning platform of some sort, they have no option but to jump off. In the absence of such an imperative, most law firms, even the finest, tend to be driven more by a fear of lagging behind their competition than by a hunger for forging ahead of their rivals. Law firms, in other words, are motivated more by the need to avoid competitive disadvantage than a thirst for the attainment of competitive advantage. This is quite unlike many other sectors, such as consumer electronics, where the driving passion is continuously to outpace and out-think the competition. When meeting with law firm leaders, I find the easiest way to motivate them is to speak of the notable achievements of their closest rivals.

因此，许多律师确实从得知其他他们高度评价的公司已经做出了适度的尝试来重新思考他们的工作方式，或拥抱技术，或采纳本书中的许多建议中获得了极大的安慰。

It follows, therefore, that many lawyers do indeed derive great comfort from knowing that other firms, of whom they think highly, have made but modest attempts to rethink the way they work, or to embrace technology, or to take up many of the suggestions in this book.

因此，你应该以极大的乐观态度看待一家公司，它坚持认为驱动其发展的不是竞争对手，而是客户需求，市场显然需要根本性的变革，而其他公司的保守主义为新的市场领导者的崛起提供了机会。如果你从一家公司听到了这些信息，那就努力争取加入这家公司。

Accordingly, you should view with great optimism a firm that insists that it is driven not by its competitors but by its clients’ needs, that the market will clearly require fundamental changes, and that the conservatism of other firms presents an opportunity for a new market leader to emerge. If these are the messages that you hear from an organization, strive to gain employment with it.

有趣的是，如果你遇到法律市场上的其他供应商，例如法律流程外包商、法律出版商或大型会计师事务所，那么你会发现他们对变革的渴望更大，对未来的兴奋更大，而主流律师事务所对不断变化的市场条件的反应往往相当低调。

Interestingly, if you meet with alternative providers in the legal marketplace, such as legal process outsourcers, legal publishers, or large accounting firms, then you will detect amongst them a far greater appetite for change, far greater excitement about the future, than that evinced by mainstream law firms in their often rather subdued response to shifting market conditions.

您首选的替代采购方法是什么？

What are Your Preferred Approaches to Alternative Sourcing?

如果对这个问题一脸茫然或一丝不解，则可能需要稍微解释一下，如下：鉴于客户越来越多地要求其法律顾问寻找降低常规和重复性工作成本的方法，您认为哪种方法最有希望？

If this question is met with a blank expression or a whiff of incomprehension, it may need a little explaining, as follows: given that clients are increasingly asking their legal advisers to find ways of reducing the costs of routine and repetitive work, which approaches are you finding to be the most promising?

对于那些仅仅声称正在认真审视这一挑战，或正在与低成本服务提供商（例如法律流程外包商、自由职业律师等）洽谈的公司，务必保持警惕。要寻找行动和活动的证据，而非反思和讨论的证据。

Treat with suspicion those firms that say no more than that they are looking very carefully at this challenge, or that they are currently in discussions with low-cost providers such as legal process outsourcers, freelance lawyers, or the like. Look for evidence of action and activity rather than of reflection and discussion.

即使公司声称已投资某些设施——例如近岸中心或分包协议——也应进一步调查，以确认这究竟是象征性举措还是认真的承诺。许多公司确实已达成协议，但这些协议通常只是合伙人向客户表明他们以某种方式参与其中的姿态。

Even if firms say they have invested in some facility—perhaps a near-shore centre or subcontracting arrangement—probe a little further to test if this is tokenism or serious commitment. A number of firms do indeed have arrangements in place but these are often no more than gestures that allow the partners to say to clients that they are involved in some way.

通常情况下，一家公司是否真心投入是显而易见的。你能感受到他们的热情，他们也会分享哪些方面做得好，哪些方面需要进一步改进。

Ordinarily, it will be clear if a firm is genuinely committed. You will sense their enthusiasm and they will have tales to tell about what has worked well and what needs further refinement.

科技将在未来的律师事务所中扮演什么角色？

What Role Will Technology Play in Law Firms of the Future?

大多数资深律师在谈论科技在其律所中不断变化的角色时，仍然感到有些不自在。他们会滔滔不绝地谈论他们目前使用的系统，例如电子邮件、文字处理、PowerPoint、会计和计费系统，以及他们似乎永远离不开的手持设备。大多数律所都拥有先进的技术部门，他们对技术的依赖程度确实非常深远。然而，我所指的技术并非后台系统，而是那些直接影响和支持客户服务的系统。例如，知识系统——一系列应用程序（从内联网到专有技术数据库，再到内部社交网络），旨在捕捉和提供律所的集体经验和专业知识（第七章中称之为“右下角”的系统）；客户关系系统，例如在线交易室，为律所及其客户提供沟通和协作渠道（左上角）；在线法律服务——例如提供法律指导和文档自动化的系统（右上角）。

Most senior lawyers are still not entirely comfortable when talking about the changing role of technology in their firms. They will speak articulately enough about the systems they currently use, such as email, word processing, PowerPoint, accounting and billing, as well as their handheld devices to which they seem permanently tethered. Most law firms will have sophisticated technology departments and their dependence on technology is indeed profound. However, the technologies I have in mind are not back-office systems but those that directly affect and support client services. One category, for example, is knowledge systems—the collection of applications (from intranets through know-how databases to internal social networks) which seek to capture and make available a firm’s collective experience and expertise (‘bottom-right’ systems, in the language of Chapter 7); or client relationship systems, those services such as online deal rooms that provide communication and collaboration channels between firms and their clients (‘top-left’); or online legal services—systems that, for instance, provide legal guidance and document automation (‘top-right’).

2020 年代，我们将看到重点从后台系统转向变革性（通常具有颠覆性）的技术（见第六章），律师与客户合作的传统方式。

In the 2020s, we will see a shift of emphasis from back-office systems to technologies that transform, often disruptively (see Chapter 6), the traditional way that lawyers have worked with their clients.

要衡量您正在考虑的一家公司的技术成熟度，您首先应该关注该公司对上述各种变革的认知，然后寻找其对这些新兴技术进行投资的证据。一个值得提出的有趣子问题是：“贵公司监控新兴技术并评估其在各个业务领域潜力的正式流程是什么？”您会发现，很少有公司拥有这样的流程。如果您找到一家拥有此类流程的公司，那就不用再继续寻找了。

To gauge the technological sophistication of a firm that you are considering, you should look in the first instance for recognition of the kinds of change just described, and then for evidence of investment in these emerging technologies. One interesting sub-question to pose is: ‘What is the formal process by which your firm monitors emerging technologies and evaluates their potential for your various practice areas?’ You will find that very few firms have such a process. If you locate one that does, look no further.

你们有研发能力吗？

Do You Have a Research and Development Capability?

如果你是一家消费电子公司，比如苹果或索尼，那么你还没有发明出五年后将成为公司业务基石的产品。制药公司的情况也类似。正因如此，这些公司以及许多其他公司都设有研发预算和部门——由非常聪明的人组成的团队（我想象他们穿着白大褂，眉毛高高在上），他们被赋予自由进行深入和创造性思考的自由，并为未来提出各种可能的解决方案。他们的大多数想法最终都未能付诸实践。研发人员被鼓励去思考那些不可思议的事情，要大胆创新。即使他们的发明没有商业化，也不算失败。

If you are a consumer electronics company, like Apple or Sony, you have not yet invented the products that will be the foundations of your business in five years’ time. The position is similar in pharmaceutical companies. This is why these and many other businesses have research and development (R&D) budgets and departments—teams of very bright people (that I envisage wearing white coats and having high brows) who are given freedom to think deeply and creatively and to come up with all sorts of possible offerings for the future. Most of their ideas never see the light of day. The R&D people are encouraged to think the unthinkable, to be bold and daring. And if their inventions are not commercialized, this is not regarded as failure.

律师事务所也面临着类似的挑战。如果我在本书第一部分和第二部分中所说的内容成真，那么或许五年或十年后，律师们也将提供他们尚未构想的服务。那么，这些律所将如何创新？谁来提供新的、改变市场的法律服务？询问律所是否投资研发，如果投资，以何种方式投资，并非不合理。这里不妨补充一个问题，即律所每年将多少比例的收费收入重新投入到研发预算中（消费电子和制药公司约有15%至20%的营业额用于研发）。

There is an analogous challenge here for law firms. If what I say in Parts One and Two of this book comes to pass, then lawyers too, perhaps five or ten years from now, will be offering services that they have not yet conceived. So, how are these firms going to innovate? Who is going to come up with new, market-changing legal services? It is not unreasonable to ask law firms whether they invest in R&D and, if so, in what way. A supplementary question here might be to ask what percentage of their annual fee income is ploughed back into an R&D budget (consumer electronics and pharmaceutical companies spend about 15 to 20 per cent of their turnover on R&D).

目前很少有公司拥有研发预算或部门，因此，一个令人鼓舞的回答是，他们知道这很快就会成为必需。那些对此不屑一顾，并希望在未来几年内还能从旧有工作方式中榨取更多利润的公司，应该被视为长期雇佣的对象，对此应持怀疑态度。

Very few firms currently have R&D budgets or departments, and so an encouraging reply would be that they know that this is soon going to be necessary. Firms that are dismissive and hope they can for some years squeeze yet more juice out of the old way of working should be viewed with some distrust as long-term places of employment.

如果您可以从头开始设计一家律师事务所，它会是什么样子？

If You Could Design a Law Firm from Scratch, What Would it be Like?

在为客户提供咨询服务的过程中，我围绕这个问题建立了一个正式的练习，我称之为“白纸思维”。我发现，大多数律师在考虑长远发展时，往往会受到现有环境的限制。他们的未来规划是基于历史遗留的；他们正在倒退着走向未来。相比之下，在这个巨变的时代，我鼓励律师事务所以愿景为本，将目标放在一个除了考虑公司目前的组织和定位方式之外，还要向前迈进，思考五年后公司能够达到什么水平以及应该达到什么水平。

In my consulting work with clients, I have built a formal exercise around this question. I call it ‘blank sheet thinking’. I have discovered that most lawyers, when thinking about the long term, tend to be contained and constrained by their current set-up. Their thinking ahead is legacy-based; they are walking backwards into the future. In contrast, in these times of great change, I encourage law firms to be vision-based, to put to one side the way their firms are currently organized and positioned, and take a leap forward to consider where they could and should be in, say, five years’ time.

为了帮助他们进行这种基于愿景的思考，我请他们回答以下问题：“如果给你一张白纸，让你从头开始设计你的业务或公司，它会是什么样子？”（我提供了一系列提示来支持他们，但他们不需要在这里耽搁我们。）沿着类似的思路，试着从你未来的雇主那里了解一下，如果他们能挥动一根魔杖，在应对当前和即将到来的压力下，能够重新打造他们的业务，情况会有什么不同。

To help them to engage in this vision-based thinking, I ask them to answer the following question: ‘If you were given a blank sheet of paper and could design your practice or firm from scratch, what would it look like?’ (I provide a series of prompts to support them but they need not detain us here.) Pursuing a similar line of inquiry, try to get a sense from your prospective employers of what would be different if they could wave a magic wand and, in response to current and impending pressures, were able to build their business afresh.

您可能会像我一样发现，这个思想实验让律师不再关注当前的工作方式，并揭示了一些有趣的见解，例如律师事务所可能位于何处、他们将雇用多少人、他们将如何开展工作、他们可能部署什么技术、他们将在多大程度上寻求外部资本等等。

You may find, as I do, that this thought experiment releases lawyers from their focus on current ways of working and reveals some fascinating insights about where law firms might be located, how many people they would employ, how they would source their work, what technology they might deploy, the extent to which they would seek external capital, and much more.

如果面试官对你问题的回答结果是，他们的业务看起来和他们现在管理的差不多，那么我会非常怀疑。另一方面，如果这个问题引发了一系列关于不同工作方式的富有想象力且引人入胜的想法，那么这家雇主对你来说可能是一个令人兴奋的前景。

If the upshot of the interviewers’ responses to your questions is that their business would look much as the one they are managing today, then I would be deeply sceptical. On the other hand, if this question leads to a series of imaginative and engaging thoughts about different ways of working, then that employer may well be an exciting prospect for you.

请记住，我并不是建议你用最后一个问题以及本章列出的所有其他问题轰炸未来的雇主。尽管如此，掌握一两个精明的问题总是令人印象深刻的，而这里建议的问题的答案可能会对你的未来大有裨益。

Remember that I am not suggesting that you should bombard prospective employers with this last question and all the others outlined in this chapter. Nonetheless, it is impressive to be armed with an astute question or two, and the answers to the queries suggested here could be highly illuminating for your future.

21创新

21 Innovation

如今，许多律师和律师事务所都自诩为创新者。这种对实质性变革的执着追求充斥在他们的网站、新闻稿、出版物以及面向客户的宣传中。而这背后，更是源于一个名副其实的创新奖项行业，这些奖项旨在表彰那些所谓的突破界限的律师。但就目前而言，现实情况更加严峻。如果我在本章中听起来有些愤世嫉俗，那是因为我本身就愤世嫉俗。我坚信，法律界需要彻底的变革，而且这种变革终将实现。需要明确的是，我仍然对我所期待的许多进步感到兴奋。但传统律师事务所当前掀起的创新浪潮，很多都未能达到我所设想和建议的彻底变革。这恰恰印证了我在本书前言中驳斥的观点——即“未来的律师已经到来”。

Many lawyers and law firms are now claiming to be innovators. This apparent commitment to substantial change is peppered across their websites, press releases, publications, as well as their pitches to clients.
